hl.seg: Spain denies suspending aid to Morocco

p.seg: Madrid 11-1 (AFP) - Spain's Prime Minister, Jose Maria Aznar, confirmed today that Spain has not stopped aid to Morocco, contrary to what Morocco's Foreign Minister Mohamed Benaissa told the Moroccan parliament yesterday.
The Spanish prime minister said at a press conference that cooperation between Spain and Morocco "has not stopped at all and has not been suspended.
I would also like to point out that Morocco receives more aid from Spain than does any other country."
Benaissa expressed his regret yesterday that "economic and financial cooperation with the Spanish government had been put on hold."
According to the government, Spain has set aside a sum of nm6.12 million for cooperation with Morocco.

Aznar said that "from Spain's perspective, there is no reason for this crisis in our relations with Morocco," adding that "while some might attempt to hurt relations between Spain and Morocco, I am working toward strengthening support for cooperation with Morocco as well as developing it to a greater degree."

Benaissa had said that recalling the Moroccan ambassador to Madrid, Abdeslam Baraka, for talks on October 28 was a clear expression of Morocco's displeasure with the quality and level of mutual relations.
Morocco's foreign minister criticized Spain's position on the Western Sahara, illegal immigration and hunting.

hl.seg: Palestinian Authority condemns Israel's continued assassination policy

p.seg: Gaza 11-1 (AFP) - The Palestinian Authority today condemned the continued policy of assassinating and killing Palestinians pursued by Israel. It held the Jewish state entirely responsible for the escalation.

Nabil Abu Radina, Palestinian President Yasser Arafat's advisor, told France Presse: "The Palestinian Authority strongly warns against the Israeli government's continued policy of killings and assassinations, the most recent of which was the assassination today near Tulkram and yesterday in Hebron and Tulkram in the West Bank."

Abu Radina said he held "(Ariel) Sharon's government entirely responsible for the military escalation against the defenseless Palestinian people," stressing that "the objective of Israeli military escalation is to sabotage ongoing international efforts to salvage the peace process in the region."
A Palestinian was killed today after two Israeli helicopters fired rockets on his car near Tulkram in the northern region of the West Bank, according to medical sources and eye witnesses.
The Israeli army carried out an assassination of a leader, Jamil Jadallah, of the military wing of Hamas using rockets fired from helicopters in Hebron in the southern region of the West Bank.

hl.seg: Threats to attack bridges in California (governor)

p.seg: Los Angeles (US) 11-2 (AFP) - California Governor Gray Davis warned yesterday of "serious threats" to blow up bridges in the United States including Golden Gate Bridge and Bay Bridge in San Francisco.
The governor's spokesman, Steve Maviglio, told France Presse that similar threats have also been made against Coronado Bridge near San Diego (southern California).

The spokesman did not give any details about the source or nature of these threats except to say that they are "specific and serious" but said that the state of California does not intend to close the bridges at the present time.
For his part, Davis told the local media that the attacks would take place November 2 and 7, probably during rush hour, and that they would specifically target suspension bridges.

Dwight Helmick, California Highway Patrol Commissioner, tried to calm public fear, saying at a press conference that "we have complete faith in the bridges' safety" and added that information about the threats had come from the federal government.
He also said that the National Guard would be stationed around the bridges and that all precautionary measures had been taken.

Golden Gate Bridge is a symbolic bridge in San Francisco which is visited by about 9 million people a year and used by some 42 million cars a year. It has been under close surveillance since the 9/11 attacks and pedestrians and cyclists were banned from using it a few weeks after the attacks took place.

hl.seg: Angolan president: "End of war in sight"

p.seg: Luanda 11-1 (AFP) - Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos announced today that the end of his country's 26-year continuous war is in sight.

He stated in a press conference held at the end of his visit to his Sao Tome and Principe counterpart, Fradique de Menezes, that the "end of the war is in sight" as the rebellion of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Unita) has only very limited forces left.
Last Monday, the Angolan president said that the Angolan armed forces would continue their operations to eliminate these limited military forces.
Angola's armed forces have been conducting a wide scale military operation against Unita since 1998 which led to rebel strongholds being regained in central and southern Angola.
Unita, led by Jonas Savimbi, no longer controls any Angolan towns but has nonetheless intensified its attacks throughout Angola, particularly in the villages.

The war between the Angolan armed forces and Unita has continued nonstop since Angola gained its independence in 1975. It has led to the deaths of over 500 thousand people and the wounding of 100 thousand, and it has caused four million people to evacuate their homes in an attempt to flee the fighting.

hl.seg: Blair to inform Bush of results of his trip to the Middle East next Wednesday

p.seg: Gaza 11-1 (AFP) - A source close to the British Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that Blair is to head for Washington on November 7 to brief US President George Bush of the results of his trip to the Middle East.

A government source close to Blair said that after the meeting with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat the British prime minister is to make a quick visit to Washington next Wednesday before returning to London on the same night, where he is likely to hold further talks with his Israeli counterpart Ariel Sharon the following day.
Blair held discussions today with Sharon in Jerusalem after holding talks in Syria, Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

In a joint press conference with Sharon, Blair said he would "do everything in his capacity to re-establish the process for peace in the Middle East," while in Gaza he emphasized two principles: Israel's security and the establishment of a Palestinian state.

hl.seg: Rumsfeld: Washington to increase troops in Afghanistan

p.seg: Washington 11-1 (AFP) - US Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld announced today that Washington is to increase special forces on the ground working alongside anti-Taliban groups.

Rumsfeld added in a press release: "We will increase the number of men until we have an appropriate number of special forces," pointing out that the task of American soldiers is to assist the Northern Alliance in communications, logistics, supplies and identifying targets for American planes.
He said "that weather conditions and other obstacles had prevented units from getting there at an earlier date" but did not give specific numbers.
He said that "there were very few troops on the ground" working alongside opposition groups in the north.
He indicated that Washington was providing assistance to a number of other groups opposed to the Taliban in addition to the Northern Alliance.

In response to a question concerning military assistance to opposition groups in central Afghanistan and in Harat (East), the American Secretary said: "We are helping them; we provide them with food and ammunition and are trying to increase the number of opposition fighters. We are trying to improve performance so that the operation is successful."

hl.seg: Main excerpts from a call by Osama bin Laden directed at Muslims in Pakistan

p.seg: Doha 11-1 (AFP) - Below are main excerpts from a handwritten statement shown on "Al-Jazeera" satellite channel in which the extremist fundamentalist Osama bin Laden calls on Muslims in Pakistan to stand against the "crusade" against Islam:
"To my Muslim brothers, civilians and soldiers, in the pious land of Pakistan.
May God's peace and mercy be upon you.

"The crusader war against Islam has intensified and the killing of Mohamed's followers in Afghanistan has become rampant. The world is split in two, part of it under the Christian banner, as the head of infidels (American president George) Bush called for, and the other part under the banner of Islam.
"Pakistan's government stood under the Christian banner.
"Oh supporters of Islam, your day has come to support Islam.
"Let he who believes in God and the last days keep his resolve until truth and its supporters triumph and God defeats the supporters of lies."

hl.seg: 2002 World Cup preliminaries: German lineup for two play-off games against Ukraine

p.seg: Frankfurt (Germany) 11-1 (AFP) -German soccer trainer, Roddy Fowler, announced a lineup of 22 players to play two games against the Ukraine on November 10 and 14 as part of the European play-off in the qualifying rounds for the 2002 World Cup final in South Korea and Japan.
Jens Jeremies, Joerg Heinrich, Mehmet Scholl and Sebastian Deisler will again be absent because of injuries.
The players are:
Goalkeeper: Oliver Kahn (Bayern Munich) and Jens Lehman (Borussia Dortmund).

Defenders: Thomas Linke (Bayern Munich), Weinz Novotni (Bayer Leverkusen), Marco Rohmer (Hertha Berlin), Frank Baumann (Werder Bremen), Christian Forns (Borussia Dortmund) and Sebastian Kehl (Freiburg).
Midfielders: Christian Ziege (Tottenham), Michael Ballack, Cartsen Ramelow and Brend Schneider (Bayer Leverkusen), Dietmar Hamann (Liverpool), Larse Ricken (Borussia Dortmund).

Forwards: Gerald Asamoa (Schalke), Oliver Bierhoff (Milan), Marco Bode (Werder Bremen), Carsten Jancker and Alexander Zickler (Bayern Munich), Oliver Neuville (Bayer Leverkusen), Miroslav Klose (Kaiserslautern).

hl.seg: Kuwait to play Strasbourg, Kaiserslauten, Freiburg and Nuremberg in German training camp

p.seg: Kuwait 11-1 (AFP) - The Kuwaiti Soccer Federation announced a series of friendly games to be played by the Kuwaiti team at its training camp in Germany between November 3 and 14 this year.
The training camp is part of the preparations for the 15th Gulf Cup hosted by Saudi Arabia next January 16-30.

Al-Azraq will start by playing French Cup holders Strasbourg (2nd division) in Germany, instead of in Strasbourg, on the 4th, after which it will play three German teams: Kaiserslautern on the 6th, Freiburg on the 8th and Nuremberg on the 11th.
The Kuwaiti Soccer Federation said it is looking for a fifth game which has not been decided yet.

Asalimiya's Saleh Albariki will not attend the training camp for personal reasons, while players of the club that heads the Kuwait league will rejoin their team the day of the 4th match to play a return match against Syrian team Jablah in the first round of the Asian Clubs Cup in Kuwait (first match zero-zero).
Kuwait's international players are Faraj Lahib, Khalaf Alsalami, Jarah Alatiki and Khalid Jarallah.

hl.seg: One Israeli killed and another injured in the West Bank (Israeli television)

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-2 (AFP) - Official Israeli television today reported one Israeli killed and another wounded by Palestinian gunfire in northern Ramallah on the West Bank.
The report did not state whether they were civilians or soldiers, saying only that Palestinians opened fire on an army checkpoint near the Jewish settlement of Beit Eil.
Army sources had previously reported that two soldiers were wounded in this area, one of them seriously, as a result of Palestinian gunfire.

Sources said a Jeep with Palestinians inside approached the checkpoint near the Israeli settlement of Beit Eil and the passengers then opened fire before heading back toward an area under complete Palestinian control.
Palestinian residents said that Israeli soldiers in a tank and 10 armored vehicles then entered the village of Salwad and arrested a 20-year-old Palestinian.
They added that the soldiers withdrew from the town, which falls within sector B where Israel is in charge of security matters.
This brings the number of dead to 947 since the Intifada began on September 28 2000, including 741 Palestinians and 184 Israelis.

hl.seg: American reconnaissance planes including unmanned planes deployed in Afghanistan

p.seg: Washington 11-2 (AFP) - An air force spokeswomen announced in Washington today that the American Defense Department has ordered additional reconnaissance planes, including unmanned planes, to be deployed in Afghanistan
Spokeswoman Gloria Kiehls said that Joint Star A-8 planes, as well as Global Hawk and Predator planes, have been deployed.
Joint Star is a Boeing 707 radar surveillance plane capable of photographing sites on the ground such as military installations.
Unmanned reconnaissance planes are already deployed in Afghanistan and are used by the military and the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), say experts.

However, this is the first time the Pentagon has announced deployment of Global Hawk, an unmanned plane which flies at high altitudes and can remain in the area to be monitored for long periods of time.

This announcement comes at a time when American air raids on Taliban defense positions against the Northern Alliance in the capital of Kabul and in the towns of Mazar-e-Sharif and Kanduz (in the north) have intensified.

hl.seg: El-Kosheh massacre: 96 people to be retried tomorrow

p.seg: Cairo 11-2 (AFP) - The retrial of 96 people accused of involvement in the el-Kosheh massacre, which took place in January 2000 and resulted in the deaths of 20 Christian Egyptians, is to resume at the Criminal Court in lower Egypt.

The Supreme Court ruled on July 30 that the 96 accused individuals, 58 of whom are Muslims and 38 Copts, be retried in Suhaj 500 km south of Cairo, at a court other than the court where the case was initially tried in February 2001.
Suhaj Criminal Court had issued a ruling on February 5 for prison sentences with hard labor ranging from 1 to 12 years for four of the accused and found 92 others innocent.
The Supreme Court ruled on July 30 that all 96 accused individuals stand for retrial
in the town of Suhaj near el-Kosheh where the massacre took place.

The public prosecutor said that the "Court made an illegal ruling and found the accused innocent even though the charges of intention to kill, possession of weapons, assembly, disturbance and threatening public safety had been proven."
The sectarian incidents which took place in early January 2000 in el-Kosheh, which falls within the Suhaj province 500 km south of Cairo, resulted in the deaths of 21 people.

hl.seg: Riyadh voices criticism to Blair about raids on Afghanistan

p.seg: Riyadh 11-2 (AFP) - The Saudi Gazette, a daily newspaper, reported that Saudi officials criticized the raids on Afghanistan during a meeting with British Prime Minister Tony Blair.
According to the paper, Blair was told in Riyadh, which he visited on Wednesday, that Saudi Arabia "supports the war against terrorism, but the world has to find a political solution in Afghanistan."
In its opening column, the paper reported that "Blair said the American and British campaign is a confrontation between the forces of order and the forces of anarchy.
In spite of these explanations for consumption in the Muslim world, the war on terrorism is beginning to be aimed at Muslims everywhere in the world."
Blair did not refer to Saudi criticism of the raids or to the situation in the Middle East during his visit to Riyadh, which also included Syria, Jordan, Israel and Palestinian Authority zones.

He said after his meeting with the Saudi monarch King Fahed that they had reached an agreement to work together to form an interim government in Afghanistan and emphasized that Riyadh responded to all the requests put forward on the subject of preventing terrorism.

hl.seg: Vedrine suggests continuing American strikes during the month of Ramadan

p.seg: Islamabad 11-2 (AFP) - French Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine suggested today that American strikes against Afghanistan continue during the month of Ramadan, which begins this mid-November.
Vedrine told journalists before leaving Islamabad, the last stop on a trip that also included India, that Ramadan is a truce not recognized by terrorists.

He added: "I think we have to keep the main objective in sight because after September 11 (attacks), there was a tremendous international desire to wipe out the ability of terrorist networks to cause harm."
With the approach of the month of Ramadan, disagreements have sprung up within the international alliance against terrorism on the issue of whether American strikes should continue or stop.
Arab and Muslim countries have made their reservations apparent, and some have strongly opposed continuing the raids, for which the Afghan people are paying dearly.
American president George Bush announced today that the United States rejects "any truce" in the campaign against terrorism during the month of Ramadan.
Bush told journalists at the White House: "I do not see the enemy announcing a truce during Ramadan, and neither will we.
We will continue this war until we achieve our objectives."
Belgium's foreign minister Louis Michel, whose country currently holds the presidency of the European Union, said he was in favor of suspending American strikes during Ramadan.

hl.seg: Al-Hariri: Moscow opposes extending American operations beyond Afghanistan

p.seg: Moscow 11-2 (AFP) - Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri said in Moscow today that Russia opposes extending American operations in Afghanistan to other countries, sharing Russian leader Vladimir Putin's position who he met in the Kremlin.
Al-Hariri, whose three-day visit to Moscow ended today, said that Putin was very clear on this matter and
that Russia would not agree to broadening the field of operations outside Afghanistan.

He also said that there was complete agreement between the Russian position and the Arab world's position regarding settlement in the Middle East and that Arab countries must insist that Moscow "reinforce" its role as a broker in the peace process alongside the United States.
The Lebanese Prime Minister continued: "Russia would like to play a more active role if the parties concerned, especially Arab countries, ask it to."

Asked about the results of his visit in trade terms, al-Hariri said that he discussed the possibility of purchasing Russian oil and creating a refinery in Lebanon in collaboration with Russian companies.
He said the project would be mutually beneficial because Lebanon would be offered special oil prices.
Al-Hariri is to hold talks with his Russian counterpart Michael Kasyanov, particularly on the subject of trade cooperation, before leaving Russia tonight.

hl.seg: Radical Liberation Party leader arrested in Tajikistan

p.seg: Dushanbe 11-3 (AFP) -Tajikistan's Interior Ministry told France Presse today that an Uzbek national leader of a wing linked to the radical Islamist Liberation Party was arrested in Tajikistan.

The source said that 24-year old Mansur Yunsov was arrested in late October in east Tajikistan close to the border with Uzbekistan. He was carrying a false passport and leaflets calling for the overthrow of the Uzbek and Tajik governments.
The same source said his real nationality was not discovered until yesterday evening.
The ministry is continuing its investigations into the network set up by Yunsov who is to stand trial before the end of the year.
The Liberation Party is banned in Central Asia where it is calling for the return of a Sharia system of government.
It is the most active party of the clandestine parties of Central Asia and has several thousand members in Tajikistan, the former Soviet Republic neighboring Afghanistan.
Since the beginning of the year, over 100 militants from this party have been imprisoned, half of them in the southern Leninabad region close to the Uzbek border, according to official figures.

After being set up in Central Asia in the mid-fifties, this radical Sunni party became established in Uzbekistan, particularly in the Farghana Valley area, after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, then spread to Tajikistan in 1998.

hl.seg: Iraq "not happy" with Pakistan's position regarding American strikes on Afghanistan

p.seg: Baghdad 11-3 (AFP) - Iraq today expressed its "unhappiness" with Pakistan's position regarding the United States' and Britain's "assault" on Afghanistan and warned of its negative effects on Islamic and Arab countries.

The Iraqi news agency reported that Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan told Pakistan's Minister for Export Affairs, Tareq Akram, that "Iraq is not happy with Pakistan's position regarding the United States' and Britain's attack on Afghanistan."
The agency reported Ramadan as saying "any attack on a Muslim country is bound to have negative effects on Islamic and Arab countries."

Akram arrived in Baghdad at the head of a large delegation to take part in the opening ceremony of the Baghdad International Fair and to hold talks with Iraqi officials on developing mutual cooperation.
Ramadan stressed the importance of strengthening mutual relations between Pakistan and Iraq and increasing ties in the fields of economy and trade to the benefit of both nations.

hl.seg: French journalist Michel Perar arrives in Pakistan

p.seg: Torkom border post (Pakistan) 11-3 (AFP) - A France Presse correspondent reported that French journalist Michel Perar, who was released by the Taliban today, crossed the Afghan border at 24h18 local time (GMT 24h13) into Pakistan.
The Taliban had arrested the French journalist who works for Paris Match on October 9.
The French ambassador to Pakistan, Yannick Gerard, and Pakistani officials met Perar at the Torkom border post in northeastern Pakistan.
An official in the Taliban movement who accompanied Perar to the border said the Pakistani journalists arrested with him would not be released today but might be released tomorrow (Sunday).

hl.seg: Nearly 2500 people demonstrate for peace in Hamburg and Kehl

p.seg: Hamburg (Germany) 11-3 (AFP) - Nearly 2500 people demonstrated today for peace in Hamburg and Kehl in northern Germany, calling for an end to American bombardment of Afghanistan, said police sources.
The demonstrators, who numbered 2000 in Hamburg and 450 in Kehl, expressed their anger and carried banners with the slogan "Terrorism cannot be fought by bombing."
Police said the demonstrations took place without incident.

The Berlin Anti-War and Anti-World Trade Organization Coalition said that peace groups and anti-globalization groups called for a rally in Berlin on November 10 to protest against the American bombing of Afghanistan.
Tens of thousands of people joined peace demonstrations in Berlin and Stuttgart on October 13 to protest against the American bombing of Afghanistan and to call for peace.

hl.seg: Israeli helicopter bombs two metal workshops in Jabalya

p.seg: Gaza 11-4 (AFP) - Palestinian security sources and eye witnesses reported that Israeli Apache helicopters bombed two metal workshops in the Jabalya area (north of Gaza city) early this morning while the Israeli army fired ground-ground missiles.

A Palestinian security official who wishes to remain anonymous said: "Israeli Apache helicopters bombed two metal workshops in the Jabalya area with rockets and the Israeli army fired ground-ground missiles from its positions on the border of the Gaza Strip."
He added: "The bombing completely destroyed the two workshops as well as a wood factory."
He said the American-made Apache helicopters fired five rockets while the army fired eight ground-ground missiles.

This strike comes a few hours after Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's decision to postpone his trip to the United States and Britain until a later date because of the security situation in Israel and Palestinian regions.
In an interview to be published in Newsweek magazine tomorrow, Sharon said: "We are in a state of war here, a special kind of war.
I have decided to continue redistributing our forces.
This might cause an upsurge in terror.
I want to be here to see how this unfolds."
Last July, Israeli helicopters destroyed a Palestinian factory, Tel Aviv saying that it produced mortar guns used in attacks against Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip.

hl.seg: Ariel Sharon postpones visit to United States (official)

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-3 (AFP) - Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has postponed his trip to the United States, which was to take place around November 11, until a later date because of the security situation in Israel, announced a spokesman for the Israeli parliament today.
David Baker said Sharon had postponed his scheduled trip to the United States and Britain "for an indefinite period because of security matters" in Israel.
He added that Israel informed the United States of this decision through the American ambassador to Tel Aviv, Daniel Kurtzer.
A spokesman for the government had previously said on October 29 that Sharon might postpone the visit "because of the security problems faced by Israel."
He was referring to attacks a few hours earlier which resulted in the death of five Israelis as well as to tensions in the Occupied Territories.
Sharon was to head for Washington on November 11, after stopping over in England, to give a speech to American Jewish organizations and to meet with American President George Bush.

hl.seg: Afghanistan: Turkish president in Tajikistan on Wednesday

p.seg: Dushanbe 11-3 (AFP) - The Tajik Foreign Ministry announced today that Turkish President Ahmet Necdet Sezer is to visit Tajikistan on Wednesday to hold talks with his Tajik counterpart Emamoli Rakhmonov on the situation in Afghanistan.

The source added that the talks would also cover security issues in the former Soviet Republics of Central Asia, three of which have borders with Afghanistan (Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan), in addition to matters concerning mutual relations between the two countries.
Turkey, the only Muslim member of NATO, had announced on Thursday that it would send a unit of 90 soldiers to Afghanistan to train anti-Taliban Northern Alliance forces.
The past few weeks have seen a sharp increase in high-level visits to Tajikistan which is a support base for the Northern Alliance.
American Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld is expected to arrive in Dushanbe today a few hours after the Austrian Foreign Minister Benita Ferrero-Waldner.

Following a visit by the German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer on October 20, Belgium's Foreign Minister Louis Michel, whose country currently holds the presidency of the European Union, also visited Tajikistan on Thursday, the first high-level visit by an EU official to Central Asia.

hl.seg: El-Kosheh massacre: retrial of 96 Egyptians accused of killing Christians begins

p.seg: Suhaj (Egypt) 11-3 (AFP) - The retrial of 96 Egyptians accused of involvement in the el-Kosheh massacre, which resulted in the deaths of 20 Christians in January 2000, began in the Criminal Court in Suhaj in lower Egypt today.

Shortly after the trial began, the court president, Lutfi Salman, decided to postpone consultations in order to allow the dossier to be examined in detail and to recall absent defendants. He said the date for the next session would be announced before next January.

The Supreme Court ruled on July 30 that the 96 accused individuals, 58 of whom are Muslims and 38 Copts, should be retried in Suhaj, 500 km south of Cairo, at a court other than the court where the case was initially tried in February 2001.
As the session started, the defense counsel asked for more time to study the 7000-page dossier. The accused pleaded not guilty and were re-released.
Suhaj Criminal Court had issued a ruling on February 5 for prison sentences with hard labor ranging from 1 to 12 years for four of the accused and found 92 innocent.

The public prosecutor said that the "Court made an illegal ruling and found the accused innocent even though the charges of intention to kill, possession of weapons, assembly, disturbance and threatening public safety had been proven."
The sectarian incidents which took place in el-Kosheh (Suhaj province, 500 km south of Cairo) in early January 200 resulted in the deaths of 21 people.

hl.seg: Thousands of demonstrators in London before World Trade Organization meeting

p.seg: London 11-3 (AFP) - Thousands of demonstrators took part today in a rally at Trafalgar Square in central London calling for fairer trade deals.
Police put the number of demonstrators taking part in the peace rally at about 2000 while the organizers said there were over 7000 people.

Ed Sweeney, the head of the International Development Group of the British Trade Union, said the "World Trade Organization cannot continue to trade as though all is well and there is no violation of basic human rights."
He added: "The Doha Summit (November 9-13) gives rulers a chance to show their intention to create an international trade system that puts people first."

hl.seg: Union Cup: two heated games in the semi-finals

p.seg: Dubai 11-3 (AFP) - The al-Jazeera and al-Ahly teams are to play the first of the two semi-final matches in the Emirates Football Association Cup, with the second semi-final to be held between al-Nasir and al-Wasil the day after tomorrow.

Al-Jazeera qualified for the fourth round heading group 1 with 21 points after beating the cup holders 2-1 in the last match of the first round, which, along with the expertise of its new international veteran player, the Liberian George Weah, has lifted the team's morale for tomorrow's game.
Al-Ahly reached the semi-final in second place in group 2 scoring 19 points.

Al-Ahly's place in the semi-final was assured even before its last game, allowing coach Fawzi al-Taisha to rest his star players in the match against al-Shabab (4-1) in preparation for the match against al-Jazeera.

For its part, al-Nasir, which heads group 2 (24), expects to continue its successful course under Czech coach Milan Matchala who is relying on the skill of his forwards Kadim Ali, in second position in the goal scorers' list (12 goals), and Angolan Da Silva and Eisa Juma'a.

Al-Wasil, which finished the first round in second position in group 1, hopes to continue its good performance under the leadership of its Dutch coach Boscamp and the aid of its international forward, Chilean Christian Montesenos, top scorer in the championship to date (13 goals) and Iranian Farhad Majidi, as well as the return of its veteran star Zuhair Bhaith from the national team.

hl.seg: FAO head stresses importance of basic human right to food

p.seg: Rome 11-3 (AFP) - The head of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Jacques Diouf, today stressed the importance, amid the current climate of fighting terrorism, of providing the basic human right to food.

The Senegalese official referred to "the shocking events of September 11" in his introduction to FAO's 31st conference in Rome, adding: "Today more than ever, there is a pressing need to implement human rights issues, the most important of which is the right to food."
He continued his speech, the text of which was released in advance by FAO, saying that the "seeds of violence and intolerance are effectively sown in the soils of poverty and oppression."
Addressing the 183 member countries, Diouf went on to give famine statistics.

The number of people in the world suffering from malnutrition is 815 million. At the current rate, it will actually take 60 years to achieve the target set in 1996 during the heads-of-state summit where this figure was to be cut in half by the year 2015.

hl.seg: Donald Rumsfeld arrives in Tajikistan

p.seg: Dushanbe 10-3 (AFP) - A France Presse correspondent reported that American Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld arrived in Tajikistan today after visiting Moscow. He will hold talks in Dushanbe with Tajik President Emamoli Rakhmonov on the subject of the international coalition against terrorism.

According to a diplomat in the Afghan opposition movement in Dushanbe, Rumsfeld will also meet with General Mohamed Kasim Fahim, the military commander of the Northern Alliance opposed to Taliban rule in Kabul.

This is Rumsfeld's first visit to Tajikistan, the former Soviet Republic in Central Asia which shares a 1340 km border with Afghanistan and has placed its airspace under United States control as part of the post-September 11 military campaign.
This visit comes at a crucial time after recent criticism that the military campaign has had no clear-cut results.

However, Russian leader Vladimir Putin yesterday expressed his support for the anti-terrorism campaign in Afghanistan, saying it was proceeding normally and rejected accusations that it is "faltering."
After leaving Dushanbe, Rumsfeld is to visit Uzbekistan, also a former Soviet Republic in Central Asia, which is allowing Washington to use one of its military bases.
Uzbekistan has a 137 km border with Afghanistan.
Rumsfeld will also visit Pakistan and India on this trip.
He is expected to return to Washington on Monday.

hl.seg: 1200 additional fighters from Pakistani tribes enter Afghanistan

p.seg: Peshawar (Pakistan) 11-4 (AFP) - The leader of a religious movement announced that 1200
additional fighters from Pakistani tribes entered Afghanistan on Sunday, bringing the number of Pakistani volunteers fighting alongside the Taliban in Afghanistan to 4400.
Mohamed Ismael, the local head of the Tehreek Nifaz-e-Sharia Mohammadi movement said the fighters crossed the border at Peshawar (northwestern Pakistan on the Afghan border).
He added that the fighters were armed with machine guns and "other weapons."
He said they proceeded to Jalalabad (eastern Afghanistan) to join other volunteers who crossed the border in recent days and that Taliban forces would specify their missions.

hl.seg: Archbishop of Canterbury in discussions with Qatar's Prince on the "peaceful coexistence of religions"

p.seg: Doha 11-4 (AFP) - Qatar's Prince Sheikh Hamad Bin Khalifa Al Thani and the Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey met in Doha on Sunday to discuss "peaceful coexistence" between different religions.
Qatar's news agency reported that Qatar's Prince welcomed the Archbishop of Canterbury in Doha on Saturday evening after the Archbishop's three-day visit to Bahrain.

The news agency said that Sheikh Hamad and the Archbishop of Canterbury discussed "a number of issues they were both concerned with and emphasized the importance of peaceful coexistence between different religions."
It said that the Archbishop of Canterbury also discussed "a set of issues of mutual interest" with the Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad Bin Jasem Al Thani.
It further stated the Qatari minister and Carey emphasized "the importance of peaceful coexistence and dialogue between different religions."

The Archbishop of Canterbury said upon arrival in Doha that his discussions with Qatari leaders would cover "relations between Christians and Muslims, the position of Christians in Qatar, religious freedom and the current situation in Afghanistan."

hl.seg: Ramadan: US use of "terrorism as justification" is "bogus"

p.seg: Baghdad 11-4 (AFP) - Iraq's Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan said today that Iraq is against the attack on Afghanistan, stating that the United States' use of "terrorism as justification to license its campaign against Afghanistan is bogus."

After visiting a number of stands at the Baghdad International fair and in response to questions from journalists regarding Iraq's position on the American military campaign in Afghanistan, Ramadan said Iraq "deplores and denounces the attack on the Muslim Afghan nation, which is bombarded on a daily basis without being guilty of anything."
He said: "We are against any attack on a third world Muslim country."

He further said that "terrorism as justification as used by America is bogus" and stated that the "real terrorism is the tampering with Arab land and Palestine taking place with America's support and protection."

hl.seg: Israel arrests six Palestinians suspected of killing Israeli woman

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-5 (AFP) - The Israeli government announced today the arrests of six Palestinians believed to be members of a group suspected of killing an Israeli woman and injuring three others last August.
A statement by the Israeli parliament said that Israel's internal security services (Shin bet) and the Israeli army arrested the six members of the group in September and October.

The government arrested the men on the basis of their being members of an organization-led cell, a name used by Israel for the military wing of the Hamas movement, headed by Palestinian President Yasser Arafat.
The six men are accused of killing a 19-year-old Israeli woman and injuring three others after they opened fire on a car carrying the victims on August 9 in Gilboa.
The statement said the men confessed to placing a bomb in a restaurant in the Golan Heights, which Israel annexed from Syria on August 14, and to planting mines in the Gilboa area.
They are also accused by the Israeli security services of planning to kidnap an Israeli and a booby-trapped car attack in the Beit Shian area (northern Israel).

hl.seg: Arafat to meet Peres in Brussels on Monday

p.seg: Brussels 11-5 (AFP) - A top official in the Palestinian intelligence services announced that Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Israel's Foreign Minister Shimon Peres are to meet in Brussels on Monday evening.

The source said the meeting, initially scheduled to be held at 22h00 local time (GMT 22h00) but changed to 19h30 (GMT 18h30) for "practical reasons," is to be held at the official residence of the Belgian Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt.

The meeting between the two men will not be a closed session, as Verhofstadt and his foreign minister Louis Michel as well as the European Union's foreign policy and security chief, Javier Solana, will be present.
The meeting will be short, and no joint press conference has been scheduled.
Arafat and Peres met on Friday and Saturday on the occasion of Formentor forum (Balearic islands) but said their talks did not lead to any progress in the peace process.
For his part, in reply to a question today concerning the possibility of a meeting with Arafat, Peres played down the importance of the meeting.
Peres said in French: "We are in the same city.
We cannot make have a big commotion about such meetings each time because the results are somewhat complex."
He added: "Everyone seems to think that simply meeting each other will suddenly solve every problem.
This is not true."
Previously, at the end of a meeting with Belgian Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt, Arafat had expressed his readiness to meet Peres if Peres agreed.

hl.seg: OPEC could cut production by 1.5 million barrels per day

p.seg: Vienna 11-5 (AFP) - A source at the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) said that OPEC may reduce its production by up to 1.5 million bpd when the ministers meet next week in Vienna.

The source, who wished to remain anonymous, said that OPEC is considering cutting production by 1-1.4 million bpd but this figure may reach 1.5 million bpd when the meeting takes place on November 14.
OPEC's secretary-general, Ali Rodriguez, had announced previously that the organization would "most probably" reduce its production by one million barrels per day.
OPEC, which produces 40% of the world's oil, is trying to stem the drop in prices which started after September 11 attacks in the US last year increasing fears of a world recession.
The price of an OPEC basket, consisting of several types of crude oil, fell to $17.18 per barrel last Friday against $18.25 on Thursday, said the organization's news agency (OPECNA).

hl.seg: Moscow regrets "inaction" of Palestinian Authority in clamping down on militants

p.seg: Moscow 11-5 (AFP) - Russia warned the Palestinian Authority on Monday about the "inaction on clamping down on terrorists" after the attack in East Jerusalem which led to a number of Israeli deaths and the wounding of 35 others.
The Russian foreign ministry said in a statement: "inaction and hesitation in clamping down on criminals cannot be justified in any way.
We call on the Palestinian Authority to take effective measures against terrorists."

The foreign ministry also said that the "Israeli authorities, for their part, must complete withdrawal of their troops from Palestinian towns as quickly as possible and should put an end to unacceptable and unlawful killing, regardless of the nationality of the victims."
Work on a political level must be started as soon as possible [...]
In this context, we must encourage continued contact between (Palestinian president) Yasser Arafat and (Israeli foreign minister) Shimon Peres."
Arafat and Peres are to take part in the Euromed conference in Brussels on Monday which will be attended by the foreign ministers of 27 European Union and Mediterranean states.
It is reported that Russia is to join the United States in sponsoring the peace process in the Middle East.

hl.seg: Comprehensive presidential pardon for prisoners of conscience in Tunisia

p.seg: Tunis 11-5 (AFP) - Tunisia's President Zin El Abidine Ben Ali issued a pardon on Wednesday for a number of prisoners to mark the President's 14th year in power, according to a press release on Monday by Tunis Africa government news agency.

These measures, which concern an unspecified number of prisoners of conscience and include reducing the sentences of some prisoners and canceling the remaining sentence of others, fall within a program called "rehabilitation pardon."
Other prisoners will benefit from conditional discharge from prison.
These measures were announced following a meeting between President Ben Ali, Justice Minister Bashir al-Tikari and Interior Minister Abdullah al-Ka'bi.

Celebrations will be held in Tunisia on Wednesday to mark the 14th anniversary of President Zin El Abidine Ben Ali's ascension to power after President Habib Borgiba was deposed because of old age on October 7, 1987.
President Ben Ali reaches the end of his third term as president in 2004.

hl.seg: Daniel Ortega admits defeat in presidential elections

p.seg: Managua 11-5 (AFP) - In a statement to supporters of his movement in Managua on Monday, Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega admitted defeat in the presidential elections against Enrique Bolanos of the Liberal Constitutionalist Party.
Ortega said: "I wish the winner good luck.
Our country is in a bad state and we need a critical opposition but it must be constructive criticism."
Ortega, partial results suggesting that he lost by 7% of the vote, added that the Sandinista National Liberation Front would call for national reconciliation and the defense of democracy.
The two candidates considered the results of the election as final even though the Supreme Election Council only issued the results of 42.5% of ballots.
According to partial results, Enrique Bolanos obtained 53.03% of votes versus 45.35% for Ortega.
The new 73-year-old president is to take up his position next January 10 and will replace Arnoldo Aleman whose Liberal Party defeated Ortega in the 1996 elections.
The elections, involving 12,500 national monitors, passed without incident.

hl.seg: Heavy gunfire in two Bangui suburbs (witnesses)

p.seg: Bangui 11-6 (AFP) - Eye witnesses told France Presse that intensive automatic gunfire mixed with heavy artillery fire was heard in two suburbs to the north of Bangui starting at 16h30 (GMT 15.30) on Tuesday afternoon.

The same source said that supporters loyal to Lieutenant-Colonel George Twagande, who was arrested on Monday, were the instigators of the gunfire to which the presidential security unit and Libyan soldiers then responded.
The gunfire was preceded by unusual movement of units in this zone, which covers the Boyrabi and Foah quarters in northern Bangui.

There was no firing in the Gabungo quarter, the place of residence of former chief army commander General Francois Bozize, who has been refusing, since Saturday, to comply with the summons issued by the legal authorities.

hl.seg: Israeli army begins withdrawal from Ramallah

p.seg: Ramallah (West Bank) 11-6 (AFP) - A top Palestinian intelligence official told France Presse yesterday that the Israeli army had begun to withdraw its forces from Ramallah on the West Bank.

The Israeli army received orders on Tuesday evening to prepare to withdraw from the town of Ramallah, which falls within the Palestinian autonomous zone and which has been partially re-occupied since November 18, but to continue the blockade of the town.
Early Monday morning, the Israeli army withdrew from the town of Qalqilya in the northern West Bank a week after withdrawing from Bethlehem and its suburb Beit Jala.
Israel is still occupying areas in three towns in the Palestinian autonomous zone on the West Bank: Nablus, Jenin and Tulkram (north).

hl.seg: Over 50 thousand private school teachers in one-day warning strike

p.seg: Beirut 11-6 (AFP) About 52 thousand teachers in the private school sector are taking part in a one-day warning strike today demanding that the authorities stop their procrastination in accepting their demands and have threatened to take further action.

The private schools' union chief, George Sa'ada, said in a press conference: "The strike comes after the authorities continued to ignore the demands we have been formulating although we did not strike for a single day last year."
He said: "If the reaction continues to be one of lack of concern, then there will be further action."

The main demands of private-sector school teachers concern higher salaries through the establishment of special posts, equivalent to that of their state school colleagues, and approval of a pension plan for the private sector.
The strike affects 1200 schools with over 600 thousand students in different parts of Lebanon.
Full-time lecturers at the University of Lebanon have also been on strike since the beginning of last week asking for independence of the University of Lebanon, better financing and higher salaries.

For their part, state school teachers have made a number of demands and intend to carry out a one-day warning strike on November 31, the feasibility of which is being examined by their union branches.

hl.seg: Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claim responsibility for attack on Israeli soldiers

p.seg: Damascus 11-6 (AFP) - In a statement issued on Tuesday, al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, which is linked to the Fatah movement led by Palestinian President Yasser Arafat, claimed responsibility for the attack which resulted in the death of an Israeli officer.
Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade said it "killed an Israeli officer on the West Bank and wounded a number of Israeli soldiers in an armed clash."

The statement said the group carried out the attack as retaliation after Israeli forces arrested a number of civilians and killed three Palestinian citizens, adding that its group "withdrew without suffering any injuries."
The statement also said that al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade is determined to fight Israeli occupation and to eject the settlers from Palestinian territory.
Israeli military sources announced earlier the death of an Israeli officer who was seriously injured during the clash.
Palestinian medical sources said the three earlier victims were members of Hamas, Fatah and the People's Party (former communist group).
The commander of the Israeli units in the zone where the clash took place told France Presse that the three Palestinians were armed and were stopped by an Israeli unit.
He added that two Palestinians were killed at the start of shooting while the third was killed after an Israeli reinforcement unit arrived.

hl.seg: Moroccan monarch reiterates that Western Sahara "belongs to Morocco"

p.seg: Marrakech 11-6 (AFP) - The Moroccan monarch, King Mohamed 6th, reiterated today that the Western Sahara "belongs to Morocco" and announced his resolve to develop the land there as part of a "provincial re-evaluation" policy.

King Mohamed 6th was giving a speech broadcast by television and radio stations on the anniversary of the 26th "green procession" (the decisive phase in Morocco's control of the Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony)

He said that Morocco is "strongly attached to this area and is confident of its sovereignty to this land," regardless of the developments that occur in the "artificial dispute concerning the desert belonging to Morocco."

The Moroccan monarch also repeated his acceptance of the framework agreement proposed by James Baker, the United Nations special envoy, "within limits that ensure total respect of our national sovereignty and unity of our land."
He added: "All parties concerned must demonstrate a positive approach to this framework agreement."

He pointed out the social and economic successes achieved in the Western Desert since 1974 and his determination to continue with these achievements, adding that this area would act as an "example" for regional strategies elsewhere in the country.

hl.seg: Kuwait national team loses 4-1 to Kaiserslautern

p.seg: Kaiserslautern (Germany) 11-6 (AFP) - The Kuwaiti national soccer team lost 4-1 today to Kaiserslautern in front of 2000 spectators in the second of its preparatory matches at its training camp in Germany where it is training until November 14.
Bashar Abdullah (87) scored Kuwait's goal while Olaf Marshall (12), Mifsod (75 and 87) and Polish Tomas Klaus (88) scored the goals for Kaiserslautern.
The Kuwaiti coach, German Bertie Foggits, included a number of players in order to evaluate their technical level.
This is the second time in a row Kuwait has lost a match at its training camp; it lost 2-1 against Strasbourg, the French Cup holder (division 2), on Sunday.
Al-Azraq is to play Frieburg on Friday and Nuremberg on the 11th of this month.
The camp is part of the team's preparations for the 15th Gulf Cup hosted by Saudi Arabia next 16-30 January.

hl.seg: Body of Egyptian citizen at Cairo airport yet to be identified

p.seg: Cairo 11-6 (AFP) - An airport source said today that the body of an Egyptian citizen returned from Jordan a week ago is still at Cairo airport because no relative has yet come forward to claim it in spite of three personal addresses accompanying the corpse.
A week after the arrival of the body of Said Najib Said (61 years old) from Jordan with three addresses for family members, no-one has come forward to claim it.

The three different addresses, two in Cairo and one in Alexandria (in the north), were recorded by the Egyptian Embassy in Amman in his passport, as well as in documents accompanying the body and in a letter to his wife.
The source said that although the airport authorities informed the family several times at the three addresses, no-one had come forward to identify the body.
This is the second time this has happened in Egypt this year.

hl.seg: The language of color and shadowy-featured crowds make up the visual world of Sakhar Farzat

p.seg: Cairo 11-6 (AFP) - In the warm, dreamy colors surging throughout the paintings of Syrian artist Sakhar Farzat, born in Banias in Syria in 1943, one can distinguish the large, fluid mass of a crowd with undefined features which make up the world of the paintings on exhibition at al-Jazeera Arts Center in Cairo.

The colors range from deep, dreamy blues to various tones of green and pink whose layering on the canvas gives the effect of a mass of small, fused human shapes with no features until, viewed as a whole, the effect of acrylic color creates the finished image of the painting in the form of a woman or a gathering or a separation is revealed.

In other paintings, the crowds form a shadowy abstraction with no final form except for the impact of pure color. This allows the artist, through the use of quick-drying acrylic paint, to construct his layers of color where the visual language develops and extends into a world of aesthetic skill, which brings out layers revealing the hidden concept.

Sakhar Farzat has held around 30 exhibitions in Syria, Jordan, Qatar, Emirates, Saudi Arabia and Tunisia, as well as exhibitions in the United States, Switzerland, Britain, and in a number of cities in France where he has lived since 1977.
He has taken part in over 20 exhibitions in different countries alongside Arab and foreign artists.
The exhibition, which opened on Sunday, continues for two weeks.

hl.seg: Islamabad asks Taliban ambassador to end "propaganda" campaign against a friendly country

p.seg: Islamabad 11-7 (AFP) - An official source told France Presse today that the Pakistani government had called on the Taliban ambassador to Islamabad, Abdulsalam Thaeef, to "stop the propaganda campaign against a country with friendly relations to Pakistan."
The foreign ministry spokesman, Aziz Ahmed Khan, said that Thaeef was called to the foreign office and
asked to comply with diplomatic protocol.
Khan said that the authorities blamed the Taliban ambassador for the "propaganda campaign against a country with friendly relations" with Pakistan.

Doon newspaper said today that Islamabad asked Thaeef to stop the daily press conferences in which he quotes from Taliban sources the number of civilian victims in Afghanistan, as well as American helicopters shot down, and in which he accuses the United States of carrying out "genocide."
Pakistan is a United States ally and member of the alliance against terrorism. It is the only country to have diplomatic relations with the Taliban regime.

Thaeef's press conferences in Islamabad attract a large number of journalists from all over the world. In them, he puts forth the Taliban regime's position on the crisis in Afghanistan, much to Washington's annoyance, as it wants at any cost to challenge the "campaign of deception" conducted by the Taliban.

hl.seg: Gunfire heard again in north Bangui

p.seg: Bangui 11-7 (AFP) - Heavy machine and automatic gunfire was heard in the distance at 8h00 local time (GMT 7h00) this morning in the Boyrabi and Foah suburbs north of Bangui, according to a resident in the area contacted by France Presse by telephone.
A resident said that the "source of the sudden gunfire was the Boyrabi suburb where loyalist forces have reinforced their security arrangements."
He added: "People have not been allowed to move about at all today after the exchange of gunfire yesterday night."

The sound of intensive shooting by automatic arms and heavy artillery was heard on Tuesday night in two of the northern suburbs of Bangui where supporters of Lieutenant-Colonel George Twagande, who was arrested on Monday after he and his men caused mayhem in the Boyrabi suburb, have been hiding.

hl.seg: Washington expresses satisfaction with North Korea joining anti-terrorism alliance

p.seg: Washington 11-8 (AFP) - An American foreign ministry official yesterday expressed the United States' satisfaction with North Korea's decision to sign the international treaty on terrorism and called on it to pursue other measures in this capacity.
The official, who asked to remain anonymous, said European diplomats informed Washington that Pyongyang will in fact join the United Nation's agreement prohibiting the funding of terrorism.
He added: "Ratifying this agreement is one of the measures required by Security Council resolutions concerning a comprehensive anti-terrorism campaign."
The United States had regarded North Korea as one of the countries supporting terrorism through actions such as sheltering Japanese Red Army hijackers.
North Korea did not give its support to the anti-terrorism campaign in Afghanistan after the September 11 attacks, but it did condemn the attacks.

Pyongyang announced its opposition to all forms of terrorism, and the North Korean news agency reported last Saturday that North Korea would sign the United Nations agreement on prohibiting the funding of terrorism and another agreement relating to hostage taking.

hl.seg: United Nations helicopter crashes in ocean near Sierra Leone

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-7 AFP - The United Nations in New York announced that one of its helicopters carrying 7 people crashed in the ocean near Sierra Leone at 20h00 local time today, resulting in the death of at least one person.
United Nations' spokesman Farhan al-Haq said the helicopter crashed not far from the international mission's headquarters in Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital.
He added that the mission carried out a search and rescue operation and that at least one body was found.
No details are known yet, particularly with regard to whether the passengers were soldiers or civilian members of the mission.

The United Nations mission in Freetown is the largest with 16,600 soldiers, 46 of whom have been killed since it was set up in October 1999, mainly through clashes with rebels of the United Revolutionary Front.
The mission also employs 49 policemen, 297 international workers and 464 local workers.

hl.seg: Head of administration loyal to Russia in Chechnya escapes attack

p.seg: Moscow 11-8 (AFP) - The head of the administration loyal to Russia in Chechnya, Ahmed Kadirov, escaped an attack on Tuesday night in which three of his guards were injured, said his spokesperson in a statement broadcast by the Russian news agency.
Spokesman Abdulaziz Israelov said unidentified men opened fire on Kadirov's car in the town of Argon near the Chechneyan capital, Grozny.
The administration loyal to Russia has escaped a number of other attacks.
An inquiry has been initiated to identify the attackers.
Chechneyan separatists have kidnapped a number of people collaborating with the administration, accusing them of treason, since Russian forces entered the Caucasian republic on October 1, 1999.
Two of Kadirov's brothers-in-law were killed in recent months.
One was shot dead in September in southern Chechnya.
The second was assassinated in June in the same area by a remote-detonation bomb.

hl.seg: Prince Turki al-Faisal: We have no information about contact between Bin Laden and the CIA

p.seg: Riyadh 11-7 (AFP) - The former head of Saudi intelligence Prince Turki al-Faisal stated that the Saudi authorities had "no information" concerning contact between the extremist fundamentalist Osama Bin Laden and the American Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) or any other foreign intelligence agency other than the "Pakistani intelligence agency."

In an interview with Middle East television (MBC), published by Al-Sharq al-Awsat newspaper, Prince Turki said: "We have no information regarding any contact he might have had with foreign government agencies other than Pakistani agencies."
He added in response to a question about a link between Bin Laden and the CIA that "his presence and missions (in Afghanistan and Pakistan) do not require contact between him and these agencies."
The former Saudi official said he met Osama Bin Laden several times in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan before his Saudi citizenship was withdrawn in 1994.
Prince Turki said he found him to be "a young man eager for Jihad, agreeable and straightforward, quiet, soft spoken and, in general, a pleasant man."

He added that Osama Bin Laden did not "cause concern when he was fighting against the Soviet Union ... I used to go to Pakistan and sometimes to Afghanistan too; I saw him there and, once or twice, he was invited to the Saudi embassy in Islamabad. That was the first time I met him, there in the field, when he was working in support of Jihad."
He went on to say: "His activities were welcomed at that time ..."

hl.seg: American transport ship in the vicinity of Qatar in readiness for any emergency

p.seg: Washington 11-8 (AFP) - An American transport ship, the USS Peleliu with two thousand Marines on board, has been dispatched as a precautionary measure to Qatar where ministers of the World Trade Organization are to meet tomorrow, said an official at the Pentagon (Defense Department) today.
Security fears have increased after a Qatari airbase used by Americans was fired at on Wednesday.
The culprit, who was shot by guards at the base, is believed to be mentally unstable.
The ship, present in the Sea of Oman as part of the military operation in Afghanistan, has been secured in order to deal with any emergency, said an unnamed American official.

General Jim Jones, the Marine commander, had announced previously that the Marines' 15th unit, on board the Peleliu, had been temporarily supported from units amassed in preparation for the war in Afghanistan, without saying that the matter was connected with improving security in the area surrounding the center where the World Trade Organization is to hold its ministerial meeting.
He said in an interview with journalists that the Marines "have been entrusted with an unusual and sensitive mission - not military but political."
The two thousand Marines on board the ship are equipped and trained to carry out rescue operations and conventional killing operations.
It is believed that Qatar has no more than a few thousand policemen while the army consists of 12 thousand men.

hl.seg: Ashcroft announces reorganization of judicial system to adapt to anti-terrorism campaign

p.seg: Washington 11-8 (AFP) - The American Attorney-General John Ashcroft announced a plan today to reorganize the Justice Department "in the climate of war" to take into account the practicalities of the campaign against terrorism.

Aschroft told Department officials: "Today, I am announcing a mobilization of legal resources and law enforcement agencies throughout the country as part of a reorganization plan compatible with the climate of war."

He said the September 11 attacks redefined the Justice Department's role, mentioning the campaign against terrorism as being "at the heart" of the Federal Bureau of Investigations' (F.B.I.) activities.
Ashcroft said: "We have to have new working relations between the various law enforcement agencies and put an end to the bureaucratic disputes between them."
The American minister added that he would present Congress with a five-year strategic plan aimed at adapting the Justice Department to the campaign against terrorism.

hl.seg: Chirac in Emirates on Monday to hold talks about Afghanistan and the Middle East

p.seg: Abu Dhabi 11-8 (AFP) - The Emirates' news agency said today that French President Jacques Chirac is to visit Abu Dhabi next Monday to hold talks about Afghanistan and the Middle East conflict as part of a trip to the region.

The news agency said that "the President of the United Arab Emirates, Sheikh Zayid Bin Sultan Al Nihyan, is to hold talks with his Excellency the French President within the framework of consultation and coordination regarding recent developments in the current situation, international efforts against terrorism and ways to revive the peace process" in the Middle East.
It added that the two leaders would also discuss "mutual cooperation between the two countries."

The French presidency announced today that Chirac is to make a tour next Monday and Tuesday covering Egypt, United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia as part of a diplomatic strategy following the September 11 attacks on the United States.
No details about the trip's schedule have been released.

hl.seg: General Franks: Bin Laden not a target

p.seg: Washington 11-8 (AFP) - The commander of Operation Enduring Freedom, General Tommy Franks, said today that Osama Bin Laden, who is hiding in Afghanistan and whom Washington believes to be the main suspect in the September 11 attacks, is not the target of American raids; he said that the aim of the campaign is to destroy the al-Qaida network and the Taliban regime.

In response to a question by a Washington journalist about why Bin Laden is not included as a target of the operation, General Franks said: "We have not said that Bin Laden is a target of our operation.
Our attack is aimed at destroying the al-Qaida network and what I call the Taliban non-state which gave Bin Laden and al-Qaida a base."
He added: "I think we would be giving the enemy information if we say he is in a more or less secure state at the moment."
American President George Bush said in the wake of the September 11 attacks that Americans regard Osama Bin Laden as the organizer behind the attacks and that they want him "dead or alive."

hl.seg: American air raid on Kabul

p.seg: Kabul 11-9 (AFP) - A Kabul resident said American air force planes bombed the Afghan capital at dawn this morning dropping two bombs.
The source added that at least one plane circled over the city at about 5:00 am local time (GMT 00h30) and that two explosions were heard west and south of Kabul.
Taliban anti-aircraft guns did not respond to the bombing.
Since the air raids on Afghanistan began on October 7, American planes have been bombing Kabul and other cities regularly.

In recent days, while continuing raids on Kabul, American planes have focused their attacks on the main fronts where the governing Taliban regime is facing Northern Alliance opposition forces in northern Kabul, as well as around Mazar-e-Sharif (north) and in northeastern Afghanistan.

hl.seg: Israel satisfied with Bush's statement concerning the Middle East and the war

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-8 (AFP) - A top Israeli official praised the statement made by American President George Bush in which he said the success of the United States war in Afghanistan against the al-Qaida network is not linked to a peace settlement in the Middle East.
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's spokesman, Ra'anan Gissin, said: "This has always been our view and we are happy with this statement."
He added: "Bin Laden said a long time ago that his real target is the United States," referring to the assumed terrorist Osama Bin Laden.

The American president had said in a joint press conference at the White House with British Prime Minister Tony Blair: "I have no doubt that we will bring al-Qaida to justice whether or not peace prevails in the Middle East."
In response to a question about whether the alliance would win the war without this settlement (concerning the Middle East) being concluded, Bush said: "I think we're capable of this.
I think we can achieve it. We are hunting them (Taliban and Osama Bin Laden) as we speak
and we will bring them to justice."

hl.seg: Jose Bouve granted entry visa for Qatar

p.seg: Beirut 11-8 (AFP) - International French activist and representative of the International Federation of Agricultural Unions, Jose Bouve, has just been granted an entry visa for Qatar, allowing him to participate as an observer in the World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference which starts tomorrow.

Bouve told France Presse before boarding a Qatar Airways plane for Doha: "I have just been given without any explanation an entry visa by Qatar's representative at the World Trade Organization in Doha."

The French activist, who took part in the first Arab anti-globalization meeting, had complained that in spite of the intervention of the French Foreign and Foreign Trade ministries, Qatar did not grant him an entry visa until a few hours prior to his arranged visit to Doha.
The World Trade Organization authorized Jose Bouve as an official observer in his capacity as representative of the International Federation of Agricultural Unions.

hl.seg: Jordan's monarch: need to set the Middle East peace process in motion

p.seg: London 11-10 (AFP) - Jordan's King Abdallah II stressed today in London the pressing need to set in motion once again the Middle East peace process between Israel and the Palestinians, saying that the September 11 attacks increased this need.
Yesterday, after a private visit that lasted 3 days, the Jordanian monarch, accompanied by his wife Queen Rania, ended an official 3-day visit where he met British Prime Minister Tony Blair.
In a press conference, the Jordanian monarch called on the international community to create a climate which would give the Middle East peace process a real chance of success.

He said "extremists have taken our (Muslim) religion hostage and tarnished it" and that Osama Bin Laden, the main suspect in the attacks against the United States, had used the Palestinian situation as an excuse to justify the attacks.
He further added that the war on terrorism could take dozens of years but that "in this crisis, there is hope" for finding a solution in the Middle East.

In a joint press conference with Blair held on Thursday, Jordan's king emphasized that the military objectives in Afghanistan had to be realized and that this is the main objective of the anti-terrorism alliance.
On the economic front, King Abdullah said he received "a very positive response" from British industrial organizations concerning future investment projects in Jordan.

hl.seg: Sleeping sickness reappears in the central region of the Democratic Republic of Congo

p.seg: Goma (Democratic Republic of Congo) 11-9 (AFP) - A resurgence of sleeping sickness has occurred in the western Kasai province, under rebel control, in the south-central region of the Democratic Republic of Congo, witnesses returning from the region told France Presse.

Travelers returning from Dimbelenge said today that dozens of people are dying every day of malaria, tuberculosis and diarrhea, and especially sleeping sickness, in the Dimbelenge area 120 kilometers from Kanaga (the biggest town in the western Kasai province).

The witnesses said that the area affected by the illness is under the control of rebels from the Congolese Rally for Democracy, an area that has been cut off from medical centers in the towns of Kanaga and Mbuji-Mayi (under government control) for the past two years.
Patients have to go to Ludga, 400 kilometers away, Kendo (600 km) and Goma (over 1000 km from Dimbelenge) to find medication, a long and arduous journey usually done by bicycle.
The witnesses also said that "in addition to the lack of medicines, there is a shortage of nursing staff.
There are only two doctors to cover the large areas of Rawanda and Burundi."

Sleeping sickness declined in the years after Zaire's independence in 1960 as a result of the Belgian Tropical Medical Fund's efforts and the opening of a hospital in Lobonga in the Dimbelenge province.

hl.seg: Six Tunisians file case in France for "undergoing torture in their country"

p.seg: Paris 11-9 (AFP) - A French lawyer, William Bourdon, said today that six Tunisian human rights activists "were tortured in their country" and had brought a case under the French legal system against the perpetrators "who visit France regularly."

The lawyer said at a press conference at the offices of Reporters without Borders that "the case was filed on November 7 at the Public Prosecutor's offices in Paris by six Tunisians who were tortured in their country.
We have provided a list of 40 identified suspects who visit France on a regular basis."

He said the case is "based on international articles covered by the 1984 Geneva Convention against torture and directly applicable under French law," regardless of the torturer's nationality or place "where the crimes were committed."

According to the lawyer, whose case is being supported by Amnesty International, International Human Rights Organization and Human Rights Watch, the victims provided evidence that they had been severely tortured at sites under Tunisian authority and especially the Ministry of Interior and Prisons."
He added that, for safety reasons, only two of the people in the group which filed the complaint could be named; they are Eman Darwish and Nuruddin Ben Tisheh who both attended the press conference.

hl.seg: Three demonstrators shot dead by security forces in Pakistan

p.seg: Islamabad 11-9 (AFP) - The Pakistani police force opened fire today on demonstrators in Darat Ghazi Khan in central Pakistan killing three people, a top police official told France Presse.
The incident occurred when approximately 5000 militants from the radical Islamic party Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam obstructed a highway and a railway line in the area.
Police opened fire on armed demonstrators who fired back, injuring four policemen.
Three demonstrators were killed and four others were wounded.
A police source said the "situation is still tense."
An official from the Society of Muslim Clergy, Riyadh Dorani, said previously that two demonstrators had been killed and four policemen held hostage.

hl.seg: Bush criticizes the loss of his country's seat on the international human rights committee

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-10 AFP - American President George Bush told the United Nations' General Assembly today that removing his country from the United Nations' Human Rights Committee has damaged the organization's credibility.
Bush said: "The world needs a leader with principles.
When the human rights committee proposes a country, which constantly violates human rights, for a seat then this damages the credibility of this important institution."
He added, in his first speech to the United Nations' General Assembly since coming to power last January, that the "United Nations is based on moral authority and this authority has to be preserved."

The United States met with a huge diplomatic failure when, on May 3, it lost the seat it had held on the Human Rights Committee for over 50 years, with France, Austria and Sweden taking the three seats allotted to the western countries' bloc.
It further pointed out that countries known for their human rights violations, such as Sudan, had won a seat on this committee.

hl.seg: Last pockets of Taliban resistance in the north will fall "soon" (Afghan diplomat in exile)

p.seg: Tashkent 11-10 (AFP) - An Afghan embassy official in exile in Tashkent said today that the last pockets of Taliban resistance in the north of the country will fall within a day or two to armed opposition forces.

Diplomat Mohamed Ghafouri said that "200 Pakistani fighters" had barricaded themselves in two houses in the northern town of Mazar-e-Sharif which fell to opposition forces today but that they will soon have to surrender.
Ghafouri said: "There are 200 fighters hiding in two houses from which they are fighting.
They are Pakistani rather than from the Taliban [...]
and have no choice but to surrender."
He added: "The only places under Taliban control at the moment are the two towns of Kunduz and Smanghan, which we will soon capture."
He also said that Northern Alliance forces were moving toward Talukan and would capture the town today or tomorrow.

A spokesman for General Abdulrashid Dustum, one of the anti-Taliban opposition leaders, told the British Broadcasting Company (BBC) today that the Northern Alliance is "in full control" of the town and airport of Mazar-e-Sharif after battles that resulted in huge losses in the Taliban ranks.

hl.seg: Five people killed in acts of violence in Algeria (newspapers)

p.seg: Algiers 11-10 (AFP) - Algerian newspapers reported on Saturday that five people were killed in acts of violence attributed to armed Islamic groups.
Le Matin and Alkhabar reported that an armed Islamic group massacred three people at a barricade they set up near Tizi Ghioul on the road leading south to Batna (430 km south-east of the capital).

The newspapers said that one of the people killed was a policeman, while the second was a member of a vigilante group and the third a teacher. They were ambushed at 22h30 (GMT 21h30) by an armed Islamic group about 40 kilometers south of Batna.
Elsewhere, security forces killed two armed Islamists in Wadi al-Inab in the province of Anaba (600 km east of the capital), according to Wahran newspaper.

This region is home to militants from the Salfia group led by Hassan Hatab, which along with the Armed Islamic Group led by Antar Zwabri, rejects the policy of accord pursued by President Abdulazziz Botfliqa.

hl.seg: Al-Wahdat temporarily reduces point difference

p.seg: Amman 11-10 (AFP) - Al-Wahdat temporarily reduced the point difference between it and al-Faisali, the league leader, to 2 points as a result of its difficult win against al-Qadisiya (2-1) today at Amman International Stadium, in the 13th round of Jordan's soccer league.

Al-Qadisiya was first to score by a penalty kick (25) executed by Issam Abu Toq but Abdullah Abu Zama, who returns to the team after recovering from an injury and a stint as a professional player with Qatar's al-Wakra team, equalized by scoring a penalty kick at the 28th minute. He later missed a penalty kick by hitting the ball above the crossbar at the 46th minute.
Mahmood Shalbaya scored the winning goal for al-Whadat at the 47th minute.
Al-Wahdat raised their points to 31 whereas al-Faisali stands at 33 points. Al-Faisali is to meet al-Ahli, which presently ranks 6th (14), the day after tomorrow at the end of the premiership.
In another match at the al-Hassan Stadium in Irbid, al-Hussein thrashed Kufarsum 7-1.
Maher Sarsur (40, 44, 87), Ghanim Himarsha (54, 90) and Khalid Nimr (72, 83) scored the Shabab al-Hussain goals while Sharman Ubaidat (42) scored Kufarsum's only goal.

hl.seg: Bush: military campaign making progress and Taliban days limited

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-10 (AFP) - American President George Bush declared today that the military campaign is "making progress" and that the Taliban's days are numbered.
He told the United Nations' General Assembly that the United States is "making progress in its war against military targets" in Afghanistan.

After a month of intensive bombing, the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance has managed to take control of the strategic town of Mazar-e-Sharif in northern Afghanistan. A spokesperson for the president also said that coalition forces had taken control of a third sector in northern Afghanistan.
Bush said that "the days of the Taliban regime, which harbors terrorists, trades in heroin and mistreats women, are now numbered."
He further said: "The Afghan nation does not deserve its current rulers.
The years of Taliban rule have brought only misery and destruction."
He added that "the world will be able to breathe a sigh of relief when they disappear from existence."

He pledged continued humanitarian aid to the Afghan people, to work with the United Nations in order to "set up a government in the post-Taliban phase that represents all Afghanis" and to help rebuild the country destroyed by 20 years of war.

hl.seg: Israel announces arrest of 12 Palestinians in the West Bank

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-10 (AFP) - A statement by the Israeli Army this morning said that Israeli forces had arrested 12 Palestinians during an incursion last night into an area under Palestinian control to the west of Jenin, a town in the north of the West Bank.

The statement added that an Israeli unit backed by armored vehicles entered the village of al-Arqa in pursuit of those who attacked an Israeli settlement on Friday night. 12 Palestinian "militants involved in terrorist activities" against Israel were arrested.

The statement also said that the Israeli forces which entered the village destroyed the house of the perpetrator of an attack on al-Afula in northern Israel last October 4 in which three Israelis were killed.

A female Israeli settler from the Mevo Dotan settlement near Jenin was killed yesterday evening in an attack for which the Popular Army Brigades/Al-Awda Battalion branch of Fatah claimed responsibility.
The attack took place close to the village of Yabud near al-Arqa.

hl.seg: Arrival of a large number of heads of state to take part in United Nations meetings
