p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-10 (AFP) - A large number of heads of state and foreign ministers arrived at the United Nations headquarters in New York amid stringent security measures to take part in the annual meeting of the United Nations' General Assembly.
Among the first delegates to arrive were Palestinian President Yasser Arafat, American Secretary of State Colin Powell and French Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine.

Two months after the terrorist attacks which destroyed the twin towers of the World Trade Center, security measures have been increased following threats by Osama Bin Laden against the United Nations and its Secretary-General Kofi Anan.
After Anan, American President George Bush will be among the first to give his inaugural speech to the United Nations.
He said he intended to encourage member states to increase their support for the campaign against terrorism and that the time had come to move from words to action.
Prominent speakers include Pakistan's leader, Pervez Musharraf, Iranian president Mohamed Khatami and Indian Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee.
Around 50 heads of state and government and over 100 foreign ministers will take part in this conference, which lasts a week until November 16.

hl.seg: Trial of nationalists and reformists begins in Iran

p.seg: Tehran 11-11 (AFP) - The trial of 60 nationalists and reformists accused of attempts to "overthrow the regime" began today in a closed session at Tehran Revolutionary Court, said a France Presse correspondent.

In response to a question by France Presse, court sources said only 31 of the accused appeared in court, in the first session which lasted three hours, of whom five were from prison while the rest are on temporary bail.
It is not known why one of the accused prisoners did not attend court.
Journalists and family members of those under arrest were prevented from attending.
The accused, who were arrested in March but the majority of whom have since been temporarily released, are charged with attempting to "overthrow the regime" and "undermine state security."
If they are found guilty, they face sentences ranging from 10 years imprisonment to execution.

During the first hearing session, the prosecutor recited the list of accusations with which the accused are charged, most of whom are members of the Iran Liberation Movement, the reformist nationalist party created by former Prime Minister Mahdi Bazrakan.

hl.seg: Al-Hariri: ending the Arab-Israeli conflict will eradicate one of the seeds of terrorism

p.seg: Paris 11-11 AFP - Lebanon's Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri said in an interview with French newspaper Le Figaro to be published tomorrow that "ending the Palestinian-Israeli conflict will weed out one of the seeds of terrorism."

Al-Hariri, who met French President Jacques Chirac in the Elysee Palace on Saturday, said: "If nothing is done to resolve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict then all the Arab regimes supporting the United States in its battle against terrorism will face internal problems."

He stressed today that after a month of bombing Afghanistan, the feeling of the Arab street is one of resentment because of what is happening in the West Bank and Gaza Strip rather than what is happening in Afghanistan.
Al-Hariri said: "Israel is occupying Palestinian land and killing Palestinians every day.
Arab viewers see this daily on their television screens.
The Israeli government is playing the role of judge and jury at the same time.
This is not healthy."

However, the Lebanese prime minister saluted American President George Bush's speech to the United Nations, considering it a first step, especially as Bush reiterated his agreement for the creation of a Palestinian state.
Al-Hariri further said that the "war against terrorism is not Bush's war alone; it is also our war because terrorism affects our country too.
By ending the Arab-Israeli conflict, one of the seeds of terrorism will be eradicated."

hl.seg: Israel expresses satisfaction with Bush's speech to United Nations (official)

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-11 (AFP) - Israel's ambassador to Washington, David Ivry, said in an interview with Israeli radio today that he is "satisfied" with American President George Bush's speech to the United Nation's General Assembly in which he called for a "just peace" in the Middle East.
Ivry said: "The speech contained no surprises for us and is in agreement with what we expected on many points. We are satisfied with its content."
Bush had announced Washington's "intention to work toward a just peace in the Middle East."
He added that his country "will do everything in its power to bring the two sides to the negotiating table."
He also said that the United States wants one day to see "two states, Israel and Palestine, living in peace within secure, recognized borders as set out in United Nations resolutions."
Bush said that "peace will only come about when we rid ourselves forever of the incitement of violence and terror."

Ivry said that the American president "supports our view regarding putting an end to terrorism and incitement of violence. What is important in our opinion is that there is no new American peace initiative and that the Mitchell Report remains the basis of a settlement."
The Mitchell Report, which came out last May, called on Palestinians and Israelis to restore calm and build trust in order to revive the peace talks.

hl.seg: Canada calls for "new language" to be adopted to satisfy the European Union on agriculture

p.seg: Doha 11-11 (AFP) - Canada's Foreign Trade Minister, Pierre Pettigrew, said today that "new language" needs to be adopted that satisfies the European Union for gradual cancellation of agricultural export subsidies within the framework of a new probable round of talks for multi-lateral trade negotiations.
Pettigrew's declarations are a first step in reaching a settlement.

The Kerns group, which includes 18 rich and poor countries headed by Canada, Australia, Argentina and Brazil, is calling for agricultural export subsidies to be cancelled, whereas Europe rejects any such reference in the ministerial communiqu� of the Doha conference.

Canada's representative at the World Trade Organization, Sergio Marchi, said Europeans must not hope that a position on the environment will mean changing the tone of the ministerial communiqu� which calls for a "gradual cancellation" of subsidies for agricultural exports.
Marchi added that the Europeans "have not hidden the idea of bargaining between environmental and agricultural issues."

hl.seg: Israeli army penetrates Beit Hanoun in northern Gaza Strip

p.seg: Gaza 11-11 (AFP) - A Palestinian security source said on Sunday that the Israeli army penetrated about 300 meters into areas under Palestinian control in Beit Hanoun in the northern Gaza Strip and bulldozed large areas of land.

The source from the Palestinian General Security Office in the Gaza Strip who wished to remain anonymous told France Presse that an "army bulldozer accompanied by Israeli tanks penetrated over 300 meters into areas belonging to residents under Palestinian control."
He added that the Israeli army "destroyed farmers' land and uprooted hundreds of trees by digging up dozens of acres of land planted with orange and olive trees."

Security sources also said that "the Israeli army opened heavy machine gun fire from tanks in the al-Mantar area (Carni) in the direction of Palestinian security forces to the east of Gaza city which was hit."
He did not say whether there had been any victims.

In addition, a Palestinian security official also said that the Israeli army closed the al-Mawasi area near the Nave Dighalem settlement to the west of Khan Younis without giving any reason for this and stopped citizens from leaving or entering this area."

hl.seg: Workers at Moulinex-Brandt threaten to blow up factory in France

p.seg: Cormel Le Royale (France) 11-12 (AFP) - A group of workers at French-Italian company, Moulinex-Brandt, threatened today, after smuggling in explosives, to blow up the factory at Cormel Le Royale (western France) if they do not receive financial compensation for their termination.
Workers wrote the slogan "give us money or its 'boom!'" on the walls of the factory in Cormel, located in the suburbs of Cannes near a residential area and a chemical factory.
A worker, who wished to remain anonymous, told France Presse: "We have put sulfuric acid, acetylene, gas and fuel in several strategic points and will explode these if we do not get compensation."
He added: "We are ready to explode a ton of acetylene which we have put inside the machines."
Hundreds of workers gathered this morning in front of the site they have been occupying since early September.

Around 1000 employees are likely to be laid off from this factory which is to close after the electrical domestic appliance company Seb decided on a partial takeover of its competitor Moulinex, including the French-Italian company Moulinex-Brandt which is currently undergoing judicial investigation.

About 150 workers at a textile factory in eastern France, who had threatened to blow up the factory they were occupying in July 2000, agreed to a severance package prepared by their representatives and local authorities.

hl.seg: Putin: "Terrorists are attempting to acquire weapons of mass destruction"

p.seg: Moscow 11-12 (AFP) - Russian President Vladimir Putin said today that the "aim of terrorists is to acquire weapons of mass destruction," making international military cooperation a necessity.
According to Itar-Tass news agency, Putin went on to say that "an analysis of the situation reveals that we have identified the nature of new threats correctly.
Terrorism threatens the strategic balance system.
We must realize that the principal aim of terrorists is to acquire weapons of mass destruction."
Putin added that this is a "worrying situation," pointing out that "biological terrorism is now a reality."

He continued: "All this necessitates a new framework for defense priorities including military and technical cooperation on an international level" with members of the anti-terrorism coalition "as well as other countries."
He added, according to Interfax reports, that Russia's role in Chechnya is "correct, appropriate and just," pointing out that Russia "faces well-trained terrorist groups in Chechnya."
Putin made these statements to Russian military commanders prior to his visit to the United States to attend a summit meeting with his American counterpart, George Bush.

hl.seg: 260 people onboard Airbus according to new American Airlines figures

p.seg: Washington 11-12 (AFP) - American Airlines announced today that

260 people, including 251 passengers and 9 crew members (and not 255 as announced previously), were onboard the Airbus which crashed after taking off from John Kennedy Airport in New York this morning.
The company explained its revision of the number of victims after it noticed that five children traveling with their parents had not been included in the first estimate.
In a short statement, American Airlines also said it would issue a passenger list once all the victims' families had been informed.
The plane, an Airbus A300, was flying from New York to Santo Domingo (Dominican Republic).

hl.seg: Nelson Mandela lends unconditional support to war against terrorism

p.seg: Washington 11-12 (AFP) - Former South African President Nelson Mandela today lent his unconditional support for the American military campaign in Afghanistan following the September 11 attacks, saying that it should be continued until the culprits responsible for these acts are caught.
Mandela said: "It will be disastrous if the president [Bush] gives in to those who call for military withdrawal before the terrorists are caught [...]
as this will allow them to claim they have defeated the United States and continue their acts."
Mandela, along with American President George Bush, was speaking to journalists after their meeting in the White House.
He further said that Bush was justified in wanting "to impose severe punishment on both the organizers and perpetrators of these attacks who are still alive."
President Bush thanked Mandela for his support, saying the he "has no qualms" with regard to his determination to punish the terrorists.
The two men also expressed their sympathy to the families of the victims of the air disaster which took place over New York this morning, as well as to all New Yorkers.

An American Airlines Airbus A300 crashed shortly after take-off from John F. Kennedy airport, over the residential neighborhood of Queens in New York, killing all 255 people on board and possibly six people on land.

hl.seg: To the participants

p.seg: Nicosia 11-12 (AFP) - Further expected topics include:
United States/attack/Brazil
Fos de Ejuaso (Brazil)

Around forty thousand people demonstrated on Sunday in the town of Fos de Ejuaso on the border between Brazil, Argentina and Paraguay, which the United States regards as a stronghold of Islamic extremists, and chanted "no to terrorism, yes to peace," said a France Presse reporter.
About 12h30 GMT
United States/attack/Bin Laden
Paris

A book, "Bin Laden: The Forbidden Truth" published in France on Wednesday, states that the first international arrest warrant against Osama Bin Laden was issued in March 1998, not by the United States which accused Bin Laden of planning the first attack on the World Trade center five years ago, but by Libya, under the leadership of Colonel Muammar Gaddafi, which Washington regards as a "terrorist state."
About GMT 13h30.

hl.seg: White House: contact with Airbus plane was normal and no threat was recorded before it crashed

p.seg: Washington 11-12 (AFP) - The White House announced that all communications with crew members on board the American Airlines' Airbus A300, which crashed in New York today, were normal and that no threat was received before it crashed.

White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said that "all contact (with the plane) was normal prior to the incident" but that the authorities are not excluding any possibility concerning the reasons for the disaster.
He said: "At this stage, we are not excluding any hypothesis nor are we endorsing a particular one, but the investigation has been handed over to the National Transportation Safety Board."
When asked whether the government had received a "credible" threat, Fleischer said it had not.
He also denied that Federal authorities had said that an explosion had happened on the plane which was flying from New York to Santo Domingo.
The Airbus exploded shortly after take-off over the Queens residential neighborhood, about 80 kilometers from John F. Kennedy Airport.
The plane was carrying 246 passengers and 9 crew members.

Fleischer added that President George Bush had been informed of the disaster at 09h25 local time (GMT 14h25), a few minutes after it happened, and that he contacted New York's mayor Rudolph Giuliani and NY state governor George Pataki by telephone to offer his deep sympathy for the residents of New York "who lately have suffered excessively."
He promised them both maximum cooperation from Federal powers.

hl.seg: Chief prosecutor issues order against Milosevic regarding Bosnia

p.seg: The Hague 11-12 (AFP) - Carla del Ponti, the Chief Prosecutor with the War Crimes Tribunal, issued a new charge against former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic for his role in the war in Bosnia, said her spokesperson.
The validity of the accusations requires the approval of the court judge who needs time to look into the large number of documents sent to him by the Chief Prosecutor in support of her decision.
Spokesperson Florence Hartman told France Presse that "the judges will examine 15 files to ascertain the credibility of the accusation."
This means Milosevic will face three principal accusations linked to the three major disputes that tore apart Yugoslavia (Kosovo, Croatia and Bosnia).
In principle, the trial is set to start on February 12.
In Sarajevo, Bariz Balkiz, the Muslim member of the Bosnian Tripartite Presidency, today expressed his satisfaction with del Ponti's decision.
He told France Presse that this is "a question of justice and will enhance faith in the court."

hl.seg: Indian nuclear stockpile "safe"

p.seg: New Delhi 11-12 (AFP) - The engineer in charge of India's ballistic missile program ended his tenure today saying that New Delhi has safer nuclear weapons standards than any other country. He further stated that the Indian nuclear stockpile included a hydrogen bomb.
In a farewell meeting with military scientists, 70-year-old Abdulsalaam said India's nuclear capabilities are "safe."

These declarations come at a time when the western press has been expressing its concern about the safety of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal. Pakistan, India's neighbor and adversary, has joined the United States' war against terrorism, especially in Afghanistan.
India and Pakistan carried out a series of nuclear tests in May 1998.
Abdulsalam revealed that India had tested a nuclear thermal bomb and tactical nuclear weapons.

He said that scientists and military officials who watched the experiment in 1998 "all expressed their satisfaction with the results," adding that "we certainly have better, safer bases than many others (countries)
and these bases are perfectly safe."

hl.seg: Anan stresses need to move quickly on Afghanistan

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-12 (AFP) - The United Nations' secretary-general today stressed the "need to move quickly" on both the political and humanitarian fronts in Afghanistan at a time when Afghan opposition forces were on the doorstep of Kabul.

Anan told journalists at the close of a conference with the United States Secretary of State and the foreign ministers of Russia and the six countries neighboring Afghanistan that "the group recognizes the need to move quickly."
He added: "At a time when events are escalating, it is important to work to harmonize political aspects with military developments on the ground."

He also said "progress" had been made in talks with all sides in Afghanistan to form a coalition government and said that his personal representative in Afghanistan, al-Akhthar al-Ibrahimi, would speed up efforts to form a post-Taliban government.

For his part, al-Ibrahimi admitted that the United Nations is not the one with control in the field as the Northern Alliance is moving toward Kabul today after achieving significant victories in northern Afghanistan over the past few days.

hl.seg: Taliban take eight hostages from Shelter Now with them

p.seg: (repeat with date correction)

Islamabad 11-13 (AFP) - The Taliban took eight hostages, who have been held in Kabul since August accused of disseminating Christianity, to their stronghold in Kandahar (southeastern Afghanistan), said the father of one of the hostages today.

After meeting with Taliban officials at the Afghan Embassy in Islamabad, John Mercer, the father of American Heather Mercer, said: "I was informed by an unofficial source that the eight hostages are in good health and have been taken to Kandahar."
The eight Shelter Now workers - four Germans, two Americans and two Australians - were accused of disseminating Christianity, with their trial officially taking place in Kabul.

hl.seg: European delegate at Doha conference: "We will enter a crisis phase"

p.seg: Doha 11-13 (AFP) - A European delegate to the fourth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organization said that the European Union was very angry that the final proposal for the Ministerial announcement did not involve progress the Union was aiming for in several areas, which suggested that the WTO was entering a "crisis phase."

The delegate told France Presse today that "we are angry because we are very far from" the points the European Union hoped to bring up in the closing statement aimed at initiating a new round of multilateral trade talks.
He added that "we are about to enter a crisis phase" whereas European ministers are negotiating with European Trade Commissioner, Pascal Lamay, regarding the version proposed by the WTO presidency.
The delegate stressed that the Europeans are "angry on all fronts and especially in the area of agriculture," saying that the proposed version is "very short-sighted."

He added that the proposed text concerning the environment includes a "limited version" of European demands, but in terms of competition and investment, it "takes several steps back compared to the previous version."

hl.seg: Palestinian woman shot dead in West Bank

p.seg: Nablus (West Bank) 11-13 (AFP) - A Palestinian woman was shot dead by Israeli soldiers on Tuesday in Tulkram (West Bank) during a shootout between Israeli soldiers and armed Palestinians, said Palestinian medical sources.
The sources said that 30-year-old Wafa Nasif was killed after being shot in the chest while in her home.
This brings the number of people killed since the Intifada began in September 2000 to 970, including 750 Palestinians and 189 Israelis.
Israeli forces have been occupying sections of Tulkram and Jenin, two towns in northern West Bank under Palestinian self-rule, since October 18.

The Israeli army initiated a large-scale land maneuver on October 18 to re-occupy sections of six large Palestinian towns under Palestinian control after the assassination in Jerusalem of Israel's Tourism Minister, Rehavam Zeevi, responsibility for which was claimed by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

hl.seg: American nuclear stockpile to be reduced to about 2200 nuclear warheads in 10 years

p.seg: Washington 11-13 (AFP) - American President George Bush said in a joint press conference with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, that the United States is to reduce its strategic stockpile to between 1700 and 2200 warheads in the next 10 years.

Bush said: "I have informed President Putin that the United States will reduce the current number of nuclear warheads in operation to between 1700 and 2200 warheads in the next decade, a level perfectly in keeping with American security needs."
This decision goes beyond the stated American agreement set out in the Start 2 treaty to reduce the number of nuclear warheads to 3500 by the year 2007.
This reduction corresponds to two-thirds of the United States' current stockpile of 7000 nuclear weapons.

hl.seg: Russian leader wants "cordial" relations with Congress

p.seg: Washington 11-14 (AFP) - yesterday Congressional leaders gave a warm welcome to Russian President Vladimir Putin, who expressed his desire for "cordial and fruitful relations."

In a working meeting, the Russian President, who is on an official 3-day visit to the United States, said "we very much value the role played" by the American Congress, expressing his hope for "cordial and productive relations" with Congress, which is usually cautious with regard to Russia.
He was met by Republican and Democratic leaders from Congress and the Senate.
The Democratic leader of the Senate, Thomas Daschle, who is small in stature, said: "I am happy to meet a president who is short like me."
Putin gave a small smile.
The senator further expressed the "United States' gratitude for the support it has received from Russia in difficult recent weeks for our efforts in Afghanistan."
For his part, the Republican leader of Congress, Dennis Hastert, welcomed the Russian president to the "people's house" as Americans call Congress.

In a letter to President Bush published yesterday, nine members of the Senate called on the American President to discount the possibility of any settlement with Russia with regard to the ABM 1972 anti-missile treaty, demanding the United States withdraw from the agreement.

hl.seg: Israeli army withdraws from Dir Albalh in southern Gaza Strip

p.seg: Gaza 11-13 (AFP) - Palestinian eye witnesses reported today that the Israeli army had withdrawn from areas under Palestinian control in Dir Albalh in southern Gaza Strip. A security source also said a Palestinian had been shot by the Israeli army.

Eyewitnesses told France Presse: "Israeli army forces withdrew from Palestinian land in Dir Albalh after Israeli army tanks and bulldozers entered the area and stayed for over 5 hours, during which time they dug up farming land and searched residents' homes in the area."

A Palestinian security source told France Presse that an "army bulldozer accompanied by several Israeli tanks penetrated over 500 meters and dug up residents' land in Dir Albalh in southern Gaza Strip and is still continuing to dig up land."

The source said: "They came in after a big explosion this morning on the road leading to the Kufur Drum settlement near Wadi Salqa in southern Gaza Strip. The army then closed the Abu Alajin road which connects southern Gaza Strip with the north."

In addition, the same source said that the "Israeli army present on the outskirts of the Gosh Katif settlement in southern Gaza Strip opened fire this morning on an 18-year-old Palestinian youth, Jihad Mukhaimar abu Sabha, who was near the area separating the settlement and Khan Younis refugee camp. His condition is said to be critical."

hl.seg: Man arrested in London in connection with September 11 attacks

p.seg: London 11-14 (AFP) - Scotland Yard announced today that it is questioning a man arrested in London this morning as part of the campaign against terrorism following a request made by the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (F.B.I.) in connection with a matter related to the September 11 attacks in the United States.
A Scotland Yard spokesman said that officers from the Anti-Terrorism Branch arrested a 30-year-old British man in a house in southwest London at about 10h00 (GMT).
France Presse asked the spokesman whether the detained man was being questioned in connection with the September 11 attacks, to which the spokesman replied, "Yes, that's right."
The police had previously refused to confirm this information.
The suspect will be questioned in a police station in central London.
An F.B.I. spokesman made a request "a few days ago."
Current anti-terrorism laws allow suspects to be detained without being officially charged for a maximum period of 7 days.
The law is expected to be changed by mid-December to allow any person suspected of supporting or being involved in terrorist acts abroad to be detained for an indefinite period.

hl.seg: Kuwait objects to reducing OPEC production without Russia's participation

p.seg: Vienna 11-14 (AFP) - Kuwait's Minister of Oil Adel al-Subaih stated today that he is against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) reducing production if Russia does not agree to the organization's efforts to improve oil prices.
The minister told journalists that he "will not support" reducing production if Russia does not make an effort compatible with its production capacity.
Russia announced on Monday that it would reduce its production by about thirty thousand barrels per day from seven million bpd which OPEC found disappointing.

Until now, Iran was the only country among OPEC's eleven members that had refused to reduce its production if the main non-OPEC oil producing countries, such as Russia, Norway and Mexico, did not cooperate with the organization to cut production.

hl.seg: 7 Palestinians injured in Israeli shelling of Khan Younis refugee camp in southern Gaza Strip

p.seg: Gaza 11-14 (AFP) - A Palestinian security source said today that the Israeli army had shelled the Khan Younis refugee camp after midnight last night, using tanks and heavy artillery. This resulted in seven Palestinians suffering various injuries and a number of houses being damaged.

The same source told France Presse: "After midnight last night, the Israeli army from the periphery of the settlement of Neveh Dekalim shelled the Khan Younis Palestinian refugee camp in southern Gaza Strip after the Israeli army claimed a mortar shell had been fired at them. Khan Younis was shelled by artillery and heavy arms and this resulted in 7 Palestinians suffering various injuries."
He denied Israel's statement that a mortar shell was fired at the Israeli position.
An Israeli spokesman announced earlier today that an Israeli soldier suffered minor injuries on Tuesday evening after a mortar shell fired by Palestinians in southern Gaza Strip exploded.
He said Israeli soldiers responded with light arms fire.

hl.seg: OPEC no longer able to control oil market alone (Kuwaiti minister)

p.seg: Vienna 11-14 (AFP) - Kuwaiti oil minister Adel Khalid al-Subaih said that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) can no longer control the market at a time when OPEC refuses to act alone in lowering production in order to raise prices.
The minister made his statement before the organization's official meeting began in Vienna saying: "OPEC can no longer control the market alone."

Ministers of the organization's member states decided to lower production by 1.5m barrels per day provided that other producing countries, such as Russia, cooperate with OPEC to prevent a fall in price.
Oil prices have fallen by 25% since the September 11 attacks.

For his part, the Emirate minister, Ubaid Bin Sayf al-Nasiri, said on Wednesday that "an agreement has been reached within OPEC to reduce production by 1.5m barrels per day if other non-OPEC producing countries agree to cooperate."
According to OPEC's news agency, the organization's members hope that their competitors will simultaneously reduce production by 500 thousand barrels a day.

OPEC, whose members produce 40% of the world's petroleum, fears it could lose its share of the market if it holds back its oil without being able to increase crude oil prices, currently around $20 a barrel.

hl.seg: Israeli security cabinet meets (Israeli radio)

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-14 (AFP) - Israeli radio reported today that Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon met this morning with the security cabinet to discuss the situation in the Palestinian territories.
It did not give any details about the meeting.

Israel's security cabinet met last October 18, after the assassination of Israeli Tourism Minister, Rehavam Zeevi, and gave the green light for the army to carry out a large-scale ground operation in the West Bank, which resulted in partial occupation of six Palestinian towns under Palestinian authority.
The towns of Tulkarm and Jenin are still under partial Israeli occupation in spite of international intervention.
Soldiers are still blockading the town of Nablus.
An Israeli police spokesman told France Presse that a big explosion occurred in the morning in one of the quarters of West Jerusalem but that no one was hurt.
He said the bomb was hidden in a trash can in the neighborhood of Hey Karyat Youvil in West Jerusalem.

hl.seg: September 11 attacks: Justice Department searches for 5000 people

p.seg: Washington 11-14 (AFP) - The American State Department announced today that it is looking for 5000 people legally present in the United States who may have information about the September 11 attacks.

It said in a statement: "We have published a list of people who entered the country with non-immigrant entry visas who may be able to help us investigate the September 11 attacks and prevent other attacks from taking place."
None of these people have yet been questioned by Federal police.
The statement further said: "We have selected these people for questioning because they match the profile of people who might know terrorists abroad."
The State Department stressed that they had not been selected because of their ethnic origin or religious beliefs.
The American press said they were of Middle Eastern decent.
The Council on American-Muslim Relations complained about the authorities' intention to question 5000 people as part of the investigation.
It said that this could "give rise to the sentiment that they were chosen because of their native and religious origin."

hl.seg: Security not completely restored in Jalalabad (Afghan commander)

p.seg: Peshawar (Pakistan) 11-15 (AFP) - Security has not yet been completely restored in the Jalalabad province in western Afghanistan, a region which local officials say was gained back from the Taliban, according to a statement today by an Afghan commander in Peshawar (northwestern Pakistan) before he left for the area.
Pashtun commander Alhaj Zaman Ghamshriq told France Presse that "according to some sources, there are still some Arab fighters hiding in the area around Jalalabad."
He said the road between the Torkom center, on the Afghan-Pakistan border, and Jalalabad "is under Mujahideen control but is not completely secure."
Commander Zaman set out for Jalalabad at the head of convoy comprising 2000 to 4000 men.
He said that the "first step" for him, before starting to consider negotiations with the Northern Alliance, was to reach Jalalabad.

hl.seg: Canada announces readiness to send 1000 additional men to Afghanistan

p.seg: Ottawa 11-15 (AFP) - In a statement today, the Canadian government announced that it is prepared to send an additional one thousand men within 48 hours to join the multinational force in Afghanistan.
Canada's Defense Minister, Art Eggleton, said in the statement: "the proposed operations will help establish short-term stability in some areas and assist the supply of humanitarian aid."
He added that the long-term aim of this is to allow "an international peace-keeping force to be established to help create stability and restore civilian life."
The Princess Patricia 3rd Infantry Division, based in Edmonton (Alberta, western Canada), has received orders to be ready for deployment within 48 hours.

Prime Minister Jean Chretien said in the statement that "the countries taking part in the campaign have clearly shown their desire to provide the Afghan people with a safe environment as quickly as possible
and Canada is standing by its obligation."

Canada had previously announced in October that it would take part in the anti-terrorism military campaign led by the United States by sending 6 military units, 6 transport or surveillance planes and two thousand soldiers currently deployed in the region.
According to the defense minister, the Canadian force may be given the task of supplying equipment, transporting soldiers and airborne medical evacuation.

hl.seg: Peres: many Israelis want a Palestinian state

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-15 (AFP) - Israel's Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that many Israelis want a Palestinian state and that this is the only solution for peace to be established.
Peres told journalists who questioned him about his statements supporting a Palestinian state: "This is my personal position.
I also believe it is the position of many Israelis."

Peres said in a speech to the United Nations' General Assembly: "There is now a consensus that setting up an independent Palestinian state, free of weapons and able to survive economically, is the best alternative," adding that such a state "will also bring real security."
These statements coincide with the 13th anniversary of the Palestinian National Council's declaration in Algiers of the creation of a Palestinian state.
Peres said the question of a Palestinian state "is not yet a formal policy of the government which is why I haven't taken an official position."
He said: "However, I can't see any other solution, whether for Palestinians, for us, or for peace in the future.
I joined this government with my views widely known."
He added: "I am such a faithful husband that I don't want to divorce my ideas."

hl.seg: Jordan ready to send troops to Afghanistan

p.seg: Amman 11-15 (AFP) - A Jordanian official told France Presse today that Jordan is ready to send troops to Afghanistan in the near future as part of a United Nations force on a humanitarian mission.

The same official, who wished to remain anonymous, said: "Jordan has given its agreement to the United Nations that it will shortly be sending troops to Afghanistan in addition to medical and food supplies."
He stressed that the "role of Jordanian troops will be in the form of humanitarian rather than military involvement."
The same official said that the departure date for the troops would be "decided by the United Nations but is expected to happen soon."
He added that "field hospitals and ambulances, as well as doctors, will accompany these troops" as part of a peacekeeping force in Afghanistan.
He also said: "The principal task of Jordanian troops is to protect hospitals and civilians and to help distribute food."
Jordan has taken part in many United Nations peacekeeping missions in several regions including the Balkans, Sierra Leone, East Timor and the Ethiopian-Eritrean border.

hl.seg: Red Cross: Afghanistan facing critical phase in humanitarian terms

p.seg: Geneva 11-15 (AFP) - Afghanistan is currently facing a "critical situation" in humanitarian terms says the International Red Cross Committee whose employees are slowly returning to the country.
Jean Michel Mono, the Committee's representative for Asian Affairs, said in a press conference: "We are now at a critical phase in humanitarian terms."
He added: "I am not talking about the food situation. I am referring to the need, inside Afghanistan, to protect families not involved in the fighting and prisoners of war."
The committee also expressed its concern about reports of the execution of prisoners and "wounded fighters no longer involved in the fighting."

Five committee members have returned to Afghanistan in recent days and are attempting to establish "a frank and direct dialogue" with the parties in dispute about their compliance with international laws on prisoners of war.
Mono praised Afghan humanitarian aid workers for continuing their work, which has prevented a humanitarian disaster from happening, with the very minimum of outside help.
He said: "We have ample reason to believe that the real crisis is in the villages rather than in the towns."

hl.seg: 81 Lebanese refugees return from Israel (with photo)

p.seg: Al-Nakura (Lebanon) (AFP) - 81 Lebanese refugees returned to Lebanon today, mainly women and children of the families of militiamen from the former South Lebanon Army who escaped to the Jewish state when it withdrew from southern Lebanon.
They were met by international emergency forces on the Lebanese-Israeli border where around 500 relatives were waiting to greet them.
They were transferred to a Lebanese army center where they were searched and questioned.
The women and children were released, as is customary, while the men were taken away for investigation, said a France Presse reporter.
64 Lebanese citizens, mainly women and children, also returned under similar circumstances last Tuesday.

Six thousand Lebanese citizens, most of whom are militiamen belonging to the former South Lebanon Army and their families, fled to Israel when it withdrew its forces from southern Lebanon in May 2000, fearing reprisals from Lebanon's Shi'a Hizbollah party or being brought to justice by the Lebanese state.
To date, nearly half of them have returned according to France Presse statistics.
An army court issued sentences against approximately three thousand militiamen from the former South Lebanon Army, including 30 default execution sentences.

hl.seg: 30 Countries discuss UN's efforts regarding Afghanistan

p.seg: New York (UN)16-11 (FP)- Representatives from 30 countries engaged in the war in Afghanistan held a meeting at the UN's headquarters in New York on Friday, seeking to promote the international organization's efforts to form a multi-ethnic Afghan government.

The UN's Special Representative for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, will also participate in the meeting, held for the first time in three years, of the group of 21 with other countries and organizations.

UN spokeswoman, Mary Okaby, said that the goal is "to get as many countries as possible to support Brahimi's efforts in forming a broad-based government in the Afghan capital of Kabul, which the armed opposition, the Northern Alliance, took over earlier.

The Northern Alliance, which includes several ethnic minorities and is dominated by the Tajiks, took control over the capital. The international group, however, wants to establish a transitional administration where all ethnic groups, especially the majority, are represented.

Brahimi seeks to achieve this goal by calling for an international conference involving all Afghan factions as soon as possible; but he hasn't been able to announce an exact date or place for the meeting.

The group of 21 includes countries bordering Afghanistan, as well as the five permanent security council members (China, the US, France, Britain, and Russia) and other countries like Egypt, India, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, and Turkey.
Other countries joined the group today as well, amongst which are Argentina, Canada and Belgium, and organizations such as the Organization of Islamic Conference and the European Commission.

hl.seg: Progress in the fight against financing of terrorism

p.seg: Ottawa 17-11 (FP)- The Canadian Secretary of Economy and Finance, Laurent Fabius, announced Friday in the Canadian capital that the effort being made to combat the financing of terrorism "is making great progress". It will be a prominent subject of the finance related meetings that will be held at the end of this week in Ottawa ...

"Things are making great progress" Fabius said before heading to a dinner with delegates of the group of 20 (G-20). G-20 is an unofficial group that includes the biggest industrial countries as well as the most important developing countries.
The French minister will make a presentation about the financing of terrorism before his G-20 colleagues and the central bank governors.

The numbers published by the US's Treasury Department on Wednesday denote that 56 million dollars, which are suspected of being related to the Taliban movement and al-Qaeda terrorist network, have been frozen so far.

The G-20 comprises -85% of world's GDP- the seven major industrial countries (United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, UK and Canada), as well as Russia, Argentina, Australia, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea and Turkey.
The group also includes the members of two organizations: the European Union and the IMF/World Bank.

hl.seg: Palestinian refugees in Lebanon commemorate Palestinian independence

p.seg: Ayn Elhelwa (Lebanon) 16-11 (FP)- Thousands of Palestinian refugees demonstrated Friday inside the Ayn Elhelwa camp near Sidon, the largest city in South Lebanon, to mark the anniversary of the declaration of the Palestinian independence.

The demonstrators took to the streets and gathered in front of Fatah movement headquarters - a political and military organization of Arab Palestinians led by Yasser Arafat- and traversed the camp's internal streets raising banners that say "Independence means Palestine and a Passport", "Jerusalem is Palestine's Capital" and "We are going back".
The demonstrators waved the Palestinian flag and shouted slogans in support of the Palestinian uprising (the Intifada)

The Palestinian Armed Resistance of the PLO called for the demonstration. This group includes the biggest Palestinian faction, the "Fatah" movement, and both Popular and Democratic Palestinian Liberation Fronts. Many fighters participated in the demonstration wearing their military uniforms and carrying their weapons.

The Palestinians celebrated the 13th anniversary of the declaration of the Palestinian state by the Palestinian National Council (PLO's parliament in exile), which took place in Alger in 1988. The West did not recognize the declared state until the 15th of November.

hl.seg: French troops arrive in Mazar-e Sharifon Monday (Ministry of Defense)

p.seg: Paris 17-11 (FP)- French Defense Minister, Alain Richard, announced Saturday that French troops began leaving the Istres base (South East) on Friday and will be deployed Sunday in Mazar-e Sharif (north of Afghanistan).
The unit, which consists of 58 men, will be added on Monday to bring the total number of French forces to 200 or 250 men, the minister told "Europe1" radio station.

Richard explained that the French force will tackle the rehabilitation of Mazar-e Sharif airport. The intention is for the airport to serve as a "logistics base" to ensure safe delivery of all international humanitarian aid coming to the region.
Meanwhile, an American team will be assigned to clear the mines in the area
200 Jordanian soldiers will be in charge of constructing a field hospital.
The French Minister of Defense confirmed that French soldiers can engage in fighting with the Taliban forces if they are attacked.

" As the French president Jacques Chirac announced Friday, additional fighter planes will be sent and will arrive in the region in two weeks "as a protective measure against possible counter attacks by the Taliban". However, he did not specify the type or operation of the aircraft.
The French aircraft participating in the current operations in Afghanistan are reconnaissance aircraft (Mirage IVB)
or electronic interception aircraft (C160 Gabriel).

hl.seg: Berlusconi cleared from all charges in corruption case

p.seg: Rome 17-11 (FP)- The Italian Appellate Court cleared Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of corruption charges brought by prosecutors of the Mondadori publishing house case.
The prosecutors had appealed a verdict, issued in July 2000, clearing Berlusconi of all charges. The court, however, did not change its decision.
Berlusconi and four other defendants including Chizar Priviti, one of Berlusconi's closest assistants, were accused in connection with the manipulation of judges.

Berlusconi in particular was accused of making his holding company Fininvest pay 200,000 euros to judge Fitorio Mita in order to get a verdict in his favor in a case dating back to the early nineties. The case involved the ownership of Mondadori Publishing House.
The appellate court overruled the appeal filed by the other four defendants and said that the trial of these people will proceed before the Milanese court.

hl.seg: Afghanistan's Rabani promises a broad-based government after getting into Kabul

p.seg: Kabul 17-11 (FP)- After entering Kabul today, President Burhanudeen Rabani, who enjoys UN recognition as President of Afghanistan, pledged a broad-based government in Afghanistan as soon as possible.

"We will seek the formation of a broad-based government as soon as possible. It is subject to how serious the Afghan people and the UN are" he said in a press conference he held in the Afghan capital upon his arrival from the North.
He also criticized the UN implicitly saying "If there is a delay caused by the UN, we should not be blamed for it".
President Rabani, who was overthrown and expelled from Kabul by the Taliban in 1996 and who is the only president of Afghanistan with UN approval, said "We will try to form a broad-based government".
We have always supported the holding of a +Loya Jirga+ (Grand council) session to elect the country's leaders".

hl.seg: Kosovo Elections: Polls close in Kosovo

p.seg: Pristina (Yugoslavia) 17-11 (FP)- Polling stations in Kosovo were closed today at 7 p.m. (1800 GMT). About 1.25 million voters were called to vote in the legislative elections that will lead to the formation of the autonomous establishments under supervision of the UN.

"_The final victory will most probably go to the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK) led by the moderate nationalist leader Ibrahim Rugova. The Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK) is expected to outdo the Democratic Party of Kosovo (PDK) and the Alliance for the Future of Kosovo (AAK)at the polls. Both organizations have origins in the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA).
Polling stations were set up in Serbia Proper and Montenegro as well, where about 2000 Serb refugees reside.

The territory of Kosovo, which has been under international administration since the end of the NATO war in June of 1999, will have a house of representatives, a provisional government and a president after the election process is completed.
The election process witnessed no incidents. The OSCE (Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe) estimated the turnout at 1400 GMT around fifty per cent.
The Albanian turnout was remarkable; it recorded around 95 per cent, while the Serb turnout seemed limited despite the call of Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica.
About 13,000 controllers supervised the election process.

hl.seg: Anan: Forming an interim government in Afghanistan is a priority.

p.seg: Ottawa 18-11 (FP) - UN secretary-general Kofi Anan announced Saturday that the priority in Afghanistan is to help the Afghan people form an interim government and to increase humanitarian assistance. Anan's announcement came after a meeting with the Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien.

In a joint press conference with Chretien, Anan outlined the immediate necessity of assisting the Afghan leaders in forming an interim government and in doubling the humanitarian efforts in Afghanistan as winter approaches.
In response to a question about estimating the cost of international operations in Afghanistan, Anan replied "I cannot give an exact figure, but I can say it will be an ongoing effort", .
Canada has sent a large number of vessels, has 1,000 soldiers stationed in the region and 1,000 infantry soldiers to participate in the multinational force in Afghanistan.

hl.seg: Bin Laden left Afghanistan for an undisclosed destination (Al-Jazeera)

p.seg: Doha 17-11 (FP)- Al-Jazeera Satellite Channel based in Qatar reported tonight, quoting Taliban Ambassador in Pakistan, Abdul Salam Dhaeef, that Osama bin Laden, the key suspect in the September 11 attacks has left Pakistan to an undisclosed destination.

Al-Jazeera correspondent in the Pakistani capital, Ahmed Zaidan, said that "Osama bin Laden left Afghanistan with his wife and children for an undisclosed destination" according to Taliban's ambassador.
Meanwhile US Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfield said on Friday that Osama bin Laden is probably still in Afghanistan.
"There are strong reasons to believe that he is still in Afghanistan just like Mullah Omar for sure", he added.

The announcement of Bin Laden's departure followed the Pentagon's announcement of the death of the military commander of the Al-Qaeda Organization, Mohammed Atef, in a bombing by the American military.
Some sources consider Muhammed Atef, who is of Egyptian origin, as the mastermind of the September 11 attacks.
Like Bin Laden, he was accused by the American authorities of being the organizer of the attacks on the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998.

hl.seg: African Champions League: Sundowns in the final

p.seg: Luanda 18-11 (AFP)- The South African team, Sundowns, reached the African football League Championship finals after defeating the Angolan Petro Atletico, winning the penalty shoot out 5-3.

When the match was over Mbiyavanga, from the Angolan team, had scored 2 goals (25,48). Similarly, the Sundowns scored in Pretoria and had a penalty shoot out, which led to the victory of the South African team.
The Sundowns will meet the Egyptian Al Ahly in the finals. Al Ahly qualified at the expense of the Tunisian Al Tarajy (Esperance), the maid of honor of the game in the last two confrontations.
The final will take place on the 8th and 9th of next December in Pretoria and on the 21st, 22nd, and 23rd back in Cairo.

hl.seg: Twenty-four die in a Russian plane crash (Novosti)

p.seg: Moscow 19-11 (FP)- The Russian news agency Ria Novosti, quoting the local police, has confirmed the death of all 24 people aboard the Russian civilian airplane "Ilyushin 18" that crashed Monday near Tver and Laroslava.
Russia's Emergencies Ministry said that the airplane, carrying six crew-members and 18 passengers, vanished from the radar screens at 21:24 hours local time (18:24GMT).
The location of the plane crash was soon identified 20 Kilometers from the city of Kalyazin. Rescue teams are still working at the disaster site.
The "Ilyushin-18" plane was enroute from Khatanga (far north) to Moscow.
The plane had taken off from the town of Khatanga at 13:07 and the pilots did not report any problems during the flight, the ministry said.
"Ilyushin-18" became operational in 1957. It has the capacity of carrying around 100 passengers.
It was used particularly in Russia and former Soviet states for regional flights.
The Aviation Safety Network, an independent group that keeps data on air disasters, said that there have been 79 crashes of both commercial and military Ilyushin-18 airplanes since 1960.

hl.seg: Head of the Federal National Council of UAE urges greater legislative jurisdiction authority

p.seg: Dubai 19-11 (FP)- The head of the Federal National Council in the UAE, Mohammed Khalifa Bin Habtoor, confirms the need to grant this Advisory Body, which includes representatives from the seven emirates of the UAE, greater legislative jurisdiction in proposing bills and code amendments.

In an interview with the Emirati newspaper "Al-Bayan" on Monday, Bin Habtoor stressed the importance of modifying and amending some articles in the constitution that concern the council, including giving the council the right to propose new bills and amendments regarding some current important issues.
He says that such a step "will allow the council to perform its duties efficiently and flexibly, especially when it comes to civil codes."

On the other hand the Head of the Federal National Council said, in an answer to a question about women participating in the council, "assigning women to the council is the responsibility of the governors of the seven emirates." The governors choose their emirate's representatives in the council.
"The constitution does not specify the sex of the representative of the Emirate" he added.

He also emphasized that "Women have always been present in the council's discussions and in issues that concern womenfolk and the community in general because the council has always communicated with women's societies and groups working in this country. Women attend the council's discussions and have their say regarding general issues and bills".
The Federal National Council was formed in 1972. It consists of 40 members representing the seven United Emirates and assigned by the governors of each emirate for a two-year term.

hl.seg: UNICEF confirms abuse of Palestinian youths detained in Israel

p.seg: Paris 19-11 (AFP)- On Monday the representative of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) in the West Bank, Pierre Poupard, condemned the abuse of some 160 youths currently being detained in Israel.

The UNICEF representative in the Occupied Palestinian West Bank and Gaza Strip, Poupard said in a press conference, "160 Palestinians between the ages of 12 and 18 are currently being detained in Israeli prisons charged with throwing stones".

UNICEF quoted the testimony of Sadam Ayad Awad (10 years old), who was arrested by Israeli soldiers on July 10th after a confrontation with several kids, "they hit me with plastic tubes all over my body".
I had to undergo surgery, and a platinum rod was implanted in my arm.
They forced me to take off all my clothes. I spent nights blindfolded with my hands tied.
And they wouldn't let me go to the toilet for two days".
A non-governmental Palestinian organization that defends children's rights and is backed by UNICEF heard the child's testimony after his arrest in Atssioun Center near Bethlehem.

hl.seg: Syrian authorities release 9 political prisoners

p.seg: DAMASCUS 19-11 (AFP)- The president of the Human Rights Advocacy group, Akram Naesa, told AFP news agency on Monday that the Syrian authorities have released nine Members of the banned Communist Labor Party on Sunday night in accordance with a presidential amnesty.

Naesa also said "starting with the release of nine members of the Communist Labor Party as part of a presidential amnesty to commemorate the anniversary of the Corrective Movement" and the 31st anniversary of the late Syrian President Hafez al-Assad's rise to power in Syria.

Naesa declared that some of the prisoners released had been held since 1987 and others were held since 1992; "We have unconfirmed information that other prisoners from the Muslim Brotherhood and the Iraqi Baath party were also expected to be released" he added.
"There are around 1000 to 1200 political prisoners in Syria" said Naesa, president of the Defense Committee for Human Rights in Syria.

The Syrian president Bashar al-Assad who assumed power in July 2000 -succeeding his father President Hafidh Al Assad who died earlier- has pardoned about 600 imprisoned politicians belonging to various political groups.

hl.seg: EMIRATES serves five new destinations next year

p.seg: Dubai 19-11 (AFP) - EMIRATES airways, which is owned by the Dubai government, announced today Monday that it will serve five new destinations starting next year.
With its newly ordered "Boeing" and "Airbus" airplanes valued at

15 billion dollars, the company will start operating flights to Osaka (Japan), Khartoum (Sudan), Casablanca (Morocco), Perth (Australia), and the Mauritius islands in the Indian ocean beginning next year according to the company's report.

The report said that the "Boeing 777" would be operated to serve the route to Osaka and Perth on an average of four non-stop flights a week to each of theses destinations. Meanwhile the "Airbus A-330" would serve the other three destinations on an average of three flights a week as a start.

hl.seg: Emirates tournament: Coach of the Al Shabab team was the first victim

p.seg: Dubai 20-11 (AFP) The Slovak coach of the Al Shabab (Youth) team, Dochan, was the first victim of the Emirate football league after the club's administration decided to dismiss him following the team's second defeat by Al Ain in the second stage.
Al Shabab lost its first two home matches so far, against Al- Jazeera 0-1 and against Alain 1-3 in Al Katara.

The club secretary, Abdul Ghafar, said "the club's administration has decided to temporarily assign the job to the Tunisian coach Waheed Al Hodowassim, who already trains the youth category, till a new coach is recruited to lead the team".

He also added that "the decision to dismiss Dochan, with whom we contracted at the end of last season, was not hasty. It was made after a careful study. It was a must for the sake of the club's welfare".

Duchan, on the other hand was surprised to learn about the decision and said "I did not get a good chance to provide all I have to offer; to get dismissed so quickly is something that has never happened to me during my coaching career".

It is worth noting that Al Shabab had a contract with the international Uzbek Mirdgalal Kasimov before the start of the league, but his team was in last place after the second stage on equal terms with the Union.

hl.seg: Saudi Airlines to operate 205 additional flights during Ramadan pilgrimage season

p.seg: Riyadh 20-11 (AFP) - Saudi Arabian Airlines announced that it will operate 205 additional flights during the month of Ramadan, which started on the 6th of November. The additional flights will be in addition to its regular flights to ensure a smooth pilgrimage season and stable international and internal flights.

The Saudi newspapers quoted the Operations Control Center's General Manager, Hassan bin Ali Nasar, as saying, "The operating of additional flights is to meet the ever growing demand for air travel by pilgrims from all over the world".
He also confirmed that the company is "capable of dealing with the huge increase of pilgrimage passengers since its new fleet consists of the state-of-the-art airplanes of huge capacity".

He also explained that the number of flights is being increased based on "the plans and schedules set to suit the expected number of pilgrims suggested by continuous studies done on air traffic during previous seasons".
The Saudi Arabian Airlines is the largest Commercial Air Transport Company in the Middle East, Africa and South Asia.
Running a state-of-the-art fleet of 126 airplanes, its revenue for the year 1999 were estimated at more than three billion dollars.

hl.seg: 250kg bomb found in a house rented by American news reporters

p.seg: Kabul 20-11 (AFP) - according to UN spokesman's declaration Tuesday, an American TV network team rented a house in Kabul without knowing that a bomb weighing 250kg, dropped by American airplanes one week earlier, is still there and didn't go off.
Eric Falt said the landlord might have felt guilty and asked a UN demining team to check the house, which the news reporters have been renting for two months.

When the demining team arrived, they found that the television crew had settled in and was having tea, unaware of the existence of an unexploded bomb that had destroyed the roof of one of the rooms in the house.
Eric Falt declared that the bomb had buried itself 30 centimeters in the ground.
The house was immediately evacuated in order to dismantle the bomb.
The spokesman said that the UN demining agency in charge planned to deploy 4,500 personnel all over Afghanistan over the next three weeks in search of similar cases.
13 foreign experts arrived in Afghanistan to train workers in this agency on how to identify and dismantle unexploded munitions.

hl.seg: The presidents of Russia and China discuss Afghanistan's situation by telephone

p.seg: Beijing 20-11 (AFP) - The newspaper Daily China reported on Tuesday that the Chinese president Jiang Zemin and the Russian president Vladimir Putin discussed the situation in Afghanistan during a telephone conversation on Monday night.

The newspaper, which issues an English edition, reported that both presidents agreed in their telephone conversation that a "more positive" role is needed from the UN side, in order to solve the problems in the country.

"The coming government in Afghanistan must represent all ethnic groups and factions in that country" Putin told Jiang Zemin, according to the newspaper; the Chinese president expressed his hope that the formation of the interim government will take place as soon as possible.

On the other hand, the new Chinese news agency reported that the Russian president informed his Chinese counterpart about the headlines of his last visit to the United States; the newspaper also reported that Putin initiated the telephone call.

Putin was not successful in reaching agreeable grounds with the American president George Bush regarding "ABM" the antimissile treaty that the American government wants to pass, while Moscow and Beijing object to it.

hl.seg: Paris criticizes the American approach to biological weapons

p.seg: Paris 20-11 (AFP) - Tuesday, France criticized the American approach expressed in Geneva on Monday, regarding the backing of the Biological Weapons Convention saying that it is "not going in the right direction".
Spokesman of French Foreign Ministry, Fran�ois Rivasseau, said "the approach presented by the American delegate, John Bolton, is not our approach".
"We do not consent to the idea that disarming should be acknowledged only by countries found suitable", he continued.

In Geneva on Monday, the United States accused North Korea, Iraq, Iran, Libya, Sudan and Syria of violating the Biological Weapons Convention that the US wants to reinforce according to its terms and not according to what was negotiated six years ago under the supervision of UN.

John Bolton the US Under Secretary of State announced in his address to the 144 BWC's (Biological Weapons Convention) countries that "the United States suspects that Iraq has taken advantage of three years of no UN inspections to improve its offensive BW program".

hl.seg: Afghan Northern Alliance agrees on a conference in Germany (UN)

p.seg: Kabul 20-11 (AFP) - The UN special envoy to Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, announced Tuesday in Kabul that the Northern Alliance has agreed to a conference in Germany, in which all Afghan parties would participate.
Vendrell, who is also the Assistant of the UN special representative for Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi, expressed his hope for the meeting to take place next Monday.

The UN special representative arrived in Kabul on Monday for talks with the Minister of Defense of the Alliance General Mohammed Qasim Fahim, the Foreign Minister Abdullah Abdullah, and the Interior Minister Youssef Qanouny.
Vendrell's spokesman, Eric Falt described the meetings as "friendly".

Vendrell did not reveal the location of the meeting in Germany, but he did announce that the Pashtun - Afghanistan's major ethnic group (about 40% of the population)- and representatives of the former Afghan king Mohammad Zahir -exiled in Italy- would participate.

hl.seg: "Lufthansa" carries out its warning and lays-off between 2,000 and 4,000 employees

p.seg: Frankfurt (Germany) 20-11 (AFP) - Sources close to the German airline company "Lufthansa" told France Press on Tuesday that the company will lay off 2,000 to 4,000 employees to cope with losses resulting from the September 11th attacks.
The company spokesman, Thomas Gashnoy, refused to confirm the number, but he admitted that the company's Board of Directors adopted prompt lay-off procedures today.
These procedures will mostly affect staff members who are still in their probationary period of employment in all departments in the company, he said.
And if that does not achieve the goal, full-time employees will also be included.
Lufthansa has been in talks with unions for several weeks about how to cut costs, but has had negative results.

Lufthansa chief executive Juergen Weber, had warned earlier in November that massive dismissals are not unlikely within the next couple of weeks if no agreement is reached with the unions on cost-cutting.
Lufthansa spokeswoman Christine Ritz also announced that the dismissal "set today by the board" are "not negotiable" with the unions.
"We have to reduce costs to prevent the economical situation (of the company) from getting worse", she said
"It's a must", she added.

hl.seg: US State Department reactivates mail via Diplomatic Pouch

p.seg: Washington 21-11 (AFP)-The US State Department announced Tuesday that Diplomatic Pouch mail will resume following the one-month suspension that was imposed after Anthrax spores were discovered in a number of post offices.

Richard Poucher, the State Department spokesman, said that 37 mailbags containing letters and parcels underwent X-ray treatment to kill any possible anthrax spores. The mail was then sent to 30 US embassies worldwide.
"We started receiving letters delivered by US mail service._
The mail was treated with X-rays, so it could be sorted with no danger" Poucher said.

He also stated that the mail is treated in the sorting center of the State Department in Sterling (Virginia, East) and is still subject to quarantine procedures after one of the employees was infected with the respiratory type of Anthrax.

The infected employee was cured successfully, but his infection led the US Department of State to suspend the Diplomatic Pouch on October 24 and all its postal sorting centers were to undergo treatment.

hl.seg: Special Australian Air force unit heads to Kuwait (Diplomatic source)

p.seg: Kuwait 21-11 (AFP) A diplomatic source in Kuwait revealed that an Australian Air Force special unit of 30 individuals left Australia Wednesday on its way to Kuwait.

A western diplomat, who preferred not to reveal his name, told France Press that "Military troops from the special Air force are expected to arrive (in Kuwait) by the end of the week, paving the way for the rest of the Australian force which is supposed to total 130 soldiers"..
A spokesman of the Kuwaiti Ministry of Defense told France Press that he "has no information".
The western diplomat refused to explain either the presence of Australian military in Kuwait or how long that presence will last.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard confirmed earlier on Wednesday that a unit of 30 soldiers had already left for the Persian Gulf.
The Prime Minister pointed out that the soldiers will participate in the massive manhunt for Osama Bin Laden.

hl.seg: Israeli fire injures 2 Palestinians in Rafah

p.seg: Gaza 21-11 (FP)- Medical sources and witnesses reported that two Palestinians, including a child, were wounded by Israeli army fire in Rafahon Wednesday. No confrontation had taken place.

"An 11-year-old Palestinian child was hit by a live bullet fired by the Israeli occupation forces. The child was injured near his house close to the Mourag Jewish Settlement north east of Rafah" a medical source in Rafah Public Hospital told France Press.

"Another (Palestinian) boy was hit in the shoulder by a bullet fired by the Israeli army in Tel El Sultan region near the Egyptian border with Rafah" same sources reported. The two Palestinians are currently undergoing treatment in Rafah Hospital. Their injuries were described as average.

Meanwhile, witnesses reported that the Israeli army "opened heavy machine gun fire on Palestinian houses near the Kfar Darome Jewish Settlement in Deir el Balah south Gaza Strip "but there were no injuries" witnesses added.
France Press news agency asked the Israeli military spokesman about the incidents but he gave no comment.

hl.seg: Seeking Bin Laden, US Marines inspect vessels departing Pakistan

p.seg: Washington 21-11 (F P)- The Pentagon announced Wednesday that US Marine ships joined the manhunt for Osama Bin Laden and other leaders from the Al-Qaeda Network, taking part in inspecting commercial ships departing Pakistani ports.

Lieutenant Colonel David Lapan, the Pentagon spokesman, clarified the process, which started Tuesday, by saying "We do not stop every single ship, but if we suspect a certain ship of carrying Senior Al Qaeda officials, we have warned that we will stop it and inspect it."

Hundreds of US Commandos deployed throughout the Afghani territories. Checkpoints were installed to stop the wanted Taliban members and Al Qaeda leaders. Meanwhile, air raids are still striking resistance pockets in the Northern Afghani city of Kunduz and Kandahar in the South, Lapan added.

Moreover, two military ships with 2200 Marines on board are still stationed in the Indian Oceanawaiting orders to take part in the campaign to bring in Bin Laden. The US considers Bin Laden the mastermind of September 11's attacks against New York and Washington which took the lives of more than 4200 people.

hl.seg: Zaeef describes the Afghani Powers Conference as "Conspiracy"

p.seg: Doha 22-11 (AFP)- The Taliban's ambassador to Pakistan, Abdul Salam Zaeef told the Al-Jazeera Satellite Channel based in Qatar, in a television interview Wednesday evening that the Taliban will not participate in the Afghani multi-ethnic conference in Bonn on Monday, describing the conference as a "conspiracy".

Answering a question concerning the Taliban's participation in the Afghani factions conference, Zaeef said, "No, we will not take part". "Participants in this conference "are plotting a political conspiracy against Afghanistan" he added.

Spokesman of the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Wednesday night that the Afghani factions conference, at which the future of Afghanistan will be discussed, will be held on Monday near Bonn.
On the other hand, Zaeef said that the Taliban does not know where Osama Bin Laden is. Bin Laden is Washington's key suspect in the September 11th attacks.
"He was in Kabul before it was taken over, after that we do not know if he is still in or out of Afghanistan" he said.
Zaeef was also asked if the Taliban regrets that it did not extradite Bin Laden. He replied "No".
We do not feel regret for not handing Bin Laden over, because we could protect him, and that is what our religion requires from us.

hl.seg: Syrian political prisoner advocate describes a press article as "slander"

p.seg: Damascus 21-11 (APF)- The advocate of Syrian opposition parliament member Maamoun Al Hemsi's, detained since August, described a press article published Wednesday about his client by the Syrian governmental Journal "Tishreen" as "slander"
The advocate Anwar Al Bunni told France Press News Agency that "this is mere slander and will be responded to, vigorously through the press and through a lawsuit".
The article written by Mohamed Abdul Razzak, a member of the political Studies Center in Damascus, alleged that Al Hemsi was a gang leader who practiced car theft and smuggling from Lebanon.
Al Bunni stressed that his client, who was elected a member of parliament in 1994 and 1998, "has a clean judicial record, just as the law requires of a Parliament member".
The advocate added that the parliament member Mamoun Al Hemsi "was tried in the late eighties for stealing cars and was acquitted of all charges".

Al Hemsi, was one of ten opponents arrested in August and September. The group of 10 included the parliament member Riyad Seif, a leader of the opponent Communist Party Riyad Turk and the economist Aref Daleila.
Al Hemsi and Seif pleaded not guilty before the Damascus Criminal Court at the opening session of the trial in late October,.
They are specifically accused of plotting to change the constitution through illegal means and could face life imprisonment
It was decided that the other eight defendants would be tried before Martial Supreme Court. Sentences of this court can not be appealed.

hl.seg: Gaddafi suggests that the Arab fighters in Kunduz be handed over to their home countries

p.seg: Tripoli 21-11 (AFP)- The Libyan news agency reported that the Libyan leader Moamar Gaddafi suggested Wednesday that Arab fighters with the Taliban be returned to their home countries in order to avoid a "massacre" that could take place in Kunduz, north of Afghanistan.

"Keen to avoid a massacre among civilians, the leader of the Libyan Revolution told all parties concerned to deliver a group of Arabs among the besieged fighters to their home countries, where they can be tried. Meanwhile, the rest of the Afghans would be treated as prisoners of war under the supervision and custody of the United Nations" the agency reported.

The Libyan leader "requested that a group of top world leaders who have met before, including former South African president Nelson Mandilla, former US president Jimmy Carter, and former Soviet leader Mikhael Gorbachev, intervene and assist in solving this problem in order to avoid inflicting injury upon civilians, among which are many children, elderly people and women. A massacre is possible if the problem is not settled".
It is worth mentioning that Kunduz is the Taliban's last stronghold in northern Afghanistan, and is being besieged by the north alliance forces and bombed by US air force.
Thousands of Taliban and Arab fighters are defending the city.

hl.seg: Afghanistan reconstruction cost approaches 10 billion USD

p.seg: Washington 21-11 (FP)- Sadako Ogata, the Japanese special representative for assistance in Afghanistan said Wednesday that the cost of reconstructing Afghanistan is tentatively estimated at 10 Billion USD.

While participating in a conference in the US capital of Washington, D.C., organized by Washington and Tokyo to discuss Afghanistan's reconstruction , she said that this estimate seems moderate in comparison to the huge mission. The conference was held with the participation of 22 countries and multinational organizations.
Ogata also mentioned that Japan will host a ministerial session in late January to discuss the reconstruction of Afghanistan.
She hoped that participants would be able to promise financial assistance.
In reply to questions about the cost of reconstruction, she said "some unofficial estimates say it will approach 10 billion USD over the next 10 years".
"This amount does not seem a like lot" she added.
The Japanese representative who has been holding the position of UN's High Commissioner for Refugees stressed that this estimate is still not official.
She also added that the governments should decide what standards will be used in the calculation of reconstruction expenses.

hl.seg: Morocco: New case involves former intelligence member Ahmed Al Bokhari

p.seg: Casablanca 22-11 (APF)-On the 28th of November, former member of Moroccan intelligence Ahmed Al Bokhari will stand before a Casablanca court, accused by 3 former Moroccan intelligence members of revealing their names in Bin Baraka's case, according to what Kareem Al Bokhari (his son) mentioned to France Press.
"My father will stand before court to face a lawsuit raised by Mohamed Al Ashashi, Abdel Kader Sakka and Mohamed Mesnawi for a slander accusation", Kareem said.

Al Bokhari's call to stand before the court comes just 10 days after his release from a 3 - month detention. Al Bokhari was arrested and detained in a Casablanca prison for issuing "uncovered checks".

According to Ahmed Al Bokhari, the Moroccan minister of interior at that time, Mohamed Ofqair and his deputy Ahmed Al Delimi arranged the assassination of the famous Moroccan opponent Al Mahdi Bin Baraka in his villa in a Parisian district.
Bin Baraka's corpse was brought to Morocco, where it was dissolved in an acid barrel.
Al Bokhari expressed his readiness to offer his testimony in France about Bin Baraka's case.
Yet he couldn't comply with the 2 calls by Judge John Baptist Parlo to whom Bin Baraka's case is assigned.
The first time was because his passport was invalid and the second because he was in detention.

hl.seg: Canada detains 32 people representing a threat to National Security (Press)

p.seg: Ottawa 22-11 (AFP)-"Globe and Mile" newspaper reported Tuesday that the Canadian immigration bureaus are detaining 32 people suspected of representing a danger to national security. Most of the detainees have been kept isolated in prison cells since the 11 September attacks.
Nevertheless, the Canadian immigration ministry spokeswoman, Danielle Sarazein said to France Press "that's impossible", providing no clear information.
"Lately, the only case where Canada issued a security certificate to a foreigner representing a threat to the national security was "Hassan Al Maraei's", she clarified.

Al Maraei (27), submitted an application seeking asylum in Canada and has been in prison in Toronto since the 19th of October because the immigration bureau suspected his affiliation to the terrorist Al-Qaeda Network.

The newspaper estimated the number of people detained in Canada as a threat to national security to be 32, indicating that they were detained confidentially. No accusation was made against them and, most probably, they were not offered the services of an attorney.
Sarazein assumed that these uncertain numbers point to other reasons for detention.

She said that the immigration authorities in Canada have no right to imprison people temporarily except for 3 reason: failing to prove identity, being "a threat to the public", and refusing to appear voluntarily before court.

On an annual basis, between 300 and 600 people coming from abroad to Canada pass by a temporary detention center or a prison, awaiting a primary check for asylum application or awaiting verification results for breaching immigration laws.

hl.seg: Ottawa agrees to extradite Yemeni citizen arrested on September 11th

p.seg: Toronto 22-11 (AFP)-The governments attorney announced Thursday that the Canadian Minister of Justice, Anne McKlilan, has approved the extradition of a Yemeni citizen possessing 4 passports, who was stopped in Canada on the 11th of September.
