Najib Abdel Jabbar Mohamed Al Hadi was stopped on the 11th of September upon his arrival in Toronto. He aroused suspicion after he changed the destination of his flight following the attacks in the USA.
The legal documents acknowledged that Hadi was carrying 4 Yemeni passports and 2 uniforms of the German airline, Lufthansa.
He has also used the names Najib Abdou Jaber Mohamed and Mohamed Saleh Naji.
The USA submitted an official request last Friday to have the Yemeni citizen extradited. The text of the request has not yet been made public.
The government's attorney, Bradley Ritz, told the Head of the Supreme Court that the minister agreed on Wednesday to extradite the Yemeni citizen.
The judge specified the 19th and 20th of December to hear both parties in the extradition case.

hl.seg: Hundreds of artists participate in the National Exhibition of Plastic Arts

p.seg: Cairo 22-11 (AFP)-304 Egyptian plastic artists took part in the 27th National Exhibition of Plastic Arts. The exhibition was inaugurated by the Egyptian minister of culture, Farouk Hosni, on Wednesday evening in Kasr Al Fonoun (Palace of Arts) in the Opera House.
The exhibition includes 400 works including drawings, paintings, graphics, photography, sculpture, pottery, assembled works, computer graphics and videos.

The artist Omar Al Najdi, the exhibition's administrator, assured the press that "the current round to coinciding with the month of Ramadan has encouraged us to establish a program that includes cultural and Ramadan evenings in addition to the exhibition events."

General Manager of Art Centers -an organization of Plastic Art Division- Fatma Ismail said, "A special party will be held to honor the creative plastic artist and critic Mahmoud Baksheesh. The event will be attended by the minister of culture, and 11 of Baksheesh's most distinguished works will be displayed".
The exhibition will also honor the following artists: Sobhi Jirjis , Sabri Mansour, Mariam Abdel Aleem and Abdel Hadi Al Weshahi.

hl.seg: No Smoking inside houses
if it affects neighbors

p.seg: Washington 22-11 (AFP)-A district in Maryland State (East) near Washington voted for one of the strictest smoking laws ever. The new law approved severe punishment for people who smoke inside their own houses if their smoke annoys the neighbors.

According to the new law, which has been adopted by the Montgomery district regarding the quality of air inside buildings, the smoke of cigarettes, pipes and cigars is classified in the same category as dangerous products like Amines, radon gas (radiant) and pesticides.

In cases where cigarette smoke leaks into a neighbor's house through a door, window or ventilation system, the neighbor has the right to file a lawsuit before the Environmental Protection Agency in the district.
Therefore, smokers, building supervisors, owners, communities or tenants can face a fine of USD 750 if they do not take suitable measures to ventilate their houses.
Douglas Duncan (democrat), the official in the Montgomery district administration, promised to sign the bill in the following 10 days so it becomes effective.

A member in the district council, who is a democrat as well, said. "This law does not prohibit smoking inside houses, it just states that the smoke should not exceed the range of the house of the smoker".

Washington Post newspaper reported that tobacco companies and several civil associations denounced this law considering it contradictory to individual freedom and targeting, in particular, poor people who live in apartments.

hl.seg: Canada applies new "Public Safety" security measures

p.seg: Ottawa 22-11 (AFP)-The Canadian government presented a bill Thursday to the House of Commons to increase public security to face possible threats following the September 11th attacks.
The new Law would allow new safety measures in the aviation industry.

The bill states, "increasing our potential to provide a quick and effective retaliation against terrorist threats, that might be plotted against Canadian security", according to the announcement made by Canadian minister of Transportation David Collenette.

The minister said that further measures are being discussed and will be adopted. Many of the intended measures require "financial allowances" and will be presented by the Minister of Finance Paul Martin in the framework of the budget draft in December.
The law suggests that security measures be extended beyond the inspections made on arriving and departing passengers to include watchtowers, runways and cockpits.

hl.seg: Khaliji 15: Tournament's referees

p.seg: Riyadh 22-11 (AFP)-The Committee of Referees for the 15th Arab Gulf Football Cup tournament (Khaliji) that will be held in Saudi Arabia from the 16th to the 30th of next January, has declared the names of Arab and foreign referees who will run the matches.

Abdul Rahman Al Dahham, the tournament's assistant director and head of the technical committee, has declared that the committee "discussed many subjects related to the tournament's arbitration and approved 12 international referees from participating countries and nominated 5 international referees, 3 of whom are to be chosen by the International Federation (FIFA)."
The referees will be:
Referees: Youssef Al Akili (Saudi Arabia), Mohamed Salem Mofleh (Qatar), Qassem Hamza (Kuwait) Qassem Mohamed AL Heil (Qatar), Ali Al Sheikh Mansour (Bahrain) and Mozeid Ali Al Marzouki (UAE).
Linesmen: Mohamed Saied Bakheet (Saudi Arabia), Malek Hamad Al Shihy (Oman), Hussein Shaaban (Kuwait), Khamis Bilal (Qatar), Hassan Ali Al Emadi (Bahrain) and Abdullah Saleh (UAE).
The foreign nominated referees: Hugh Dallas (Scotland), Kim Milton (Denmark), Ourus Mayer (Switzerland), Mark Morris (Germany) and Allen Sar (France).

hl.seg: 4 Italian warships cross the Suez Canal..

p.seg: Port Saied (Egypt) 22-11 (AFP)- The Suez Canal authorities reported that 4 Italian warships crossed the Suez Canal Thursday heading to the Indian Ocean in order to join the forces contributing to the military operations in Afghanistan.
The 4 warships are two frigates, "Xavier and Wafeyri", the supply ship"Etna" and the aircraft carrier Garibaldi, which carries 8 helicopters, Harrier "AV-8B plus" planes and 4 "SH-3D" choppers.
An Italian navy unit totaling about 1400 men, under the command of Admiral Morizeo Jaminiani, had left the port of Taranto (in southern Italy) on the 18th of November.
On the other hand, 10 warships (4 Americans and 6 British) also crossed the Suez Canal last Thursday on their way to the Indian Ocean.

hl.seg: Lebanon Championship: Mechantaf first player to pass 3000 point record

p.seg: Beirut 22-11 (AFP)- The leader of the Lebanese national team and Al Hekma Basketball team, Elie Mechantaf, was the first player to break the 3000 point record. Mechantaf who was participating in the Lebanese tournament, left his competitors behind by a great margin. He attained this achievement during the Al Hekma- Antranique match in the sixth round, which resulted in Al Hekma's winning 103-84 on Wednesday.

Mechantaf (31) had scored 2989 points since 1995. With Antranique, he managed to score his 3000th point with a free-throw 3 minutes and 54 seconds before the end of the third quarter and before he wound up the meeting with 20 points, raising his record to 3009.

Mechantaf is ahead by more than 500 points over his closest competitor, the Nigerian Mostafa Abdul Salam of Shanville, and the American Michael Cumberland, who did not sign any contracts this season with any Lebanese teams.
Al Hekma, Lebanon's best reputed basketball team in the past 4 seasons, is in first place this season with 16 points.

hl.seg: Palestine joins executive office of Arab Sport Federation

p.seg: Riyadh 22-11 (AFP)- Prince Sultan bin Fahad, Head of the Arab Sport Federation and Youth Custody director of Saudi Arabia, announced Thursday that Palestine joined the Federation's executive office.

Prince Sultan said that Palestine has joined the Arab Sport Federation and that its executive office and will hold a permanent seat. the prince made the announcement during the 18th session of the executive office.
" Iraq's membership in the associations and executive office will remain frozen since "So far, no suggestions have been presented to unfreeze it."
Prince Sultan also declared Prince Nawaf Bin Faisal a vice president of the executive office.

hl.seg: Tony Blair still misspells "tomorrow" in English

p.seg: London 23-11 (AFP)-Former teacher of British Prime Minister Tony Blair confirmed that he faced difficulties in the past with Blair's misspelling of the word "tomorrow". Blair misspelled the word 3 times recently in handwritten letters.
Ian Robertson, who taught Tony Blair at Fettes School, in Edinburgh (Scotland), told the "BBC" (British Broadcasting Corporation) "I had to tell him a thousand times" how to write the word.
Robertson added that although Blair was a "clever student", the former Oxford University student obviously did not manage to overcome this problem.
Blair sent a Labor Party candidate in the partial legislative elections, organized on Thursday in Ipswich East Britain, a letter of encouragement that included the misspelling of the word "tomorrow".
Blair made the same mistake twice in a letter of encouragement to the Ipswich soccer team, which played last Thursday against Inter Milan in the European Union Cup.
The British opposition and press have abused this gaffe to the maximum.
Governor Damian Green, conservative shadow education secretary said, "As a symbol of promises in education not being matched by performance, this is impossible to beat."

hl.seg: Demonstrations - 4 Palestinians injured in Ramallah

p.seg: Ramallah (West Bank) 23-11 (AFP) Palestinian medical sources reported Friday that 4 Palestinians were hit by rubber bullets while confronting the Israeli army at the northern entrance of Al Beira town. The four were slightly injured.

"Dozens of Palestinians threw stones at the Israeli army units installed at the northern entrance of Al Beira town. The Israeli soldiers fired back at the young Palestinians with gunshots and tear-gas bombs. Some demonstrators suffered inhalation injuries resulting from gas and four of them were injured by rubber bullets", the same sources added.

A Correspondent of France Agency said, "Today, about 1000 Palestinians traveled the streets of Ramallah (north Jerusalem) after Al Dhuhr to pray. Representatives of the Palestinian national and Islamic factions also took part, shouting anti-occupation slogans and raising the Palestinian and organization flags.
The Israeli flag was burned and about 200 people headed to the demarcation line with the Israeli forces.

It should be mentioned that Friday's demonstration in Ramallah is weekly, called for by the coalition of Palestinian national and Islamic powers (13 factions) to protest the occupation and confirm the continuation of the Palestinian People's Uprising (Intifada).

hl.seg: Israel assassinates prominent Hamas military leader

p.seg: Nabulus (West Bank) 23-11 (AFP)- Israel assassinated a prominent military leader of the Palestinian Hamas movement, Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, Friday. The assassination was carried out by an Israeli helicopter raid. According to Abu Hanoud's brother, an official in Hamas, the attack also killed two other Palestinians near Nabulus,.
Abu Hanoud, who was a prominent activist pursued by Israel, died today when Israeli helicopter gunships fired missiles at a car in the village of Yassid near Nabulus north of the West Bank.
Hospital Sources said that three people were dead. Only two of them were identified.
Mostafa Abu Hanoud, Mahmoud's brother and an official from Hamas movement, told the AFP agency that the third body is that of Mahmoud Abu Hanoud.

hl.seg: : Bonn conference: Flying over Petersburg prohibited till December 2nd

p.seg: Offenbach (Germany) 23-11 (AFP)- On Friday, German airspace surveillance authorities announced a ban on flying in Petersburg airspace. The no-fly zone is situated near Bonn (west) where the Afghan factions conference is scheduled to take place next Tuesday.
The ban will be effective from Sunday until the 2nd of December.
No official clarification about the duration of the conference was made. On Friday, the German Foreign Ministry did talk about a "few days".
The United Nations will host the Afghan factional conference "Afghanistan Talks" in Bonn.
The conference is supposed to bring together the four Afghan Ethnic Groups according to Andreas Mikhaelis, the German foreign ministry spokesman.

The spokesman declared that the four factions are: The Northern Alliance, representatives of the former Afghan King Zahir Shah, representatives of "Cyprus process" consisting of the Hazaras of the Islamic leader Qalbuddin Hikmetyar backed by Iran, and the "Peshawar process" led by Pir Syed Hamid Gailani representing the Pashtuns, the biggest ethnic group in Afghanistan, which is backed by Pakistan.

hl.seg: Repeated. Correct the number mentioned in the last paragraph

p.seg: Two Palestinian brothers killed in an Israeli operation Friday night (Palestinian sources)

NABULUS (West Bank) 23-11 (AFP)- According to Palestinian sources, two Palestinian brothers were killed Friday night, when an Israeli helicopter launched five missiles at their cars in the village of Yasid to the north of Nabulus, one of the biggest cities in the west bank.
The sources say that the bodies of both Mamoun and Ayman Hashayka were completely burnt and were taken to a hospital near the city of Jenin.

Palestinian sources said that Ayman Hashayka was Mahmoud Abu Hanoud's companion. Abu Hanoud is an active leader of Hamas, and is accused by the Israelis of being the commander of the military wing of Hamas, confirming rumors of the death of Abu Hanoud in the same operation.

The Hamas movement had declared recently that Hanoud was still a prisoner of the Palestinian Authority and still suffering from an injury caused when Israeli helicopters bombed a police station north of Nabulus where he was detained on the 18th of last July. Eleven Palestinian policemen were killed in the raid.

Mahmoud Abu Hanoud is considered one of the Israeli army's "most wanted" men. He escaped with an injury when Israeli commandos stormed the Assira Shamaliya village late last August in an attempt to capture him. Three Israeli were killed instead.
The killing brings the number of fatalities since the beginning of Intifada in September 2000 to 987; 776 of them were Palestinian and 189 were Israeli.

hl.seg: Straw: Kunduz may suffer a "humanitarian disaster"

p.seg: ISLAMABAD 23-11 (AFP)- ISLAMABAD 23-11 (AFP)- British Foreign Minister Jack Straw warned Friday of a "human disaster" in Kunduz (North East Afghanistan) where the opposition forces are besieging thousands of Taliban members including Afghans and Foreigners.
Straw said Friday in Islamabad that he discussed the issue in his meeting with the Pakistani president Pervez Musharraf and the Foreign Minister Abdul Sattar.
In a joint press conference with his Pakistani counterpart, Straw said, "we discussed a situation that seems very difficult and potentially very serious".
" We all understand the possibility of a human disaster in Kunduz".

The British Minister expressed his concerns about the situation in Kunduz, following a UN announcement citing the deaths of at least 100 young Taliban members after the fall of Mazar-e Sharif in northern Afghanistan on the 9th of November.

The international Red Cross recovered 600 bodies in the town of Mazar-e-Sharif after the Taliban had left the city. The organization failed to confirm information about the circumstances of the deaths.

Straw declared that the situation Kunduz is "grave" and that the British government didn't send any "forces there" to investigate the contradictory information about fleeing Taliban members in the sector of Kunduz.

hl.seg: UN urges Eritrea and Ethiopia to remain calm

p.seg: Addis Ababa 24-11 (AFP)- The UN Special Representative to Ethiopia and Eritrea urged the two nations to remain calm in an effort to resume the peace process that began
on December 12th 2000, according to a UN peacemaking mission's statement received Saturday in Addis Ababa.

The statement reported that the Botswana diplomat Legwaila Joseph Legwaila said Friday in a video conference between the two metropolises of the African Horn "let's remain calm and work to maintain stability and calm in the zone of separation, until the Delimitation Committee finishes its work and announces its decision".
"The committee is based in the Hague and will announce its final statement in three or four months" he added.
The commission in charge of drawing the Borders between Eritrea and Ethiopia started its work last year.

This call, made by the Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary General Kofy Anan, comes following Ethiopian accusations against Eritrea of mobilizing military forces on the border between the two countries.

The UN delegation to Ethiopia and Eritrea, which is in charge of monitoring the cease-fire, denied any mobilization of forces by Eritrea in the zone of separation. The UN delegation confirmed the "absence of information" in this regard.
About 4200 people of the UN's international forces and military controllers are deployed in the zone of separation in southern Eritrea.

hl.seg: New Syrian government is probable soon

p.seg: DAMASCUS 24-11 (AFP)- A Syrian political source announced on Saturday that a new government is likely to be formed soon for the first time since Bashar al-Assad was sworn in as president of Syria in July 2000.

"The issue is definitely being considered" the source told AFP regarding the formation of a new government in Syria, adding "it has been raised within the framework of a process for improving, reviewing and reconsidering the functions of Muhammad Mustafa Miro's government".

Nonetheless, the source did not give a specified date for the awaited changes. He also gave no information about whether it will be a partial ministerial change or whether a completely new cabinet will be formed.

On the other hand an official from one of the seven parties constituent of the National Progressive Front (a coalition lead by the Baath ruling party) told AFP that he "asked the National Progressive Front to support its highly qualified candidates" affirming that "high qualifications are what matter, regardless of the factional identity"
"The government will be a new one even though it is lead by the same prime minister" he added.

The government of Muhammad Mustafa Miro, currently in office, consists of 36 ministers and was formed in March 2000 before the death of the late Syrian president Hafez al-Assad, father of the current president Bashar al-Assad.
Leading Syria out of the economic recession is one of the challenging missions awaiting the new government.

hl.seg: Doha condemns "the brutal Israeli attacks" on Palestinians

p.seg: Doha 24-11 (AFP)- Qatar today condemned "the brutal and inhuman Israeli attacks and practices" against Palestinians. It also condemned the systematic assassination of Palestinian figures and leaders" According to the Qatari news agency.

"Theses attacks and practices are a breach of the Principles of International Law as well as of international legitimacy", said the spokesman of the Qatari Foreign Minister, one day after the assassination of the military leader of the Islamic Resistance Movement (Hamas), Mahmoud Abu Hanoud by Israel.

Such aggressions "threaten the peace and stability in the region and shake the agreed principals of US Foreign Minister (Colin Powell) which aimed at restoring the appropriate climate to resume the peace process in the Middle East and bring it back to its normal course.

Powell had announced on Monday that American envoys were sent to the Middle East, urging Palestinians to stop the violence and the Israelis to stop the construction of settlements in the Palestinian territories.

hl.seg: Pakistani airplanes evacuated Taliban allies (press)

p.seg: NY 24-11 (FP)- The "New York Times" newspaper reported Saturday quoting Afghani opposition sources that Pakistani Air Force aircraft were used to evacuate Pakistanis who fought with Taliban forces in Kondoz (North East).
The Pakistani authorities completely denied the information.
The newspaper quoted the sources as saying that five Pakistani airplanes have landed in Afghanistan in the past few days in order to evacuate the said fighters.
The information came after large numbers of Taliban forces began to surrender in the city of Kondoz, which is under siege by Northern alliance forces.
Probably around two thousand foreign fighters have fought side by side with the fundamental militias; most of them are of Arab, Chechen and Pakistani origins.
A spokesman for the Pakistani government announced that the information reported by the New York Times newspaper :"is completely groundless".
The spokesman said in his statement "We don't even know the people inside Kondoz".

Pakistan asked the international community to guarantee that Afghan and non-Afghan fighters who are going to surrender in Kondoz will be treated according to the international recognition of human rights.

hl.seg: Clashes in Khan Younis, three Palestinians injured

p.seg: Palestinian Medical sources reported that three young Palestinian men were injured Saturday morning when the Israeli army opened fire on them in a confrontation that took place between Palestinian students and the Israeli Army in Khan Younis, south of the Gaza Strip. Meanwhile, there were demonstrations in several locations.

Same sources and eyewitnesses reported that the Israeli army installed around the Ghosh Qateef settlement near a Palestinian Refugees Camp in Khan Younis, south of Gaza Strip opened fire on Palestinian demonstrators. The demonstrators were students protesting the killing of five students in Khan Younis on last Thursday, and also the assassination of Mahmoud Abu Hanoud "Military leader of Hamas Movement in West Bank on Friday". The incident left at least three students injured by Israeli live bullets".
The Gaza Strip witnessed student demonstrations protesting the killing of five students and of Abu Hanoud.
Mosques in the Gaza Strip announced the mourning of Abu Hanoud all over the area.
The Israeli government issued a statement today, in which it claimed responsibility for the killing of Hamas Military leader Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, in the Gaza Strip.

hl.seg: 11 killed, 15 injured in violence in Algeria.

p.seg: Algiers 11-24 (AFP) Newspapers reported on Saturday that 11 people were killed and 15 others were injured on Thursday and Friday in Algeria following attacks believed to have been carried out by extreme armed Islamic groups,

Four people were killed on Thursday evening in Al-Arba' (25 Km south of the capital Algiers) in a trap set by an armed group. The same sources reported that three people were also injured by automatic weapons.
In Sakikdah province (500km east of the capital) three young men were killed when gunmen fired live bullets inside a caf� in Hajra Mafroush district after Iftar (fast breaking).
Several newspapers reported that a soldier was killed and 11 others were injured on Thursday in two attacks carried out in the region of Aein Daflah (160 km west of Algiers).

A individual activist belonging to an extremist group was assassinated on Thursday in Kunar in the Jeijel region (300 KLM east of the capital), A municipality employee was also killed on Thursday in a village near Sayyedi Bilabbas (440 KLM west of Algiers).

A shepherd was found dead on Thursday in Sayyedi Duma near Suaidah (430 KLM south-west of the capital). According to the same sources, a man was seriously wounded when a bomb exploded on Friday in Bani Umran near Bumardas (50 KLM east of the capital),.
An armed Islamic group, led by Antar Zawabri, and the Salafi group for Preaching and Fighting, led by Hassan Hatab, are blamed for the attacks.

hl.seg: Man slain in Kufr Daroum settlement in Gaza is Israeli soldier (Palestinian Security Source).

p.seg: Gaza 11-24 (AFP) A Palestinian Security source told France Press News Agency on Saturday evening that the Israeli Army has informed the Palestinian Authority that a soldier was killed and several people were injured in a bomb attack on Kufr Daroum settlement in the middle of the Gaza Strip.

The source said that the Israeli army retaliated by bombing the Palestinian Deir al-Balh district near the settlement, using tanks and heavy artillery. Illuminating bombs were fired over the district as well.
No immediate reports were available about Palestinian casualties.

Israeli public Radio confirmed the death of an Israeli and two other casualties caused by one or two mortar bombs that hit the settlement of Kufr Daroum. The radio report did not specify whether the casualties were civilians or military personnel.
With the killing of an Israeli, the number of people killed since the beginning of the Palestinian Intifada (uprising) on Sep 28th went up to 990, including 778 Palestinians and 190, Israelis.

hl.seg: US sponsored Israeli-Palestinian Security meeting (Israel)

p.seg: Jerusalem 11-25 (AFP) - An Israeli official told France Press News Agency that the Israeli - Palestinian Supreme Security Committee, which includes security officials from both sides, will hold a meeting Sunday evening.
A Ministry of Defense official, who preferred not to reveal his identity, said, "this meeting was held at the request of the U.S., on the eve of the American envoys' tour in the region."
The ministry official stated that CIA officials and high-ranking officers from the Israeli Interior Security System, "Shein Beit," will participate in the meeting.
The official did not mention whether a statement would be issued at the end of the meeting.
When questioned by France Press News Agency, Palestinian officials could not confirm the meeting.
The Security Committee meeting was held on the 29th of October, but no settlement was reached.

The American Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern Affairs, William Burns, and General Anthony Zeni, the former Commander of US forces in the Middle East, are expected to arrive in the region on Monday. The two men will attempt to reach a cease-fire agreement and encourage the resumption of Israeli - Palestinian peace talks.

hl.seg: Urgent: President Rabani provides guarantees to foreign fighters

p.seg: Kabul 11-24 (AFP) - In a press conference held in Kabul today, the Afghan President Burhanuddin Rabbani, vowed to guarantee the safety of foreign members of the Taliban. He confirmed that he instructed field units of the Northern Alliance to maintain the safety of said fighters and give them fair treatment.
He said, we "support forgiveness" denouncing press reports of massacres of Pakistani and Arab Taliban members.
He clarified that Afghan Taliban members will not be treated as POWs, but will be allowed to go back to their homes after being interrogated.
He added, "People fear that we will kill the foreign Taliban fighters".
"This is not true. The fate of these fighters is being discussed with the representative of United Nations, Franscisco Fandril" he added.
In a bid to relieve the International community's fears, Mr. Rabbani repeatedly said "The Taliban and its allies are criminals" but, he stressed "We will not punish them".
They will be "our guests" after their surrender and disarmament, he confirmed.

hl.seg: Spanish customs officials seize two tons of cocaine in the Atlantic.

p.seg: Madrid, 11-25 (AFP) - A Spanish Ministry of Finance official said on Sunday that Spanish customs had seized two tons of cocaine yesterday on board a fishing-boat inspected in the Atlantic Ocean 550 km north of Portugal's Madeira Island.

The source said that eleven people were arrested. Six of them were aboard the boat while others were arrested in several sites in the Galesia region (North-western Spain) following investigations that took more than a month.
Ten of the defendants were Spanish and the eleventh is Colombian, the source reported.

Customs Authorities put the boat Rabanwi, flying a Chilean flag, under secret observation. The boat crew used, false Honduran documents and left Gibraltar on the 12th of October. It sailed a complicated route along the American and European shores, the spokesman said.
The spokesman added that the customs ship 'Peterbel' inspected the boat at 3:50 A.M. on Saturday.
The customs personnel found the cocaine shipment hidden in the rear bridge of the boat. The crew of the boat used for smuggling did not offer any resistance.
The Finance Ministry of Spain reported that the ship "Peterbel" has undertaken five inspection missions since the beginning of the year, resulting in the confiscation of eleven tons of cocaine.

hl.seg: Russia to set up permanent diplomatic mission in Kabul (Evanov)

p.seg: Moscow, 11-26 (AFP) - The Russian Foreign Minister announced to the public television (RTR) yesterday evening that starting Monday, Russia will set up a permanent diplomatic mission in Kabul.

Evanov said: "A special group of people are in-charge of setting up a diplomatic mission (permanently in the Afghan capital). The group will start its work on Monday and we hope that everything will be ready soon".

"We found a suitable building in which to set up the mission" he mentioned. "The building where the former embassy was located suffered heavy damage and could not be used in the near future" Evanov added.
The embassy was evacuated dramatically, under gunfire in 1992.
"Another Russian group is working to set up a center for humanitarian aid in the Afghan capital" the minister said.

The Russian Foreign Minister said that Russia was the first country to send a formal delegation to Kabul after the fall of the Taliban, and the delegation "is working and meeting with Afghan representatives and international organizations".

hl.seg: Russian Military caravan arrives in Kabul.

p.seg: Kabul, 11-26 (AFP) - A Russian caravan consisting of 13 vehicles: a number of trucks, containers and soldier-carriers, arrived in Kabul on Monday evening. It is the first time in 12 years, that Russian machinery has entered Afghanistan, the correspondent of France Press News Agency reported.
They refused to talk to journalists, but one of them confirmed that they are Russians.
At least two of the men were wearing blue jackets with a label written in Russian.

According to a previous announcement from Interfax News Agency, Twelve Russian airplanes carrying equipment needed for setting up the diplomatic mission in Kabul landed at the Baghram airport, north of the Afghan capital.

The Russian Foreign Minister, Eghor Evanov announced on Sunday that "a special group assigned to set up the (permanent diplomatic mission in the Afghan capital) will start its work, effective Monday".

Mr.Evanov said that Russia has found the proper building for its diplomatic mission, regretting the heavy damages suffered by the former Russian embassy building, which makes it unusable at least for the near future.
The former embassy was evacuated tragically and under gunpoint, in August 1992.
On the sixteenth of November, Moscow announced its intention to send an official delegation to Afghanistan, considered to be an important player in the Afghan field after the fall of the Taliban.

hl.seg: Nepal government asks king to declare State of Emergency.

p.seg: Kathmandu, 11-26 (AFP) - A government source has announced that the Nepalese government will ask the king for permission to declare a state of emergency following a series of attacks carried out by Maoist rebels, which claimed the lives of 270 people.

The source told France Press News Agency that the cabinet held an emergency session on Monday under the leadership of its premier Sher Bahadur Duba, and will ask King Gayanendra to declare the State of Emergency.
"The government has asked the king to announce a state of emergency according to the constitution" the same source added.

The National Radio of Nepal announced on Monday that more than 220 people including 200 Maoist rebels, were killed in battles fought between Maoists and governmental forces on Sunday evening, east of Nepal.
The latest casualties raised to 290 the number of people killed since Maoist rebels broke a fragile four-month cease-fire on Friday.

hl.seg: Bush: Americans may suffer losses in war against terror.

p.seg: Washington, 11-26 (AFP) The American President George Bush warned Americans on Monday that the forces participating in the campaign against terrorism may suffer "losses", and reminded them that the present stage has become "dangerous".
"I believe that Americans understand that the combat to rescue the world from terrorism will be long, and will result in losses"
"I pray that we can avoid it" he said.
"But, the brave people who serve in the military know the risks of what they are doing".
Bush made his announcement as the Marines began to deploy around Qandahar, the Taliban's stronghold in southern Afghanistan.
""Americans should understand that there is a long way ahead until our goals are achieved" the American president added.
"But we are full of patience and determination, and we will persevere till we reach our goals", he confirmed. The terrorists of Al-Qaeda " will end up in court", Bush said.
He also mentioned that the war against terror requires sacrifices.

Several sources mentioned the death of a CIA officer in a possible rebellion in the prison where foreign Taliban fighters are kept in the northern city of Mazar-e-Sharief, controlled by Northern Alliance forces.
The United States did not confirm the death of its agent.

hl.seg: China and Iraq trade more than 2.7 billion dollars (Chinese diplomat).

p.seg: Baghdad, 11-26 (AFP) The Chinese Ambassador to Baghdad, Keau Weight Jant said that Beijing is trying to consolidate economic and trade cooperation with Iraq in all fields, stating that the size of the exchange between the two nations in the framework of the "Oil for Food" Accord has reached "more than 2.7 billion dollars".

On Monday, the Iraqi newspaper "Al-Jumhuriah" quoted the Chinese Ambassador as saying that economic and trade relations between Iraq and China "have witnessed great development in recent years despite the ban imposed on Iraq" since August 1990.

"The size of trade cooperation" between the two parties in the framework of the "Oil for Food" Accord" has reached "more than 2.7 billion dollars" since the beginning of the aid programs, the result being that Chinese industrial and trading companies have concluded a large number of commercial contracts with Iraq" he added.

The contracts include foodstuffs, equipment and spare parts "for the industrial, commercial, transportation, communication and electricity sectors", as stated by the Chinese Ambassador. The Chinese diplomat confirmed that the commercial and economic relations of both countries suffered heavy losses because of UN sanction on Iraq.
China is a permanent member of UNSC. Next week the council is to discuss the extension of the "Oil for Food" Accord, which took effect in December 1996.
Last July, Beijing supported a US - British project imposing new restrictions on Iraq.

hl.seg: Hundreds of Taliban surrender after the fall of Kunduz.

p.seg: Kandahar, (Afghanistan), 11-26 (AFP) - Hundreds of Taliban fighters besieged in Kunduz for weeks surrendered Monday to Northern Alliance forces, which captured the north-eastern city, a reporter of France Press reported.
The commander, Salim Mohammad, told France Press Agency that "about 500 Taliban fighters surrendered this morning after fierce fighting in which hundreds were killed on both sides".
In the afternoon the city was fully under the control of the Northern Alliance forces.
The Taliban fighters, wearing their black turbans and carrying Kalashnikov machine-guns, were jam-packed inside trucks waiting along the main highway of Kunduz.
The commander confirmed that most of them were Pashtuns.
According to Northern Alliance sources, there were still some resistance pockets in the region of Shar Dara (10 KLM west of the city).
The surrender of Kunduz, the last stronghold of the Taliban in northern Afghanistan, was inevitable, especially after the mass surrender of Taliban members during the past days.

hl.seg: American Marines seize airport near Kandahar (Pentagon).

p.seg: Washington, 11-26 (AFP)- The American Marines captured an airport near Kandahar in southern Afghanistan. The move will allow the US forces to perform their biggest military deployment since the beginning of the US war in Afghanistan last October, military officials in Washington announced.
Pentagon spokesman Lieutenant Colonel David Laban, announced that "the goal was to seize the airport, and the goal was achieved".
The Marines started an airdrop operation on Sunday in the desert of Afghanistan. They were transported by helicopter from two ships, the Beliliu and the Batan, in the Gulf of Oman.
More than one thousand soldiers will arrive in the desert the same way, Colonel Laban said.
He added "we will have more than one thousand marines' inside Taliban territory within the next two days". He reported that General James Mathew will command the operation.
The spokesperson reported that the men will move in the field in coordination with the other forces, particularly the special units.

hl.seg: Russian- Iranian discussions on the eve of Afghan Factions Conference.

p.seg: Moscow, 11-26 (AFP)- The Russian Foreign Ministry issued a statement on Monday saying that Russia and Iran have started discussing the future of Afghanistan on the eve of the Conference of Afghan Factions, which is due to start in Bon (Germany) tomorrow.

The statement said that these discussions were held last Friday in Moscow at the level of deputy foreign ministers. It discussed "the efforts being made to achieve real progress in Afghanistan. The agenda included the rehabilitation and construction of infrastructure by the interim authority.

The statement stressed "the basic role of the United Nations" in this mission, and both Russian and Iranians expressed their support for the constitution of "multi-ethnic Afghan government, which represents the interests of all Afghans and works to establish peaceful relations with neighboring countries, and cooperates with the international community in the war against terror and drug trafficking".
It is said that Moscow and Tehran have been supporting the Northern Alliance for a long time. Their ally managed to capture a large part of Afghanistan supported by American air bombardment.

hl.seg: Prince Abdullah and Arafat call for mechanism to implement the American message on Palestinian State.

p.seg: Riyadh, 11-26 (AFP)- The Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz, and the Palestinian President, Yasser Arafat, called for "the formulation of a mechanism" to implement the content of the message delivered by the American President, George Bush, and the statements given by Colin Powel regarding the Palestinian State.

The Palestinian Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Mustufa Al-Sheikh, told France Press News Agency that Prince Abdullah and Arafat emphasized during their meeting on Sunday night - Monday "the necessity of formulating a mechanism to implement the content of Bush's message and Powel's statements" about the Palestinian State.

He further said that both men agreed that Saudi Arabia should continue "its efforts with the American Administration to promote its approach to bring a solution for the Palestinian issue that would lead to the establishment of a Palestinian State, and solve the problem of refugees".

The Palestinian Ambassador to Saudi Arabia emphasized that both parties "also agreed on the necessity of immediate appointment of international observers in the Palestinian territories to protect the Palestinians from Israeli atrocities."

Arafat, who visited the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia recently in his tour among a number of Arabian countries, held talks on Sunday evening with the Saudi King, Fahd bin Abdul Aziz, and discussed ways to reactivate the Middle East peace process.

hl.seg: Palestinian leadership denounces attacks against Israelis in Gaza Sector and Israel.

p.seg: Ghazza, 11-27 (AFP) - On Tuesday, the Palestinian leadership denounced the two attacks that led to the killing of three Israelis in the Gaza Strip and Israel, reiterating that it had given strong instructions to the Palestinian security systems to track down the perpetrators of these attacks and to bring them to justice, particularly as they have violated the cease-fire.

The Palestinian leadership said in a statement published by the Palestinian News Agency that it "severely denounces the operations of Al-Afoula and (near the settlement) of Ghosh Qateef (south of the Gaza Strip), which targeted Israeli civilians. The leadership denounces all the operations which target Palestinian or Israeli civilians".

The leadership pointed out that it "has issued strict instructions to security forces to track down the perpetrators of these operations in Al-Afoula and Ghosh Qateef, and to bring them to justice as they have seriously violated the cease-fire, and to intensify the peace effort and snatch away means from the hands of Israeli government.

An Israeli woman was killed yesterday after being wounded when the Palestinians opened fire on the bus in which she was a passenger in the Gaza Strip, according to reports from Israeli medical sources. A Palestinian was also killed. Palestinian sources say that he was the perpetrator of the attack.

Two Palestinians opened fire today in the north of Israel, killing two passersby and injuring 34 others before they were killed by the bullets of police at a time when the American envoys were discussing the cease-fire with the Israeli Premier, Ariel Sharon.

hl.seg: Rumsfeld: The war will not end quickly.

p.seg: Tampa (USA), 11-27 (AFP) - The American Defense Secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said on Tuesday that the war in Afghanistan will not end quickly despite the progress achieved.
Enroute to Makdel airbase in Tampa, Florida (south), Rumsfeld told journalists that the situation on the ground was "dangerous".
He said "We would be wrong to thimk that it's all over in the Afghan cities (which the Taliban no longer controls).
"That is not the case" .
At CIA headquarters in Tampa he added, "it seems that things are going as planned so far, but we are entering a more difficult stage".
The defense minister said that cities wrested from Taliban control "are not secure" because some Taliban fighters may still be hiding there or they may be rejoined by other fleeing Taliban members.
He went on to say that the success in Afghanistan "will need time and it will be difficult and dangerous (...) There will be victims.
This is a tough environment for us and for the opposition forces".
Rumsfeld said that the danger to American Forces is the shifting of the war from cities to mountain caves, wherein the leaders of the Taliban and individuals of Al-Qaeda network are hiding.

General Tommy Frank, Commander of the American forces in Afghanistan, announced during the meeting that the number of Marine infantry at the advanced base near Kandahar (south) is between 800 and 1100 individuals.

hl.seg: Northern Alliance recaptures large part of Janji Fort.

p.seg: Janji Fort, (Afghanistan), 11-27 (AFP) - The local commander, Mohammad Nouri, told France Press Agency that the Northern Alliance Forces recaptured a big part of Janji Fort in Northern Afghanistan from non-Afghan Taliban fighters.
He said "the matter is close to an end, there is no fighting, but we are waiting until tomorrow to enter because we think some of the dead bodies might have been tied to bombs".

But it appears that some of those fighters were still resisting on Tuesday afternoon, and the Northern Alliance Forces opened fire on the western walls of the Fort, as some fighters were still showing resistance.
About 45 to 50 soldiers of Northern Alliance were killed during the fighting according to information from commander Nouri.
The Northern Alliance announced that 300 to 400 foreign fighters, loyal to the Taliban, were killed.
The foreign fighters have been resisting from inside Fort Janji for over 48 hours after launching a rebellion.
They surrendered to the Northern Alliance Forces in Kandahar city before their transfer to this prison.

hl.seg: British Marine commandos present near Kabul for back-up.

p.seg: London 11-28, (AFP)- The London based daily newspaper the "Times" said on Wednesday that Britain has sent forty Marine commandos to back-up the special forces, assigned to protect Baghram Airport, near Kabul.
The newspaper added that those commandos would replace the elite soldiers in the special Marine forces, who will be assigned more suitable tasks in Afghanistan.
Spokesman of the Ministry of Defense said "This is just a change."
"So the Marine forces can replace those already installed there and give them rest".
The "Daily" confirmed that currently about 130 soldiers are deployed in Baghram airport.
The British Defense Minister was content, on Monday, saying that the team in Baghram "was consolidated at the end of the week".

hl.seg: Lloyds Insurance Corporation expects extra losses because of terrorist attacks.

p.seg: London 11-27 (AFP) - The giant British insurance company, Lloyds, announced on Tuesday that it is expecting losses
equal to 1.9 billion pounds sterling (3.06 billion dollar)".
In the beginning, Lloyds estimated its losses at 1.3 billion pounds sterling, which is absolutely the most the company is obliged to pay as the result of an incident.
Sax Relay, Head of the Lloyds Insurance Group announced "Anyone looking for indications of the death of Lloyds in these figures will be disappointed".
He further said that financial performance began to improve "quickly" due to the big hike in the value of Insurance Certificates, which customers are required to pay.

The Lloyds Corporation explained that it is auditing to determine the cost of the attacks because it has received new applications for compensation for the destroyed buildings and increases in its outstanding payments to other insurance companies, as motivation for reinsurance.

hl.seg: IAAF reduces the number of Golden League events from 7 to 5.

p.seg: Monaco, Nov. 27 (AFP) - The IAAF (International Association of Athletics Federations) announced Monday that it will reduce the number of Golden League Jackpot events from seven to five for the 2003 season.
The IAAF indicated that it is reducing the number of events to make the Golden League more attractive, but reiterated that athletes must still win the same event in the five Golden League meetings.

After finishing first in their respective events in 5 of the original 7 meetings (Rome, Oslo, Paris, Monaco, Zurich, Brussels, and Berlin), Hicham El Guerrouj (Morocco), Andre Bucher (Switzerland), Allen Johnson and Marion Jones (USA), Olga Yegorova (Russian Federation), and Violeta Beclea-Szekely (Romania) split the 50 kg in gold ingots earmarked for the 2002 Golden League Jackpot winners.
The IAAF also announced that it has awarded the 2003-05 Grand Prix Finals to the principality of Monaco. The Finals will be held over two days in September.
As host of the Grand Prix Final, Monaco is procluded from organizing a Golden League meeting. The IAAF decision thus requires that a new city be chosen to host the meeting formerly held in Monaco.

hl.seg: United Nations extends mission of International Forces in Golan for six months.

p.seg: New York (United Nations) 11-27 (AFP)- On Tuesday the UNSC Security Council extended the UNO Disengagement Forces mission on the line of cease-fire between Israel and Syria in the Golan Heights for a period of six months until next May 31st.
At the recommendation of UNO Secretary General, Kofi Annan, the Security Council decided that the presence of observers is quite necessary despite the instability on the 76km long line.

In his report, Kofi Annan pointed out that "the situation in the Middle East is still very dangerous and it will remain so until the conclusion of a comprehensive agreement involving all the parties of the conflict".
A statement from the UNO Security Council confirms that the Secretary General's statement "reflects the stance of the Security Council".

Israel and Syria have agreed on the new extension of the Disengagement Force's mission, which was installed in May 1974. The current mission of the force is due to expire on Friday at midnight in the Syrian Golan Heights, which was occupied by Israel in 1967.
The International Observation Force numbers 1056, and is among the oldest active peacekeeping forces of UNO.

hl.seg: Al-Afoula attack was joint operation of Al-Jihad Al-Islami and Al-Aqsa Battalion.

p.seg: Nablus (Western Bank), 11-27 (AFP)-Sources of the Al-Jihad Al-Islami Movement declared that the armed attack by two Palestinians on Tuesday in Al-Afoula (North of Israel) was a joint operation of Al-Qudus Battalion, the armed wing of Al-Jihad Al-Islami and Battalions of Al-Aqsa Martyrs, linked to the Fatah Movement.

The same source said in a statement sent to France Press Agency "The perpetrators of the operation were Abdul Karim Abu Naisa (19 years) from Al-Qudus Battalion, and Mustufa Abu Sariah (19 years) from the Battalions of the Al-Aqsa Martyrs, and both of them are from Jenin Camp, north of the West Bank".
The Israeli Police reported that the armed Palestinians opened fire on the passersby in Al-Afoula (Northern Israel), and gunned down two of them before they were themselves killed.

The same source explained that the attack was carried pit with machine guns, and left 34 people injured, the condition of nine of the victims was described as serious, while the other 25 were described as medium.

Al-Jihad Al-Islami movement erroneously announced the name of Hussein Abu Naisa as the perpetrator of the pizza restaurant explosion in Jerusalem on the ninth of last August, to clarify, that the executor of the operation was one of the Hamas activists.
The source clarified that Abdul Karim Abu Naisa is brother of Hussein Abu Naisa.

hl.seg: More Lebanese refugees in Israel return home.

p.seg: Al-Naqourah (Lebanon) 11-27 (AFP)- About 70 Lebanese, who are families of the former Southern Lebanon Militia Army backed by Israel, returned to their homeland in Lebanon on Tuesday. The returning refugees took refuge in Israel after Israeli forces withdrew from Southern Lebanon.

International Emergency Forces installed on the Lebanese - Israeli boarders received the returning refugees, who spent more than a year in Israel. There were about 200 of their relatives waiting for them.
The people returning were transferred to Lebanese Army Headquarters, where they were inspected and interrogated.
Women and children were released immediately, while 35 people were considered suspicious according to France Press News Agency reports.

It is said that more than six thousand Lebanese, most of them from the former Southern Lebanon Militia, along with their families, retreated to Israel with the forces from southern Lebanon in May 2000. They didn't return, fearing revenge by the Shiite Lebanese Hizbullah Party or prosecution by the Lebanese State.
So far, according to statistics from France Press Agency, about half of them have returned.
To date, the Lebanese military court has issued rulings in three thousand cases of Southern Lebanon Militias, included 30 death sentences in absentia.

hl.seg: Bonn Conference resumes dialogues on all issues of work-schedules.

p.seg: Bonn (German)11-28 (AFP)- An Afghan official told the France Press Agency that the Afghan envoys in the Bonn Conference were called upon Tuesday morning in an expanded session to discuss all issues listed in the agenda, set yesterday at the beginning of the discussions, that are related to the period of political transfer in Afghanistan.
Afghan Consul in Berlin, Sultan Bunyad said that four existing groups in Bonn were called around 9:30 (8:30 GT).

The conference began on Tuesday with the hope that the envoys could reach an initial agreement on the agenda topics, which specifies a settlement "in three to five days". The agreement would solidify the establishment of an interim government until the meeting of "Loya Jirga", which is likely to be held in the spring.

It is expected that this traditional assembly will create an interim government and a parliament that will govern the country for about two years, which is the required time for the formulation of a new constitution, which will then be brought before the "Loya Jirga" for approval.

hl.seg: Jewish settlers erect camp near Palestinian town.

p.seg: Jerusalem, 11-28 (AFP)- On Friday, a group of Jewish settlers erected a big camp near the Palestinian town Sanjal, north of Ramallah, in the West Bank. An officer, speaking on behalf of the settlers, told France Press News Agency that the move came after an attack perpetrated by the Palestinians in the West Bank
A Chinese, who was working in nearby settlements, suffered slight injuries in the attack, which was carried out on Tuesday evening.
The officer, Ghadi bin Zimra, further said "we will remain in this camp until the Israeli Army sets up a permanent control center to prevent new attacks" .
He made it clear that this is a move from the residents of neighboring settlement Ma'ali Livuna, who are obliged to use a road near Sanjal to reach their settlement.
Since the beginning of Intifada (uprising) at the end of September 2000 there have been 15 Palestinian attacks in this sector, resulted in injury to four Jewish settlers.

hl.seg: American virus specialist disappears mysteriously in USA

p.seg: (Return as precaution)

Washington, 11-28 (AFP)- The local police announced Tuesday that a scientist, specializing in the Apulia other deadly viruses has been missing, under suspicious circumstances, from Memphis, Tennessee in the southern US since the 16th of this month.

Prof. Don Willy (57 years), an expert in Chemistry and Bio-physics at Harvard University, was seen alive for the last time on the 15th - one day before his disappearance- at his hotel in Memphis, where he was to participate in a meeting of experts at the city hospital.
The local newspapers reported that his rented car was found the next day on the Mississippi River Bridge with the keys still inside, and its tank full of gas.
The local newspapers quoted the police lieutenant in charge of the investigation as saying, "We have been attempting to discover his whereabouts since that day".
Prof. Willy is known for his research on the Apulia virus, which caused the spread of deadly epidemics in Africa, and still has no cure.
He also did studies on AIDS and hemorrhage fever, according to the Howard Hugs Institute, where he is employed.
His disappearance comes at a time when the American police are in the process of investigating letters carrying the anthrax agent, which caused the death of five people in the USA since September.

hl.seg: George Bush congratulates Consortium States for oil pipelines in the Caspian Sea.

p.seg: Washington, 11-29 (AFP)- On Wednesday, US President George W. Bush congratulated Russia, Kazakhstan, Sultanate of Oman, and their partners in the consortium of Caspian Sea oil pipeline, for launching the facility. It intended to give the US more opportunities to diversify energy resources, he said.
He continued, "for the world, this is an example of cooperation between USA, Russia and Kazakhstan for development and stability in this part of the world.

He went on to say that the consortium of oil pipelines in the Caspian Sea, which was started on Tuesday, will also contribute to an environment of transparency and stability for international trade and investment.

The proprietorship of pipelines is owned by Russia (24%), Kazakhstan (19%) and Sultanate of Oman (7%) in addition to the companies, Chevron (15%), Look Well-RCo. (12.5%) , Russia Oil -Shell (7.5%) and Exxon Mobil (7.5%) and AGIP (2%).
The 1500 km pipeline required an investment of 2.6 billion dollars and is considered one of the biggest international projects in the territories of former Soviet Union.

The pipelines emanate from the giant Tengheez Oilfield, and its commencement is considered an important step in ending the isolation of Kazakhstan by allowing it to export the best of its wealth of energy.
The raw oil will be transferred from the Russian port of Novorossiysk to the oil carriers, which will cross the Black Sea and supply southern Europe and the markets of Mediterranean Ocean.
The capacity of the pipeline, which was essentially 28 million tons per annum, will rise to 67 million ton per annum in the future.

hl.seg: Fouler on his way to Leeds United

p.seg: London, 11-28 (AFP)- Liverpool Club, the leader of the England Football Championship, agreed to trade the international footballer Roby Fouler to its archrival Leeds United for 11 million pounds sterling (about 15.4 million dollar).
Fouler (26 years) still has to give approval on his monthly salary with Leeds and undergo a medical check-up before signing officially today or on Thursday.

Leeds refused to pay the 15 million pounds sterling (about 20 million dollars) that Liverpool previously demanded for Fouler, on whom Leeds may have spent 97 million pounds sterling (about 130 million dollars) since his training with David Oleri three years earlier.

Fouler, who is considered among the most prominent football players in England, failed to make an impression in Liverpool, either due to his injury or due to his legal violations, and his relationship with the French coach, Jerar Hoieh, and his assistant Veel Thomson.
Some sources said that Liverpool entered into negotiations with Manchester United to obtain the services of, Doyet York, a native of Trinidad.

hl.seg: Palestinian police arrest promoters of CDs that recount life of Bin Laden.

p.seg: Gaza, 11-28 (AFP)- The Palestinian police arrested two Palestinians for recording and promoting compact discs (CDs), describing the personal career of Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in the September 11 attacks on New York and Washington.

A Palestinian police source informed the France Press Agency on Wednesday that "the police arrested two citizens yesterday (Tuesday) and today (Wednesday) with the accusation of printing, owning and promoting CDs on the life of Osama bin Laden, leader of the Al-Qaeda Movement and Islamic organizations in Chechnya".
The source pointed out that "a group of owners of CD shops underwent an investigation on on the same topic. A number of department stores were inspected for these materials as well.
The police officer observed that "promoting such materials is against the Palestinian Publishing and Registered Trade Marks law, and comes under piracy".

hl.seg: Uzbekistan reconfirms its strong support for United States.

p.seg: Washington, 11-30 (AFP)- Yesterday in Washington, the Uzbek officials confirmed that they will fight "till the last" in the war against terror being waged by the US, insisting that the promise of American aid should not be considered the price for their support.

The delegates, including Deputy Prime Minister Rustam Azeemov, Defence Minister Qader Gholomov, and Deputy Minister of Uzbekistan supported the American campaign against the Taliban and Osama bin Laden during their meeting with the American Assistant Foreign Secretary, Richard Armitage.
The Asst. Minister of Foreign Affairs, Sadeq Safeef, pronounced "the readiness of Uzbekistan to move on to a "preliminary' resolution as the Uzbeks are afraid of the dangers of Islamic communalism.
He said that this support is based on "principle".
He said, pointing to the American promise of providing aid, that "this matter is not a deal or a barter".
Uzbekistan is hosting American forces and has opened its airspace to American warplanes.
The spokesman of the US Foreign Ministry, Richard Boucher, refused to give details of the support that Washington may provide to Tashkent.
He said "I have nothing new to say about the level of support now.
And we will hold discussions".
It was decided that the US Foreign Secretary, Colin Powell, will visit Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan during his tour of Europe, next week.

hl.seg: Israeli Army transfers mobile homes to Khan Younis and sweeps away Palestinian lands in Rafah.

p.seg: Gaza, 11-27 (AFP)- Palestinian Security sources reported on Thursday that the Israeli Army transferred three mobile homes near Al-Matahen round-about, close to the settlements of Ghosh Qateef in Khan Younis, while Israeli bulldozers demolished Palestinian houses in Rafah, South of the Gaza Strip.

The Security sources told France Press, "The Israeli Army put three mobile homes on residential lands between the Kesoveem site of the Israeli Army and the settlement complex of Ghosh Qateef in Khan Younis.

"These mobile homes have been added to the Israeli military presence in the region with an aim to continue building an upper bridge for the service of extremist Jewish residents on confiscated Palestinian lands, i.e. four hundred thousand sq. m. in a span of few days" the same sources reported.

"The Israeli Army, with the help of bulldozers and military machines, swept away more than forty thousand sq. m of planted land, near the settlement of Muragh in Rafah, south of Gaza Strip" the sources said.
The sources considered this act as "a part of continued Israeli aggression against the isolated Palestinian nation, despite the consistent American and international efforts".

hl.seg: United Nations confirms the arrest of Ahmad Omar Abdur Rehman

p.seg: Islamabad, 11-30 (AFP)- The spokesman for "Alliance against Terrorism", an American Journalist Center based in Islamabad, confirmed on Friday that Northern Alliance forces arrested Ahmad Omar Abdul Rahman, who is believed to be a member of the Al-Qaeda network led by Osama bin Laden.

The spokesman of "Alliance against Terrorism" media center, Kenton Keith said "we can confirm that during the last 24 hours the forces of the United Front (Afghan Northern Alliance) arrested Ahmed Omar Abdul Rehman".
The center was established recently in Islamabad to promote the American viewpoint of the US war against Afghanistan, which began on the seventh of last October.
The Spokesman confirmed during the press conference " We are expecting him to be handed over to the Alliance authorities.
It is said that Washington accuses the fundamentalist Osama bin Laden of masterminding the attacks of 11 September in the United States.
The American Administration has launched an air campaign against Afghanistan's Ruling Taliban for giving shelter to Bin Laden.
Washington considers this bombardment and the land operation launched by the Special Forces as a "war against terror".

hl.seg: AAR About one thousand Palestinians demonstrate in Hebron.

p.seg: Hebron, 11-30 (AFP)- Around one thousand Palestinians demonstrated in Hebron on Friday, commemorating the massacre of Muslim worshippers in Al Ibrahimi Mosque, by an extremist Jewish settler in 1994.
The FPA correspondent reported that the demonstrators, among whom were about one hundred masked fighters, were shouting anti-Israel slogans, and burnt a dummy of the Israeli Premier, Ariel Sharon.

The settler, Baroush Goldstein, opened fire with a machine-gun on February 25th 1994- corresponding to fifteenth Ramadan inside the Ibrahimi Mosque -a Holy-place in Hebron in the West Bank- killing 29 Muslim worshippers before he was beaten to death by the crowd.

On Sunday, Israeli soldiers strengthened the siege around Hebron, which lies in Palestinian Authority territories. They also fired rubber bullets and tear-gas bombs at those whom they suspected, according to Palestinian eyewitnesses.

In accord with an agreement with the Palestinian Authority, Israel evacuated 80% of Hebron in 1997, but it still has control over a settlement area where about 400 Jew settlers are living under the protection of hundreds of Israeli soldiers.

hl.seg: Burhanuddin Rabbani supports the right to vote for Afghan women.

p.seg: Kabul, 11-30 (AFP)- The leader of the Northern Alliance, Burhanuddin Rabbani, said on Friday in a press conference he held in Kabul that "Afghan women should be given the right to vote and nominate" in the elections.
Rabbani, head of the Alliance, who ousted the Taliban from Kabul on November 13th, believes that there should be elections in Afghanistan under the supervision of international organizations.
He said that the path leading to these elections should take into consideration three factors, i.e., population of the country, tribes, social establishments and groups or parties.
He further said "we think that the elections should be held on the basis of percentage of population in the country" relying on dependable organizations such as the UN.
Rabbani pointed out the importance of various ethnic groups in Afghanistan, particularly the importance of the Pashtun ethnic group, of which several key Afghan figures are members.

hl.seg: Paris: Extension of Oil for Food Program will pave the way for arms inspectors.

p.seg: Paris, 11-30 (AFP)- France expressed its pleasure on Friday over the extension of the Oil for Food Program on Thursday, asserting that this will pave the way for the return of arms inspectors to Iraq.
The Spokesman for French Foreign Affairs, Francu Rivasu said "We express our pleasure at the passage of such an important resolution by the World Security Council..
That will lead to the improvement of the humanitarian conditions in Iraq.
He further said "The civil contract will never be subject to the approval of the Penal Commission (of UNO), except in very limited circumstances".
He explained, "This resolution opens, on the other hand, the way for the return of arms inspectors to Iraq, a matter which is also in keeping with our goal".
He pointed out that with the improvement of the human condition and resumption of arms inspection "There is a chance for a comprehensive solution, for which we hope and pray".
He also said "The Security Council has proved its desire to achieve progress in the Iraqi dossier.
From now on, it is up to Iraq to express its desire to cooperate with the international community in the field inspection of prohibited weapons.
But on Friday, Baghdad continued its attacks on the Security Council, accusing the latter of trying to open way for the return of arms inspectors, to which Baghdad is completely opposed.
Responding to a question on Iraq's continued refusal to welcome the UNO arms inspectors, the French spokesman said only "We will see, but the situation is still hypothetical".

hl.seg: Al-Najmah renews contract with Trinidad footballer Mcferlin.

p.seg: Beirut, 11-30 (AFP)- The Al-Najmah Lebanese Football Club renewed the contract of Trinidad Footballer Erol Mcferlin for another year during a meeting of the club's delegation. The renewal was done in the presence of the Technical Manager of the Tunisian team, Omar Mizyan, and member of the Football Committee, Sa'aduddin Itani, in Port of Spain, capital of Trinidad and Tobago.

Mcferlin (27 years) recorded 7 goals for the club when the latter won the tournament championship in the season 1999-2000 for the third time in its history. He also scored 21 goals in the last season, before cancellation of the tournament. The athletic sector was shocked by the scandal resulting from manipulation of the results of the matches.

The well known Egyptian football club Al-Zamalek tried to recruit Mcferlin this season according to the proposal of the former Egyptian coach of Al-Najamah, Mr. Farooq Al-Sayed. The present German coach of Al-Zamalek, Mr. Otobefester, turned the recommendation down and asked Al-Zamalek's footballer Mr. Farid Mawali to join his team. Mawali was under aprobation period with the Club.

The Chairman of Al-Najmah Club, Mr. Omar Ghandoor, said in a telephone conversation with the France Press Agency that the Cameroon footballer, Mr. Nekula Mobainda, drew the attention of the technical department during his probation period. But the final decision has to be made by Omar Mizyan, he continued. Al Mizya arrived in Beirut in the late hours of yesterday evening from Trinidad and Tobago.
The club has another foreign player, who is the heart of the Nigerian defence, Mr. Sandai Oko.

hl.seg: Deputy Chairman of Al-Faisali steps down.

p.seg: Amman, 12-1 (AFP)- Deputy Chairman of the Jordanian football club Al-Faisali, Mr. Salim Khair (Jordan), announced on Friday that he submitted his resignation to the Chairman of the club Al-Sheikh, Sultan Al-Adwan. Mr. Khair pointed out that the resignation is not associated with the withdrawal of the team from the Seventeenth Arabian Club Champions' Cup, which is being hosted by Qatari Block till the 10th of this December.
Al-Faisali withdrew from the Arabian Championship, protesting the judgment of Libyan referee, Badar Salim.

Khair reiterated in his resignation application, a copy of which was received by France Press, that he feels deep sorrow because certain circumstances will not enable him to continue his services to this club. "a role that I am proud of, which requires a great effort that I am unable to provide". He wrote in his resignation.

He further said "even though I am submitting my resignation, I assure you that I will always provide support and back up, as much and as long as I am able to give. I feel honored for having served the sport career of this club.".

hl.seg: Zeini starts his visit to Gaza.

p.seg: Gaza, 12-1 (AFP)- The American envoy, Gen. Anthony Zeini, began a field tour in the Gaza Strip, and will hold meetings with the Palestinian political and security officials, Palestinian sources reported on Saturday.

The Palestinian official sources told the France Press Agency that Gen. Zeini, who arrived in Bait Hanoon Crossing (areas north of Gaza Strip) where he was received by the Palestinian Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Mr. Nabeil Sha'ath, and Col. Abdul Razzaq Al-Mojaedah. Two meetings will be held; a political meeting with Minister Sha'ath in Ghazza, and a second one with the security officials".

Sources reported that the American Envoy will meet Col. Ameen Al-Hindi, Director of Palestinian Public Investigations and the Col. Al-Mojaeda, Director of Palestinian Public Security in the Gaza Strip and Mohammed Dahlan, Director of Protective Security System in Gaza, at the Headquarters of Public Investigation.
On the first leg of his tour, Zeini will visit the Marine Police Headquarters and the American School in Bait Lahia town, north of Gaza.
It is said that Marine Police Headquarters and the American School were hit by Israeli bombardment. Bait Lahia town was also heavily damaged.

The senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat announced Friday that the Palestinian side produced a proposal before the American Envoy, which includes the setting of a time frame for the implementation of recommendations and agreements of Michel and Tenet.

hl.seg: Anti-Taliban Pashtun tribes 25 KM away from Kandahar (Karzai)

p.seg: Islamabad, 12-1 (AFP)- An anti-Taliban Pashtun leader confirmed to France Press News Agency on Sunday, that their forces came as close as 25 km from Kandahar, the last Taliban stronghold in Southern Afghanistan.

Mr. Hamid Karzai asserted "I am near Kandahar at a distance of 25 km north-west of the city, and our advancement is being achieved without fighting. Meanwhile, dialogue continues with the Taliban officials in Kandahar".

Karzai, who is a former Deputy Foreign Minister of Afghanistan and one of the close associates of the deposed king Mohammad Zaheer Shah, declared that "he has advanced more than eighty kilometers since the departure of the Taliban from Turban Kot in Orozghan State, last night."
He further said "the tribes of the region stand with us, and we hope the Taliban movement will cooperate with us to avoid blood-shed".
Karzai expressed suspicion over the announcement of the Taliban's former Ambassador Pakistan, Abdussalam Dhaif, who vowed that the Taliban will fight till the last breath.
"He can say whatever he wishes, but the senior officials of the Taliban have contacted us, and at present, talks are on" Karazai commented.

hl.seg: President Saddam Hussein heads major political meeting.

p.seg: Baghdad, 12-1 (AFP)- On Monday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein chaired a major political meeting attended by members of the Iraqi leadership, the Iraqi News Agency (INA) reported. But the agency gave no indication of the meeting agenda.

The agency reported that participants in the meeting were Vice president Mr. Ezzat Ibrahim, and members of the Revolutionary Council Mr.Taha Yassin Ramadhan, Mr. Taha Mohiuddin Ma'arouf, Mr. Al Hassan Al-Majeed , Deputy PM Mr. Tariq Aziz, and Sa'adoon Hamadi, Head of the National Council (The Parliament).

Mr. Latief Nasief Jassem, member of the leadership council of Iraq Territory of Al-Ba'ath ruling Party, Mr. Ahmad Hussein Khedhiyer, Head of the Presidential Office, Mr. Mohammed Saeed Al-Sahaf, Minister of Information, and Naji Sabri Ahmad, Minister of Foreign Affairs, also attended the meeting.
The meeting was held just 48 hours after UNSC resolution to extend the Memorandum of Understanding of the Oil for Food deal for another six months w.e.f. Saturday.
The meeting coincides with increasing American threats to launch strikes against Iraq, if Saddam does not let UN inspectors back into Iraq.

The American President, George Bush, asked Iraq last week to permit the return of UN inspectors to prove that it has not been developing weapons of mass destruction since the inspectors left Iraq in 1998. Bush considered his words new warning to Iraq.
The Deputy Premier Mr.Tareq Aziz said in statements to journalists that "these warnings do not terrorize us" this leadership is in the right place despite all foreign threats" he added.

hl.seg: Israeli police informed of three imminent attacks in Jerusalem (Radio).

p.seg: Jerusalem, 12-1 (AFP)- Israel Radio said on Sunday that the Israeli police received a telephone call warning of three imminent attacks on Saturday evening in Jerusalem. The caller was unknown, and the call came in just minutes before the incidents.

The radio said that an unknown person with an Arab accent informed police headquarters in Bait Shamash, near Jerusalem, that Palestinians from Jenin (north of West Bank), were preparing to perform the suicide attacks in the middle of Western Jerusalem.
"Police took the call seriously and sent bomb experts to the said location in the middle of Western Jerusalem" the radio added.
The Israeli police announced that two suicidal acts were carried out yesterday in the middle of Western Jerusalem and left 12 people dead, including the two attackers.
A booby-trapped car exploded near the place of suicide attacks, causing no damage.
On Saturday, the Israeli army tightened its siege on the city of Jenin and other Palestinian cities in the West Bank after the last attacks, which took place in the Israeli territories.
Israel considers the city of Jenin as the prime source for acts of violence that target the Israelis.

hl.seg: Kasianov will discuss reduction of exports with Russian oil companies in first quarter of 2002.

p.seg: Moscow, 12-1 (AFP)- Russian Interfax News Agency reported that the Russian Prime Minister, Michael Kasianov, announced on Saturday that he would talk next week with officials from eight or nine major Russian oil companies regarding the potential of reducing exports in the first quarter of the next year.
Kasianov announced before reporters that it is necessary to prepare an integrated approach for the first quarter of the next year.
He further said that the aim was to stabilize oil prices, stating that a "just price" varies from 20 to 25 dollar per barrel.
Kasianov wished to hear the views of other oil producers.
But he stated that the decision, which would be made by Russia, will consider not only the stances of other states but also the commitments of Russia "and its position in the world".
OnOnOn the other hand, the Russian Premier emphasized that the implementation of the 2002 budget should not face problems even if the price of oil goes down to 12 dollars a barrel.
The TheThe Organization of Petrol Exporting Countries (OPEC) asked Russia to tangibly reduce its production with a view to hiking the price of oil in the international market once again.

Moscow has not agreed as yet, and will only deduct 50 thousand barrels per day, i.e. 0.7% of its total production, during the last quarter of the current year, which is considered insufficient by OPEC.

hl.seg: Zeini: Arafat has to act without delay and without excuses

p.seg: Jerusalem, 12-2 (AFP)- The American Envoy to the Middle East, Mr. Anthony Zeini, said that the Palestinian President, Yasser Arafat, has to act without delay and without excuses to stop those responsible for the attacks of Saturday evening in Western Jerusalem.

Zeini pointed out in a statement published on Saturday night- Sunday in Jerusalem that he spoke to the Palestinian President in the evening and told him clearly that those who are responsible for the formulation and implementation of such attacks must be arrested and brought to justice.
This a summary case, which cannot bear delay or excuses for not taking action decisively" he added

The American Envoy, who arrived in Jerusalem on Monday, continued working to reach a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians, pointing out that inhuman acts cannot be avoided, unless the Palestinians work permanently and comprehensively to capture the terrorists and bring them before the courts.
He said "I will be working consistently with the Israeli and the Palestinian governments in an effort to put an end to such attacks".

Gen. Zeini reiterated "This cannot be achieved except through consistent and comprehensive action by the Palestinian Authority against the persons responsible for these acts and against the infrastructure of terrorist groups that support them, and also through serious and active cooperation between the security systems of Israel and Palestine.
He also condemned "in the most severe terms these inhuman terrorist attacks" which left 12 dead, including the suicide bombers, and 170 injured.

hl.seg: Perez invites all appointed ambassadors in Israel for an emergency meeting (Radio)

p.seg: Jerusalem, 12-2 (AFP)- On Sunday afternoon, the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Perez, invited all the appointed ambassadors for an emergency meeting after the operation of Haifa in the north of Israel, which resulted in the death of at least 16 people, according to Israeli official Radio.

Perez made this decision at the end of a governmental security meeting, which he chaired in the absence of Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, who is currently on a visit to the US, where he will hold meetings with the American President, George Bush, at the White House during the day.
The radio further said that Perez will clarify the dangerous situation to the ambassadors"
The two suicide attacks were carried out on Saturday evening, and resulted in the killing of ten Israeli young people in the middle of Western Jerusalem.
In a short statement, the government has given its approval for the measures demanded by the Defense Minister, Benjamin bin al Ya'azer, the radio reported. No details were given.

hl.seg: UN proposes "symbolic" role for the former Afghan King.
