p.seg: Bonn, 12-2 (AFP)- the United Nations told the Afghan delegates, meeting in Bonn for the arrangement of the interim stage in Afghanistan, to give the former Afghan King, Zahir Shah, a "symbolic" role. The deposed king has lived in exile in Italy for decades, a UN official reported.

Ahmad Fouzi, spokesperson of UN Special Envoy to Afghanistan, Mr. Al-Akhzar Al-Ebrahimi, announced that the draft agreement which was produced before the Afghan delegates in the Conference of Afghan Factions in Bonn "stipulates the nominal role of the former king, by virtue of which he will inaugurate the Loya Jirga", the traditional Shoura Council of Afghanistan. The council is assigned to constitute an interim government for a span of two years after the completion of six months interim period.

Fauzi explained that the proposal of United Nations also stipulates to the constitution of "an independent commission" consisting of 21 members, assigned to call for holding Loya Jirga and "organizing the same" at the end of six months duration.
Fauzi went on to say that Loya Jirga would be assigned to constitute an interim government for a period of two years.
The draft agreement does not designate the former king, aged 87, who is chairing this commission, which has been named "Special Commission for Calling the "Loya Jirga" the spokesman said.
But he informed that the delegate representing King Zahir Shah in Bonn Conference did not express any opposition to the proposals of United Nations regarding the role of the former king.

hl.seg: Argentina starts control over currency

p.seg: Boeings Airbus, 12-2 (AFP)- The Argentinean Economic Minister, Domengo Cavalo, declared that the Argentinean government has decided to "control the national currency movement" As of today it will allow "only payments associated with the foreign trade and funding".
He further said "the only payments permitted are those associated with trade or funding, and whose legality can be ascertained".
He said during a press conference "the aim is to stop the currency from leaving the country".
The Customs Dept. will supervise in ascertaining that passengers leaving the country hold no more than a thousand dollars".

This decision, which falls under a set of measures initiated by the Argentinean government on Saturday, aims to avoid the break-down of the financial system and to stop the exchange rate of Argentinean currency from falling further and further. It is also meant to control the Dollar control system in the country, in addition to banning the use of bank accounts.

hl.seg: Harsh American bombardment on Tora Bora (Afghan Islamic News Agency)

p.seg: Islamabad, 12-2 (AFP)- The Afghan Islamic News Agency reported on Sunday that a severe American bombardment targeted Tora Bora in the State of Nanghar (eastern Afghanistan). Some sources reported that the mountainous area is used as a shelter by Osama bin Laden and a number of his followers.
The Agency quoted the Taliban spokesperson, confirming the bombardment without giving details about its timing or whether there were victims.
There are conflicting information and reports about the location of Bin Laden.
The British and American newspapers quoted Afghan witnesses as saying that Bin Laden is in Tora Bora, south of Jalalabad.
there is a network of tunnels in Tora Bora, which is hundreds of meters deep inside , allowing Al-Qaeda members to escape the American bombardment.
Bin Laden can also flee to tribal regions in neighboring Pakistan.
But the Northern Alliance affirms that Bin Laden is still in Southern Afghanistan, and not in Tora Bora.

hl.seg: Canada expresses its "resentment" over the suicide attacks, yet calls for hope.

p.seg: Ottawa, 12-2 (AFP)- Canada expressed its "resentment" on Sunday, over the suicide attacks that took place on Saturday and Sunday in Israel, but called Israelis and "the peace loving nations in the region" to be hopeful for the sake of reaching permanent peace.
The Canadian Prime Minister, John Chretien, said in a statement, "all Canadians are angry over this heinous crime against the innocents" such actions cannot be justified.
He further said that Israel suffered on Saturday and Sunday, in Jerusalem and Haifa (north), the worst atrocities since the Intifada (uprising) broke-out 14 months ago.
These operations caused thirty deaths and 220 injuries in an unending consequence.
The Head of Canadian government described "Israel is terrorized by this new provocation".

Though he observed "the important thing is that Israel and all peace loving nations in the region show patience on the path of hope, and that they work consistently with an aim to achieve permanent peace, which they have long awaited".

hl.seg: Victims of Jerusalem suicide attacks included French citizens (Society)

p.seg: Paris, 12-2 (AFP)- The Council of Jewish Societies in religious Saint-Saines- on the outskirts of Paris, announced on Sunday that there were French youths among those killed and injured in the Jerusalem suicide attacks"

Bin Yahuda Street, where the Palestinian suicide-bombers set off the explosive cells they were carrying, is a popular street lined with bars and restaurants, and the French youths who are studying in Israel or accompanying their families go there very frequently.
In addition to the suicide-bombers, ten youths were killed and 170 injured in the explosions.

The Council of Jewish Societies identified at least three of the French youths from Paris or from its outskirts, and their names are mentioned in the list of those killed, and it recognized the names of many of the injured, among whom is the son of the Pope of the Virginia City in the western area of Paris.

In its statement, the Council of Jewish Societies expressed its condolences and solidarity with the families of the victims and observed that Palestinian terrorism must be condemned without any reservation and should be rooted out without any further delay.

The statement added that "the Jews of France, regret the silence of our State's personnel and the politicians when the Palestinian terrorists kill a Jew in Israel or when Arab Muslims set the Jewish synagogues on fire in France, and commit acts of violence against Jews."

hl.seg: Holland asks Iran to "use its influence" with Hamas

p.seg: Tehran 2/12 (AFP) Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs Jozias van Aartsen asked the Iranian authorities on Sunday to "use their influence" with the Islamic Resistance Movement, Hamas, to stop operations against Israel.

Following a two-day visit to Tehran the Dutch Minister told journalists, "We asked the Iranians to use their influence with Palestinian groups such as Hamas, with Lebanese Hizbullah or with those responsible for the terrorist attacks, in order to stop them."

Van Aartsen added, "I asked my counterpart Kamal Kharazi for Iran to exert further efforts to stop the attacks." About 30 people have been killed in a range of attacks against Israel in the period between Saturday evening and Sunday.

When asked about the Iranian response, he added, "We completely disagree [with Tehran] which speaks of a form of resistance that can be interpreted along the lines that the Palestinian territories are subject to Israeli occupation."
He added, "As far as terrorism is concerned, there should be no distinction drawn between good terrorism and bad.
Terrorism kills innocent people."
The Dutch Minister strongly condemned the attacks against Israel, saying, "The Dutch Government condemns these attacks.
They are appalling and terrifying incidents, and obstruct progress in the peace process, notwithstanding the remote possibility of round-the-table negotiations."
Iran does not recognise the state of Israel and supports Palestinian and Lebanese groups fighting against the Jewish state.

hl.seg: Fumigation of US Senate continues

p.seg: Washington 2/12 (AFP) About 150 specialists are cautiously continuing to fumigate one of the US senate buildings by fumigating it with chlorine dioxide to eliminate any remaining anthrax spores.
Chlorine dioxide, which is being stored in giant plastic containers beside the Hart building, was sprayed over 270 square meters of office yesterday.

It is thought that specialists from the Environmental Protection Agency intend subsequently to conduct analyses within the building in order to ensure that it has been effectively cleared of any remaining anthrax bacteria.
Richard Robert, an official and scientist from the Agency, said yesterday evening, "Matters are proceeding very well given that this is the first time we have done this."

The Environmental Protection Agency had sought the views of scientists, public health officials, historians and archive experts to determine the most effective means of eradicating the lethal bacteria in the building without destroying paper documents, computers or furniture.
It is not know when the Hart building will officially reopen.

hl.seg: The Palestinian Authority detains three Hamas leaders in Gaza

p.seg: Gaza 2/12 (AFP) A Palestinian security source reported on Sunday that the Palestinian security apparatus had detained at least three senior political leaders from the Islamic Resistance Movement, Hamas, following the failure of the movement to abide by the Authority's ceasefire.
Hamas sources confirmed the report of the leaders' detention. Two of the leaders detained are known to be Ismail Abu Shanab and Ismail Haniya.
The sources explained that orders had also been issued to detain two other leaders from the movement but that they were not in their homes.

A Palestinian security source had announced that the Palestinian Security Apparatus detained on Sunday 75 Hamas and Islamic Jihad activists in the West Bank and Gaza, which represents the full complement of those detained as a result of the failure of the two movements to abide by the ceasefire announced by the Authority.
At least 30 were killed and 220 injured in the 12 hours between Saturday evening and Sunday morning in a series of Palestinian suicide attacks in Israel and the West Bank.

hl.seg: Hamas declares, "We can provide martyrs for the next 20 years"

p.seg: Damascus 2/12 (AFP) The Islamic Resistance Movement, Hamas, which is responsible for the suicide attacks that have killed 30 and injured more than 220, declared on Sunday that it "could provide martyrs for the next 20 years."

During an iftar meal organised by the movement in the al-Yarmuk Palestinian refugee camp in the southern district of Damascus, the head of the movement's Political Office, Khalid Mashaal, said, "We can resist, stand firm and provide martyrs for the next 20 years."
He added, "But we will be victorious in the end because the occupation cannot bear the human losses."
He further explained, "The philosophy of the movement is to exhaust the capacities of the enemy to the point where the cost of occupation of Palestinian land is too great for it to bear."
Mashaal criticized the Palestinian National Authority for its criticisms of the suicide attacks in Israel.
He said, "There are those who will initiate security programmes and will take steps against the movement on the ground, but we will move beyond this phase."

He added, "The resistance is facing difficult circumstances, but the battlefield is the only place where the fighters waging jihad can train, plan and implement their operations, and this is why the circumstances are difficult."
He said, "The resistance is an effective weapon whose time has not come to an end. The phase of peace and globalization means nothing to us."
Mashaal declared, "We will liberate Palestine in its entirety and regain Jerusalem. This is not some empty dream but the reality of the situation."

hl.seg: 37% of Israelis want to "get rid" of Arafat

p.seg: Jerusalem 3/12 (AFP) A survey published by the Yediut Ahranut newspaper on Monday reported that at least 37% of Israelis want to "get rid" of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. They also want the Palestinian Authority to be dismantled in response to the wave of suicide attacks against Israel.
The paper did not specify the means by which they would like to "get rid" of Arafat.
By contrast, 32% of Israelis believe that intensive peace talks should begin with the Palestinians without there being a demand for a ceasefire as a precondition.
18% of Israelis said that they would support the reoccupation of the areas under Palestinian self-rule for an unspecified period of time.
Only 10% of Israelis believe that Israel should limit itself to a policy of targeted responses to terrorism.
The survey was conducted by the Mina Tasmakh Institute and included a sample of 502 persons representing people having reached the age of majority in Israel and has a margin of error of 4.3%.
Israeli Ministry of Science and Sport Matan Vilnai (Labour Party) raised the possibility of expelling Yasir Arafat from Palestinian land.
He added, "If there is no other option, we can work with relative ease to make Yasir Arafat disappear from the area."

hl.seg: Palestinians demand US intervention (Uraiqat)

p.seg: Dubai 3/12 (AFP) The Palestinian Authority has demanded US intervention to stop Israeli raids on the Gaza Strip according to an announcement made by senior Palestinian negotiator Saib Uraiqat on Abu Dhabi television on Monday.
Uraiqat said, "I spoke to the Americans minutes after the raids began
and they said that they would maximize their efforts to stop them."

He added, "We told them that we had received their message and would make intensive efforts." This was a reference to the warning addressed by George Bush to the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat on the importance of punishing those responsible for the bloody attacks that took place in Israel at the end of last week.
On Monday, following the Israeli raids on Gaza, the White House stated that Israel had "the right to defend itself".

hl.seg: Saddam Hussein calls for US threats against Iraq not to be given any weight.

p.seg: Baghdad 3/12 (AFP) On Monday Iraqi President Saddam Hussein called on Iraqis not to give weight to US threats against the country, adding that Iraq would not yield to such threats.

The official Iraqi news agency quoted a statement made by Saddam Hussein during a reception given by him to tribal leaders in the governorates of Basra and Misan, in which he said, "Do not give any credence to this type of statement which is often made. One person may say one thing, another something else, but what is important is that it is the inhabitants of the country who will determine all these matters. Anything else is but words without substance."

He added, "I do not think that we need to mobilize when someone thinks of attacking Iraq because we are already mobilized, in terms both of faith of the Iraqi people and of their intellect, which has been tested over a long period of time and enjoys the certitude that truth is on its side."
On the 26th of November George Bush intimated that the US might target Iraq if the Iraqi president continued to reject UN inspectors.
Bush stated that should Saddam refuse to co-operate, he would "see" the results.
On Sunday US Secretary of State Colin Powell stated that the US had not taken "any decision" about the possibility of widening military operations in Afghanistan to other countries, including Iraq.

hl.seg: Increase in Iranian non-petroleum exports over 8 months

p.seg: Tehran 3/12 (AFP) On Monday the radio quoted an Iranian Customs Authority report stating that Iranian non-petroleum exports had seen a 21% increase over the period from March to November 2001 in comparison with the same period the previous year.
The Customs Authority reported that the value of these exports totaled 2.75 billion dollars over the first eight months of the Iranian calendar, which began on the 21st of March, 2001.
This increase in exports, which include gas, carpets, pistachio nuts and minerals, has been attributed to customs restrictions being lifted.
According to the same report, imports, which exceeded 11 billion dollars during the same period, also recorded an increase of 19% in comparison with the same period the previous year.
Imports include plant machinery, minerals, equipment, wheat, paper, cooking oil and chemical, plastic, petrochemical and medical products.

hl.seg: CIA ask Saudis to monitor "terrorists" during Hajj season

p.seg: Cairo 3/12 (AFP) Wajhat al-Nazar, an Egyptian monthly magazine, has reported that the CIA has asked the Saudi authorities to co-operate in monitoring potential meetings to be held between "terrorist leaders" during next year's Muslim pilgrimage or Hajj.

The journalist, Muhammad Hasanain Haikal, reported that the CIA had asked the Saudis to facilitate monitoring of the Hajj season, which falls in February next year. According to secret sources, unknown terrorist leaders have decided to meet during the Hajj season.
Haikal said that he obtained his information during a tour of Europe conducted over the past few weeks to investigate the situation in the wake of the 9/11 attacks.
He did not say whether the Saudi authorities had agreed to the American request.

hl.seg: Jordanian court sentences Abu Nidal to death in Jordanian diplomat assassination case

p.seg: Amman 3/12 (AFP) On Monday the State Security Court passed a death sentence in absentia against the founder of the Fateh Movement Revolutionary Council, Sabri al-Banna, otherwise known as Abu Nidal, who was found guilty in the case of a Jordanian diplomat assassinated in 1994.
The court also passed the death sentence against four members of the group, three of whom are still at large.
Those sentenced are to be hanged.
Palestinian Yasir Abu Shannar was the only one of the five to appear before the court.
He was detained by the Jordanian authorities in March 2000.

The five accused were charged with "conspiring to mount terrorist activities that led to the death of the First Secretary of the Jordanian Embassy in Beirut, Naib Amran al-Muaitah" and "membership of an illegal organization", a reference to the Fateh Movement Revolutionary Council.

Al-Muaitah was assassinated on 29th January, 1994, at a time when rejectionist currents opposed to the Arab-Israeli peace process accused Jordan of preparing to make a peace accord with Israel. The peace agreement was eventually signed in October of the same year.

hl.seg: Israel to widen scope of operations against Palestinian Authority

p.seg: Jerusalem 3/12 (AFP) During an emergency meeting convened on Monday evening in Jerusalem the Israeli Government decided to intensify military operations against the Palestinian Authority and to declare the Authority officially "an organization supporting terrorism".

In a statement issued followed the meeting, which lasted for nearly five hours, the Israeli government stated, "The bloody terrorist attacks at the end of last week arose as a result of the failure (of the Palestinian Authority) to detain the enemies, necessitating an expansion of operations against Palestinian terrorism."
In the statement the Israeli government declared the Palestinian Authority "an organization supporting terrorism" and said that "action must therefore be taken against it".

Without giving any detail, the statement pointed to military, economic and political revenge measures to be taken against the Palestinian Authority under the leadership of Yasir Arafat. It added that these measures would be reviewed once "terrorist bases had been destroyed".

The Israeli government further decided to include Force 17 in the list of terrorist organizations. Force 17 is the Palestinian security force charged with protection of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and is the military arm of the Fateh movement led by Yasir Arafat.

An Israeli official who asked to remain anonymous reported that Labour ministers left the meeting before votes were cast on these measures in an expression of their reservations at the measures adopted against the Palestinian Authority.
The official did not give any information about the number or identity of the ministers expressing reservations. The resolutions were supported by 17 votes with 1 vote against.

hl.seg: Syria and Yemen condemn "organized Israeli terrorism"

p.seg: Damascus 3/12 (AFP) Syria and Yemen have condemned the "organized terrorism perpetrated by the Israeli occupying authorities", which carried out attacks against prominent members of the Palestinian Authority in Gaza and the West Bank on Monday.

The condemnation came during a meeting between Syrian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Farouq al-Shara', and his Yemeni counterpart, Abu Bakr al-Qurbi, who today began a tour of Arab states in Damascus according to the official Syrian Press Agency.
Both ministers confirmed "the importance of strengthening national unity between Palestinian groups" and "of a decisive Arab stance to combat Israeli suppression".
The official Yemeni press agency reported that Al-Qurbi would deliver letters from the Yemeni President Ali Abdallah Salih, who recently visited the US, to the leaders of Syria, Jordan and Iraq.
Yemen, Syria and Jordan strongly oppose any attack on Iraq that the US might propose as part of its war on terrorism.
Elsewhere, about 150 Palestinian demonstrated on Monday evening in the Yarmuk Camp and the suburbs of Damascus against the Israeli raids on Palestinian territory.
According to the France Press correspondent, the demonstrators, who carried a Palestinian flag, shouted "Arab Palestine".

This evening Israel carried out raids against Gaza and the West Bank in response to the attacks last Saturday and Sunday by Hamas in West Jerusalem, which led to the deaths of 31 and wounded more than 200.

hl.seg: 2002 Winter Olympics: Muhammad Ali lights the Olympic torch

p.seg: Atlanta, US, 4/12 (AFP) Former Olympic heavyweight champion Muhammad Ali lit the Olympic torch which arrived in Atlanta, Georgia, on its way from Greece to Salt Lake City, which is to host the Winter Olympics next February.
Ali previously lit the torch for the Summer Olympics held in Atlanta in 1996.

Ali handed the flame to PJ Fleming, technical ice skating champion in the 1968 Olympics, and to her trainer, Bob Cole, who won gold in 1960, before it was passed to Dan O'Brien, decathlon champion at the Atlanta Olympics.
11500 people will take turns to carry the flame on its journey in the US until it reaches Salt Lake City on the 8th of February, on the evening before the opening ceremony.

hl.seg: Successful US missile intercept test

p.seg: Washington 4/12 (AFP) The Pentagon yesterday announced that the US had conducted a successful test to intercept and destroy a missile over the Pacific Ocean for the second time in succession. The test formed part of its controversial missile defense shield project.
The anti-missile defense test had been cancelled on Saturday for the second time within two days on account of bad weather.

The intercepting missile was fired from Kwajaien Atol, in the Marshal islands, about 20 minutes after a modified ballistic missile carrying an empty warhead was fired from the US Air Force base at Vandeburg, California.

The last successful test of this type to intercept and destroy a missile with an empty warhead above the Pacific Ocean took place on the 14th of July and stands as a remarkable success for the controversial American missile defense shield project.

hl.seg: Iraq condemns Israeli attacks against the Palestinian Authority's territory

p.seg: Baghdad 4/12 (AFP) The Iraqi Government, meeting on Tuesday under the leadership of Saddam Hussein, condemned the rise in "criminal" attacks carried out by Israel against Palestinian territory, according to the official Iraqi news agency.

The agency reported that "The Iraqi Council of Ministers, which has monitored Arab and international developments, condemned the criminal Zionist attacks carried out on a daily basis against our people in Palestine."
It went on, "The Council praised the lofty meaning, efforts and generous sacrifice of our people in Palestine in defending Palestine and the honour of the Arab nation."

Meanwhile al-Jumhuriya, the official newspaper in Iraq, stated that "suicide attacks were the only way to liberate Palestine". This follows suicide attacks which had killed 26, in addition to the five Palestinians who mounted them, by the end of the week.
On Monday and Tuesday Israeli helicopters and F-16 fighters mounted major operations against Palestinian territory.
Two Palestinians were killed and more than 100 wounded in an Israeli air strike today on the security headquarters of the Palestinian Authority in Gaza and Khan Yunis, south of the Gaza Strip.

hl.seg: Israeli army re-enters Bait Lahiya, north of Gaza Strip

p.seg: Gaza 3/12 (AFP) Israeli tanks today penetrated more than 1 km into territory under the control of the Palestinian Authority at Bait Lahiya, north of the Gaza Strip, for the second day in succession.
Inhabitants of the area told French Press, "at least two Israeli tanks penetrated more than 1 km into Palestinian territory under fire."
The sources added, "The Israeli tanks centered on the private American school on the outskirts of the village."
No information was available about casualties or damage resulting from the incursion.
On Monday Israeli tanks entered the same area a few hours after Israeli shelling targeted the landing pad for Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat near his presidential headquarters in the town of Gaza.

hl.seg: Repeat with correction to paragraph 2

p.seg: UK to train forces for attacks in Somalia, Sudan and Yemen (Press)

London 4/12 (AFP) British newspaper, the Independent, reported on Tuesday that Britain is to train certain military units for rapid attacks on specific targets in countries suspects of harbouring al-Qaeda terrorist cells, including Somalia, Sudan and Yemen.

The newspaper reported that UK defence minister Geoff Hoon (repeat Geoff Hoon) will, during a speech on strategic defence to be given on Wednesday, present plans for specific attacks to be carried out by military units tasked for such purpose.

The newspaper added that the response to the 9/11 attacks on the US will include a consolidation in force mobilization in Europe, which will speed up the European Rapid Reaction Force to comprise 60,000 troops.
The agency noted that Turkey, which had threatened to use its right of veto against the project, may change its position in the coming days, thereby facilitating its realization.

hl.seg: Karghistan prepared to open its air bases to NATO (official)

p.seg: Bashkik 4/12 (AFP) An official from Karghistan's Security Council announced on Tuesday that his country is prepared to allow NATO members, including France, Italy and Canada, to use its air bases for operations in Afghanistan.
Nur al-Din Tchumuyev, spokesman for the Security Council of this former Soviet republic in Asia Minor, announced that "Karghistan is prepared to open its air bases to NATO member states".
Officials in Karghistan announced last month that France, Italy and Canada had sought permission to use the air bases but that the authorities in Bashkik had not yet responded to the request.
Tchumuyev added, "The Karghistan parliament will sign all documents allowing the airports to be put at the disposal of these countries."
President Askar Akayev yesterday received senior French and American military officials.
On this occasion Karghistan announced its intent to provide additional support to the coalition against terror.
According to a State Department source, US Secretary of State Colin Powell is expected to arrive in Bashkik next Saturday to discuss Karghistan's co-operation with the coalition.

hl.seg: Mahir asks Washington to put pressure on Sharon

p.seg: Cairo 5/12 (AFP) Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ahmad Mahir, today asked the US to bring pressure to bear on the Israeli Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, to revoke the measures taken against "the Palestinian people and its leaders" and stressed the importance of "US intervention to the cycle of violence".

In an interview with Radio Cairo, Mahir, who is in Washington, said that he had asked his American counterpart, Colin Powell, during a telephone call yesterday to "put pressure on Israel to end the measures being taken against the Palestinian people and its leaders" and impressed upon him "the importance of action in light of his recent speech".
Mahir expressed the view that "Sharon must put an end to his policies of escalation and immediately resume talks with the Palestinians with the aim of reaching a final settlement."

He added that Powell had expressed "his readiness to co-operate with us" and his belief in "the importance of both sides taking measures to calm the situation, but that the Palestinians bore the greater share of the responsibility for the recent escalation, and that had head asked both sides to find a way out of this cycle".

He added, "What worries us all is the wicked attack on the person of Yasir Arafat and the Palestinian leadership and the attempt to make the Palestinian leadership bear responsibility for events the cause of which lies ultimately with the measures taken by Israel against the Palestinians."

hl.seg: Arafat visit to Moscow still on

p.seg: Moscow 5/12 (AFP) Interfax have quoted the Palestinian ambassador to Russia, Khairi al-Aridi, who said in statement on Wednesday that the planned visit of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to Moscow before the end of the year was still on.
He said, "These visits are always urgent because Russia plays an important role as a sponsor of the Middle East peace process."
On the 15th of November a spokesman for the Palestinian Embassy in Russia said that Arafat's visit to Moscow "was possible before the end of the year".

Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Igor Ivanov, said yesterday that Palestinian officials must take "harsh measures against extremist organizations to prevent them damaging the political settlement".

A suicide attack took place on Wednesday in Jerusalem following raids launched by the Israeli airforce on Tuesday and Wednesday against Palestinian targets in the West Bank and Gaza in response to suicide attacks that targeted Israel at the end of the week.
Israeli forces have mounted assassination attacks against Palestinians it deems to be terrorists.

hl.seg: Jordanian King expresses anxiety at Israeli attacks against Palestinians

p.seg: Amman 5/12 (AFP) The King of Jordan, King Abdallah II, expressed his "deep anxiety" following the Israeli attacks against the Palestinians during telephone conversations with US Secretary of State Colin Powell and Turkish President Ahmet Necdet Sezer according to the Jordanian Press Agency.

The Agency, quoting an official source, reported that during a telephone conversation with the Powell the King expressed "his deep anxiety at the Israeli military escalation against the Palestinians", stressing "the importance of the ongoing US role in limiting the extent of the violence" and "the pursuit of dialogue as the only means to resolve outstanding issues".

King Abdallah also discussed the escalation of violence in the Palestinian territories with Turkish President Ahmet Necdet Sezer. Both leaders stressed "the importance of working to intensify efforts to find a way out of the deteriorating security situation in the Palestinian territories".

On Tuesday the Turkish Prime Minister, Bulent Ecevit, condemned the stance adopted by his Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, who was "intent on imposing excessive and unjustified punishments against the Palestinian Authority and the Palestinian territories". He further warned of the possibility of a war, the results of which would be far more dangerous than the present situation in Afghanistan.
Israel has launched the most extensive wave of military operations in the Palestinian territories since 1994 in response to Palestinian resistance operations against Israelis.

hl.seg: Iraqi oil exports reach 18.7 million barrels in one week

p.seg: New York, United Nations, 5/12 (AFP) The United Nations announced that Iraq had exported

18.7 million barrels of oil last week, recording an increase in exports compared with the previous week. In doing so, however, it matched the maximum limit allowed under formula for the most recent phase of the Oil for Food Program but did not exceed permitted levels.

It is expected that Phase 10 of the humanitarian program, which covers the six months ending on 30 November, will produce export revenues allowing the import of food and medicine to the value of 5.5 billion dollars. Iraqi imports, however, have not exceeded 3.8 billion dollars.
The remaining profit, a total of 1.7 billion dollars, is due to a reduction in Iraqi oil prices, which fell last week to 17.85 Euros per barrel (15.75 dollars) compared to
24.30 Euros in mid-September.
Last week's exports constitute the largest since the introduction of the Oil for Food program five years ago.
Phase 11 of the Oil for Food program, which has been in operation since 1996, began last Saturday. Iraq is expected to submit an implementation program to the UN this month.

hl.seg: Islamic Conference Organisation calls on UN to investigate Jhangi massacre

p.seg: Riyadh 5/12 (AFP) On Wednesday the Secretary-General of the Islamic Conference Organisation, Abd al-Wahid Bilqiz, called on the United Nations to investigate the massacre at Jhangi fort, near Mizar al-Sharif, where foreign prisoners fighting in the Taliban ranks were killed.

In a letter addressed to the UN Secretary-General, Kofi Anan, Bilqiz called on the United Nations to investigate the massacre for which there is information to suggest that 160 Taliban and foreign prisoners were killed.
Meanwhile the Northern Alliance reported that the operation to suppress resistance at Jhangi fort, which was supported by US and UK commando units, resulted in the deaths of at least 450.
Bilqiz expressed "the condemnation of the Islamic states at the massacre, in which 100s of prisoners were killed" and the belief that "what happened to them contravenes the Geneva Convention
for the Treatment of Prisoners, signed in 1949."
Bilqiz called on Anan "to open an investigation to uncover what really happened and to guarantee that there would be no repeat of similar such acts in other areas of Afghanistan".

Bilqiz expressed satisfaction at "the positive efforts being made by the UN to bring about peace and security in Afghanistan and its success in bringing together all the principal Afghan groups to form a transitional government to pave the way for the country's return to stability".

hl.seg: Security Council welcomes Bonn Accord

p.seg: New York, United Nations, 6/12 (AFP) On Wednesday the Security Council welcomed the Bonn Accord which resulted in the formation of an Afghan government but postponed a resolution on the formation of an international force to support that government.
Security Council members held a closed meeting, which lasted for about 2 hours, to discuss a draft resolution on the Bonn Accord.

The brief statement distributed to journalists called on states providing aid and organizations "to renew their affirmation, and to consolidate and implement their commitments, to provide aid to rebuild and reconstruct Afghanistan".
But some diplomats announced that the US has stressed the importance of waiting until Thursday before submitting the draft resolution for a vote to be taken.
Farid Ekhart, spokesman for the United Nations, said that it was not clear whether the Council would approve the deployment of troops outside Kabul.
He noted, "Kabul is fundamental because representatives of all these groups will travel there."
Diplomats explained that the Security Council may approve the Bonn Accord with two days by a resolution but without agreeing to the security force.

hl.seg: Swiss national wishes to rebuild two giant Buddha statues in Bamyan

p.seg: Bal, Switzerland, 5/12 (AFP) The director of a small museum located in Bonnborg, near Bal, Switzerland, which specializes in Afghanistan, has proposed that the two giant statues of Buddha destroyed by fundamentalist Taliban militias be rebuilt.

Paul Pashirir, director of the Afghanistan museum and institute, explained to ATC, the Swiss press agency, that the project would require the two statues of Buddha, which were 53 meters high and had been carved out more than 1500 years ago, to be rebuilt.
He said, "We are doing this at the request of authorized persons in the new local government." Atiya al-Hazara, a Shiite, has returned to power following the expulsion of the Taliban from Bamyan.
The Swiss museum possesses a detailed statement of the size of the two statues prepared by the Austrian Robert Costla in 1970.
On the basis of these measurements, the museum is proposing to create a model of the two Buddha statues to facilitate their reconstruction.

Pashirir said that it would be possible to commence construction of two life-size statutes "once calm has returned, if the new Afghan government invites us to do so." He believed that the project would be of interest to UNESCO.
He added that the reconstruction of the two statues would bring back tourism to Bamyan.
He noted, "Until the mid-1980s these two statues were the face of tourism [in Bamyan] and were well received," providing a living for about one million people.

hl.seg: Jack Straw: All those sheltering terrorists must be brought to justice

p.seg: London 7/12 (AFP) UK Foreign Minister Jack Straw announced in a statement yesterday that "all those sheltering terrorists must be brought to justice" in response to information suggesting that Mullah Omar might negotiate his surrender.
Straw said, "All those who shelter terrorists and who have committed terrorist acts must be brought to justice" but he added that their guilt would depend on the evidence brought against them.

An American spokesman from the international coalition fighting the war on terror yesterday announced that the Taliban's supreme leader may be holding talks about his surrender in Qandahar with Hamad Karzai, leader of the Pashtun, who has been appointed leader of the future transitional government in Afghanistan.

The American secretaries of state and defense, Colin Powell and Donald Rumsfield, announced on Sunday that the US would not permit the supreme leader of the Taliban movement, Mulla Omar, to make an agreement with anyone in order to escape justice.

Powell said, "We have examined the information which suggests there has been an attempt to negotiate but there can be no possible agreement." He stressed that Mulla Omar is a wanted man in exactly the same way that Osama bin Ladin, who the US accuse of preparing the 9/11 attacks on Washington and New York, is wanted.

hl.seg: Moratinos arrives in Egypt for talks

p.seg: Cairo 6/12 (AFP) A transport source reported that the European envoy to the Middle East, Miguel Angel Moratinos, arrived on Thursday in Cairo where he is to hold talks on the latest developments in the region.

A source in the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced yesterday that "Moratinos will inform Egyptian officials of the results of European Union contacts with relevant parties to put an end to the violence and kick start the peace process" between Israel and the Palestinians.

The source continued, "The visit of the European delegation forms part of Egypt and the European Union's efforts to calm the situation, especially following the recent escalation in the Occupied Territories."

The European delegation in Cairo told France Press that Moratinus "would meet during the 24-hour visit with Osama al-Baz, Political Advisor to the Egyptian President, and Amr Musa, Secretary-General of the Arab League.

Mauratinus was to have met with Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs Ahmad Mahir, but the meeting was postponed due to Mahir's meetings with Israeli Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, and Chairman of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat, in Israel and the Palestinian territories.
Sources added that Mauratinus is to meet with ambassadors of European states in Cairo,
and that he had arrived from Tel Aviv, where he will return. He will not visit any other countries on his present tour.

hl.seg: Call from ISESCO to protect Palestinian schools

p.seg: Rabat 6/12 (AFP) The Islamic Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (ISESCO), whose headquarters are in Rabat, called on the United National Education, Science and Culture Organisation (UNESCO)to make an urgent intervention to limit acts of Israeli violence against Palestinian students.

This call came in a letter address from the Director General of ISESCO, Abd al-Aziz al-Tawajiri, to the Director General of UNESCO, Kushiro Matsura, following Israeli attacks on Monday and Tuesday against a number of Palestinian institutions during which two Palestinians were killed and 120 wounded, including 60 pupils.
In the letter ISESCO expressed "concern" at the "massacre perpetrated by Israeli forces against Palestinian students".
The letter also said that the Israeli forces "do not hesitate to use the most lethal weaponry or to destroy schools, colleges and institutes, even when students and teachers are inside."
Al-Tawajiri told Kushiro that "ISESCO called on your organization to move at the appropriate time and to take the necessary decisions."
Meanwhile ISESCO called on its Member States "to provide aid for the Palestinian people in these difficult circumstances".
ISESCO forms part of the Islamic Conference Organisation, whose headquarters are in Jeddah and which includes 56 Islamic countries.

hl.seg: Armed man detained near the White House

p.seg: Washington 6/12 (AFP) The office of the Secret Service, which is charged with protecting the American President, reported that their officers detained a man behaving strangely and carrying weapons on Thursday morning near the White House. He is being held pending further investigations.

Secret Service spokesman Tony Paul explained that the police, who were interrogating the man this morning in an attempt to find out the reasons for his actions, discovered, in addition to a knife and a 30 cm blade in his possession, a number of loaded weapons in his car.
Police officers discovered a loaded AKS assault rifle in the seat of the man's car, a small Dodge truck registered in Idaho.
The intensive search operation also revealed a rifle with sight, a loaded pistol and a bullet-proof vest.
Spokesman for the White House, Ari Fletcher, told reporters that President Bush, who was in the White House at the time, "was not threatened at any time".
He added, "He continued his day without disturbance."
The identity of the man, who is awaiting a formal charge according to Tony Paul, has not been revealed.

hl.seg: Princess Sophie sad and in shock at ectopic pregnancy

p.seg: (picture attached)

London 7/12 (AFP) Sophie, Countess of Wessex, who was transferred on Thursday to a London hospital after being diagnosed with an ectopic pregnancy according to the newspapers is "very sad and in shock" a Buckingham Palace source said on Friday.

A palace spokeswoman told France Press that the Countess (aged 36) had "spent a quiet night" in King Edward VII Hospital, where she was transferred by helicopter as an emergency patient on Thursday morning.
She added, "We believe she will spend a number of days in hospital."

The Countess and her husband, Prince Edward (aged 37), the spokeswoman added, were suffering from "great sadness and shock" following the operation. But she did not specify officially the nature of the operation.
On Friday most British newspapers reported that Sophie, who was in her sixth week, had suffered from complications arising from the pregnancy, which she had kept secret.

The newspapers added that the Countess, who had suffered sever abdominal pain on Thursday, underwent surgery following diagnosis of an ectopic pregnancy, which can have severe medical consequences and may affect her chances of becoming pregnant in the future.
Sophie had previously told the News of the World last April that she wished to have a baby and indicated that she was prepared "to try different possibilities", including "test-tube fertilization".

hl.seg: Asylum granted in France for refusal of female circumcision

p.seg: Paris 7/12 (AFB) A refugee committee in France today granted asylum to a married couple from Mali who refused to subject their daughter to circumcision.
In a statement the committee said that these decisions "confirm and determine" the rulings of a similar decision in 1991.

The committee issued its decision following the refusal of the French Office for the Protection of Refugees and Non-Nationals to grant asylum to the Mali couple Musa and Nasira Sisuku, who refused to subject their daughter, who was born in September 1999, to circumcision, and to a Somali woman whose daughter died as a result of a circumcision operation carried out without the knowledge of the mother.
In a third case studied by the committee today a Ghanaian woman was refused refugee status whilst confirming that she had been subject to circumcision by force.
Annually, two million girls undergo circumcision according to the Balance and Peoples Organization, including 30 thousand in France.
According to Dominique Bauble from the Organization, circumcision is on the rise in France.

Frequently African women who have lived in France for 20 years are ignorant of the fact that these practices have changed in their countries and that laws have been passed prohibiting circumcision (such as Senegal, Burkina Faso and Ghana).
Whilst circumcision is usually carried out at an early age (one or two years of age) in Africa, families in France sometimes wait until they are of marriageable age.

hl.seg: Chechen rebels confirm six Russian soldiers killed

p.seg: Sliptsovsek (Russia) 7/12 (AFP) A spokesman for the Chechen separatist leader Aslan Maskhedov told French Press today that Chechen rebels in the northern Caucasus had killed five Russian soldiers and one senior police official.

He added that the Chechen rebels said that the official responsible for criminal investigations in the town of Godrimis (30 km east of the capital Grozny)was killed following "a long and carefully prepared operation". Only the family name of the official, Turnokiev, was revealed.

Five Russian soldiers were also killed in a number of attacks mounted against Russian federal forces in Grozny, and in the areas of Vidino and Shirshen-Yurt in the south-east of the separatist republic.
Daily confrontations continue in the Chechnya despite attempts since the last month to start direct peace talks between the two sides.
Russian forces entered Chechnya on 1st October 1999 to limit the separatist authority, but they continue to face daily harassment by the rebels.

hl.seg: Bin Ladin's mother not angry with him

p.seg: Riyadh 8/12 (AFP) A Saudi newspaper today reported that the mother of extreme fundamentalist Osama bin Ladin confirmed that she was not angry with her son, though she "did not agree" with his aspirations or "his opinions or the actions attributed to him".
Al-Madinah quoted the following words of bin Ladin's mother: "I do not agree with his aspirations, opinions or the actions attributed to him". She denied "reports that she was angry with her son".
She added that she "was, like any mother, satisfied with her son and wished him peace and guidance".
Bin Ladin's mother, whose name was not mentioned by the newspaper, criticized reports published in the media about her family, her eldest sons and about her personally.

Last October, the New York Times reported that Bin Ladin had contacted his mother by telephone on the eve of the attacks on New York and Washington to tell her that "something important" was about to happen. But this was denied by a member of the family.
Bin Ladin's mother called on the "Islamic media" not to "fall into the idolatry of the western media by transmitting such information without first verifying it".

hl.seg: Lebanese Prime Minister travels to Paris

p.seg: Beirut 8/12 (AFP) An official source reported that Lebanese Prime Minister Rafiq al-Hariri today left for Paris where he is to meet with French Prime Minister Jacque Chirac to discuss the regional and international situation and bilateral relations.
Chirac will receive al-Hariri on Sunday morning at 10:30 am in the Elys�e according to the French presidential media office.
Al-Hariri is accompanied by Finance Minister, Fuad al-Sanyura, and Minister of Trade and Economy, Basil Fulaihan, according to the national press agency.

Sources close to al-Hariri report that he and Chirac will discuss the signing of a partnership agreement with the European Union which is now open for re-examination following a recent British request for the inclusion of a clause on co-operation against terrorism.

Al-Hariri will also discuss an invitation to hold a meeting of international sponsors to the so-called Paris 2 Conference to support the Lebanese economy, which is facing an unprecedented crisis. It has been decided that the conference will be held following Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon in May 2000 following 22 years of occupation.

hl.seg: Relief in Berlin following release of German hostage in Yemen

p.seg: Berlin 8/12 (FB) German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer today expressed "relief" following the release of the German hostage who has been held captive in Yemen by members of a tribe since 298 November. He thanked Sanaa for its efforts to mediate.
A statement issued by the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs said, "Minister Joschka Fischer was relieved at the news and thanked the Yemeni government for its efforts."
The statement reported that the hostage was in good condition and was at a safe location near Marib,
170 km from Sanaa in the charge of the German ambassador to Yemen.
A Yemeni official in the governorate of Marib announced that Yemeni armed forces and police had succeeded in securing the release of the hostage today and had detained one of the kidnappers.
On Tuesday evening members of the armed forces and police launched a military operation to release the hostage, which resulted in the deaths of at least five people, including two policemen.
The former hostage is in his fifties and director of the technical department of the Yemeni branch of the German car manufacturer, Mercedes.
He had been kidnapped outside his house on the 28th of November in an area of Sanaa inhabited by a large number of foreigners.

hl.seg: Assassination of two workers, head of a municipal council wounded in Algeria

p.seg: Algeria 8/12 (FB) An official source announced today that two workers had been assassinated and the head of a municipal council wounded on Friday evening in Algeria in two attacks attributed to the Armed Islamic Group (GIA).

An armed group succeeded in killing two workers at a sand workshop in Taibarkamin, near Ain al-Dalfa (160 km west of the capital), opening fire at their vehicle whilst they were on their way to work. Two other workers were injured.
The head of the municipal council for al-Qadiriya, which is located near al-Bawaira (120 km south-east of the capital) was wounded in an attempt on his life.
Security forces, who entered immediately, killed one of the armed men who tried to flee.
Since the beginning of Ramadan on 16 November 58 people have been killed in Algeria according to a total prepared using official and press statistics.
On Thursday evening 17 people were killed and four others wounded in the state of Ain al-Dalfa (160 km west of the capital).
The GIA usually become active in this month, during which Algerians anxiously await their attacks.

hl.seg: German detained for selling munitions to Iraq (press)

p.seg: Hamburg 8/12 (AFP) The weekly magazine Der Spiegel has reported in next Monday's edition that a German national suspected of acting as a broker in the sale of equipment with military applications to Iraq was detained in prison on the 27th of October.

The prosecutor in Menheim (south-west) and the police and customs in Cologne (west) had begun investigations with the German, a mechanical engineer on a charge of "suspicion of violating the embargo imposed on Iraq".
The Menheim prosecutor, Hober Jobsky, announced that "he is suspected of brokering the sale" of equipment with military applications.
Jobsky said that he believed that the first shipment of this equipment, including a drill capable of cutting gun barrels from sheet metal may have been transferred to Iraq via Jordan.
He expressed his fear that these guns could be use "to fire nuclear, biological and chemical ammunition".
According to the magazine Iraq had consulted German companies with the purpose of supplying sophisticated technology to build a large caliber gun.
Since 1990 the UN has imposed an embargo on Iraq banning it in particular from conducting any trade linked to armaments.
Since 1996 the Oil for Food program has allowed Baghdad to sell crude oil under tight international supervision in order to buy food and medical supplies.

hl.seg: Egyptian Kammouna on route to signing agreement

p.seg: Riyadh 9/12 (AFP) The former striker to the Egyptian national team and the al-Ahli club, Samir Kammouna, arrived in al-Dammam to put the final touches to the contract that will tie him to the al-Ittifaq club, which lies in 7th place in the Saudi football league.

Engineer Khalid bin Ali Al-Dusri, chairman of the club, announced that Kammouna was a famous player in the Arab world and did not need a trial. "We await the medical examination in order to sign the contract," he added.

An official source in the al-Ittifaq administration confirmed that agreement had been reached with the player on an initial payment of 55 thousand dollars and a salary of four thousand dollars over a period of four months.

Al-Ahli lent Kammouna to Boursat al-Turki in return for 200 thousand dollars to the Egyptian club and 100 thousand dollars to the player in view of his being suspended for one year by the Egyptian Federation on account of his behavior during a match against al-Mahallah in last season's cup competition.
Kammouna returned to al-Ahli in the middle of last season from the German club Kaiserslautern after an unsuccessful professional journey that had lasted two years.

hl.seg: Perez: Negotiations are the only way to establish peace

p.seg: Jerusalem 9/12 (AFP) Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Perez said today that negotiations with the Palestinians were the only way to find peace.
In an interview with CNN he said, "I want to tell you that I do not believe that there is any other way but negotiation to peace.
Peace cannot be imposed but can only be realised by agreement. It cannot be unilaterally imposed by force."
He added, "Many agree, and they are right, that you cannot bring about a ceasefire by firing your weapons.
We must also give [the Palestinians] hope and political horizons."

In a reference to the Mitchell report Perez added , "We said to our Palestinian neighbours that when we reach a ceasefire then we will be able to make progress on other stages by taking measures to restore confidence and negotiations."
He further said, "Continuing the confrontation through bombs and shooting is a waste of time and a loss of human life." He stressed that he had not lost hope.

The Mitchell Committee report recommended an end to violence followed by measures which aim to restore confidence, such as a freeze on settlement, giving the Israeli and Palestinians the chance to return to the negotiating table.

hl.seg: Dustum opposes the results of the Bonn conference but he will not resort to weapons

p.seg: Heraton, Afghanistan, 9/12 (AFP) The leader of the Uzbeck party, Abd al-Rashid Dustum, today expressed his objection to the results of the Bonn conference but he gave an undertaking not to resort to arms to express his opposition.
He said that the Bonn conference, which, on Wednesday, determined the framework for a transitional Afghan administration, "had not gone as he would have liked."
"Despite the results, however, there would not be a war and power would not be shared after today by resorting to arms."
General Dustum has been fighting beside the Northern Alliance, but the Alliance has not always held firm in the past.
At Heraton, by the border with Uzbekistan, he said, "Some say that General Dustum will cause bloodshed and start a war."
"This is not true. We will hold talks in Kabul and reestablish the force of law."

Regarding the military situation in the country, General Dustum confirmed the presence of "Taliban elements who are not fighting but hiding in Mazar al-Sharif" and other cities. He intended to expel them from such places.
He added, "I do not think it impossible that they could be hiding in Qunduz, Baqlan and Prishna."
"From tomorrow [Monday], and within two days, we will clear these areas of the terrorists."
He warned that he would impose "harsh punishments" against those who provided shelter to Taliban elements adding that "the world would not allow the return of the terrorists".

hl.seg: Putin concludes official visit to Greece and moves on to Hanover

p.seg: Salonica (Greece) 9/12 (AFP) Transport sources report that Russian President Vladimir Putin today left Salonica (north) heading for Hanover (Germany) at the end of an official visit to Greece which lasted 3 days and aimed to consolidate bilateral cooperation, in particular in the energy sector.

Putin, who arrived last Thursday in Athena, concluded his visit in Salonica yesterday when bad weather prevented him from carrying out a planned visit to Mt Atos, one of the most important Orthodox sites.
He will be met in Hanover by German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder in the latter's private home for an unofficial meeting.
Putin's visit to Greece aimed to strengthen bilateral cooperation and focused on economics, in particular the energy sector. Russia hopes to break into EU markets.
Six cooperation agreements were signed, one concerning the energy sector and the remainder focusing on marine trade, air transport, fighting crime and scientific and cultural exchange.
In the political sphere, both countries expressed agreement on most international problems, in particular those of the Balkans.
Putin also received Greek support for the desire he has expressed for continued close contacts with NATO and the EU.

hl.seg: Clashes between Palestinian police and Hamas cadres in Gaza

p.seg: Gaza 9/12 (AFP) Eye witnesses reported that clashes occurred today between members of the Islamic Resistance Movement (Hamas) and members of the Palestinian security forces trying to detain a Hamas activist in Gaza.
The source added that tens of Hamas cadres threw stones at the police when they arrived at the home of the activist in al-Shati' camp in order to detain him.
At least one member of the police was injured and damage was caused to two police vehicles.
The police fired in the air to disperse the crowd.
Witnesses reported that the activist managed to escape.
About 300 inhabitants from the camp later met in front of the al-Shati' mosque before heading for a police station close by to throw stones at the building.
Police again fired into the air to disperse the crowd but tension ran high this afternoon.

On Thursday a Hamas activist died as a result of bullet wounds received on Wednesday in clashes with Palestinian police, who had come to enforce the decision imposed by the Palestinian authority to place the spiritual leader of Hamas, Shaikh Ahmad Yasin, under house arrest.

The Palestinian Authority, which had been warned by both Israel and the US, has carried out a campaign of arrests in the ranks of Islamists following a series of suicide attacks, for which Hamas claimed responsibility and in which 31 died and more than 200 were wounded during the period between 1-2 December.

hl.seg: (Repeat as precaution)

p.seg: Japanese Championship: Kashima Antlers keeps the title
Tokyo 8/12 (AFP) Kashima Antlers won the Japanese football championship by defeating Jubilo Iwata with a golden goal 1-0 at the end of today's final at the Kashima stadium.
Mitsu Ugasawara scored the only goal of the match in the 100th minute.
Kashima Antlers, home champions, secured a valuable draw with ten players against Jubilo Iwata, away champions, in the away leg two weeks ago.
The Japanese league does not follow the away-goals rule and so the teams were required to play two further halves to determine the winner.
Ugasawara scored the only goal from a direct free kick at a distance of 25 meters.

Jubilo Iwata had a golden opportunity to score the golden goal in the 94th minute when the ball fell before Nurihiro Nishi who struck it from the penalty spot, but international keeper Hitushi Sugahata deflected it for a corner.
This is the fourth time that Kashima have won the title. They previously won the championship in 1996, 1998 and 2000.

Kashima, who are coached by the Brazilian Antonio Carlos, came 11th in the away championship and won the treble last season (home championship, league champions and the cup). Jubilo Iwata claimed the Asia championship in 1999 and the title on two occasions in 1997 and 1999.

hl.seg: Lebanon and Syria sign gas agreement

p.seg: Beirut 9/12 (AFP) An official source announced today that Lebanon and Syria have signed a gas agreement, to come into effect within 9 months, which will halve the cost of electricity in Lebanon.
The agreement was signed by Minister of Energy and Water Resources Muhammad Abd al-Hamid Baidun and Syrian Minister of Oil Mahir Jamal.

Baidun said that the agreement provided for a 45 km gas pipe line to be laid, 15 km in Syrian territory and 30 km in Lebanese territory, to provide the al-Badawi electricity plant in northern Lebanon with Syrian gas.

Baidun explained that the agreement provided for the delivery of an increasing amount of gas in three phases: 1.5 million cubic meters per day in the first phase; 3.5 million cubic meters per day in the second phase; and 6 million cubic meters per day in the third phase. The duration of each of these three phases was not specified.
He added that this represented the beginning of a strategic development in consumption that will lead to a two-thirds reduction in the cost of fuels needed to operate the al-Badawi plant.
He also said that the cost of producing 1 kW of electricity would be reduced by half, from the current price of 7 cents to somewhere in the region of 2.7-3.2 cents.

Lebanon and Syria, which have been linked since 1991 by a "Brotherhood, Cooperation and Coordination Treaty", concluded in 1998 agreements to establish a gas pipe network to feed Lebanese electricity plants with Syrian gas.

hl.seg: American military in Somali spying mission (press)

p.seg: London 11/12 (AFP) British newspaper the Daily Telegraph reported today that American officers had arrived secretly in Somalia, which, it believed, indicated the intent of US President George Bush to widen the war on terror to countries other than Afghanistan.
The newspaper reported that five officers had contacted one of the rebel groups in Paidawa, 240 km west of Maqdisho, in search of terrorist camps.
The newspaper, quoting an official from the Rahanuin rebel army, added that they had contacted the leaders of this movement and had visited an airport and a number of military camps.
Since the 9/11 attacks the US has taken measures against Somalis and Somali organizations.
The Islamic fundamentalist organisation al-Ittihad, which is based in Somalia, was cited in the list drawn up by Washington of organisations with links to international terrorism.
On Sunday Somalia wholly denied the presence of al-Qaeda elements or any Somali Islamic organisation in its territory.

The Somali Presidential Delegate to Khartum, Yusif Hasan Ibrahim, told France Press that "the reports were mistaken, because there are no al-Qaeda bases or camps in Somalia, and most Somalis only heard about al-Qaeda after the 9/11 attacks on New York and Washington".

hl.seg: American Professional League: New Sacramento Victory

p.seg: Washington 10/12 (AFP)Sacramento Kings won a new victory, their 16th this season with only 5 defeats, after beating Miami Heat 95-88 yesterday in the American Professional Basketball League.

Sacramento star Chris Webber, who entered his first game this season after recovering from an anklebone injury during a preparation game on the 14th of last October, scored 18 points, 14 in the second half, giving his team their best start in its history.
At the start of this season Webber renewed his contract with his current team for a period of 7 years in return for 123 million dollars.
Yugoslav Predrag Stojakovic also scored 23 points for the winning team making him the best scorer for the team on 12 occasions this season.
Elsewhere, the Detroit Pistons defeated Houston Rockets 105-77, Los Angeles Clippers beat the Charlotte Hornets 89-78 and Toronto Raptors lost 90-91 to Phoenix Suns.

hl.seg: US Ambassador in Beirut: Hizbullah is a terrorist movement

p.seg: Beirut 10/12 (AFP) US Ambassador to Beirut, Vincent Battle, announced yesterday evening that the statement made by Lebanese President, Emil Lahud, in which he said that Lebanese Hizbullah was not a terrorist movement "had not convinced the US".

In a television interview with the Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation, exerts of which were published by the al-Nahar newspaper today, Patel said that "what President Lahud said about the purely local range of Hizbullah had not convinced the US".
He said, "Hizbullah is on the list of terrorist organizations because it is an organization that carries out terrorist acts and is able to do so internationally and in a comprehensive manner."
He accused Hizbullah of training activists opposed to Israel in Islamic organizations such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad.
He added, "Hizbullah must renounce terrorism, and if you want to label these activities 'resistance', then resistance fighters must not resort to terrorist methods."

Lebanon agreed to the UN resolution to freeze the deposits of terrorist groups and entities but Beirut refuses to freeze Hizbullah funds as Washington has sought. It further wants the US to withdraw Hizbullah from the list of terrorist organizations.
Without UN approval, Washington published on the 2nd of November an additional list including the names of 22 organizations it deems to be terrorist, including Hizbullah.
Britain has also included the Foreign Security Organization of Hizbullah on a list of 25 organizations it deems to be terrorist.

hl.seg: Wife of Nagib Mahfouz asks for main Cairo road to be named after her husband

p.seg: Cairo 10/12 (AFP) The wife of Nagib Mahfouz, Mrs Atiyallah, today asked the Governor of Giza, Mahmoud Abu Lail, "to name one of the main roads after her husband given that their home runs parallel to the Nile in the Agouza district".

She told a gathering which included a number of cultural luminaries on the occasion of her husband's 90th birthday that "a writer of Nagib Mahfouz's talent and ability deserved to have a main road named after him and not the small side-street that runs parallel to their home, which is one of the most prominent locations in Giza".
A number of poets, writers, journalists and publishers went to the house to offer their congratulations.

After being subject to routine search procedures carried out by the guards who have been charged with protecting Mahfouz since the 1994 attack on him by Islamic fundamentalists, the visitors noticed a wooden plaque above the door to the flat bearing a Quranic inscription.

The novelist greeted his guests standing and received his present from the Egyptian Lebanese Publishing House, a copy of seven books published by the House, five containing articles written by Mahfouz and published in the al-Ahram newspaper between 1974 and 1988 on various topics, such as "Piety and Extremism", "Knowledge and Work", "Fairness and Justice", "Liberation and Progress" and "Arabs and Arabism".

hl.seg: Two Lebanese journalists transferred to military court on charges of "contact with Israel"

p.seg: Beirut 10/12 (AFP) A legal source reports that two Lebanese journalists detained last August during arrests in the ranks of Christians opposed to the Syrian presence in Lebanon were today transferred to the military court in Beirut.

Habib Yunis, editor's secretary in the Beirut office of al-Hayat, which is published in Lebanon, and Antwan Basil, correspondent of MBC, the Saudi satellite station, were charged with "having contact with the Zionist entity", with "instigating a gathering which aimed to wrong the authority of state", with "disturbing relations between Lebanon and the fellow state of Syria" and with "illegal entry of Israeli territory", according to the charge sheet.
They could be sentenced to death.

Basil was referred to the judiciary last Wednesday on a separate charge of facilitating contacts between the advisor to the banned Christian Lebanese Forces Party, Tawfiq al-Hindi, who was also detained last August, and an Israeli official.
Al-Hindi was on Wednesday transferred to the military court in Beirut on the same charges.
He is accused specifically of telephoning an Israeli official from Paris to coordinate a media campaign against the Syrian military presence in Lebanon.

hl.seg: Hungary beat Oman 3-1

p.seg: London 10/12 (AFP) The Omani national team today lost 3-1 to their Hungarian counterparts in a friendly international match held at the Sultan Qabus Complex in Muscat as part of the Omanis' preparations for the 15th Arab Gulf Cup, which is to be held in Saudi Arabia from the 16th to the 30th of next January.
Kristien (51st and 53rd minute) and Farkas (67th minute) scored the Hungarian goals with Hani al-Dhabit scoring that of Oman (67th minute).
The two teams drew nil-nil two days earlier.
The first half was a cautious affair and both teams lacked structure.
The first Omani attack was launched by Wali Ati who jumped to meet a ball placed by Saif al-Sultan and headed it just above the bar (3).
The Hungarian team responded when Kristien penetrated the area but stumbled, missing a good chance (5).

The situation changed completely in the second half when the Omani trainer made eight changes and Hungary managed to score 3 goals in the space of 16 minutes, the first when Walter Robert crossed into the area and Kristien headed the ball into the back of the net.
The second goal also bore the signature of Kristien, who was unmarked. Farkas scored the third with a long-range shot.
In the same minute, the referee awarded a corner to Oman which was taken by Jamal Bakhsh and headed home by Hani al-Dhabit to record Oman's only goal.

hl.seg: Freeman to return to track next March

p.seg: Melbourne, Australia, 10/12 (AFP) Australian sprinter Kathy Freeman, Olympic and world champion in the 400 meters, announced that she would return to international competition on the 8th of March in Melbourne.

Freeman (aged 29) had decided to stay away from competition for a complete year following the massive pressures she faced during the Sydney Olympics, in which she carried her country's flag before winning a gold medal.
Freeman, who began training 45 days ago under the supervision of her coach Peter Fortune, said, "I want with all my heart to return to competition as of next March at the Melbourne track".
She added, "I am training well, I am not sick and have never been as enthusiastic for this as I am at present."
Freeman, whose weight has increased 10 kg since the Sydney Olympics, continued, "I am training twice a day and my body is responding well."
Freeman is preparing to take part in the Commonwealth Games to be held in Manchester, UK, next July.

hl.seg: Brahimi: No opposition to deployment of international force

p.seg: Kabul 11/12 (AFP) Lakhdar Brahimi, Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary-General, announced on Tuesday evening in the Afghan capital that the Kabul authorities were not opposed to the deployment of an international force in the city.
Brahimi added, however, that he would deal in his talks today with the issue of the withdrawal of Northern Alliance troops from Kabul.
In a news conference Brahimi explained that this force "would come as a friend, not an enemy".
He added, "It does not want to fight anyone".

He said that he had obtained from the defense minister of the alliance, General Muhammad Qasim Fahim, confirmation "that the agreements (between Afghans) concluded in Bonn would be implemented in full, including anything relating to the multi-national force."
However, the UN Special Representative did not give any details about the composition, size or "leadership" or the force.

Officials from the Northern Alliance, whose forces have seized control of Kabul, have decided over the last few days that in the event that the international force is deployed in the Afghan capital by UN decision, it should be small in number and its tasks should be limited to protection of government buildings.

hl.seg: American-Saudi relations "strong" (Ambassador)

p.seg: Riyadh 11/12 (AFP) The Saudi ambassador in Washington confirmed on Tuesday that American-Saudi relations were "strong" despite the aggressive media campaign mounted in the West against the Saudi stance on combating terror.
The Saudi Press Agency quoted Prince Bandar bin Sultan as saying "American-Saudi relations are strong and based on mutual respect and common interests".
He believed that "everything that is being said about the poor treatment of Saudi nationals in the US is merely rumor".
He added, "Co-operation with the US administration is proceeding in the best possible manner."
He continued, "There are certain persons who do not want American-Saudi relations to be strong."
He did not specify who those "persons" might be.
Following the 9/11 attacks the western media, in particular that of the US, accused Saudi Arabia of acting leniently towards terrorism and tolerating religious extremism.
The list of those suspected of involvement in the 9/11 attacks includes a number of Saudis.
The Saudi press report that thousands of Saudi have been ill-treated in the US following the terror attacks.

hl.seg: 4 dead and 3 wounded in violence in Algeria (press)

p.seg: Algeria 11/12 (AFP) Four people were killed and three wounded during violence on Sunday in Algeria, according to press reports on Tuesday.
Two were killed and a third wounded at a false checkpoint set up by an armed Islamic group in al-Karmiya in the al-Shalaf area (200 km west of the capital), according to the press.

One person was killed and two others wounded at the hands of an armed group who opened fire on a cafe frequented by members of the security forces in Zighut Yusif in the Qasnatina area (430 km east of the capital), according to the same sources.

In addition to the above, an armed Islamist who "repented" and had been granted amnesty was assassinated in the town of Filfila in the area of Skikida (500 km east of the capital), according to the same sources.

Since the beginning of Ramadan, which extremist armed Islamic groups believe to be an impetus to "jihad" and "holy war", on the 16th of November, 69 people have died in acts of violence, according to figures prepared from official statistics and media reports.

hl.seg: FA Cup: Arsenal out and Spurs move on

p.seg: London 11/12 (AFP) Arsenal were knocked out of the English FA cup quarter-final, suffering a heavy loss to Blackburn 4-0 on Tuesday.
Arsenal played with a selection from the reserve team because it does not give much significance to this competition, despite the fact that the winner gains a place in the European Cup next season.
The star of the match was Blackburn striker Matt Yansen, who scored 3 goals in the 11th, 15th and 68th minute. Wales veteran Mark Hughes scored the other goal in the 21st minute.

In another match, former England attacker Les Ferdinand made himself star of the match when his team, Tottenham, played Bolton at home. Ferdinand scored three goals in the space of 9 minutes (29th, 30th and 38th) in a match which ended in a comprehensive victory 6-0.

Simon Davis opened the scoring for Tottenham in the 21st minute before Anthony Barnes, who scored an own goal in the 79th minute, and Stephan Everson, who scored in the 84th minute, added the last two goals.
Tomorrow, Chelsea play Newcastle and on Wednesday the 19th of his month Sheffield Wednesday meet Watford.

hl.seg: Jordan population exceeds five million in 2000 (official)

p.seg: Amman 11/12 (AFP) A recent periodical published by the Jordanian Public Statistics Department has reported that Jordan's population will reach 5 million and 40 thousand, compared with 4.9 million in 1999, an increase of 2.8%.

The Department said in the publication, quoted by the Jordanian press today, that almost 40% of Jordan's inhabitants live in the capital, Amman, whilst about half the population fall below 19 years of age.
The Department noted that 7% of employees in the country are foreigners.
The Jordanian workforce was estimated at 1 million 325 thousand in 2000.
Population growth in Jordan (2.8%) remains high but the impact of intensive birth control programs in recent years have reduced this rate from 3.5% in the 1990s.

In addition to natural population growth, the influx of Palestinian refugees to Jordan since the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948 and the return of almost 300 thousand Jordanians from the Gulf states in the first half of the 1990s have played a part in the population increase in the country.

hl.seg: End to proceedings against Lebanese Canadian suspected of possible links with Hizbullah

p.seg: Montreal 13/12 (AFP) A Canadian legal source announced that the Canadian judiciary had, on Wednesday, stopped proceedings against a Lebanese Canadian suspected of working for Hizbullah and detained in Vancouver (British Columbia, west) last October.
A spokeswoman for the High Court in British Columbia told French Press that Ali Adham Amhaz "had been cleared" of all charges directed against him.
She explained that the US had not persisted in the arrest warrant issued against him, which is the first stage in any extradition proceedings.

A court in the state of north Carolina, US, has accused Ali Adham Amhaz (aged 35) of working as part of an American cell with Lebanese Hizbullah, which purchased for him binoculars and night-vision glasses.
The US State Department has included Hizbullah on its list of terrorist organizations.
Amhaz, who was born in Lebanon and has lived in Canada since the 1980s, denied the charges brought against him.
The judge who ordered his release on bail said that there was insufficient evidence against him to justify his detention in prison.
The US has until tomorrow to submit a formal extradition request to the Canadian authorities.

hl.seg: Qatar championship: Qatar and al-Wakra draw 1-1

p.seg: Doha 12/12 (AFP) Qatar drew 1-1 at home to al-Wakra, the title holders, at the Hamad bin Khalifa stadium in the al-Ahli Club on Tuesday during the first match of the fourth stage of the Qatar football league.
Both teams now have 4 points.

Al-Wakra took the lead via al-Mirghani al-Zain following an individual effort by the Moroccan Yusif Ashmi, who beat more than one player, but his shot deflected off the defenders and fell to al-Zain, who played it to the right of the keeper (70).
Qatar secured an equalizer in the last minute through Angolan Fabris Akua, following a ball from Abdallah al-Hamad, which he headed into the net.
The match was refereed by Qatari international referee Jasim al-Hil.

Another match will be played next Thursday, between al-Rayan and al-Ittihad. The stage will be completed on Friday by two matches: al-Sadd, Arab champions, will meet al-Ahli, and al-Arabi will play al-Ittifaq.
Order [sic]
