The team played won equalized lost its points [sic]

hl.seg: Emergency meeting of Israeli security government yesterday evening

p.seg: Jerusalem 12/12 (AFP) The Israeli Prime Minister's office has reported that the security government was called to an emergency meeting yesterday evening to discuss how to respond to the bloody attack on an Israeli bus near the Emmanuel settlement in the north West Bank.

The same source reported that the Israeli Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, will hold talks before the meeting with Israeli defense minister, Benyamin Ben Eliezer and foreign minister Shimon Perez, within a scaled-down framework of government.
Israel blamed the Palestinian Authority for the bus attack on Wednesday in the north West Bank, which resulted in 8 Israeli dead and 30 wounded. The two Palestinians who opened fire were also killed.

But the Palestinian Authority condemned Wednesday's attack on the day it occurred and also the two suicide attacks that took place in the Gaza Strip and resulted in the deaths of the Palestinians involved.

hl.seg: Morocco and Mali draw 1-1

p.seg: Satat, Morocco, 12/12 (AFP) Morocco and Mali drew 1-1 today in Satat (160 km south of Rabat) in a friendly international football match as part of the teams' preparations for the finals of the African Nations Cup, which is to be held in Mali from the 19th of January to the 10th of February.
Yusif Shibo scored for Morocco in the 9th minute from a penalty kick and Bakayuku equalized for Mali in the 38th.
Mali beat Morocco 2-1 in the international friendly hosted by Mali last October.
The draw for the finals placed Morocco in Group 2 with South Africa, Burkina Faso and Ghana. Mali will play in Group 1 with Algeria, Nigeria and Liberia.
Morocco are to play to further friendly games at home: the first against Angola on the 12th of January and the second against Gambia on the 15th of January.

hl.seg: Israeli F-16 fighters circle above Nablus and Ramallah following Palestinian attack

p.seg: Nablus (West Bank)12/12 (AFP) Witnesses report that Israeli F-16 pursuit aircraft were circling the skies above Nablus and Ramallah in the West Bank this evening following a Palestinian attack on an Israeli bus near a neighboring Jewish settlement.
Palestinian security sources said that the Palestinian security organization buildings in Ramallah had been cleared in case of an Israeli revenge attack.

The Israeli army announced that at least 8 Israelis were killed and 30 wounded in the attack near the Emmanuel settlement, which lies between the towns of Nablus and Qalqiliya, both of which lie within the area of Palestinian self-rule.

At the beginning of December Israeli fighters and helicopters launched a series of attacks against Palestinian Authority targets in Gaza and the West Bank following a series of bloody Palestinian attacks which left 32 dead and 200 wounded in Israel.

hl.seg: 4 B-1 bomber crew members rescued

p.seg: Washington 12/12 (AFP) A spokesman for the US Defense Department announced that the 4 members of the US B-1 bomber that crashed into the Indian ocean today had been rescued.

The spokesman, Captain Timothy Taylor, said that the destroyer Russell headed for the accident site, which lies 50 km north of the British Diego Garcia island where the bombers are based, and rescued the four crew.
The B-1 Lancer bomber, which is participating in the military campaign in Afghanistan, crashed into the Indian ocean to the north of Diego Garcia, according to Victoria Clarke, Pentagon spokeswoman.
A statement by US Central Command, which oversees military operations in Afghanistan, said that the incident occurred at 16:00 GMT and that the cause was not known.
This is the first manned aircraft that the US has lost since Operation Enduring Freedom began on the 7th of October.

hl.seg: (Repeat of report 146 with correction to numbers)

p.seg: Sultanate of Oman reduces cost of entry visa and eases conditions
Muscat 12/12 (AFP) The Sultanate of Oman has decided to reduce the cost of entry visas with effect from the 5th of next January and to grant these visas at its airports to encourage tourism.

The Omani Ministry of Commerce and Industry announced in a joint statement with the police that the fee for the business visa would be 7 Omani riyals (18.23 USD), that of the tourist visa 5 Omani riyals (12.99 USD) and that granted to residents of Gulf states 3 Omani riyals (7.79 USD).
The Sultanate has created a gratis visa for visitors arriving by ship to any port who wish to remain for less than 24 hours.
The statement added that visas would also be given at other border points when the necessary facilities are ready.
Oman is trying to develop its tourism sector and aims to create jobs for Omanis and diversify its revenue sources.

hl.seg: Syria condemns terror attack against Indian parliament

p.seg: Damascus 13/12 (AFP) Syria today condemned the terror attack on the Indian parliament in New Delhi.

The Syrian Press Agency (Sana) quoted an official source in the Syrian Ministry of Foreign Affairs as saying that "Syria condemns the terror attack on the Indian parliament today, in which a number of innocent people were killed."

The Agency added, "The terror attack carried out by a group against the Indian parliament confirms once more the importance of fighting terrorism and dealing with its roots and causes within a UN framework, and of reaching just solutions to current international issues."
The Indian parliament was attacked at 11:40 (06:10 GMT)
this morning by an armed group of 6 people. No-one has yet claimed responsibility.
The Minister for Parliamentary Affairs, Baramud Mahajan, said that all the six attackers had been killed and that six policemen were also killed.
The shooting continued for 40 minutes.

hl.seg: EU grants Palestinian Authority 30 million Euro in new aid

p.seg: Brussels 13/12 (AFP) The European Commission today awarded the Palestinian Authority direct budget aid to the value of 30 million Euro to enable it to secure "the bare minimum of operation" in its administration, according to a spokesman in Brussels.
This aid will be paid over three months from December to February in tranches of 10 million Euro.
In fact, this amounts to a continuation of the same type of aid paid between May and November of this year, which amounted to 60 million Euro.
A team from the International Monetary Fund will supervise the use of the money to prevent corruption.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon last month asked the EU not to provide the Palestinian Authority with any aid, stating that it was being used to buy weapons.
Head of the European Commission Romano Prodi quickly responded by saying that "such charges had no basis".
But an EU spokesman for foreign affairs said today that "the Palestinian Authority was a vital partner in combating extremism and searching for peace".

hl.seg: Washington dismisses significance of rumors about use of Kenya base for operations against Somalia

p.seg: Nairobi 13/12 (AFP) The American embassy in Nairobi today dismissed the significance of rumors circulating in the local press which suggest that military facilities in Kenya will be used in any potential operation against Somalia, whom Washington has accused of sheltering terrorists.

A spokesman for the American mission told France Press, "During my last visit to Kenya the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Walter Kansteiner, did not discuss practical issues relating to the use of Kenyan facilities of military bases."

He added, "The [American] military operation is focused on Afghanistan." When asked if that meant that the US had decided not to bomb Somalia, he said that there was no scope to infer that from what he had said.
The Kenyan and international media had published rumors about the possibility of future American military operations against Somalia.
Kenyan newspaper the Nation wrote on its front page that "the US wants Kenya as a base in the war against terror".

Washington accused the fundamentalist Islamic Union organization of establishing relations with al-Qaeda, which is led by Osama bin Ladin. It also froze the assets of the Somali al-Barakat Group, which it accuses of funding al-Qaeda.

hl.seg: Arrest of opposition leader in Zimbabwe

p.seg: Harare 14/12 (AFP) Zimbabwe opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai was arrested at his home at dawn today and detained for several hours before being released.

Learnmore Jongwe, spokesman for the Movement for Democratic Change, which is headed by Tsvangirai, said, "The matter related to wireless communication equipment which the police found with three of his guards when they stormed his house. He noted that there had been no official charge.
He added, "The wireless equipment does not need a license.
It can be brought at any large store."
Following his release, Tsvangirai said , "I do not believe the matter related to a license for possession of a radio."
"They are just trying to irritate me."
Presidential elections in Zimbabwe have been set for March 2002.
Tsvangirai was arrested at 04:38 (02:38 GMT) at his home in the Harare suburbs.

hl.seg: Indian Parliament resumes business following bloody attack

p.seg: New Delhi 14/12 (AFP)Speaker for the Indian Chamber of Deputies GMC Balayughi announced that the Federal Parliament would resume business today in New Delhi following the attack mounted by a commando unit on the building in which 12 were killed and 20 wounded.
Commenting on events, Balayughi said, "This attack did not just target the parliament but the nation."
An official source reports that the Prime Minister, Bihari Fajbai will hold talks before the opening with the leaders of all political parties and the speakers of both chambers.
He will put before the two chambers a resolution on terrorism.
The parliament building was placed under military protection and checkpoints were established on roads leading to the building.
The commando unit comprised five men who yesterday attacked the Indian federal parliament building with automatic weapons and grenades, which led to a shoot-out lasting 40 minutes.
The attack left 12 dead, including the 5 attackers, 6 members of the security forces and a gardener.
Minister of Defense George Fernandez said that the authorities were attempting to "identify" the attackers.
He said, "We are in contact with the Kashmir police," indicating that the attack may be the work of Islamic separatists in Kashmir.

hl.seg: Fawani: Sharon is turning "a dispute over sovereignty" into "a religious war"

p.seg: Paris 15/12 (AFP) The Secretary-General of the French Green Party Dominique Fawani said in an address before her party's regional national conference today in Paris that Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was turning "a dispute over sovereignty" into "a religious war".
According to Fawani, "There are not many people to talk with on the Palestinian side other than Yasir Arafat despite the serious charges directed against his team, in particular that of corruption."
She said, "By resorting to confusion and by publishing biased reports, the present Israel government is turning a dispute over sovereignty into a religious war."
She continued, "We have gone from bad to worse, returning to the phase that preceded Oslo."
She condemned "Ariel Sharon's shameful policy of attempting to weaken the peace camp".

hl.seg: Arab Israelis demand protection for West Bank and Gaza Palestinians

p.seg: Nazareth, Israel, 15/12 (AFP) Representatives of Arab Israelis today demanded that the international community provide protection for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Following a meeting in the town of Jaffa, near Nazareth in Galilee, leaders of local councils representing Israeli Arabs demanded that the US, EU and UN "provide immediate international protection for the Palestinian people in the West Bank and Gaza Strip."

They decided to organize a demonstration on Saturday the 22nd of December in the Arab town of Shafa Amr (north) in protest "at the escalation of Israeli aggression against the Palestinian people" and "at the massacres and criminal practices" of the Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

The representatives of Israel's Arabs decided to organize "a visit to support Yasir Arafat on Monday in Ramallah". Arafat is facing an unprecedented attack by Israel, which accuses him of not making sufficient efforts to stop extremist Palestinian groups.
They also expressed "their great frustration at the Arab silence" towards the suffering of the Palestinian people.
Arab Israelis are Palestinians who remained on their land when the state of Israel was established in 1948 and their descendants.
They are subject to discrimination, particularly social and economic, which the Supreme Court in Israel has admitted.
13 were killed by Israeli police during demonstrations at the beginning of the intifada.

hl.seg: Putin expects "to be consulted" on follow-up to fight against terror

p.seg: London 17/12 (AFP) In an interview with British newspaper the Financial Times, published today, the Russian President said that when asked about whether he would be consulted he answered, "Yes, I expect so," according to the transcript published on the Financial Times website.
He added, "If this happens, the decisions will be more mature and have a stronger basis, and the implementation of these operations will be more beneficial."
The Russian President warned against any military action against Iraq. He believes that the next phase of the war on terror must focus "on the issue of the funding of terrorist organizations".
He added, "I have nothing to indicate that Iraq is funding the terrorists that we fight."
US Secretary of State Colin Powell announced last Tuesday in London that the US would consult with its allies in the coalition against terrorism before mounting any new military operation.

hl.seg: Powell calls on India to exercise caution in pursuing right to self-defense

p.seg: Washington 16/12 (AFP) US Secretary of State Colin Powell today called on India to exercise caution in pursuing its right to self-defense following Thursday's attack on the Indian parliament, in which the Indian government believes Pakistan is involved. Pakistan has, however, denied this.
Powell said in a statement to NBC, the television network, that it was important that both sides cooperate on this issue, which might otherwise become very dangerous.
The US Secretary of State explained, "I believe that the Indian Government has a legitimate right to self-defense."

He added, "But I also believe that we must be very careful because if the two countries attack each other whilst pursuing this right, we may create a more difficult situation, one that might be impossible to control."
He expressed the view that the situation was very tense "and had the potential to become more dangerous".
He said, "For this reason, I encourage both parties to exchange information, to cooperate in the campaign against terrorism and to avoid putting relations in a situation beyond control."

In this context, he expressed his satisfaction at the condemnation of the attack issued by Pakistan's President Parwaz Musharraf and his commitment to pursue every person in Pakistan who have been involved in the attack on the Indian parliament, which left 13 dead.
New Delhi claims that Pakistan's intelligence services are involved in the attack, a claim that Pakistan wholly denies.

hl.seg: Perez: We will judge Arafat by "his deeds"

p.seg: Jerusalem 16/12 (AFP) Public Israel radio has quoted the Israeli Minister of Foreign Affairs, Shimon Perez, as saying that Israel will judge Chairman Yasir Arafat by his deeds alone. He made this statement several hours before Arafat makes a speech today.
Perez added, "It is what Arafat does and not what he says that is important."

Perez reiterated his opposition to the stance adopted by the Israeli government of cutting off links with Arafat and deeming him as having been "sent off". He said, "It is a mistaken decision for the more you say he has been dismissed from the game the more his importance is confirmed."
Perez explained that a high-level Palestinian official "other than Arafat" had informed him that the Palestinian Authority had closed the offices of Hamas and Islamic Jihad.
Arafat has been surrounded since the 3rd of December in Ramallah, West Bank.
Today he will address the Palestinian people on the occasion of Eid al-Fitr.

hl.seg: Israeli aircraft break sound barrier above Beirut

p.seg: Beirut 16/12 (AFP) Israeli aircraft violated Lebanese airspace and broke the sound barrier above Beirut today, causing two sound explosions, according to the France Press correspondent.

A statement issued by the Lebanese Army Command announced that two Israeli bombers had circled at medium altitude above southern Lebanon and had broken the sound barrier above Beirut before returning to their hangars.

Israeli aircraft fly above Lebanon on an almost daily basis since Hizbullah shelled Israeli sites in the disputed Mazari Shabaa area on the border between Lebanon, Israel and Syria on the 22nd of October. The shelling did not lead to any casualties.

The UN regularly condemns these flights, which it views as a violation of "the blue line" which it drew and which represents the borders between Lebanon and Israel since the withdrawal of Israeli forces from southern Lebanon in May 2000, following 22 years of occupation.

hl.seg: Israel must mount own initiative says London

p.seg: London 16/12 (AFP) Britain announced today that following the undertaking given by head of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat, Israel must mount its own initiative and withdraw its forces and put an end to its policy of targeted assassinations as demanded by the European Union.
A spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair said, "The Palestinian Authority is assuming responsibility for breaking up the terrorist networks, in particular detaining suspected terrorists.
"We welcome Yasir Arafat's address and expect him to honor his undertaking."
He added, "But the European Union has also called on the Israelis to withdraw their military forces and put an end to targeted assassinations."
He concluded, "What is important, we believe, is that the two sides are politically committed to the interest of peace, which will enable us to bring them back to the negotiating table."

EU government and leaders have demanded that Israel "withdraw its military forces, put an end to extra-judicial killings, lift the embargo and restrictions imposed on the Palestinian people and freeze new settlements."
The European leaders repeated their call to the Palestinian Authority to dismantle "the terror networks of Hamas and Islamic Jihad".

hl.seg: Socialist Joao Suarez admits defeat in Lisbon

p.seg: Lisbon 17/12 (AFP) Head of the municipal council of Lisbon, socialist Joao Suarez, admitted defeat on Sunday evening and acknowledged the victory of his central right opponent, Pedro Santana Lopez, in elections for the mayor of Portugal's capital.

Socialist Prime Minister Antonio Guterres announced on Sunday evening that he would offer his resignation to President Jorge Sampayo, acknowledging that the Socialist Party had been defeated in the municipal elections.
Voters in Portugal yesterday went to the polls to elect town councils and mayors in a process which is considered to be a mid-term test for the socialist government of Antonio Guterres.

A poll conducted by weekly journal Expresso reported on Saturday that the basic element in the opposition, the central right Social Democratic Party, was expected to win somewhere in the region of 123-143 councils with the Socialist Party expected to win in the region of 114-138 councils.

hl.seg: Preparatory consultations for meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Cairo

p.seg: Cairo 17/12 (AFP) Arab diplomats announced on Tuesday the continuation of preparatory consultations for a meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Cairo to discuss the situation in the region. It is expected that the meeting will be held next Thursday.
A Palestinian representative to the Arab League, Muhammad Subaih, told France Press that "the meeting will certainly happen" but that a number of countries may ask for a change in the date.

The Assistant Secretary-General for Palestinian Affairs, Said Kamal, told France Press that he was awaiting the results of consultations between Egypt and Syria in order to confirm the proposed date for the meeting.
Egypt supported without reservations the address given by Chairman of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat, yesterday , in which he called for an end to armed operations against Israel.
Syria has made no official comment on the address but Syrian press today called for a continuation of the Intifada.

Subaih said that the head of the political department in the Palestinian Liberation Organization, Faruq al-Qudumi, and the Minister for International Co-operation in the Palestinian Authority, Nabil Shaat, will participate in the conference.
He added that he did not know whether Arafat would be able to come to Cairo.

hl.seg: Washington criticizes the arrest of Palestinian official

p.seg: Washington 17/12 (AFP) The US today condemned the arrest of Sirri Nisibah, responsible for the Jerusalem portfolio in the Palestinian Liberation Organization, which it described as "not constructive".
Richard Poutcher, spokesman for the US State Department, said, "We believe that Israel's detention of Sirri Nisibah is an act of provocation".
In a press statement he added that Washington had informed the Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon directly of its "concern".
These statements are a rare instance of the US criticizing Israel since Israeli operations began in response to the recent suicide attacks against Israel.
Washington had given its implicit support to Sharon's government, believing that these operation constituted the response of a democratic government to terrorist attacks.
Sirri Nasibah, President of Jerusalem University, was entrusted with the Jerusalem portfolio in the Palestinian Liberation Organization following the death of Faisal Husaini last May.

Sirri Nisibah was arrested and interrogated today by Israeli police after they banned a reception he was planning to organize in an East Jerusalem hotel in spite of the warnings given by the authorities.

hl.seg: Palestinian child killed by Israeli army bullet in Khan Yunis

p.seg: Gaza 17/12 (AFP) Medical source and Palestinian witnesses reported today that a Palestinian child was killed by an Israeli army bullet in Khan Yunis.

The medical sources told French Press, "The child, Muhammad Hunaidaq, aged 12, was fatally wounded by a bullet fired by the Israeli army based in the military sites surrounding the Nafih Dikalim settlement, west of Khan Yunis, and died immediately on arrival at Nasser Hospital in Khan Yunis."
The same sources reported that the child "was wounded by a bullet to the heart which continued out through his back".
Elsewhere, eye witnesses confirmed that "the Israeli army opened fire on a number of boys and children without there being any confrontation, leading to the death of Muhammad Hunaidaq".
This brings the number killed since the beginning of the Intifada in September 2000 to 1106, 850 Palestinians and 233 Israelis.

hl.seg: Boris Yeltsin on his way back to Moscow (press)

p.seg: Berlin 17/12 (AFP) A spokesman for a specialist heart surgery clinic in Berlin reported that former Russian president Boris Yeltsin, who attended the clinic last week for medical checks, had left for Moscow today.
Yeltsin had gone to the clinic for medical "checks".
"It was a routine, comprehensive examination," said Barbara Nikolas of the German Heart Disease Center in Berlin.
She added, "He has left and is on his way to Moscow."
Yeltsin, who five years ago underwent a catheter operation, was examined by medical director of the center, Dr Roland Hetzer.
According to a statement issued by the center showed that the results of the operation were "excellent" and that the health of the former Russian president was "very good".
The statement explained that Yeltsin, aged 70, had been examined by his Russian doctors but had wanted a second medical opinion.

hl.seg: Seizure of more than 50 kg of heroine on the Afghan-Tajik border

p.seg: Dushanbi 17/12 (AFP) Russian border guards yesterday seized 50 kg of heroine on the Afghan/Tajik border, according to the media department of the Russian border guards administration.
According to the same source, two colts who were making their way to cross into Tajikistan via Afghanistan left the quantity of drugs on the borders.
This is the largest amount of heroine that the Russian border guards have been able to seize in two months, since the Taliban lost control of Afghan north.
Over an 8-month period Russian border guards have managed to seize 8.5 tones of drugs on the Afghan-Tajik border, including two tones of heroine.
About 11 thousand Russians monitor the Tajik border under an agreement between Moscow and Dushanbi.
The former soviet republic of Tajikistan is a pipeline for drugs coming from Afghanistan, which is the world's number one producer of opium.

hl.seg: Former bodyguard to Iraqi President seeks asylum in Australia

p.seg: Sydney 17/12 (AFP) An Australian member of parliament has announced that a former bodyguard to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was placed under arrest today after effecting an illegal entry to Australia on board a ship for asylum seekers.

The member, Ross Cameron, explained that the man had destroyed the papers establishing his previous activities but investigations by the Immigration Department had allowed them to uncover his identity.
Speaking to an Australian radio station Cameron said, "Following detailed investigations we discovered that he was a member of Saddam Hussein's bodyguards in Iraq."
The Australian government received information indicating that a man involved in the 9/11 attacks on New York and Washington succeeded in entering the US as a refugee.
He added, "It is unreasonable to think that every person arriving on a ship here is a potential terrorist, but this case brings home the fact that we have to be very aware of those arriving here."
The Immigration Department must carry out a detailed investigation with those arriving on ships.

Minister for Immigration, Phillip Rodwick, recently linked the tightening of Australian immigration policy and the war on terror, adding that Australia must ensure that terrorists do not attempt to enter its territory as refugees.

hl.seg: 40 Greenpeace activists arrested following storming of nuclear reactor in Australia

p.seg: Sydney 17/12 (AFP) Australian police announced the arrest today of about 40 activists from Greenpeace, the organization which defends the environment, after they stormed a plant using a nuclear reactor in Sydney and occupied areas subject to intensive security measures.
The demonstrators, who wanted to protest at the plan to replace the reactor with a newer one, are to face charges of breaking and entering.
The demonstrators used a vehicle to block the entrance to the Lucas Heights plant, where Australia's only nuclear reactor is used to produce medical isotopes.
About 30 activists entered on the back of two lorries to the heart of the plant and prevented entry of tens of employees of the Australian nuclear sciences and technology organization.
A group of 6 activists climbed on the roof of the building which houses the reactor, some climbed a radio tower and others a waste storage site, to erect a banner reading "Nuclear is Never Safe".
Stephen Campbell from Greenpeace Australia said, "There is no point in having a new reactor since there is no solution to the problem of radiological waste."
The demonstration came as a meeting is being held in Sydney on the security conditions for changing the reactor.
A police spokesman said that the incident required a review of protection measures in place at the Lucas Heights plant.

hl.seg: Lebanese Championship: Champville extends its lead with victory over al-Riyadi 108-101

p.seg: Beirut 17/12 (AFP) Champville extended its lead at the top of the Lebanese basketball league with a victory over Al Riyadi Beirut 108-101 on the central court in Juniye (north Beirut), in the 13th stage.
Champville, who won their 11th game, are now 35 points ahead of al-Hikma, in second place, who lost to Anibal Zahle 74-77, and are stuck at 33 points. Third-placed Al Riyadi remained at 31 points.

Champville's superiority was clear in the first three quarters, which ended 31-24, 27-20 and 25-21 in its favor, before losing the fourth and final quarter 25-36 as Al Riyadi tried to reduce the deficit.

American Joe Fogel, who scored 27 points, and fellow countryman Tony Madison, who scored 27 points and 11 assists, were the stars of Champville. Ice Kastiss and Scotty Terman, who scored 22 and 21 points respectively, starred for Al Riyadi.
In Zahle, Anibal Zahle became the only team in the league to beat al-Hikma, who have won the title for the last four years, twice. They won 77-74 at home, having won 103-100 playing away.

In the first quarter Anibal led 19-8, al-Hikma 25-14 in the second, whilst Anibal led 16-15 in the third, and with a difference of only three points in the final score, Anibal won the fourth quarter 28-26.
The star player for Anibal was American Prentice McGroder, who scored 19 points, and for al-Hikma, American Cherille Ford, who scored 16 points.

hl.seg: US supports reduction in Bosnian force to six thousand by end of 2002

p.seg: Brussels 18/12 (AFP) A US official announced that American Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfield will today propose to his NATO counterparts in Brussels a reduction in the strength of the multi-national peace-keeping force in Bosnia (SFOR) to six thousand by the end of 2002.

The official, who asked to remain anonymous, added that Rumsfield will propose to his European counterparts that the EU undertake to form a multi-national force from armed police in Bosnia to reduce the peace-keeping duties undertaken by SFOR.
The US believe that the forces deployed in the SFOR framework may more usefully deployed elsewhere as part of the war on terrorism following the 9/11 attacks.
NATO defense ministers will hold their bi-annual meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Washington hopes that they will take a decision to reduce the strength of SFOR during their next meeting in Spring 2002, according to the same source.

hl.seg: Democratic Front refuses to stop resistance operations

p.seg: Damascus 18/12 (AFP) The Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine (DFLP) (opposition) today refused the call by Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to stop armed activities against Israel and itself called for a continuation of the Intifada.

The statement made by the DFLP, which is headed by Naif Hawatima and is based in Damascus, stressed "that the call made by Arafat to stop all armed activities...is to concede to the conditions imposed by the US and Sharon to put an end to the Intifada and legitimate patriotic resistance against the occupation and settlement".
The DFLP stressed, "Decisions made by the Authority behind the back of the civil leadership of the Intifada and Palestinian resistance groups are not binding on those groups and forces."

The DFLP, which has claimed responsibility for armed attacks against Israel, has called on all Palestinian parties to engage in "comprehensive national dialogue to review Palestinian policies since Oslo (the self-rule agreements of 1993)... to develop the Intifada and unify Palestinian resistance".

Hamas, which has claimed responsibility for most bloody operations against Israel, and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), which is an extreme left opposition group, announced on Monday their rejection of Arafat's call.
The Palestinian leader had issued an unprecedented call on Sunday to stop all armed attacks against Israel, which he called upon to resume peace talks "immediately".

hl.seg: Ebola fever in Congo but situation under control claims WHO

p.seg: Libreville 18/12 (AFP) The representative of the World Health Organization (WHO) in Gabon, Alan Bran, announced today in Libreville that Ebola fever, which has been rampant since the end of last November in the north-east of Gabon, had "crossed the border" to Congo, Brazzaville, but despite this the situation was "under control".
A WHO official said in a press conference at the Gabon Minister of Health that "the disease had crossed the border but the situation was under control".
He added, "At the beginning of the outbreak a woman and child managed to cross the border between Gabon and the Congo, looking for treatment from practitioners of traditional medicine.
According to our information, the child has died and the woman is in a critical condition."
He explained, "The Gabon Ministries of Health and the Interior have taken measures" in co-operation with the Gabon authorities.

hl.seg: Israeli wounded by Palestinian bullets in the West Bank

p.seg: Jerusalem 18/12 (AFP) An Israeli military source reports that an Israeli civilian in a vehicle suffered mild injuries today when shot at by armed Palestinian near Hawara village in the north West Bank.
But the same source did not say whether the wounded man was a settler or lived in Israeli territory.
The Vanguard of Popular Army - al-Awda al-Qariba Battalions, part of the Fateh movement, claimed responsibility for the attack on a "settlers' vehicle".
A statement issued by the group and received by France Press said that "attacks by the free fighter will continue against occupation sites".

An Israeli settler and three-year old son suffered minor injuries yesterday inside a vehicle near the Afra settlement, north of Ramallah. Another settler was injured in similar circumstances to the west of Ramallah.
Three Palestinians including a child were killed yesterday by Israeli army bullets following Yasir Arafat's call to stop armed activities.

hl.seg: Paris: Arrest of Sirri Nisibah "extreme"

p.seg: Paris 18/12 (AFP) The French Ministry of Foreign Affairs today expressed the view that Israel's arrest of the official responsible for the Jerusalem portfolio in the Palestinian Liberation Organization, Sirri Nisibah, yesterday in East Jerusalem was "extreme".

Laurance Auier, spokeswoman for the Ministry, said that this arrest was "regrettable and stemmed from an extreme and shockingly partisan stance at a time when it was necessary to do everything possible to guarantee peaceful coexistence between all parties".
She continued, "This arrest is difficult to understand, especially given that it targets a man well-known for his spirit of dialogue and perceptive vision."
Nisibah, who is President of East Jerusalem University, was entrusted with the Jerusalem portfolio in the Palestinian Liberation Organization following the death of Faisal Husaini in May.

Israeli police stopped him in East Jerusalem for one and a half hours to question him about a reception he intended to organize in East Jerusalem despite the fact that the Israeli authorities had prohibited this demonstration, according to Israeli police.

hl.seg: (Repeat to Beirut)

p.seg: Qatari squad of 27 players in preparation for the Gulf Cup

Doha 17/12 (AFP) The Director of the National Teams in the Qatari Football Federation, Ahmad al-Sulaiti, announced today that French coach Pierre Lechanteur had selected a squad of 27 players in preparation for the Gulf Cup, to be hosted by Saudi Arabia from the 16th to the 30th of next January.
The squad is missing some prominent names, such as Mubarak Mustafa, Abd al-Nasir al-Ubaidli, Abd al-Aziz Hasan, Yusif Adam, and Jasim Abdallah, and includes a number of young players.
Players invited to join the squad will commence training tomorrow. The squad is as follows:
Goal: Amir al-Kaabi (al-Ittihad), Ahmad Khalil (al-Sadd), Husain al-Rumaihi (Qatar) and Salman al-Ansari (al-Ahli).

Defense: Saud Fath and Saad Sattam al-Shamri (al-Ittihad), Adil Darwish, Abd al-Rahman Mahmoud, Jaffal Rashad and Dahi al-Nubi (al-Sadd), Wassam Rizq and Khalid Salih (Qatar), Muhammad Yasi (al-Rayyan) and Jasim al-Tamimi (al-Wakra).
Midfield: Muhammad Ghullam, Ahmad Khalifa and Jasim Mahmoud (al-Sadd), Yasir Nazmi (Qatar), Abd al-Rahman al-Kawari and Husain Yasir (al-Rayyan), and Sayyid Ali al-Bashir (al-Arabi).
Attack: Adil Jadwaa (al-Ittihad), Salman Misbah (al-Rayyan), Mashaal Abdallah (al-Ahli), Naif al-Khatir (al-Wakra), Walid Hamza (al-Arabi) and Muhammad Salim al-Inzi (al-Wahda, UAE).

hl.seg: Turkey: 15 dead in 3 days due to bad weather

p.seg: Ankara 19/12 (AFP) Snow storms and winter temperatures paralyzing life in Turkey since Monday have led to the deaths of 7 other people, raising the total killed to 15, according to the reports of the Turkish Anatolian News Agency today.
In Istanbul, the country's largest city, a beggar was discovered frozen to death in the Uskadur district on the European side of the Bosphorus.
Another beggar was discovered probably dead in a lorry in which he had sought shelter in the Bairam Basha district on the Asian bank.
A third person was found dead in a cafe in Istanbul. Police in the town of Panderma (north-west) found the body of an unknown man in the streets who had died in the cold.
Another person (aged 32) died from the cold in the Kirkilarili area (north-west).
In Janakali (west) a man (aged 46) who lived alone was found dead from the cold at his home.
Policemen found the body of a fisherman (aged 36) who had been declared missing three days ago.
With the deaths of these seven, the total number of victims of the harsh weather in Turkey has reached 15 since the wave of bad weather began on Monday.
The bad weather is causing traffic problems on a number of roads, many villages have been cut off and hundreds of telephone lines are not working.

hl.seg: Washington: No decision yet on whether to attack Somalia

p.seg: Washington 19/12 (AFP) The US today confirmed once more that no decision has yet been taken on whether to launch military attacks against countries other than Afghanistan after a German official said that Somalia would be a target for American strikes.

Spokesman for the US State Department, Richard Poutcher said, "No recommendation has been made to the President [George Bush] and the President has made no decision" as to whether to widen the scope of military operation in Afghanistan.
Poutcher added that Secretary of State Colin Powell had articulated this position on a number of occasions of the past few days.
The US spokesman derided the statements made by the German official, who refused to reveal his name, on the fringe of a NATO meeting, where he confirmed that Somalia would be attacked.

Poutcher said, "These statements are important and are news to us all because the situation remains as it was." He reiterated that Washington had not taken any decision on the possibility of widening the scope of operations.
The German official had announced, "The matter is not whether the US will combat terrorism in Somalia but how."
Somalia is accused of having relations with the al-Qaeda network which is led by the terrorist suspect Osama bin Ladin.

hl.seg: Governor of Jalabad: Osama bin Ladin "not in Afghanistan"

p.seg: Islamabad 19/12 (AFP) A spokesman for the governor of Jalalabad, Ibad al-Hajj Muhammad Zaman told the Afghan Islamic Press Agency today that he was now "certain" that Osama bin Ladin was not in Afghanistan.

The spokesman added, "Our operations in Tora Bora are complete and we only arrested 17 fighters from al-Qaeda, some of whom were Afghans." He added that other leaders had arrested some fighters from the organization.
He added, "We are now certain that bin Ladin is not in Afghanistan."
The spokesman, who made these remarks to journalists at a military base in Afghanistan, noted that "there was no longer any refuge for Mulla Omar".
The Jalabad governor himself had previously announced to the Afghan Press Agency, which works from Pakistan, that al-Qaeda prisoners would be handed to Kabul.
Zaman confirmed that there were no longer any Arab fighters in Tora Bora and that the area will not be bombed any more.

hl.seg: Vendrell travels to Kabul today, Brahimi on Friday

p.seg: Kabul 19/12 (AFP) A UN spokesman in the Afghan capital announced that he expected the arrival of the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative in Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi on Friday. His deputy, Fransesc Vendrell, is expected today.
On Wednesday Brahimi left London for Kabul. It is expected that he will arrive at the end of the week in time for the official transfer of power to the transitional Afghan government.
No program for the officials is available at the present time according to UN spokesman Yusif Hasan.
Brahimi, who is supervising talks between Afghan groups, made a quick visit to Kabul on the 11th of the month.

hl.seg: Palestinian police close five workshops making mortars in Gaza

p.seg: Gaza 19/12 (AFP) A Palestinian police source reported today that the Palestinian police had this evening closed five lathe workshops in Gaza that were making mortar shells.
The source told France Press, "Palestinian police this evening closed 5 mechanical lathe workshops which were making mortar shells in Gaza City and the north of the Gaza Strip."
The source noted that the closure of these workshops "was in implementation of the decision of the Palestinian leadership to abide by the cease-fire", adding that "this campaign would continue".
He stressed that "the Palestinian Authority will fully comply with the cease-fire".

Witnesses in Jabaliya, in the north of the Gaza Strip, confirmed to France Press that "members of the Palestinian police and security force had, in the evening, closed a workshop used to make mortars, whose owner was believed to be close to Hamas".

hl.seg: Palestinian killed in exchange of fire with Israeli army

p.seg: Nablus, West Bank, 20/12 (AFP) A Palestinian was killed this evening in an exchange of fire with Israeli forces who once more entered Nablus in the area under Palestinian self-rule in the north West Bank, according to Palestinian medical sources.
Witnesses reported that the shooting began once Israeli armored vehicles reentered an area from which they had withdrawn in the morning.
This brings the total killed since the beginning of the Intifada at the end of September 2000 to 1107, including 851 Palestinians and 233 Israelis.

The Israeli army had withdrawn its armored vehicles from three areas under the control of the Palestinian Authority which it had occupied on the 4th of December following bloody Palestinian suicide attacks.
The three areas are the suburbs of Nablus, al-Tira and Baituniya, located to the west and north of Ramallah respectively.
But Israeli tanks returned in the evening to al-Tira and the area surrounding Nablus according to witnesses.

An Israeli military spokesman answering journalists' questions said that the Israeli army "had never announced that it was withdrawing from these towns" and refused to give details on "these tactical movements".

hl.seg: Former Jordanian Islamist Deputy stopped in the US (Islamic Work Front)

p.seg: Amman 20/12 (AFP) A former Jordanian deputy, Dhib Anis, a member of the Islamic Work Front, the largest Jordanian opposition party, was recently detained in the US on a matter relating to his entry visa, the Party reported on Thursday.

Abd al-Latif Arabiyyat, Secretary-General of the Islamic Work Front, sent a letter to the Jordanian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Abdallah al-Khatif, asking for Jordan to intervene "to secure the quick release" of Anis who "suffers from heart and respiratory illnesses".

The letter, a copy of which was sent to France Press, indicated that Dhib Anis "had become accustomed to visiting the US for several years at the invitation of Arab and Islamic organizations and authorities there, in particular during the holy month of Ramadan, in which he played a cultural and charitable role. He had never previously been questioned about his activities."

The letter continued, "As was his custom, he traveled this year...but was surprised when he has detained by the security forces in the town of Chicago on this spurious charge just two days before his planned return to Jordan."
Arabiyyat added that Anis had been detained "on the pretext that the visa by which he entered the US was not valid".
In its letter the Islamic Work Party asked the Minister "to notify the US State Department of Jordan's protest at this measure".
Jordanian Ambassador in Washington, Marwan al-Muashar, recently announced that the American authorities had detained since the 9/11 attacks 23 Jordanians for questioning.

hl.seg: Resignation of Argentinean President

p.seg: Buenos Aires 20/12 (AFP) Minister of Production Nikola Galo announced that Argentinean President Fernando de la Rua had tendered his resignation to Congress today.
Galo said that the President had submitted his resignation to the Parliament as an expression of democratic intent at a time when the country had seen two days of confrontation.
De la Rua will be temporarily replaced by the Head of Congress, Ramon Puerta, of the Peronist opposition.
The position of Vice President has been vacant since last year when Vice President Carlos Alvarez resigned.

The announcement of de la Rua's resignation led to demonstrations of delight in the streets of the capital which, all day long, had seen dangerous confrontations between the police and demonstrators which left 4 dead. This was in addition to the 16 killed yesterday in clashes that occurred during looting and pillaging.

hl.seg: Iranian saved from the death sentence at the last minute; 3 others executed

p.seg: Tehran 20/12 (AFP) An Iranian was saved from the death sentence at the last minute on Wednesday when the family of the victim he had killed forgave him; three other Iranians were executed on the same day in Tehran.
The Rasalat newspaper reported that Ibrahim B.
was saved from the noose at the moment he was to be executed for murder when members of the victim's family decided to forgive him.
Ahmad Hidayati, Ughil Nabizadeh and Masaud Yughanah were all hanged in the Palace Prison in Tehran.
This brings to five the number of executions by hanging in Iran since the start of the week.
Crimes of rape, theft of weapons, drug trade and murder are all punished by death in Iran.
Under Sharia law the victim's family have the right to waive the death sentence by pardoning the perpetrator.

hl.seg: Order to withdraw armed fighters from Kabul

p.seg: Kabul 20/12 (AFP) An official in the Afghan Ministry of Defense announced that he had requested all armed fighters with the exception of certain elements and the police "to leave the streets of Kabul immediately".
Qalb al-Din, spokesman for the Ministry, said, "the Security Committee agreed to an order that does not allow anyone armed to move about in the streets; they must return to barracks."
He added, "If they wish to move about in the streets, they may do so but without weapons."
He explained that the order included "people who were not officials" and not those who had been deployed by the Security Committee to patrol the streets.
The Security Committee comprises representatives of the Ministry of the Interior, the intelligence services and the Ministry of Defense.
The spokesman added that those permitted to move in the streets included the mujahidun fighters from Kabul barracks, Ministry of Interior police and secret police from the intelligence services.
Qalb al-Din confirmed that "nobody else may carry weapons in public places, especially at this time as power is being transferred."
The new transitional government under the leadership of Pashtun Hamid Karzai who is loyal to the former King, will assume its duties on Saturday for a term of six months.

Since the departure of the Taliban from Kabul on 12 November thousands of fighters have been seen on the streets of the Afghan capital. Armored vehicles and trucks equipped with anti-aircraft batteries have also been seen.

hl.seg: 23/Bahrain Prime Minister: Parliamentary Life to be Practiced Soon

p.seg: Riyadh 10 November / Xinhua / The Prime Minister of the State of Bahrain, Sheikh Khalifa Bin Salman Al Khalifa, announced that "Bahrain is on the verge of a new parliamentary life that must be prepared for and practiced in a civilized and responsible spirit, taking into consideration our values and traditions."

Bahrain's newspapers, published today, said that Sheikh Khalifa Bin Salman is hoping for the cooperation of everybody during the upcoming period in order to achieve the mission and arrive at the realization of these ambitious national goals in the service of the country and citizens.
He said that the period of openness that Bahrain is witnessing requires caution and care by all to prevent taking advantage of this openness to spread disunity and scattering of the one people.
He called for the preservation of the freedom enjoyed by Bahrain and for care in adhering to it in order to preserve the national unity that is the foundation and strength of societies.
He said that the diversity of opinions must not be directed against the interests of the country and citizens, asserting that loyalty comes first and must not be overlooked.

He emphasized that Bahrain will continue to be a guiding light and an example to be followed due to her leading role in the region, her distinction and her openness to the world, and her positive initiatives at all different levels.

He touched on the subject of food security in Bahrain and the Arab World and, in that regard, affirmed the need to prevent the deterioration of agricultural areas and to work on preserving them in order to achieve food security.

He said that Bahrain will seek to preserve the agricultural resources and expansion of the green areas in order to resurrect the wealth enjoyed by Bahrain due to her distinguished agricultural production.

hl.seg: 46/ Central Africa's Former Chief of the Army Surrenders in Chad

p.seg: Yaound 10 November / Xinhua / Sources in Bangui, the capital of Central Africa, said today that the former chief of Central Africa's army, who fled his country on Wednesday after days of fighting with Presidential Guard units, surrendered to Chadian authorities this afternoon.

General Bozize, 54, former Army Chief of Staff of Central Africa and a one-time close associate of the country's president, Ange-Felix Patasse, was disarmed and was to be moved with his followers from the border area to the Chadian capital N'Djamena.
The Central African presidential spokesman, Prosper Ndouba, announced that his government will seek the extradition of Bozize by Chad's authorities in order to return him to his country for trial.
Bozize, who had been summarily dismissed by Patasse, was recalled last weekend to investigate his role in May's coup d'Etat which left 59 victims.
Bozize had rejected the recall, and his followers carried out attacks against Patasse's headquarters in the capital.
Presidential Guard units responded by attacking and taking over Bozize's barracks, while he fled North to Chad on Wednesday.
Patesse openly accused Bozize, who defended Patesse's government during the army's insurrection in the late nineties, with planning the May coup d'Etat.
It is worth mentioning that Patasse has been in power since he won the elections of 1993, ending the rule of the military dictator Andre Kolingba which lasted 12 years.

hl.seg: 57/ Headline News in Major American Newspapers

p.seg: Washington 10 November / Xinhua / The following are the top stories reported by major American newspapers published today:
// Washington Post //:

- The Northern Alliance in Afghanistan announced that it succeeded with the aid of strategic backing by American bombing and aerial support in the taking over last night of Mazar El-Sharif, considered a crossroad, and took pride in the success of its forces in dissipating the Taliban defenders and securing two airports and one major highway.

- With the United States staying on the sidelines, negotiators from 160 countries, including Great Britain, Japan and Russia reached agreement last evening on an initial treaty for climate control that sets mandatory goals to lower heat-retaining gases.
// New York Times //:

- Pakistani President Pervez said that he came to the United States seeking major initiatives from the Bush Administration, including the release of the American F-16 combat planes that were sold to Pakistan at the time she was an ally against the Soviet Union, but were held due to the development of nuclear arms at home.
- Iranian President Mohammad Khatami described Osama Bin Laden as a radical image of Islam and said that he does not represent the majority of Moslems now estimated at 1.2 billion.

hl.seg: 95 / Zayed and Mubarak Stress Importance of Avoiding Expansion of Military Operations

p.seg: Abu Dhabi 10 November / Xinhua / Egyptian Information Minister Safwat Al-Sharif, who is accompanying Egyptian President Mohammad Hosni Mubarak in a visit to the United Arab Emirates, confirmed tonight that Sheikh Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahayan affirmed with President Hosni Mubarak the importance of avoiding the expansion of military operations so that it does not include other regions, and the importance of developing a joint Arab view vis-�-vis what is happening in Afghanistan.

Safwat Al-Sharif said in remarks to reporters that the negotiations between Sheikh Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahayan and President Mubarak focused on the challenges facing the Arab Nation in this dangerous period the world is currently experiencing.

He added that talks between the two leaders also touched on the repercussions of war in Afghanistan on the Arab region, the Palestinian cause and what the Palestinian people are subjected to by Israeli terror and the continuation of occupation of the Palestinian territories.

He stressed that the views of Zayed and Mubarak were identical regarding the aggressive practices being committed by Israel against the Palestinian people, that they view what Israel is doing as a serious matter that can't be ignored, that the international community must move to affect an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories and evacuation of Palestinian cities ending their siege immediately, and beginning the implementation of the Mitchell Plan and moving toward the final solution.
He clarified that the two leaders affirmed the need to establish a Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital and that all holy places be under Palestinian sovereignty.

hl.seg: 51/ France Arrests Islamists Suspected of Planning Attacks in Strasbourg

p.seg: Paris 10 November / Xinhua / French Radio Europe 1 announced that five Algerian Islamists were arrested yesterday for suspicion of membership in Osama Bin Laden's network in the city of Strasbourg in eastern France, where they were planning to carry out attacks in the city.
The radio said that the five suspects received training in Algeria before being sent to Strasbourg at the end of last year to carry out a full attack.

It is worth mentioning that the leaders of the team were arrested last year in Frankfurt, Germany, where German police confiscated a large quantity of powerful explosives and a video tape that the team used to point out key areas in Strasbourg, including a market and a cathedral.
The radio said that the tape was recorded in a car with Afghani war songs as background music and with comments stating that "places of worship rejected by God must be destroyed."

After French terrorist prosecutors who conducted investigations at the time managed to get a judgment to hand over the leader of the team, Mohammad Bin Zakariya, 34, who was Osama Bin Laden's deputy responsible for his group in Europe.
He was arrested in Spain last June.
In July, Zakariya was accused in Paris that "he had connections to terrorist networks and was planning terrorist activities."

hl.seg: Jordan's King Calls for Quick Settlement for Middle East Crisis

p.seg: London 10 November / Xinhua/ The Jordanian Monarch, King Abdullah II, renewed on Friday his call to find a quick solution for the Middle East crisis.
During a meeting with reporters, King Abdullah said that there is a "pressing need to move on the Israeli-Palestinian path."
Just before ending his official visit to Britain, the Jordanian king re-iterated the need for the international community to create "suitable atmospheres to push the peace process forward."
The King added that the terrorist attack incident on the United States last September 11 underscored the pressing need to find a solution to the crisis in the Middle East.
He indicated that the war against terrorism may go on for decades, adding "in the midst of this crisis, there's hope" to achieve peace in the Middle East Region.

It is worth mentioning that King Abdullah II paid an official visit to Britain that lasted 3 days, during which he attended a dinner hosted by Queen Elizabeth II, and became the first Arab leader to address the British Parliament.. He also conducted talks with British Prime Minister Tony Blair in the government offices at Downing Street.

Following his meeting with Blair on Thursday, King Abdullah said that he "sees equal importance between the coalition led by the United States against terrorism and the need to make progress in the peace process in the Middle East."

hl.seg: Security Council Backs Dialogue Between Democratic Republic of Congo's Factions

p.seg: / First Addition /

The resolution stated that the Security Council expressed its "deep concern" regarding the repeated violations of human rights "in this country which is located in the middle of Africa, and particularly "in the territories subject to the control of the rebellious groups involved in the Lusaka Ceasefire Agreement", and the resolution called "all parties to put an end to these violations."
The resolution expressed utmost concern toward the human situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo and urged the international community to increase its support of human activities without delay.

At the same time, the resolution expressed grave concern toward economic difficulties in the Democratic Republic of Congo, asserting that "progress in the peace process, rejuvenation of the economy and development of the country are interrelated."

The resolution also criticized "all illegal exploitations of natural resources" in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and demanded putting an end to such exploitation affirming the need for not exploiting the natural resources of Congo "to finance the conflict in that state."

hl.seg: Security Council Calls on All People of Kosovo to Participate in Local Elections

p.seg: United Nations 10 November / Xinhua / The Security Council called on all citizens of the Province of Kosovo to participate in the local elections due to be held on November 17 and praised the role the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia played before the elections.

In a statement read to news media in an open council meeting, the president of the council for this month, Patricia Durrant from Jamaica, said that the council, which is composed of 15 members, welcomes the constructive role played by Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica, his government and the government of the Republic of Serbia in encouraging the Serbs in Kosovo to participate in the elections.
The statement said that the participation of Kosovo's Serbs in the voting will allow them to contribute in the formulation of the future multi-ethnic vision in the province.

The statement welcomed the mutual document signed by the UN Mission in Kosovo and Belgrade on November 5 which was consistent with UN Resolution 1244 and the constitutional framework for self rule in the province.

The council simultaneously called for re-enforcing the constructive dialogue between the UN Mission in Kosovo / UNMIK/ and the Yugoslavian authorities, emphasizing the responsibilities of the regional institutions in self-rule and concerned parties in respecting the final format of Resolution 1244.

hl.seg: Culture Ministers of Ibero-America Countries Agree on Liam Declaration

p.seg: Lima 10 November / Xinhua / Culture ministers from 10 Latin American countries, Spain and Portugal agreed on the "Lima Declaration" during the Fifth Cultural Conference of Ibero-America Countries on Friday.

The Lima Declaration asserts that the culture of the Ibero-America Region is a product of a continuing relationship lasting five centuries which requires integration based on similar and joint traits, and the Declaration also asserts the multi-cultural personality and multi-ethnicity in the region.
The Document / Declaration/ touched on what has been accomplished during the past decade and made positive remarks on the prospects of cultural collaboration.
During the conference, several issues relating to the multi-faceted cooperation agenda were discussed, including fostering the cultural policies and legislations in each country in the region.
The participants agreed to present the Declaration at the group's upcoming summit that is scheduled to convene on the 23rd and 24th of November in the Peruvian capital, Lima.

hl.seg: Facts and Figures: Chinese Exports to the United Kingdom

p.seg: Beijing 15 November / Xinhua / The following are the latest facts and figures for Chinese commodity exports to the United Kingdom in the first nine months of the year 2001 according to what came from the General Authority of Customs.
Machinery products, electronics, audio visual equipment, spare parts and associated necessities: 1.763 billion US dollars.
Raw materials and textile products: 548.976 million US dollars.
Miscellaneous products/light fixtures, furniture, etc./ : 557.278 million US dollars.
Base metals and associated products: 356.431 million US dollars.
Chemicals and associated products: 251.002 million US dollars.
Leathers, fur and associated products: 230.150 million US dollars.
Plastics, rubber and associated products: 220.707 million US dollars.
Transportation vehicles: 191.769 million US dollars.

hl.seg: Chinese and Foreign Experts Call for Re-enforcing Ecological Health Infrastructure

p.seg: / First and Last Addition /

It is worth mentioning that there are 2.4 billion people in the world who lack an ecologically-friendly health system, which result in ecological pollution and disaster, directly threatening human health and life and restricting permanent social and economic development.

The conference participants proposed conducting more experiments and research to create a more suitable ecological health system and to publicize the results of experiments and advanced research in the village, cities and suburbs in all countries, especially in developing countries.

Those experts expressed their affirmation of China's accomplishments in publicizing countryside ecologically-healthy lavatories and agreed unanimously that the Chinese approach is a model that must be followed by other countries, especially the developing countries.

hl.seg: 37/ The American Envoy for Peace Begins Visit to the Sudan Tomorrow

p.seg: Khartoum on 11 November / Xinhua / John Danforth, the American president's envoy for peace, begins on Monday evening his visit to Khartoum that will last until next Thursday and during which time he will meet with a number of state officials and other dignitaries as well as visit some areas.

The Sudan News Agency reported today that the American envoy will meet with Ghazi Salah El-Din, the president's peace advisor, as part of his meetings with officials to discuss peace issues within the framework of his mission concerning ending the war and establishing peace.

Mustafa Othman Ismael, the Sudanese Foreign Minister, has met last night in New York with Senator John Danforth along the sidelines of the UN General Assembly Annual Session in the presence of Walter Kansteiner, the American Assistant Secretary of State for Africa; Ambassador Robert Oakley, the American envoy's aid; Ambassador Jeffrey Millington, the envoy's advisor; and Michael Milber, Deputy Head of African Affairs, at the American National Security Council. The meeting reviewed the envoy's mission in the Sudan.

Mustafa presented a synopsis of past peace missions and efforts exerted to establish peace in the Sudan as well as the obstacles facing its realization, and he re-iterated the government's commitment to facilitate the envoy's mission as long as it is accomplished under the framework of the required transparency and neutrality.

It is worth mentioning that the decision to appoint the American envoy for peace in the Sudan was taken last September, and in preparation for the envoy's visit, an American advance delegation visited the Sudan at the end of last October headed by Charles, the American Assistant Undersecretary of State for Africa, and met with a number of officials and some political activists for the purpose of feeling out the different points of view about peace.

hl.seg: Annan Meets with Brazilian President on Situation in Afghanistan

p.seg: United Nations 11 November / Xinhua / The United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan met on Saturday with Brazilian President Fernando Henrique Cardoso and discussed with him the situation in Afghanistan and the Middle East, according to what UN officials said here.
The meeting was held along the sidelines of the 56th General Assembly public discussions that last one week and which opened in the UN headquarters in New York on Saturday morning.

During the meeting, Annan reviewed with the Brazilian president the current human efforts of the UN and said that the most urgent challenges are moving between 50 thousand and 60 thousand tons of food within one month and avoiding the disruption of the UN food distribution system that was in place in Afghanistan.
The Secretary General also indicated that UN personnel responsible for Afghanistan continued their work despite the current situation, according to what officials said.

Annan also reviewed with the Brazilian president the work of his special representative in Afghanistan, Al Akhdar Al Ibrahimi, aiming for the establishment of a stable Afghani government, faithful to the people.
They also discussed the situation in the Middle East and fighting terrorism, according to what officials said.

hl.seg: Meeting between UN Secretary General and Chilean President on Afghanistan and Poverty

p.seg: United Nations 11 November / Xinhua / The UN Secretary general, Kofi Anan, met on Saturday with the Chilean president, Ricardo Lagos Escobar, and the two leaders discussed eradicating abject poverty, fighting the Aids virus, and preventing conflict and steady development, according to what UN officials said.
The Chilean president said that now is the time to take practical steps to execute them taking into account the changing realities in the world.

The two sides also affirmed, during the meeting that was held along the sidelines of the public discussions of the UN General Assembly in its 56th Annual Session, the importance of the financial conference on funding development that will be convened in Mexico next year.
They also covered the importance and repercussion of the current Doha meeting of the World Trade Organization and the Steady Development Summit that will be convened in South Africa next year.

hl.seg: Chile Welcomes China Joining World Trade Organization

p.seg: Santiago 11 November / Xinhua / The Chilean-Chinese Cultural Academy congratulated China on Saturday on her joining the World Trade Organization after 15 years of negotiations.

In a congratulatory letter signed by the Academy's president, Abilardo Mila Cozada, and his first deputy, Dazio de la Fuente Duarte, the Academy said "that there's no doubt that useful results will ensue from the People Republic of China joining the World Trade Organization at the local and international levels."
It is noted that the World Trade Organization which encompasses 142 members, accepted China on Saturday as a member.
The Academy highly valued the distinct achievements of the Chinese people in the path to modernization during the past 20 years via the application of reform and openness policy.

hl.seg: Healthy Economic Growth in Tibet

p.seg: Lhasa 13 November / Xinhua / The self-rule region of Tibet / southwest of China / achieved total economic growth in the first nine months of this year.
By the end of September, the added value of the industrial institutions at the town level and above increased by 7.5 percent to 596 billion yuan.
The total value of the region's imports and exports reached 85.59 million US Dollars.
The region's revenues reached 490 million Yuan, an increase of 12.9 percent, and total unpaid saving deposits were 17.5 billion Yuan, an increase of 19.5 percent from the same period of last year.

The Tibet region invested 5.7 billion Yuan in constant receipts in the first nine months, and construction began in 30 out of 70 projects this year that were listed among projects that will be built with the help of other counties and towns.
The disposable income of the city population increased by 15 percent this year.
The average single family's expenses on transportation, entertainment, education and culture increased by 20 percent.

hl.seg: Intensification of Illegal Immigration Fighting Measures in Shanghai

p.seg: Shanghai 12 November / Xinhua / In a campaign that lasted three months in the summer of this year, police in Shanghai, the largest industrial and commercial center in China, arrested 728 Chinese who tried to immigrate illegally and deal in the human trade.
A police spokesman said that 36 cases were discovered dealing with illegal immigration and human trade in a campaign against illegal immigration from July 15 to September 15.
Among these cases, 21 relate to attempts to trade humans and 10 to attempts to obtain illegal entry documents.

The spokesman said that 60 persons // snakeheads// are profiting from organizing illegal immigration, and 313 law-breaking cases were settled and fines were imposed upon them in the amount of 646 thousand Yuan / 780.78 US Dollars/.
It became apparent that a Shanghai citizen named // Fan // has smuggled 29 people from China in collaboration with a // snake head // from South Korea in the last three months of last year.
// Fan // made about 400 thousand yuan through illegal activities.
Two other snakeheads were also arrested during the course of this campaign.

hl.seg: 3,000 Young Chinese Sturgeons Fish Released into Sea

p.seg: Xiamen 12 November / Xinhua / China released on Saturday 3,000 of young sturgeons fish into the sea near the outpouring of the Julong River in the Fujian Province, located in southeast China; The released young sturgeons weigh about one kilogram each.

This release came within the framework of a campaign put together by the Seas and Fishery Resources Authority of the Fujian Province to release 10,000 young Chinese sturgeons fish, including 7,000 that will be released in the Mingjang River basin in the province.
It is noted that this Chinese sturgeons fish is one of the rare species indigenous to China, and is also known as "the live fossil" since it is the oldest vertebrate.
It inhabits the coastal areas in southeast China.
It was listed among the land animals under top protection of China in 1988.
China has released some of the young Chinese sturgeons fish in the basin of the Yangtze River, China's longest river, and other places in order to protect and increase this fish resource.

hl.seg: 28 / Rwandan President Urges Establishing More Exchanges between Chinese and Rwandan Companies

p.seg: Beijing 12 November / Xinhua / The Rwandan President Paul Kajima said Monday that he hopes that Chinese business organizers will cooperate more with their counterparts from his country and that they seek to achieve a mutual development.

Kajima, who is currently paying a visit to China lasting five days, said in a seminar for business between China and Rwanda hosted by the China Council on Promoting International Trade that frequent communications in the area of trade and investment will help improve the relations between the two countries and the two peoples.

The vice president of the China Council on Promoting International Trade said that China's joining of the World Trade Organization points to a new phase in her openness and participation in the economic globalization process.
He said that China will expand with economic and commercial activity with the rest of the world, especially the developing countries.

It is to be noted that the Rwandan business organizers, who total 27 and are accompanying Kajima in his visit, have exchanged views with Chinese businessmen in the special cooperation seminar in the areas of agriculture, banking, information and construction industries.

hl.seg: 105 / American Russian Summit to be Held on Time Despite Plane Crash

p.seg: Washington 12 November / Xinhua / The White House said that American President George Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin will go ahead with convening a summit meeting between them this week in the United States despite the plane crash accident in New York City.

White House Spokesman Ari Fleischer responded to a question whether Bush will go ahead with the meeting, which is scheduled from Tuesday to Thursday in Washington and in Bush's ranch in Crawford in the state of Texas, saying that "he is definitely still planning to convene this summit."
The Russian president and his wife will arrive in Washington this evening, and he will hold talks with Bush on security, economy and business issues tomorrow.
Putin and his wife will go to Houston and then to Crawford on Wednesday for dinner with Bush and his wife at Bush's ranch in the state of Texas.
This will be the first visit for Putin to the United States and his fourth meeting with Bush.

hl.seg: 38/ Kidnapping of Philippine Citizen Confirmed and Kidnapping of Indian Citizen Denied

p.seg: Manila 12 November / Xinhua / The Philippine army confirmed today the kidnapping of a Filipino businessman while the local police denied reports about the kidnapping of an Indian citizen.
ABS-CBN Channel said in a report via the internet today that 15 armed men kidnapped on Saturday Lidio Castro, a fishing boat owner, in the province of Tawi-Tawi located in southern Philippines.
The report said that Castro was kidnapped from aboard his boat then taken to Languian Island in the south and that police did not discover yet the kidnappers' motive.

On another front, a separate report explained that the alleged kidnapping of an Indian citizen in the city of Manila earlier today turned out to be an operation carried out by a group from the immigration forces.
The group was aiming at capturing the Indian but it "forgot" to coordinate with the police authority who published a major headline in the news media asking police to search in the surrounding areas.
The apprehended Indian citizen was taken to the Immigration Authority offices, but he was immediately released.
The police authority asked other law enforcing agencies to coordinate with it first to avoid chaos between the authorities, especially in these "delicate times."

hl.seg: 48 /Arab-Israeli Legislator Accused of Aiding Hezbollah

p.seg: Jerusalem 12 November / Xinhua / The Israeli Attorney General's Office issued an indictment against the Arab legislator, Azmy Bshara, for aiding Hezbollah in the local court in Jerusalem, according to what Radio Israel reported.
The Knesset had voted to lift the parliamentary immunity off of Bshara last Wednesday due to statements he made in favor of the Hezbollah Party against the Israeli occupation.
Azmy Bshara is considered the first Arab legislator to lose parliamentary immunity in the history of Israel going back 53 years.

Bshara had made these statements separately in a popular rally in northern Israel during a celebration to commemorate the first anniversary of the passing of Syrian President Hafez Al Assad in Damascus, Syria.
Bshara was also accused of encouraging the Palestinians to resist the Israeli aggression.
It is also suspected that the Arab legislator helps Israel's Arabs in visiting Syria illegally.

It is to be noted that Hezbollah, which is supported by Syria and Iran, continued resistance until it forced the Israeli forces to withdraw eventually from Southern Lebanon in May 2000, ending their occupation which lasted 22 years in the border region.
Hezbollah has vowed to continue with its war against Israel as long as she occupies the disputed Shaba farms on the Syrian-Lebanese-Israeli borders.

hl.seg: Ripe Fruits for Trade Fair in Central China

p.seg: Woohan 13 November / Xinhua/ The Third Woohan Economic and Trade Fair was concluded a few days ago in the city of Woohan, the capital city of the Hopei Province in Central China.
The fair, which lasted four days, brought about 46 foreign-financed projects with foreign investments of 979 million US dollars.
The fair covers a wide series of sectors such as retail sales, energy, transportation, protection of the environment, communications, tourism and logistic services.
Thousands of local visitors and managers of large international companies participated in it.
During the fair, discussions were held on regional cooperation between the provinces on the banks of the Yangtze River, as well in the western and central parts of the country.
31 contracts were signed in with an investment of 2.98 billion yuan / 359 million US dollars/.

hl.seg: Facts and Figures: China's Exports to the European Union

p.seg: Beijing 14 November / Xinhua/ The following are the latest facts and figures for China's main exports to the European Union for the period of January/September this year, according to the General Authority of Customs.
Machinery products, electronics, audio visual equipment, spare parts and associated necessities 10.427 billion US dollars.
Textile materials and products 3.505 billion US dollars.
Miscellaneous products / light fixtures, furniture, children toys, etc./ 2.
492 billion US dollars.
Base metals and associated products 2.113 billion US dollars.
Chemical products 2.006 billion US dollars.
Automobiles, planes, ships and transportation means 1.605 billion US dollars.
Fur, leathers and associated products 1.409 billion US dollars.

hl.seg: China Joins the World Trade Organization and the Banking Sector Develops in Hong Kong

p.seg: Hong Kong 13 November / Xinhua / Banking sources unanimously agreed that China's joining of the World Trade Organization and the opening of the banking sector in the Chinese inner regions will open unlimited commercial opportunities for the banking sector in the private administrative region of Hong Kong.
It is noted that Hong Kong is an international financial center, and its banking sector is distinct with long history, ample expertise and good performance qualification.

Following China's joining of the World Trade Organization, the sizzling development of trade and investment in the Chinese inner regions will require more money, the development of the country's west, industrial re-framing, and Beijing's readiness to host the Olympiad in 2008 demand a great deal of investments, which makes the financial market in Hong Kong play a bigger role in offering financial services to the Chinese inner regions.

hl.seg: 37/ Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Talks about Fighting Terrorism

p.seg: Beijing 13 November / Xinhua / China welcomes and supports the resolution and the unanimity reached by the international community on fighting terrorism, according to what was iterated by the spokesman of the Foreign Ministry, Chou Pang Xiao, on Tuesday.
