It is noted that the Security Council has organized a meeting of the foreign ministers on the subject of fighting terrorism, which was ratified by the above-mentioned resolution.

Xiao said that the resolution has demonstrated the resolve of the international community and agreement on consolidating cooperation in the struggle against all forms of terrorism and on effecting the leading role of the United Nations and the Security Council to the maximum level.

hl.seg: 106 / Saudi Helicopter Crashes

p.seg: Riyadh 13 November / Xinhua / An official source at the Saudi Ministry of Defense and Aviation said that a Saudi helicopter crashed yesterday evening and that three of its crew died.

The Saudi News Agency reported from the source that an accident occurred when a model 212 helicopter belonging to the Saudi Royal Air Force crashed yesterday evening in the north western region, 30 miles south of King Faisal Airbase, as a result of a technical malfunction while on a nightly training flight.

The source explained that "as a result of the accident, the plane was destroyed and all of its crew, consisting of the pilot, Air Captain Ghazi Bin Ahmad Al Asmari, Air Captain Saad Bin Ali Al Garni and Chief Technical Sergeant Faleh Bin Mohammad Al Aydi, died."

hl.seg: 13/ Jiang Sends Letter of Condolences on Plane Crash to Bush

p.seg: Beijing 13 November /Xinhua/ The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, sent a letter of condolences to the American president George W. Bush today expressing his condolences to the American government and people for the plane crash accident in New York.

Xiang said in his letter "as soon as our phone conversation ended yesterday evening, I was shocked when I learned that a passenger plane had crashed in New York and left a large number of victims and property losses; I feel a great sadness for all of that."

The President added "on behalf of the Chinese government and people, I would like to convey our deepest condolences to you and through you to the government and people of the United States of America.
We also give our condolences to the victims."
The American Airlines Flight 587 had crashed with 255 persons on board shortly after takeoff from John Kennedy Airport in New York on Monday.

hl.seg: 66 / Russian Brigade Number 210 in Tajikistan Consolidates Security Measures

p.seg: Moscow 13 November / Xinhua / A high-level official at the Defense Ministry said today that Russian Brigade Number 201, which is deployed on the Tajikistani borders, consolidated its security measures due to the Taliban's threat to use weapons of mass destruction.

Lieutenant General Vladimir Khofostov, Director of Radiological, Chemical and Biological Protection Force, said that the brigade is taking additional security measures although "no more units fighting such attacks were sent to the region."
He added, "We do not see a need for that at this time".

Khofostov talked about the situation in Chechnya and said that the Chechnyan rebels tried to use biological weapons against the federal forces many times during the second Chechnyan war and that danger is still present.
He re-iterated that the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Protection Unit is "ready to respond to possible use of any weapons in Chechnya whether it is chemical or biological."

hl.seg: 113 / The Sudan and America Stress Need to By-pass Difficulties on Path to Bilateral Relations

p.seg: Khartoum 13 November / Xinhua / The Sudan and the United States expressed their desire to reach the hoped for objectives from improving relations and confirmed the continuation of dialogue and meetings via diplomatic channels.

That came in a meeting between Mustafa Othman Ismael, the Sudanese Foreign Minister, and the American Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Walter Kansteiner, along the sidelines of the UN General Assembly's meetings currently being convened in New York, where they discussed the bilateral relations.

The Sudanese News Agency / SUNA / this evening quoted Khedr Haroun, Acting Ambassador at the Embassy of the Sudan in Washington, as saying via a telephone communication that the meeting covered the standing issues between the two countries and the need to incessantly seek to by-pass the difficulties that impede the road of bilateral relations.
He added that an agreement was reached between the two parties to step up the tone of dialogue seeking tangible results in the area of relations.

He said that Minister Mustafa expressed Sudan's desire to improve relations with the United States and stressed the importance of creating transparency to migrate from this phase of relations to a another special phase, especially since the previous period had witnessed dialogues and meetings between the two sides.

hl.seg: United Nations Warns of Exacerbation of Human Crisis in Case of Deterioration of Security Situation

p.seg: United Nations 13 November / Xinhua / The United Nations warned in a press release issued on Monday that the already desperate humanitarian conditions in Afghanistan will worsen if law and order broke down on a larger scale in this country.
The release said "that the continuation of violence and security deterioration may impede the efforts to reach people who are in urgent need for humanitarian aid."

The release warned by saying that "if food, shelter and medicine were not made available as soon as possible, northern Afghanistan may witness an unimaginable humanitarian catastrophe" due to the spread of the already impending famine on a large part of the region.

It described the situation in the city of Mazar El-Sharif, which fell in the hands of the Northern Alliance at the end of last week, as explosive, pointing that "reports indicated that some elements looted UN offices and non-governmental organizations, including food storerooms."

Meanwhile, the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, called on all fighters in Mazar El-Sharif to take every possible measure "to guarantee total observation of the rights of fighters and non-combatants, including civilians from different minority groups.

The Commissioner said in a statement issued this Sunday, "It is time to end the state of escaping from punishment in Afghanistan, and added, "This is the least that can be guaranteed for civilian inhabitants who have been suffering for a long time."

hl.seg: Prime Ministers of Portugal and Britain Discuss Future of Europe

p.seg: Lisbon 13 November / Xinhua / The Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Guterres will meet with his British counterpart, Tony Blair, this week amid displeasure caused by Lisbon's exception from attending the mini summit that gathered the European Union's leaders in London on November 4, according to what Guterres' office announced on Monday.
But Guterres said that his meeting with Blair on Wednesday morning in London will focus on Europe's future and not on easing relations.
Guterres told reporters after a meeting with Estonian Prime Minister Mart Lar, "Portugal is always interested in working for the future.
As far as we are concerned, working for the future means the need to work for a united and politically effective Europe, and one which agrees on fighting terrorism."
On the relations with London, Guterres affirmed that "relations are very quiet."

Blair, who had called on the leaders from Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Holland and Belgium / who periodically presides over the European Union / to meet on November 4 in London on Afghanistan, laid exception to Portugal and seven other small countries from the Union.

The official added that Guterres will head to Brussels on Wednesday for a meeting with Belgian Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt; then he flies to Vienna to hold talks with Austrian Chancellor Wolfgang Schuessel, who also expressed his displeasure on the mini summit called by Blair.

hl.seg: Discovery of First Mad Cow Disease in Slovenia

p.seg: Belgrade 13 November / Xinhua/ The Yugoslavian Tanug News Agency reported Monday that the first case of Mad Cow Disease was discovered in Slovenia.

The agency quoted Slovenian Agriculture Minister Franc as saying that the National Veterinarian Institute in the Slovenian capital, Ljubljana, had confirmed the case of contracting this disease after conducting three tests on a cow from a farm belonging to a company in the Jornija Savinijaka region.

Tanug added that this news added a new worry to local farmers and meat exporters concerning the possibility of beef price deterioration in the domestic and international markets, and cast more dark shadows over the already-pessimistic horizons in the country.
It is noted that Mad Cow Disease, scientifically called Inflammation of Spongy Brain, can be transmitted to humans and causes an impairment of the brain.
In Britain, more than 80 people died from this disease.

hl.seg: 83/ Canadian Police Investigates Possibility of Relationship Between Company and Al Qaeda Network

p.seg: Ottawa 14 November / Xinhua / Local papers said today that the Royal Canadian police are investigating the possibility of an existing relationship between a Canadian company and the terrorist Al Qaeda Network led by Osama Bin Laden.

A business card bearing the name and address of 4-U Enterprise Limited in Vancouver region was found in an office vacated by Al Qaeda Network in Kabul yesterday, shortly after the entry of Northern Alliance forces into the city and the Taliban's escaping it.
Written in the card "Omar M.
Hamid General Manager of 4-U Enterprise Company."
Also found in the Kabul office were explosives and a large number of documents describing how to blow up bridges.
Also, the British Broadcast Corporation reported that the company manufactures airplane simulators.
But when Central TV reporters in Vancouver went to this address, they discovered that it is a post office box in an entertainment gadget store.
A lady in the store said that police officers asked her to take a letter that was found in the rented box with documents full of records when the box was rented for the first time.
A search of business records in British Columbia showed that the company was merged in 1998 and is now being dismantled.
The records showed the names of two men, considered company managers, and they are Esam Marzouk and a misrepresented name of Hamid listed under the name Amr Mohammad.

hl.seg: 44 / Chinese Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister Visits Jordan

p.seg: Amman 14 November / Xinhua / Mr. Chi Fong Cheng, the Chinese Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Minister, arrived in Amman this afternoon for a visit to Jordan that will last three days.

Leading the welcoming party for him at Queen Alia International Airport was Dr. Salah El-Din Al Bashir, the Jordanian Minister of Industry and Trade, and several Jordanian officials at the Ministry of Industry and Trade.

The Chinese minister is to meet during his visit with the Jordanian monarch, King Abdullah II, and the Jordanian Prime Minister, Ali Abu Al Raghib, and is also to hold talks with his Jordanian counterpart on ways to enhance and develop the commercial and economic relations between the two countries.

hl.seg: 84 / Palestinian Authority Arrests Jihad Leader in the West Bank

p.seg: Gaza 14 November / Xinhua/ Palestinian security forces arrested one of the leaders of Islamic Jihad Movement in Jenin in the West Bank, according to the Palestinian sources.
The sources added that Mahmoud Nourasi Al Twalbi /23 / was arrested at the hands of Palestinian security forces and was thrown in one of the prisons in the city of Nablus.
It was said that Al Twalbi was one of the men wanted by Israel and accused of involvement in planning suicide bombings.

Jenin witnessed a wide-spread riot following the arrest of Twalbi, where thousands of Palestinians demonstrated in protest and surrounded the headquarters of the Preventive Forces in the city and threw hand grenades and rocks at police and burned some cars which were parked in streets.
Some demonstrators were injured as a result of the anti-riot operation carried out by Palestinian security forces.

hl.seg: Interest Rates on American Treasury Department Notes Fall to Lowest Levels in 43 Years

p.seg: Washington 14 November / Xinhua / Short-term interest rates on Treasury Department notes fell to their lowest levels in 43 years on Tuesday.
The Treasury Department sold three-month notes valued at 16 billion dollars at a lower interest rate of 1.815 percent, which is lower than last week's rate that reached 1.
975 percent, and with that, three-month notes scored their lowest interest rate since August 11, 1958, when it reached 1.524 percent.
The Department also sold 16 billion dollars worth of six-month notes at a lower interest rate of 1.820 percent, which is lower than last week's rate which was 1.
920 percent and which is considered the lowest level scored by these notes during the 43 years since they were first issued for circulation.
It is noted that the Treasury Department had issued the six-month notes for circulation in December 1958, while the three-month notes debuted in the month of December of 1929.

In a separate report, the Federal Reserve Bank said on Tuesday that rates on the Treasury Department one-year notes with constant interest, which are considered most popular when making changes to constant debt ratios, fell to 1.99 percent last week after it was 2.11 percent the week before.

hl.seg: UN Envoy Stresses Importance of Bringing Afghan Sides to Talks

p.seg: United Nations 14 November / Xinhua / The United Nations Special Envoy said here on Tuesday that it is not time yet to send UN peace-keeping forces to Afghanistan, which is torn by war, and that it is important to include all Afghani sides in the peace talks.

Al Akhdar Al Ibrahimi, the Special Representative on Afghanistan to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, told reporters here that "it is not time yet" to think about sending UN peace-keeping forces to Afghanistan.
He said, "I think that the important thing is putting them together," meaning all Afghani sides, including the Northern Alliance which had earlier occupied the Afghani capital.

Al Ibrahimi made this statement after he gave his speech before an open meeting of the Security Council on Afghanistan and in which he presented a political five-point plan on Afghanistan that starts with convening a conference for all Afghani parties.

Al Ibrahimi, who formerly occupied the position of the Algerian Foreign Minister, revealed to the Security Council, which is composed of 15 members, that a high-level political official at the UN may head to Kabul, security permitting, but he opposed sending UN peace-keeping forces to the country.
Al Ibrahimi said before a general meeting of the Council that his five-point plan "was based on ideas that Afghanis themselves thoroughly discussed."

hl.seg: Bolstering of Infrastructure Construction in Waiqaoxiao Free Zone in China

p.seg: Shanghai 18 November / Xinhua / Shanghai / The largest industrial and commercial center in China / decided to invest more than 10 billion yuan to consolidate the infrastructure and trading sector construction in the Waiqaoxiao Free Zone / the largest free zone in China / for the purpose of establishing an international transaction base with more competitive power in the Asian and the Pacific region.
According to the plan, this base will split into two sectors, one north and one south.

A transaction park will be built in the northern sector on an area of 1.2 square kilometers relying on marine transit to make available a service launch for Chinese and foreign transaction institutions dealing with container transportation.
The southern sector will be for developing aerial trading.

In light of the plan, the Waiqaoxiao Free Zone will achieve a total value of 40 billion US dollars of exports and imports annually by attracting 20 international ship companies, 50 giant transaction institutions and 200 transcontinental institutions.

hl.seg: Bolstering Post-Doctorate Works in China

p.seg: Nanxiang 16 November / Xinhua / According to the tenth five-year plan 2001 / 2005 for boosting post-doctorate works, China will boost work in this field for the purpose of establishing a thousand stations for post-doctorate works and will raise the number of researchers in them from 12 to 15 thousand in the year 2005.

According to this plan, the state will allocate funds to help a number of doctorate holders to practice research and projects dealing with areas of interest to development strategy and national socio-economic development.

This plan will also encourage doctorate holders who study abroad and foreign doctorate holders to conduct post-doctorate research in China for the purpose of expanding the international exchange in post-doctorate fields.

So far, 947 post-doctorate research stations were established in China, in which 7 thousand researches are working, provided that 20 percent of recipients of funding from the Youth Fund, which is a part of the National Natural Sciences Fund, are post-doctorate researchers.

hl.seg: Bolstering of Testing, Censorship and Management of Medicine Advertising in China

p.seg: Beijing 16 November / Xinhua / A Chinoi reporter has learned from the State Authority of Censoring and Managing Medicine Advertising in China that it will bolster its work to test, censor and manage the required advertisements for non-prescription medicines.

It is known that since the first of December 2001, advertisers must submit information on non-prescription medicines that were approved by the State Authority of Censoring and Managing Medicine Advertising.

Beginning on the first of February 2002, public media will be banned from publishing advertisements on some prescription medicines like the medicines used for heart attacks, high blood pressure, liver inflammations and diabetes, as well as antibiotics and hormonal medicines.
Beginning the first of July 2002, the media will be banned from publishing advertisements on medicines that only meet local standards.
The State Authority of Censoring and Managing Medicine Advertising affirmed that the recently-amended "Medicine Management Law" will take effect soon.

hl.seg: 43/ Urgent: CNN Says Bin Laden in Southern Afghanistan

p.seg: Islamabad 15 November / Xinhua / The American CNN TV network said today quoting sources inside Afghanistan that Osama Bin Laden, prime suspect in the September 11 terrorist attacks against the United States, is now inside Afghanistan.
CNN quoted the same sources as saying that Bin Laden is moving "from cave to cave".

In another related development, Pakistan tightened security measures along the borders with Afghanistan in which the ruling movement, the Taliban, suffered a series of defeats at the hands of the opposing Northern Alliance in order to prevent Bin Laden from infiltrating the Pakistani territories.

hl.seg: 50/ Zhu Rung Xie Calls for Faster Modernization of Tax System

p.seg: Beijing 15 November / Xinhua / The Chinese State Council Premier, Zhu Rongji, called on the National Tax Administration to use the information technology to fight tax evasion.

Zhu made his speech before high-level officials at the state's Tax Administration early this week in which he called for doubling of the efforts to carry out this work known as the Golden Tax Project.

The project started in 1995 in an attempt to establish a national network based on computers and other advanced technology means to fight counterfeit bills, such as the counterfeit value-added tax bills.

During his exploratory tour of the Administration, the State Council Premier expressed his gratitude to tax collectors all over the country for the steady growth in tax revenues during the past years.
He also called for exert efforts so that governmental administrations to bolstered by the general electronic administration.

He said that a link must be established between the information system used by customs, banks, foreign currency administrations, police, foreign trade and tax administrations in order to improve the efficiency of government work and consolidate law enforcement.

hl.seg: 59/ Tianjin Fourth Largest Port in China

p.seg: Tianjin 15 November / Xinhua / Officials at the Tianjin Port in north China said today that the port exceeded the 100 million ton mark in volume of goods shipped and unloaded so far this year, making it the fourth most active port in China.
The Tianjin Port is now considered the first in north China to ship and unload more than 100 million tons of goods in a year.
It is noted that China's three other biggest ports are Shanghai and Ningbo in the east and Guangzhou in the south.
Sources said the Tianjin Port plans to increase its shipping and unloading capacity to 140 million tons and 7 million 20-foot units by 2010.

hl.seg: 83/ Man Dies after 83-Year Marriage

p.seg: Los Angeles 15 November / Xinhua / Harry Otter, who set a record in the length of his marriage, died at the age of 103 five months after of celebrating his eighty-third wedding anniversary with his wife.
Otter died last Monday in a home for the elderly where he and his wife, Silvia, lived.
The two married on June 15, 1918, at the bride's parents home in Pittsburgh near Dayton.
They did not have enough for a honeymoon.
Then they moved to Dayton where they rented a house for 19.50 US dollars a month.
They also lived in Rochester, New York, then moved to Chicago before they went back to Ohio during the Depression.
Otter worked as an accountant at the Greenville Luggage Company until he retired in 1965.

During their eighty-third wedding anniversary celebration, Silvia Otter, who's also 103, said that she does not believe in divorce and talked about the importance of marriage to her three children who have all been married for a long time.
She said that she and her husband lived "a good and clean life" without smoking or alcohol, and they used to attend church regularly.
She added, "We still live one day at a time and are content with what is meant for us."
The Guinness Book of World Records listed this marriage as the longest of its kind between two people who are still alive.
Otter was survived by two sons and one daughter besides his wife.

hl.seg: 3 / Iraq Opens Trade Office in Germany

p.seg: Baghdad 15 November / Xinhua / An Iraqi newspaper said today that Iraq will soon open a trade office in the German capital for the first time since 1990.
The weekly // Al Zawra // Newspaper issued here quoted an official source in the Iraqi Commerce Ministry as saying "Iraq in the near future will open a trade office in the German capital, Berlin."
The source explained that the recent expansion of trade relations between Iraq and Germany requires such an office, which will unofficially oversee all of such transactions.

It is noted that Germany participated effectively in the 34th Annual International Baghdad Fair, which concluded yesterday, where the German pavilion's area was 6 thousand square meters and various German goods such as cars, equipment, technical and electrical systems, food items and medicines, etc., were exhibited.

Diplomatic relations between Iraq and Germany were cut since the second Gulf War in 1991, and a number of German figures and businessmen have called for re-opening the German Embassy in Baghdad and activating the economic and commercial relations with Iraq.

hl.seg: 10/ Headline News in Major Israeli Newspapers

p.seg: Jerusalem 15 November / Xinhua / Following is the headlines news reported by major Israeli newspapers on Thursday.
// Jerusalem Post //:

-- It is expected that the Israeli Foreign Minister will deliver a speech to the General Assembly of the United Nations in which he will say that there is wide support between Israelis for the establishment of two states for two peoples - Israel with a disarmed Palestinian state.
// Ha'aretz // :

-- The United States will send retired Navy Commander Anthony Zinny and prominent diplomat William Burns as special envoys from Bush to the Middle East, immediately following the speech of American Secretary of State, Colin Powell, on Middle East policy next week at the University of Kentucky.
// Maariv // :

-- Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, told CNN network on Wednesday that an independent Palestinian state has become "today an acceptable solution by almost all sides", and said that the idea that each of the Israeli and Palestinian peoples have a separate state and that they co-exist fairly has been acceptable by everyone.
// Yediot Aharonot // :

-- The President of the Palestinian Authority, Yasser Arafat, ordered the release on Wednesday of a leader from Islamic Jihad who was detained in the city of Jenin in the West Bank in the aftermath of rapacious Palestinian demonstrations outside the prison where he was being held since his arrest.

hl.seg: 31/ Israel Eases Restrictions on Palestinians in Ramadan

p.seg: Jerusalem 15 November / Xinhua / The Israeli Defense Minister, Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, decided to ease restrictions on the Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip on the eve of the holy month of Ramadan.
This was reported by Radio Israel on Thursday.
These measures will be effective starting today, Thursday, two days before the start of Ramadan, the ninth month in the Islamic year and the month of fasting from sunrise to sunset.
It is noted that the restrictions imposed on Palestinians' travel that will be eased include removing road blocks and opening of certain roads.
Eretz and Rafah passes on the northern and southern borders of the Gaza Strip will also be opened for a few extra hours to allow the crossing of more goods into Gaza.
Also, the fishing limits for Palestinians will be extended to three miles from the Gaza Port.
It is worth noting that Moslems from the West bank and Gaza Strip will be allowed to pray in the holy mosque inside the old city of Jerusalem.

It is noted that since the outbreak of the Palestinian uprising against the Israeli occupation in September 2000, Moslems from the West Bank and Gaza Strip were banned from praying in Jerusalem's old city mosques.

hl.seg: Russia Sends Humanitarian Aid to Cuba

p.seg: Havana 15 November / Xinhua / Two planes arrived from Russia carrying humanitarian aid to the Caribbean country that suffered destruction by Hurricane Mitchell.. according to // Granma //, the official Cuban daily newspaper on Wednesday.

The two planes which are carrying emergency supplies such as baby food, canned meat, milk, rice, window glass and door were sent by the Russian Civil Defense and Emergencies Ministry, and landed at Jose Marty International Airport in Havana.
The Russian Ambassador to Cuba, Andre Dimitrov, explained that this donation is considered "a normal step between friends in tough times."
The Russian diplomat added that, even though Cuba did not ask for international aid, the Russian president Putin, decided on Monday to give aid to Cuba to help overcome the disaster.

It is noted that Hurricane Mitchell, which had a speed of 210 kilometers per hour, ravaged Cuba during the period from November 4 to 5 resulting in the death of 5 people and forcing 700 thousand people to evacuate their homes and caused serious economic losses.

hl.seg: 10/ Rwanda Protests Arrest of Citizens

p.seg: Kampala 16 November / Xinhua / Rwanda protested the arrest of 9 Rwandans and detaining them without trial by the Ugandan security forces, according to the Monitor newspaper today.
This protest came in a statement issued on 14 November from the Rwandan Embassy in Kampala and signed by the Acting Ambassador, Bin Rutsinga.

The statement read "that the Embassy of the Republic of Rwanda in Kampala urges the government of Uganda and the human rights organizations in the world to intervene to correct this non-humane situation."
Rutsinga said that Rwandans residing in, visitors to, and those who temporarily stopped in Uganda were randomly arrested.
The statement added "the Ugandan security forces arrested them and some of them were subjected to torture."
Rutisinga said that no specific charges were filed against the Rwandans. but they have been detained for over a month.

hl.seg: 91 / Annan and Putin Meet to Discuss Terrorism and Situation in Afghanistan

p.seg: United Nations 16 November / Xinhua / The United Nations said that the UN Secretary General, Kofi Annan, met yesterday evening with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who is visiting the UN Headquarters in New York to discuss fighting terrorism and the situation in Afghanistan.
Putin affirmed the importance of the role played by the Security Council whose recent resolutions formed a good basis for international cooperation to defeat terrorism, according to a UN report.
The Russian leader said that it is important to make sure that these resolutions, including the issue of funding terrorism, were adhered to.
The UN said that "there is a long discussion on the situation in Afghanistan and the need to form a wide-based and inclusive government.
They agreed that the challenge is how to move early toward that government."
Annan and Putin also discussed the summit that was just concluded between Putin and the American president George W. Bush.
The UN said that "the Secretary General expressed his conviction that the American-Russian bilateral relationship is proceeding well and that it is a valuable relationship to the world."
Putin was on his way home after the conclusion of his talks with Bush, during which they failed to reach agreement on permitting the United States to build a comprehensive defense system.

hl.seg: China Interested in Unique Role Played by Tunisia on World Stage

p.seg: Tunis 16 November / Xinhua / Lee Ping, China's prominent legislator, iterated on Thursday that China is very interested in the unique role played by Tunisia in resolving regional and international issues, following her selection as a non-permanent member of the Security Council.
Lee Ping, Chairman of the Chinese Parliament's Permanent Committee, made that statement during his talks with his Tunisian counterpart, Foad Al Mibza.
Lee Ping pointed that China and Tunisia maintained friendly coordination and cooperation in international affairs and exerted joint efforts regarding the issue of peace and development in the world.
Lee is currently conducting an official visit to Tunisia.
The two leaders exchanged viewpoints and reached agreement on pending issues by coordinating the bilateral relations and parliaments of the two countries.

hl.seg: Storm Hits Sweden and Norway

p.seg: Stockholm 16 November / Xinhua / A strong storm hit Sweden and Norway on Thursday resulting in disrupting transportation and power lines in these two countries.
Meteorological reports said that some places in these two countries were swept by stormy winds with speeds of 115 km per hour, equivalent to hurricane winds in its strength.
The two countries were forced to shut down railroads and highways, and some ports and airports were also closed because of the storm.
Power and telephone lines were cut from hundreds of homes.
The Oresund Bridge, which connects Norway with Denmark, was closed for four hours.
Meteorologists expected that the storm will quiet down Friday night.

hl.seg: Standardization of Construction Market System in China

p.seg: / First Addition /

And the serious enforcement of laws, related tariffs and compulsory standards of project construction, and actually guaranteeing its quality and safety, and consolidating the build-up of law-enforcement worker units in the construction market, and raising the level of government authorities responsible for the construction market in performing work according to the law, and enforcing the law accurately and achieving separation of government authorities from institutions, and separating politics from administrative work, and executing "State Council regulations concerning banning regional barriers during economic activities in the market", and correcting work related to placement of barriers and obstacles before the construction market in violation of the laws, and placement of protective and regional barriers.

The circular noted that the executive stature of the state's laws and regulations related to construction projects must be bolstered, and investigations in violations of laws and regulations intensified.

hl.seg: High-Tech Exports in China Increasing Beijing 17 November / Xinhua / Chinese high-tech exports continue to increase progressively since the current year.

According to customs statistics, high-tech exports reached 36.465 billion US dollars during the period of January/October of this year, increasing by 23.6 percent compared to the same period last year; the growth rate was higher by 17.5 percentage points of the national sum in which it constitutes 16.8 percent.

p.seg: The Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Deputy Minister // Sun Chun Yoy // said that the high-tech export volume comprised 64.8 percent of all exports in the first ten months of this year, including 4.531 billion US dollars of these exports last October at an increasing rate of 28.
36 percent.

hl.seg: Discovery of 1600-Year-Old Battlefield

p.seg: Taiwan 17 November / Xinhua / Ruins were recently discovered of a battlefield from the Mingqing wars that had an important impact on the development of ancient history in China.
This field is located at the crossroads of Xiangfin and Chiwah counties at the city of Linfin in the Shansi Province.
Available historical records did not readily explain where the battlefield of the ancient Mingqing wars is located.

After 3 years of field studies, Professor Xian Cheng Kha, the renowned Chinese history and geography expert, has arrived at a solution to this problem, in cooperation with one of the Shansi map publishers.

Professor Xian Cheng Kha said that four battles took place in Mingqing: the battle between the northern Wi family and last Chen family in the year 402 A.D., the battle between the eastern Wi family and northern Wi family in the year 538 A.D., the battle between the northern Cho family and northern Chi family in the year 576 A.D., and the battle between the last Liang family and last Xian family in the year 909 A.D.
The first and third battles were the most important battles in which more than 200 thousand soldiers participated.

It is noted that Mingqing is comprised of a valley on the Llos Plateau extending 15 kilometers in length and one kilometer in width, and it was a strategic location in the era of hand-to-hand fighting.

hl.seg: 54 / Russian Arms "Contract Bag" Inflated

p.seg: Moscow 17 November / Xinhua / The Russian Deputy Prime Minister, Ilya Klebanov, announced today that as of now the number of Russian arms sales has risen by 50 percent during this year.
Klebanov said that "the arms bag" helped increase cash flow adding that there are other very large aircraft manufacturing contracts already under study.
He said that most countries give priority to modernizing offensive aircraft, then the navy in the second place, while ground forces occupy the third place.

The Deputy Minister, who is in charge of the military industry in the country, also said in a press conference today that the international effort to fight terrorism will not affect Russia's understanding on military-techno cooperation.
He said that Russia does not violate her commitments in the area of arms sales because she "possess one of the strictest arms sales mechanisms in the world."

He added that when Russia receives purchase requests for arms that can be in the very least classified as banned, the issue involves a joint decision by the president, the Security Council, the Foreign and Defense Ministries.
Klebanov said that Russia works closely with a number of European companies in the arms market.
He gave an example of France as a major partner in aircraft and space technology modernization and other areas, and he noted the close cooperation with Germany.
Klebanov indicated that Russia needs to look for new markets for weapons, especially the Latin America and Africa markets.
He said, "We are trying to enter these markets, but it will be quite difficult to penetrate them.

hl.seg: 11 / Sudanese Government Ratifies Establishment of Independent National Center for Human Rights

p.seg: Khartoum 17 November / Xinhua / The Sudanese government ratified the establishment for the first time of an independent and neutral national center for human rights in the Sudan to face a flood of criticism that has been continuously directed toward the human rights record of the Sudan.

// Al Ayyam // Newspaper quoted the Sudanese Justice Minister, Ali Yassin, as saying that intensive efforts are being conducted now in the government administrations and parliament to establish the neutral and independent center and to staff it with experts and various political rainbow colors so that the reports issued on human rights and follow-up on violations enjoy credibility, transparency and neutrality.

The Sudanese Minister announced earlier the approval of the Council of Ministers for establishing this center through his sanctioning of the ministry's plan that called for it, aiming for more neutrality and credibility on human rights issues and improving their record.

Ali Yassin expressed his hope that the center, which was ratified by the parliament earlier, maintain its neutrality and does not adopt political agendas and practices constructive criticism with neutrality, credibility and transparency for a better status for human rights in the Sudan.

The United States and some Western countries had accused the Sudan of violating human rights and practicing slavery in the Sudan and had imposed sanctions on her while the unilateral American sanctions on the Sudan have been extended for another year under the pretext of the US concern about the human rights situation in the Sudan.
Improving the human rights status is considered a major issue in the dialogue between the Sudan and the European Union countries.

hl.seg: Latest Development on American Attacks in Afghanistan

p.seg: / First Addition /
Islamabad - A Pakistani government spokesman described on Friday the news which reported that Osama Bin Laden had entered the Pakistani territories as "an absolute lie and pure fantasy."

This came in response to what Radio Iran reported about Osama Bin Laden's escape from Afghanistan and his hiding in the Pakistani Tayra region, according to was reported by the Pakistani Associated Press.

Moscow - An official Russian delegation departed on Friday to Afghanistan "to establish working communications with the legitimate leadership in that country", according to what the Defense Minister, Sergei Ivanov, announced here on Friday.
Ivanov said, "This first group includes representatives from the Foreign, Defense and Emergency Affairs Ministries."

Interfax Agency quoted military sources as saying that the delegation, which is comprised of ten members, will fly to the Tajikistani capital, Dushanbe, first and then fly by helicopter to the Afghani capital Kabul, where the headquarters of the Afghani opposition leader, Burhan Al-Din Rayani is located.

hl.seg: 23 / Iran's Foreign Minister Returns from UN General Assembly Annual Session

p.seg: Tehran 18 November / Xinhua / Local news media said that Iran's Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharazi, returned home early this morning after attending the 56th Annual Session of the UN General Assembly.
Kharazi was accompanying President Mohammed Khatami who attended the UN General Assembly's Annual Session on November 8.
He also met with UN Secretary General, Kofi Annan.

In addition, Iran's Foreign Minister met with his counterparts from a number of countries including China, Britain, South Africa, Pakistan, Morocco, Libya, Jordan, Azerbaijan and Syria and discussed with them bilateral cooperation and the current crisis in Afghanistan.

Kharazi spoke on Saturday before the annual meeting of the Non-aligned Movement, along the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, stressing that the war against terrorism can not be complete without dealing with Israeli "state terrorism".

He indicated that the Middle East crisis and the Palestinian issue can be resolved through acknowledging historical and current realities in the regions, the restoration of the indispensable Palestinian national rights and the establishment of an independent Palestinian state with Jerusalem as its capital.
The UN General Assembly's Annual Session, held from the period from November 8 to 10, discussed the international campaign against terrorism and the latest developments in the Afghani crisis.

hl.seg: 66 / News Analysis: Kandahar Last Taliban Refuge in Warm Waters

p.seg: /First and Last Addition/

Despite that and between all news and rumors that have been spreading about the Taliban's decision to retreat, a question comes up about the reason for the continuing presence of the Taliban forces or some of them in Kandahar.

Surely they are seeking to select suitable areas that will be more secure and more secretive hiding places in Kandahar while they consider turning over power to parties not closely aligned with the Americans or the Northern Alliance in order to preserve their influence in this city and the surrounding region in anticipation of their possible "return."
The second question is certainly raised, based on previous justification, which is where are they going?
There will be no suitable place for the Taliban except for the mountains that they are as used to living in as they are used to living in their homes.
It is possible that they will fix these areas to make them new centers in order to save themselves from the caves and tunnels that the Americans cannot reach with their high-tech military machine.

Also, the Taliban are seeking, as a possibility albeit excessively costly, to quench their wild ambition to restore their military power and terrorize the upcoming Afghani governments in Kabul and other regions.
Nevertheless, the Taliban are looking for a break to survive for the longest possible period.

hl.seg: 44/ The Jordanian Monarch Receives French Foreign Ministry Official

p.seg: Amman 18 November / Xinhua/ The Jordanian monarch, King Abdullah II, received today in Amman the Director of the Middle East and North Africa Department at the French Foreign Ministry, the visiting M. Zierre Yves Oban.

The Jordanian News Agency / Petra / reported that the French official conveyed to the Jordanian monarch a letter from French President Jacque Chirac relating to the Franco-European efforts aiming at moving the peace process in the Middle East region.

President Chirac affirmed in the letter the importance of the efforts exerted by King Abdullah II to help end the cycle of violence witnessed by the Palestinian territories and the return to the negotiating table, indicating that France will work with the European countries to support all movements aiming at returning the peace process to its right path.
The French official arrived here earlier today on a short visit to Jordan.

hl.seg: The Group of 20 Supports Everyone Benefiting from Globalization Equally

p.seg: Ottawa 18 November / Xinhua / Financial officials in the Group of 20 countries called on Saturday for exerting more efforts to guarantee that everyone is benefiting equally from globalization.

Finance ministers and central bank governors agreed, in a statement ratified by them during a meeting of the Group of 20 that started on Friday and lasts three days, that the big economic integration led to a noticeable improvement in people's standard of living.
The statement said "that the Group of 20 and other countries that joined the world system generally achieved a significant improvement in their revenues and in reducing poverty."
The statement indicated that "despite that, globalization raises a number of challenges and risks, which leads to bolstering international cooperation."

The statement added that the ministers agreed to work with international finance organizations and the World Trade Organization to guarantee that everyone benefits equally, including poor countries as well.

The Group of 20 includes the industrial countries of the Group of 7 and other major economies such as Argentina, Australia, Brazil, China, South Korea, India, Indonesia, Mexico, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and Turkey.
The first meeting of the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of 20 was held in Berlin, Germany, in 1999.

hl.seg: NATO Welcomes Elections in Kosovo

p.seg: / First and Last Addition/
Robinson added, "During these elections, all minorities in Kosovo participated in a positive way in electing their general representative in the local parliament.
And I express my admiration for all minority members, including members of the tax minority who showed their responsible spirit by taking this opportunity to practice their rights."

According to reports received here, participation was wide-spread among the ethnic Albanian group, which comprises the majority in the province, especially in the voting centers in the capital, Prishtina.

Despite that, early indications pointed to the fact that Serbian participations was low where the number of participants in the election in the city of Metrovica with a Serbian majority did not exceed five, and reports indicated that the reason for that is the presence of threats.

The elections were faced with opposition by the Serbian minority in Kosovo, which had a large number of people who believed that participation in the election will legitimize the ethnic Albanian's rule.

hl.seg: Foreign Investments on the Increase in Shanghai

p.seg: Shanghai 21 November / Xinhua / Local officials said that Shanghai / the largest industrial and commercial center in China / achieved an accelerating growth in foreign investments last October.
Shanghai licensed 195 foreign-financed projects with contractual foreign investments of 795 million US dollars, increasing by 42 and 38 percent, consecutively.
Officials of the Foreign Investment Business Committee in the Shanghai municipality said that 16 percent of the projects represents an investment of 10 billion US dollars for each project.
Officials added that the giant British Petroleum company invested 451 million US dollars in a huge petrochemical project.
Shanghai licensed 2040 foreign-financed projects during the period of the first ten months of this year and absorbed 6.63 billion US dollars of contractual foreign investments.
Shanghai absorbed 495 million US dollars of contractual investments in 19 real estate projects that were licensed during the period of the first ten months of the current year.

hl.seg: 18 / Report: Anti-Terrorism Legislation Dominates Indian Parliament Session

p.seg: New Delhi 19 November / Xinhua / It is expected that the confrontation between the government and the opposition on a proposal for an anti-terrorism law will dominate the current parliament winter session that started here today.

The government fully threw its weight behind the terrorism prevention law, which the government announced last October in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the United States on the eleventh of last September.

While the government will work to obtain the parliament's approval on the legislation and seek to enact it, the opposition said that it will reject the law on the grounds that it will be abused in targeting political minorities and opposition.
Despite that, the two sides agree that the danger is beyond the national security, which the government claims is the main reason behind the special measures.

The upcoming local parliamentary elections will formulate the position of the various parties from this measure, especially in the key state of Uttar Pradesh where the Bharatiya Janata Party makes anti-terrorism the focal point of its election campaign.

The Bharatiya Janata Party's proposal, which was introduced by the Interior Minister L. K. Advani, stems from the hope that the anti-terrorism election campaign will attract voters as a result of increasing national fears due to the threats of terrorism.

hl.seg: 57/ Lebanon and France Sign Mine Clearing Agreement

p.seg: Beirut 19 November / Xinhua / The official Lebanese National News Agency said today that Lebanon signed today an agreement with France on mine clearing in southern Lebanon.
The Lebanese Defense Minister, Khalil Al Harawi, and the French Ambassador to Lebanon, Philip La Courtier, signed the agreement.
According to the agreement, France will sponsor a five-year program to train on mine clearing and will host 100 Lebanese officers annually.
In addition to that, France will send experts to Lebanon to help clear mines on site.
During the signing ceremonies, Al Harawi expressed his thanks to France for the continuous help she offers to the Lebanese Army.
It is worth noting that Israel planted about 130 thousand mines in southern Lebanon during an occupation that lasted 22 years.
Israel had withdrawn her forces from southern Lebanon in May 2000, but Lebanon and the UN Interim Force in Lebanon / UNIFIL / accused Israel of not giving accurate maps for the mines.
UNIFIL, which has been clearing mines since July 2000, says that it will take about 20 years to remove all the mines left by Israel at the current pace.
More than 10 people died so far and 70 others were injured in mine explosions in southern Lebanon since the Israeli withdrawal.

hl.seg: 67/ Powell: United States Will Push Israelis and Palestinians to Reach Peace

p.seg: Washington 19 November / Xinhua / The American Secretary of State Colin Powell, said today that his country will push the Israelis and Palestinians to reach peace, and it urges them to do that.

Powell speaking at Louisville University in Kentucky renewed his call to temper down violence in the Middle East and called on both Israel and Palestine to face the reality of what they have to do to end tensions and live as two neighbors.
Powell called on the Palestinian leaders to "apprehend those who commit terrorist acts and to try and punish them."
He said, that "the Palestinian leadership must exert 100 percent efforts to end violence and terrorism."
He added "there must be real results and not just words and speeches."
Powell mentioned that the Israelis must do their part.
Many Palestinians grew up "amid road blocks, raids and humiliating treatment."

hl.seg: Yugoslavian Deputy Prime Minister Affirms Importance of Country's Unity

p.seg: Belgrade 19 November / Xinhua / Yugoslavia said on Sunday that the decision by the Paris Club to cancel her outstanding debts worth three billion US dollars shows that the international community pays more respect to her when she has become a unified country.

Deputy Premier of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, Miroljub Labus, told a local TV station that the Yugoslavian government delegation under his leadership conducted negotiations with the Paris Club on outstanding debts owed by Yugoslavia that resulted in foreign debts falling from 12.3 billion US dollars to 9.3 billion.
The country's debt ratio per capita fell to 900 dollars from 1,200 dollars.

He expressed his confidence that the debt ratio per capita in Yugoslavia will continue to drop from 900 dollars to 700 dollars after November 26 when an official government delegation will conduct another negotiation with the London Club.

The Yugoslavian Deputy Prime Minister re-iterated that if the federal republic split into two countries, neither Serbia nor Montenegro, as two separate countries, can achieve such great results in negotiations with the Paris Club or the London Club.

hl.seg: Wildlife Protection Bolstered in Chinese Province

p.seg: Chegiachwang 20 November / Xinhua / Khabe Province, located in northern China, bolstered wildlife resources protection.
Incomplete statistics showed that this province rescued about 50 thousand wild animals from 23 species during the last five years.
Khabe is rich in wildlife resources, where more than 530 species of land vertebrate live, constituting one fourth of the national total.
This includes more than 400 bird species, constituting about one third of the national total.

Among those are 17 species of animals under first-degree state protection, such as the red-crowned crane, long-tailed black tragopan and panther and 74 species of second-degree state protected animals such as the gray crane and the lynx.

In order to protect wildlife from extinction, the Khabe Province intensified its efforts to spread information on "Wildlife Protection Law" and "relevant international agreements" and organized annual activities such as "Bird Loving Week" and "Wildlife Protection Promotion Month", and arranged for certain authorities to strengthen the fight against illegal activities that consist of wild animal hunting, transporting and merchandising.
This province also built tens of natural protective habitats and forest parks that play an important role in protecting wildlife.
For example, the number of long-tailed black tragopans in Little Mount Wootai Natural Reserve increased from about 1,000 before the establishment of the reserve to more than 2,000 now.

hl.seg: 47/ Spokesman: Iranian Embassy in Kabul Commences Activities

p.seg: Tehran 20 November / Xinhua / Iran's Foreign Minister, Hamid Redha Assifi said today that the Iranian Embassy in Kabul began operations during the past few days.
Radio Bayam (The Message) quoted the spokesman as saying that many other countries announced the re-opening of their embassies in Kabul after the ruling Taliban regime was forced to flee the capital.
Earlier today, Iranian and Afghani diplomatic sources denied foreign media reports about the re-opening of the Iranian Consulate in Herat.

An Iranian official at the Foreign Ministry said that the Iranian Consul General has returned to Heart and added that this measure does not necessarily mean the re-opening of the Iranian Consulate there.
Iran remains one of the main supporters of the Northern Alliance, the Taliban opposition, which achieved a quick progress in the country that is being torn by war during the past few days.
Iran supports the Alliance's government led by Burhan El-Din Rayani who was ousted by the Taliban, which is hated by the Shiites, from Kabul in 1996.

hl.seg: 12 / Philippines President Orders Precautionary Arrest of Misuari

p.seg: Manila 20 November / Xinhua / The president of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, ordered, in the middle of her visit to the United States, to place the governor of the autonomous region of Mindanao, Nur Misuari, under precautionary arrest.

A statement issued by the presidential palace here said that the president's order was issued against Misuari "for the leading responsibility" as 400 of his followers attacked a number of military and police posts in the Jolo and Sulu Island in southern Philippines.

It was reported that the attackers came from Misuari's battalion of the Moro National Liberation Front, and no less than 59 people were killed and 28 others were injured in the battles in which rifles were used.

National Security Advisor, Roilo Golez, said, "We must remember that Misuari is not the supposed leader of the government's committee in Jolo but that he is a governor for the region and he is the senior peace officer there and, therefore, he is directly responsible for peace and order in the region."
Last week Misuari threatened to renew hostilities if the government proceeded in its goal toward holding elections that are scheduled for November 26 in the autonomous region of Mindanao.

Defense Minister, Angelo Rice, said that Misuari was firmly ordered to explain within 48 hours his role in the armed incidents, and to justify why he should not be held responsible for the confrontations.
A bomb exploded in an office for the upcoming elections in the city of Zamboanga in Mindanao last week and killed an officer from the branch in Manila on Monday morning.

Misuari continued to fight since 1972 for the establishment of an independent state in the southern third of the Philippines until a peace agreement between his group and the government was signed in 1996.

hl.seg: 15 / Major Headline News in Israeli Newspapers

p.seg: Jerusalem 20 November / Xinhua / Following are the headline news reported by major Israeli newspapers on Tuesday:
// Jerusalem Post //

-- Yesterday, in the first political speech on the Middle East by the Administration of American President George W. Bush yesterday, Secretary of State, Colin Powell, pledged first for US participation to guarantee the ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians, then to convene talks between the two sides on the final status for the establishment of a Palestinian state next to Israel.
// Ha'artez //
-- Powell urged the Palestinians and Israelis to deal with each other with respect and also face "the basic realities" embedded at the heart of the long-term conflict.
// Maariv //
-- The new American Envoy to the Middle East, Retired General Anthony Zinny, will arrive in the region next week to hold shuttle talks on the ceasefire with Israeli and Palestinian top officials.
// Yeddiot Aharonot //
-- Powell said yesterday that the United States is ready to embark on a leading and active role to help the Palestinians and Israelis solve the difficult issues which are facing them.

hl.seg: 87/ Kuwaiti Finance Minister Stresses Importance of Re-thinking Kuwaiti Economic Infrastructure

p.seg: Kuwait 20 November / Xinhua / The Kuwaiti Finance Minister, Yousef Al-Ibrahim stressed today the need to re-think the Kuwaiti economic infrastructure in view of the fact that the world economies are moving toward a market economy.

This came in a statement released to reporters by Al-Ibrahim at the end of the Kuwaiti National Congress meeting, in which a report by the Economy and Finance Affairs Committee regarding a proposal for regulating privatization programs was discussed.
Kuwaiti News Agency quoted Al-Ibrahim as saying that this law is "a fundamental part of the sought-after reform in Kuwait."

The Kuwait official explained "that the government now owns and manages the Kuwaiti economy", indicating that no government in the world economies now owns and manages the economy and that "the world economies are moving toward market economy."

With regards to the fears expressed by some representatives during the discussion that the economic sector privatization will adversely affect the national labor force, Al-Ibrahim emphasized that "the government will not accept that any Kuwait employee be terminated or fired from any privatized entity."

hl.seg: 119 / Expectations for Reduced Spending by Americans in Holiday Season

p.seg: Los Angeles 20 November / Xinhua / A report released today said that it is likely that the economy slowdown, lower consumer confidence, joblessness and the tragic events of the eleventh of September will result in reduced spending during the holiday season the United States.

Based on a study of spending forecasts during the Christmas holidays that covered five thousand American families, the National Research Network Council discovered that families will spend an average of 462 dollars on gifts during the holiday season, lower than the expected average spending last year which reached 490 dollars.
It is expected that retail sales will reach approximately 50 billion dollars, which is 4 percent lower than the expected rate last year.
It is worth noting that about 21 percent of American consumers bought gifts through the internet last year.
Ninety percent of them were impressed by the internet experience.

The conference's council said that 22 percent intend on buying gifts through the internet this year and that children's toys, games, books, clothes, shoes and music discs will be on top of the gift list.

hl.seg: Lee Roy Huan Meets Speaker of Singapore Parliament

p.seg: Lee Roy Huan, President of the National Council of the Consultative Political Conference for the Chinese People, met on Monday with Tan Soo Khoon, Speaker of the Singapore Parliament.
Lee praised the smooth progress of both the official and non-official relationship between China and Singapore.
Lee added that China has achieved a fast economic progress since it adopted a policy of reform and openness.
Despite that, the general level of the economy is still weak, and its growth will require a long period of time.
Lee went on to say that feeding and clothing 1.3 billion people in China is considered a magnificent contribution to world stability.

Lee indicated that the policy of reform and openness proved and will prove that Chinese development will only be directed in the interest of her neighbors and the whole world, not the other way round.
The Speaker of the Singapore Parliament agreed with Lee's opinion, saying that his country is ready to bolster a more inclusive cooperation relationship of mutual benefit with China.

Lee Roy Huan had arrived last Sunday in Singapore for a cordial, official visit to the country that will last five days, and which will be his last stop on his tour of three countries in the Asia-Pacific region that also included Fiji and Papua New Guinea.
Lee will conclude his visit to Singapore on November 23.

hl.seg: 58/ Cold Wave Paralyzes Daily Life in Turkey

p.seg: Ankara 21 November / Xinhua / The Anadol News Agency reported today that a wave of bitter cold resulted in paralyzing the daily life and traffic all over Turkey.
Snowfall starting this morning, disabled daily life activities in the northwestern municipality of Bolu.
26 roads leading to villages were closed to traffic due to the heavy snowfall in the district.
Countryside service Officials said that teams were working hard to re-open for traffic the 26 roads leading to villages, and drivers were asked to exercise caution when driving on snow-covered roads.

In the central municipality of Sivas, daily life and traffic in the city, were also affected by the heavy snowfall, and the highways between Sivas and Ankara, between Sivas and Erzurum, and between Sivas and Kayseri were closed to traffic.
Meanwhile, snow accumulation in eastern Turkey reached 10 centimeters in the region of Bengol, while in the Agri and Kars regions, it reached 3 centimeters.
Snow is also falling in the regions of Erzurum, Erdahan and Mousse.
Snow was falling in the high altitudes of the northwestern region of Sakaria.
Snow accumulation reached 15 centimeters in Khandak and Kukali centers.
Schools were given a two-day holiday in Saymbeli center of the Adana Region where snow accumulation reached 10 centimeters.

hl.seg: 61/ Russian Foreign Minister Visits South Africa

p.seg: Johannesburg 21 November / Xinhua / South Africa's Foreign Ministry said today that the Russian Foreign Minister, Igor Ivanov, accepted an invitation from South Africa to visit the country for the purpose of bolstering bilateral relations.

The ministry said in a statement that the Foreign Minister, Nkosazana Dlamini/Zuma, extended her invitation to Ivanov during a Foreign Affairs Ministers Meeting at the United Nations in New York last week.
The statement said that Ivanov accepted the invitation and arrangements are being made for the trip's timing.

He said that Dlamini/Zuma told Ivanov that South Africa and Russia need to cooperate to help solve the problems faced by Africa and that the two countries must combine their efforts in fighting terrorism.
Dlamini/Zuma was quoted as saying that "the serious effort to maintain a constructive dialogue on the political settlements of conflicts in Africa is vital."
Ivanov said in an address at the 56th Annual Session of the UN General Assembly that most countries in the world are facing social instability.
He said, "It is a tough crisis.

Either we exert joint efforts collaborating in the vital task to build a democratic world order that guarantees security and a sustained and balanced development for all countries or that we ignore the problem entirely."

hl.seg: Thai Official: Thailand Will Benefit from China's Entry into World Trade Organization

p.seg: Bangkok 21 November / Xinhua / A high-level Thai official said on Wednesday that China's entry into the World Trade Organization will benefit Thailand more than it would harm her.

Sufarn Phalaisathin, Deputy Trade Minister, added in a statement to // Nation // TV channel that "the major reductions to be enacted by China after joining the World Trade Organization, especially the agricultural products, will make Thai products more competitive there."
He indicated that "China consumes about one hundred million tons of rice annually.

And when tariffs are reduced, the prices of rice and other Thai products will become cheaper, which will enable Thailand to sell surplus products at a competitive price with other producers in the Chinese market."

He went on to say that as soon as China becomes a full member in the World Trade Organization, Thailand may suffer from a reduction of electrical goods exports but that it won't affect the majority of products.
He stressed that Thailand will gain more than she will lose.
He also dismissed the opinion that says that China's entry into the World Trade Organization will pull foreign investments out of Thailand.
He explained by saying, "This is because we are one of the more politically, socially and economically stable countries of Asia.
The government must still re-consider the laws and regulations related to foreign investment in order to attract more foreign investors."

hl.seg: 10 Nepalese Women Rescued from Smuggling into India

p.seg: Katmandu 21 November / Xinhua / The // Katmandu Post // Newspaper reported on Wednesday that ten Nepalese women were rescued on Tuesday in the Nepalese city of Birganj, which is located on the Indian borders, as they were being smuggled into Indian prostitution houses.

The English-speaking paper quoted the non-official, women-welfare organization // Mina Dahonjana of Mighty Nepal // as saying that the ten women, including an unmarried woman, were stopped on suspicion that they were being sold to India as they were on their way to India accompanied by four men unrelated to them and without any papers.
The organization said, "We must stop these young women for not knowing with whom they were traveling and for not having recommendation letters from official authorities to visit India."
The organization added that the four men were also stopped to be investigated.

It is worth noting that the Nepalese government required the women to to obtain recommendation letters to visit India from their guardians and from local officials due to the increasing number of Nepalese young women being sold to prostitution houses in the past few years.
The organization statistics showed that between 5,000 to 7,000 Nepalese young women flee annually to India to practice prostitution.

hl.seg: France/China 2001 Exposition in Beijing

p.seg: Beijing 21 November / Xinhua / The France/China 2001 Exposition, which is organized by the French government and the International Development Agency for French Companies, opened in the Chinese capital, Beijing, on Tuesday.

At the exposition, which lasts five days, products from more than 150 French companies, including products from the fields of space, aviation, information, communications, electronics, transportation, machinery, building materials, metallurgy, energy, environmental protection, agriculture, services and sports, are on exhibit.
A series of seminars on information technology, communications, urban transportation and economy regulations will be held during the exposition.

Among those who attended the opening ceremonies were Kha Lu Lee, Vice President of the Permanent Committee of the National Council of the Chinese People's Representatives; Cheuy Kwan Hua, the Chinese Minister of Science and Technology; and Francois Howart, State Secretary for Foreign Trade at the French Ministry of Economy, Finance and Industry.

hl.seg: Economic Expert Calls for Upgrading National Credit System

p.seg: Shanghai 21 November / Xinhua / A distinguished Chinese economic expert called for a national credit system to guarantee sound economic and social development.

Wu Xiang Lian, the distinguished economic expert at the State Council Development Research Center, said that China is in dire need of a new system to define national credit that reflects individual, company and government credibility.

In a seminar held recently here on guarantees, Wu said that the lack of such a system resulted in the spreading of fraud and deceit activities which, in turn, led to varying degrees of chaos in the country's young economy.
He gave examples of poor contracting, counterfeit products, violations of rights, fraud and sequential debts in his important speech at the seminar.

hl.seg: International Companies Pioneer New and High-tech Industry in West China/ Second and Last Addition /

p.seg: Currently, the Chinese government is focusing its efforts on developing the infrastructure in west China, such as transportation and communications for the benefit of improving the investment environment there that will increase foreign businessmen's confidence in the future of western China's regions.
But in comparison to China's coastal regions, new and high-tech development in west China faces issues like the weak base and lack of qualified people with expertise.

Besides improving the investment environment and implementing preferential policies, the central and local governments are paying more attention to developing education in the western parts of the country, and several projects were implemented to help more people from these regions enroll in colleges and higher institutions in order to improve the quality of locals and preparing qualified people.

Mao Win Xian, Deputy Governor of Kweichow Province / south west of China / said at the New and High-Tech Advances Exposition // it is inevitable that the future of new and high-tech technological industries in western China will be bright.

hl.seg: 72/ Iran Takes First Place in Soccer for Asia Despite Failure to Qualify for World Cup

p.seg: Tehran 22 November / Xinhua / The national soccer team of Iran ranked twenty ninth on the most recent list of best teams in the world to become the top Asian team and ranked six points higher from last month.

The official Iranian News Agency, IRNA, reported that despite that the Iranian team did not qualify for the World Cup, which will be held in Japan and Korea in 2002, "it is at least better than five teams that did qualify for it, according to the latest FIFA ranking."
This news was released in the sports section of Iran's internet sports site under the heading "Best Asian Team Unqualified for World Cup."
The report bitterly said, "What an irony that the FIFA should classify Iran as the best team in Asia, but it failed to qualify for the World Cup."
It added that this ranking proves that Iran enjoys theoretical capabilities that it failed to apply practically.
The internet site mentioned that Iran, which scored a total of 640 points, was ahead of Saudi Arabia / which ranked as the second best Asian team.
The site commented by saying, "It is unfortunate that points are not counted in soccer, but scores are".
It is worth noting that Iran ranked thirty-fifth in September's ranking prepared by FIFA.
The team did not qualify for the World Cup in 2002 after it lost to Ireland 2/1 in the home and host games.

hl.seg: 10/ Kenya Relocates More Than 6 Thousand Elephants

p.seg: Nairobi 22 November / Xinhua / The Kenyan Wildlife Commission decided to relocate more than 6 thousand elephants in central Kenya to new places to ease the conflict between wildlife and human life, according to what the East African Standard Newspaper reported on Thursday.
The mammoth animals now live in the Marmanent and Romoroti Forests in Likebia Region in the Rift Valley Province, and they will be relocated to Mirojeem Reserve in the Eastern Province.
The operation will last five years and will cost about one billion shillings or the equivalent of 13 million US dollars.

The number of elephants in Kenya is experiencing a progressive increase thanks to the strong protection efforts adopted by the Kenyan government and banning trade on elephants tusks, which also caused increasing conflict between human life and wildlife.

Last week, a group of vicious elephants from the Marmanent Forest invaded buildings belonging to the university, located 30 kilometers away, destroyed an experimental farm and disrupted the midterm exams.

hl.seg: 116 / Pilotless American Reconnaissance Planes Commence Operation over Afghanistan

p.seg: Washington 21 November / Xinhua / "Global Hawk" reconnaissance planes, which are new, pilotless planes belonging to the American Air Force and fly at high altitudes, commenced operations over Afghanistan this week, according to what the American Defense Secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, announced today.
In a press conference, Rumsfeld said that the Global Hawk is used to pursue the Saudi dissident Osama Bin Laden and the Al Qaeda Network that he leads.
In another development, the United States asked neighboring Uzbekistan for permission to host heavy military helicopters of model AC130, which fly at low altitudes and throw lightening walls of fire.

Rumsfeld added, "It will be useful to have the AC130 planes in the north, especially in a similar situation to Kunduz," where thousands of Taliban and Al Qaeda forces are resisting in spite of the American air raids that started on October 7.
He said, "This weapon system and program can particularly use a massive amount of assets with ultra high accuracy that can avoid collateral damage."

hl.seg: Mayor of Sofia Seeks to Head New Party

p.seg: Sofia 22 November / Xinhua / The mayor of Sofia, Stefan Sofianski, announced on Wednesday that he will compete to lead a new party for the Middle Right that will be formed next month.

Sofianski, who withdrew from the Democratic Forces Alliance a few days before the presidential elections that were held on November 11, said that he will return to the political arena and will work for "new achievements" for his new party in the next elections in two years when he ends his term as mayor.

The party, named as the Free Democrats, will seek a strong support from the voters, will establish a position somewhere between the center and the right in the political arena, and will work with whomever shares its values and principles.

hl.seg: European Union Approves Brazilian Meat Export

p.seg: Rio De Janeiro 22 November / Xinhua / The Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul received on Wednesday the European Union's agreement that allows the export of fresh boneless beef starting next December first.

Before exporting to the Union, which is composed of 15 countries, Brazilian cattle farm owners must submit additional guarantees, which are listed in the Animal Transportation Guide, so that they can be ratified by the agricultural authorities in the European Union.

The guarantees include a signed declaration by the cattle farm owners confirming that the slaughtered animals were not in contact with animals outside of the farms for a period of 40 days before slaughter.

The veterinarian specialists at the European Union want to know the results of vaccination tests that were conducted in six towns belonging to Rio Grande do Sul State, which had witnessed the discovery of 30 infected areas in May of this year, in order to verify that the state is free of the Foot and Mouth Disease Virus.
The state's government announced that 30 thousand samples, out of 60 thousand, showed negative disease test results, while the rest of the tests will be concluded soon.

hl.seg: Russia and Jordan Discuss Fighting Terrorism and Situation in Afghanistan and Middle East

p.seg: Moscow 22 November / Xinhua / The Russian President, Vladimir Putin, and Jordan's King, Abdullah II, discussed cooperation in fighting terrorism and the situation in Afghanistan and the Middle East.
The media commission at the Kremlin said that King Abdullah II paid a short working visit to Moscow, which was particularly aimed at holding talks with Putin on Wednesday.

During the talks, the Russian president and Jordanian monarch exchanged "views in a detailed and deep manner" on a number of important international issues, on top of which are fighting terrorism and the situations in the Middle East, Iraq and Afghanistan.

Abdullah II, who had arrived here Tuesday evening and left for home Wednesday afternoon, said, "It is very important now to focus the effort of all countries to fight international terrorism in light of the tragic events that took place last September 11."
On the developments in the Middle East, Abdullah II indicated that Russia "plays a fundamental role" in the Middle East region.

hl.seg: Expert Talks about Bright Horizons of New Economy

p.seg: Beijing 30 November / Xinhua / Lu Jongxiang, Director of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, said that the new economy still holds a wide future despite the drop in spider technology.

Lu said that information technology and communications will affect all aspects of social development in the era of a knowledge-based economy ranging from sciences, culture and education to finance, insurance, trade and national security.

Lu said at the China Netcom 2001 International Internet Cooperation Symposium, which deals with the large-scale information technology industry, that this will create ample opportunities for the wide-frequency communications industry in China.
He said that the world internet industry currently faces a slowdown after the short boom in the past few years.
But that does not matter to the future of industry and economy over the long term.
Lu predicted that the Chinese communications industry will develop faster in the next five years.
And she will become an enormous force in the field of communications and internet in the 21st century.

hl.seg: German Company Bolsters Investments in China

p.seg: Shanghai 22 November / Xinhua / The Mayor of Shanghai, Xu Kuangdi, welcomed the German company of Degussa for increasing its investments in China.
He said during his meeting on Wednesday with Utz / Hellmuth Felcht, the company's executive official, that he trusts that foreign companies will find bigger markets in China.
The Degussa Company is the largest specialty chemicals producer in the world, and ranks 269 among the top 500 companies in the world.
Its total annual sales are valued at 20 billion US dollars.
Felcht arrived here to lay the corner stone for an Asian research and development base for the company's poly additives.
The project's first-phase investments will reach more than two billion US dollars.
It is expected that its annual capacity will reach more than 1,200 tons.
He said that this project will be expanded to become the company's technology and service center in China and all of Asia.

hl.seg: Discovery of 30 Thousand-Year-Old Archeological Find in Inner Mongolia

p.seg: Hohot 26 November / Xinhua / Chinese archeologists discovered a large number of antique artifacts from the previous Stone Age in an ancient cave discovered in an Xinglonggou prairie located in the autonomous region of Inner Mongolia.
They confirmed that they are ruins of a cave inhabited by ancient man.
The cave has a width of 16 meters and a depth of 24 meters.

Archeologists also discovered stone tools such as a stone hammer; animal bones and animal fossils of wild horses, camels and antelopes dating back to the previous Stone Age or 50 thousand to 100 thousand years ago; and a large collection of gray and black clay pottery and some copper pots dating back 30 thousand and 3 thousand years ago.
