According to the report, the Indian police stated that Mohamed Afrouz belonged to the Indian Islamic Students' Movement, banned because it is suspected of being linked to the Al-Qaeda Organization.

hl.seg: New airlines link the Yellow River Delta to major Chinese towns

p.seg: Jinan December 7 \ Shenkhu \ Recently a Boeing 737 aircraft landed on the runway at Dong Yang Airport to mark the opening of the first airport in the Yellow River Delta area.
This airport is 13 kilometers from the town of Dong Yang in Shandong Province in eastern China.
The airport has a capacity to handle 120 thousand passengers.
Flights from there will go to Peking, Shanghai, Shensing, Harbin, Tientsin and Kurla in Shandong Province and other towns in China.
This airport was constructed in 1985 and has only recently come into operation.
Officials said that the opening of this airport will facilitate the development of the Yellow River Delta area.

hl.seg: \ 7 China supports Nepal in preserving unity and stability

p.seg: Peking December 8 \ Shenkhu \ The Chinese Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, stated here today that China supports the urgent measures taken by King Gyanendra and the Nepalese government to preserve the unity, integrity and stability of the country.
Tang made this announcement during a telephone conversation with Sher Bahadur Deuba, the Prime Minister of Nepal and Foreign Minister.
The two sides exchanged points of view on bilateral relations and other issues of common interest.

Deuba informed Tang of the internal situation in Nepal recently, saying that the Nepalese government was taking the necessary measures to counter terrorists and that the internal situation was stable.
Tang said that China was opposed to terrorism in Nepal and in fact, terrorism in all its forms.

He expressed his belief that Nepal will continue to maintain a state of peace, stability and development under the leadership of the king and the Nepalese government and that there will be a strengthening of Chinese Nepalese friendship, based on the five principles of peaceful coexistence.

hl.seg: \ 61 Nigerian peace discussions on Democratic Congo reach an impasse

p.seg: Lagos December 8 \ Shenkhu \ The meeting of representatives of the warring parties in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which took place through the mediation of the United Nations, entered its third day without any sign of achieving progress.
The Nigerian news agency reported from the capital, Abuja, that the meeting which began in Abuja, Thursday, is unlikely to end tomorrow, Sunday.

Representatives of the principal warring parties, including the government, the League for Congolese Democracy, the Goma Group and rebels from the Congo Liberation Movement, took part in discussions which followed the meeting held in New York last month.
Al-Ibrahimi Ful, the representative of the Secretary General of the United Nations stated in reply to a question on whether there was any progress: "The sun is shining."

The civil war has decimated the Democratic Congo since 1998 when rebels supported by Uganda and Rwanda tried to remove the late President Laurent Kabila, while Angola, Zimbabwe and Namibia sent their forces to support the Congolese government.
The Abuja discussions are considered a preparatory step towards the main discussions to be held in the same city next week, which are expected to be attended by President Joseph Kabila.

hl.seg: \ 70 The Ugandan President arrives in Tanzania

p.seg: Kampala December 8 \ Shenkhu \ The Ugandan President, Yoweri Museveni arrived in Dar Es Salaam this evening to attend the national celebrations in Tanzania to mark the fortieth anniversary of independence, according to a press statement issued by the President's office.
The Tanzanian Independence Day celebrations will take place tomorrow, Sunday.
Museveni was met at Dar Es Salaam International Airport by the Tanzanian President, Benjamin Mkapa and a number of other senior officials, according to the statement.
Museveni inspected a guard of honor from the Tanzanian People's Defense Forces.
Later on he attended a performance in which various artistic groups put on displays of singing and dancing.
The Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi also arrived in Tanzania, Friday, to attend the Independence Day celebrations.

hl.seg: Russia allocates a budget to make the army professional from 2004

p.seg: \ first and last addition \ He added that all plans on contract soldiers and reduction of periods of service must be submitted to the coming conference on military reforms which is to be held next March.
The preparatory and trial stage for the army reforms will begin in 2003, and a number of units which will include soldiers recruited on a contractual basis will be formed during 2004.

The Russian Prime Minister confirmed that all aspects of financing these reforms must be studied comprehensively in the light of the economic and social situation in Russia during these years to avoid mistakes and lost opportunities.

Previously, following discussions with President Putin on the plan to transform the army into professional forces at the end of last November, Kasyanov stated that the transition to a volunteer military service must be a gradual operation without making radical changes in the system, and the number of persons who serve in the army on an annual contractual basis will increase gradually.

hl.seg: Experts call for scientific decisions to be taken on major projects

p.seg: Peking December 11 \ Shenkhu \ A few days ago an academician in the Chinese Academy of Engineering called for the establishment of a scientific and democratic decision-making mechanism for major construction projects.

Kuh Chung Cheng, a professor in the University of Tungchi, stated in a seminar on engineering organized by the Chinese Academy of Engineering that hasty economic growth and wide-scale construction could lead to an improvement in the standard of living and also ecological destruction and financial chaos.

In line with proposals made by the academic groups of the Chinese Science and Engineering Academies, Kuh proposed that the decision makers in China should establish a national scientific and technological consultative board and that the managerial authority over such projects should be defined whilst the legislative powers should be extended.

hl.seg: \ 67 Bangladesh releases the detained Indian fishermen

p.seg: Islamabad December 9 \ Shenkhu \ The Pakistani Associated Press news agency reported that the Pakistani authorities had today released the 38 Indian fishermen it had detained.
The Pakistani Naval Security Agency had arrested the fishermen in Pakistani territorial waters during the last week of October and they had been detained.
They were released as a result of efforts by the Fishermen's Cooperative in Karachi which lasted one month.
The Naval Security Agency accompanied the fishermen and their vessels this afternoon as far as international waters.

The news agency reported that the Fishermen's Cooperative in Karachi had exerted its efforts with the Ministry of the Interior and the Foreign Ministry for the release of the fishermen as an expression of good will.

hl.seg: \ 26 The Head of the interim Afghan Government praises Iran

p.seg: Tehran December 9 \ Shenkhu \ The Leader of the interim Afghan Government, Hamid Karzai, praised neighboring Iran and described Iran as a "brother" state in view of the role it played in removing the Taliban regime, according to reports in local newspapers today.

Karzai stated in an interview with the official Iranian radio yesterday, Saturday: "We praise the role of Iran in Afghanistan and hope to maintain the friendly and brotherly relations between Kabul and Tehran."

This was the first statement by Karzai to Iran since his appointment as the Head of the new Afghan governing coalition, Wednesday, by Afghan delegations from various forces opposed to the Taliban during their discussions in Bonn in Germany.

Karzai said in the interview: "The Islamic Republic of Iran is a neighbor and brother to Afghanistan and we have lived together for many centuries." He said that the leaders and brothers in Iran had called for "participation in the re-establishment of peace and stability in Afghanistan and in the country's advancement."
Iran, which borders western and south western Afghanistan supported the Northern Alliance opposed to the Taliban which was composed basically of a minority of Afghan citizens.

In a reaction to the Bonn Conference, the Iranian government stated that it was not opposed to the appointment of a leader of the Pashtun ethnic group, Karzai, as Head of the interim Afghan Government.

hl.seg: \ 27 A glimpse of the personality of the new Sri Lankan Prime Minister, Ranil Wickramesinghe

p.seg: Colombo December 9 \ Shenkhu \ The Leader of the United National Party, Ranil Wickramesinghe, took the oath as the new Prime Minister in Sri Lanka today following his party's victory in the parliamentary elections which took place last Wednesday.

Wickramesinghe is a graduate of the Faculty of Law in the University of Colombo and is the eldest son of the brother of J. R. Jayawardena, the first executive president of Sri Lanka. This is the second time he has become Prime Minister.
Wickramesinghe was Prime Minister during the period from May 1993 to August 1994.

Wickramesinghe was born on March 24, 1949. He studied in the Royal College in the capital, Colombo, obtained a bachelor's degree in law from the University of Colombo and became a lawyer before he began his political work.
In the University, Wickramesinghe was involved in student activities and was Chairman of the Faculty of Law Students' Association and Deputy Chairman of the Student Council.

He began political work in 1978 as Deputy Foreign Minister in the government of President Jayawardena and then occupied the position of Minister for Youth Affairs, Education, Workforce Mobilization and National Service.
He was also Minister of Industry, Science and Technology in the Premadasa government and President D. B. Wijetunga then appointed him as Prime Minister.
Wickramesinghe was the leader of the opposition in the previous parliament.
He married a university professor, Maithree, at the beginning of 1995.

hl.seg: \ 43 Al-Assad and Mubarak study the situation in the Middle East

p.seg: Damascus December 9 \ Shenkhu \ The Syrian President, Bashar Al-Assad, and his Egyptian counterpart, Hosni Mubarak, began their discussions today in Damascus focused on the explosive situation in the Middle East.

Syrian official radio reported that the meeting was held immediately Mubarak arrived in Damascus earlier this afternoon. President Bashar Al-Assad and his two deputies Abdul Halim Khaddam and Zuhair Masharqa led those who met him at Damascus International Airport.

Syria and Egypt are calling for an Israeli withdrawal from the territories occupied in 1967 as a basis for a settlement in the Middle East. However they have different attitudes to Palestinian - Israeliclashes.
Damascus calls for a continuation of the intifada to compel Israel to withdraw, while Egypt wishes to announce a ceasefire so that negotiations can be resumed.
The discussions were followed by a closed meeting between the Syrian and Egyptian presidents.

hl.seg: Moussa receives a verbal message from Arafat on developments in the occupied territories

p.seg: \ first and last addition \

Furthermore the Secretary General of the Arab League, Amr Moussa, announced in press statements in Cairo, Saturday, that he believed that the Palestinian President, Yasser Arafat, might participate in the extraordinary ministerial meeting of the Islamic Conference Organization to be held in the Qatari capital, Doha, Monday next, and it is expected that he will present a report on the situation in Palestinian territories in the light of Israeli military escalation against the Palestinians.

Arafat's journey to Doha is his first journey since he was forced to remain in his office in Ramallah, the West Bank, following the military incursions launched by Israel against Palestinian territories since last Monday. These incursions destroyed Arafat's helicopter landing pad in Gaza and destroyed his three helicopters.

hl.seg: Libya seeks to rescue Arabs and foreigners who are not involved in terrorist activities in Afghanistan

p.seg: \ second and final addition \

Regarding Osama bin Laden, the leader of the Al-Qaeda Organization, Saif Al-Islam Al-Gaddafi said in the press conference: "I do not consider that bin Laden will seek refuge in any state or area," again emphasizing that the objective of the Libyan initiative is primarily to rescue Arabs and foreigners with members of their families in Afghanistan from the dangers now besetting them, as long as they are not involved in any terrorist activities."

Saif Al-Islam Al-Gaddafi described the Libyan initiative towards these Arabs and foreigners who have been cut off in Afghanistan as "a humanitarian initiative with heart and mind" which has no political implications.
The special envoy to the Libyan leader, Colonel Muamar Gaddafi, will conclude his visit to Pakistan today, Sunday.

hl.seg: \ 31 The Israeli Prime Minister and the Minister of Defense meet an American envoy

p.seg: Jerusalem December 10 \ Shenkhu \ The Israeli Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, and Minister of Defense, Benyamin Ben Eliezer, met the American envoy, Anthony Ziny, Monday, to convince the envoy to continue the peace process in the region.
The meeting followed a warning from Ziny yesterday that he will leave the region if the Palestinians and Israelis fail to take constructive decisions to end the bloody clashes within 48 hours.

It appears that Sharon and Ben Eliezer are extremely anxious about the expected consequences, because if the American envoy leaves the Middle East the tense situation in the region may witness further deterioration.
They both believe that Ziny's continued presence in the region will exert pressure on the Palestinian National Authority and its Chairman, Yasser Arafat, to take steps to combat "terrorism".
Ziny's visit, which comes as part of the American efforts to achieve a ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians, faces obstacles from both sides.

In spite of the difficulties he faces in achieving the objective of his task, the American State Department decided last week that Ziny should remain in the region and continue American efforts to achieve a ceasefire between the two sides.

hl.seg: \ 41 The Kuwaiti Stock Market index falls 2.7 points

p.seg: Kuwait December 10 \ Shenkhu \ The Kuwaiti Stock Market index reached 1681.3 today, a fall of 2.7 points below the closing rate yesterday when it reached 1684.0 points, a fall of 10.5 points below the previous closing rate.
This was reported in an official statement issued by the Kuwaiti Stock Market.

It is clear from the report that the level of dealing in the market today saw a decline in the volume and value of share traded, and in the number of transactions, 54.38 million shares with a value of 7.16 million Kuwaiti dinars, equivalent to 23.62 million US dollars, were exchanged in 834 deals in comparison with 53.21 million shares negotiated with a value of 9.47 million Kuwaiti dinars, about 31.25 million US dollars in 1111 deals yesterday.

hl.seg: \ 70 Li Peng holds discussions with his Russian counterpart

p.seg: \ first and last addition \
Li stated that through joint efforts the two countries will attain with certainty new achievements in strengthening relations in the new century.

Li said that in recent years the State Council, the Duma, had increased its exchanges and cooperation with the Chinese People's National Council of Deputies and this forcefully strengthens Chinese Russian relations.
He added that the Chinese National Council of People's Deputies hopes to reinforce exchanges and cooperation with its Russian counterpart so as to strengthen mutual understanding and trust.
Li explained to his guest the legislative work being undertaken by the Chinese National Council of People's Deputies and the Standing Committee of the National Council.

For his part Seleznev stated that thefriendly relations between Russia and China had been strengthened and the two meetings between President Jiang and President Putin in 2001 symbolize this as does the growing cooperation between the two countries within the framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.
He said that leaders of the member states of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization will hold discussions in Russia next June and President Putin will visit China.
He added that he believes that the two countries will continue to strengthen their relations in the coming year.
Seleznev expressed his congratulations on the inclusion of China in the World Trade Organization and his hope that Russia would learn from China in this regard.
He said that he hopes that the State Council, the Duma, will increase its cooperation with the Chinese National Council of People's Deputies.

hl.seg: News report: President Jiang's visit to Myanmar adds a new chapter to relations between the two countries

p.seg: \ first addition \

The two countries have a close common point of view on many major issues, such as protection of the independence, sovereignty and security of national territory in addition to their opposition to tyranny and the policies of force.
In relation to international issues, the two countries support each other and cooperate closely.
Mutual trust and cooperation in drawing up policies have become an important cornerstone of the friendly relations between the two countries.

China will always respect the independence of Myanmar, its sovereignty and its territorial integrity, while Myanmar firmly adheres to the policy "China is one" and supports the major issue for China of reunifying the nation, recognizing that the government of the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government, that Taiwan is an integral part of Chinese territory and undertaking not to establish formal relations with Taiwan of any kind.
The mutual visits between the leaders of the two countries represent an important fundamental factor strengthening friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries.

hl.seg: The latest developments in American attacks in Afghanistan

p.seg: Peking December 10 \ Shenkhu \ Below are the latest developments in American attacks in Afghanistan.

-- The United States has obtained a video tape in which Osama bin Laden described the losses suffered by the World Trade Center as greater than he anticipated, according to the report of the Washington Post newspaper on Sunday.

The newspaper quoted a senior official who had seen the original copy of the tape as saying that this tape "makes it quite clear that bin Laden not only had advance information, but also proves that he was responsible for the planning."
This tape was obtained in Afghanistan during a search of a house in Jalalabad, and the Bush administration is considering whether or not to announce the contents of the tape and how to do so.

-- IRNA, the official Iranian news agency reported on Sunday that El-Akhdar El-Ibrahimi, the special envoy of the Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, will arrive in the Afghan capital, Kabul, next Tuesday to ensure the transfer of power from the Northern Alliance to the interim Afghan government.

An informed source in the Northern Alliance was quoted as saying that El-Ibrahimi would hold discussions to seek means of transferring power to prepare for the formation of an interim government in Afghanistan.

Discussions will also take place on the formation of the Loya Jirga or traditional national council, according to the source, who refused to reveal the period the United Nations envoy would spend in Afghanistan.

hl.seg: \ 73 A commander in the Northern Alliance: Members of the Al-Qaeda Organization will surrender to the Northern Alliance tomorrow

p.seg: Islamabad December 11 \ Shenkhu \ The Afghan Islamic news agency stated today that members of the Al-Qaeda Organization in Tora Bora close to Jalalabad will surrender their weapons to the Northern Alliance Forces under the command of Al-Hajj Mohamed Zaman from eight o'clock tomorrow morning, Wednesday.

The agency report quoted Zaman as saying that a temporary ceasefire will be implemented with effect from this evening until tomorrow morning so that members of the Al-Qaeda Organization hiding in the Tora Bora mountains can surrender quietly.
Zaman stated that all members of the Al-Qaeda Organization who have given up their weapons will be transferred to the United Nations instead of being handed over to the American Special Forces.
He added that he is not responsible for identifying Osama bin Laden's hideout and arresting him.
The commander stated that four Arabs belonging to the Al-Qaeda Organization had died during a battle that took place today.

hl.seg: \ 96 Mubarak: The whole of humanity is threatened if it does not act quickly to eliminate international terrorism

p.seg: Cairo December 11 \ Shenkhu \ The Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, confirmed here Tuesday evening that the whole of humanity is threatened by huge dangers if it does not act quickly to eliminate the phenomenon of international terrorism.

Mubarak stated in a speech he made on the occasion of the celebration of Lailat Al-Qadr that the situation in occupied Palestinian territory and Israel's continued obstruction of the peace efforts is the principal reason which gives those who undertake suicide operations the incentive to carry them out, because they see that life, overshadowed by the current grave situation and by failure to achieve a just and comprehensive peace, has no point.

He added: "The planet on which we live is about to be transformed into an unsafe place for life because of terrorism crossing borders and the policy of eliminating others adopted by some governments."

Mubarak called upon Israel to withdraw from occupied Palestinian territory and Syrian Golan and asserted that the sole means of living in peace and security is the attainment of a comprehensive and just peace.
\ end of the report \ Sabir

hl.seg: \ 31 The Chinese Embassy resumes its work in Afghanistan

p.seg: Peking December 11 \ Shenkhu \ It has been decided that China should send its diplomats to Afghanistan this week to inspect the Chinese Embassy there and make contact with the parties concerned.
This was announced by a spokeswoman for the American Foreign Ministry Jiang Zhi Yuh during the regular press conference today.
It is noted that China has maintained diplomatic relations with Afghanistan but it had recalled its diplomats in the country in 1993 on security grounds.
Jiang stated that the Foreign Ministry was currently studying a resumption of the embassy's work in Afghanistan at an appropriate time.

In relation to the peace-keeping forces in Afghanistan, Jiang stated that China considered that such operations must take place on instruction from the General Assembly of the United Nations and with the approval of the Afghan people, and must assist in establishing peace and stability in Afghanistan.
She added that China had not so far participated in any multinational forces.
She stated that China would make its contributions for peace in Afghanistan in its own way.

hl.seg: The White House: Bush intends to show the video tape to the American people

p.seg: Washington December 11 \ Shenkhu \ The American President, George Walker Bush, intends to broadcast a video tape, described by government officials as proof of Osama bin Laden's involvement in the attacks of September 11 last.

The spokesman for the White House, Ari Fleisher, announced to journalists, Monday, that as long as the operation does not harm national security, Bush is inclined to broadcast the tape in which Osama bin Laden describes the level of destruction suffered by the World Trade Center as much greater than he anticipated.

Fleisher added: "The President's opinion is that it would be best to share the information on the tape with our fellow citizens and with the world, as long as there is no security threat from doing so."

He stated: "The President believes that it is important that fellow citizens know what bin Laden said in this respect, on the other hand we also do not want to give bin Laden an opportunity to appear on television."
Fleisher said that security experts had studied the tape to confirm that it is unlikely that there would be any negative security effects from broadcasting it.
President Bush had on Monday met his national security team and discussed with them the issue of the tape, which was found in a deserted house in the town of Jalalabad in Afghanistan.

hl.seg: The Qatari Foreign Minister defends the resolutions of the emergency meeting

p.seg: Kuwait December 11 \ Shenkhu \ The Qatari Foreign Minister, Sheikh Hamad bin Jasim bin Jabr Al Thani, defended the decisions contained in the final declaration issued by the emergency meeting of Foreign Ministers of the Islamic States which concluded its agenda in Doha Monday evening.

The Qatari Foreign Minister in a press conference held following the meeting described these decisions as expressing the reality of the Arab and Islamic states, statingthat it crystallized a balanced and logical position towards the Israeli aggression suffered by the Palestinian people, according to a report received from Doha Monday evening.

The Qatari Foreign Minister rejected a call by some to cease contact with Israel and asserted that such communications were beneficial to the Palestinian cause. He referred in this respect to the visit of the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Ahmed Maher, to Israel recently, which revealed that Sharon is not serious about achieving peace and that he is a man who does not want peace.

hl.seg: The latest developments in the American attacks on Afghanistan

p.seg: \ second and last addition \

-- In Rome on Monday the European Union Special Envoy, Reno Serrie, warned against launching military action against Somalia within the context of the campaign against terrorism. He said that government stability was the key to withstanding the threat of terrorism in that African country.

Serrie, who is the European Union Envoy concerned with the struggle between Eritrea and Ethiopia, said at the end of a conference organized by the United Nations on Somalia: "Somalia is not Afghanistan, and does not have a Taliban regime for us to eliminate."
-- The American President, George Walker Bush, intends to broadcast a video tape described by government officials as proof of Osama bin Laden's involvement in the attacks on September 11 last.

The spokesman for the White House, Ari Fleisher, announced to journalists, Monday, that as long as the action did not harm national security, Bush is inclined to broadcast the tape in which Osama bin Laden describes the level of destruction suffered by the World Trade Center as much greater than he had anticipated.

-- The new administration for Ninghahar Province announced late on Monday evening that its forces had seized the Malawa cave complex following a fierce battle with supporters of Osama bin Laden, according to the Afghan Islamic news agency.

The special news agency quoted this from a source in the Ninghahar Advisory Council as saying that three Arab soldiers died during the clashes while other members of the Al-Qaeda Organization withdrew to another area in the mountains.

hl.seg: Controlling the sands in north western China

p.seg: Yingchuan December 11 \ Shenkhu \ Work has recently started on a Sino - Japanese project to create a belt of forests in the central course of the Yellow River, the second longest Chinese river, in the Autonomous Region of Ningxia of the Hui ethnic group in north western China.
This is the first free economic aid granted by Japan to protect the biological environment in China.

Within the scope of this project, whose investments amount to 675 million Japanese yen, trees will be planted over an area of 4,281 hectares of land in the two provinces of Jianxi and Tawla and the city of Lingwu in Ningxia during the period from 2001 to 2003 to afford protection from the spread of the sands.
Sand storms blow as a matter of course in the arid and semi-arid regions of central Asia.
The powerful solar radiation leads generally to a rapid rise in the temperature of the earth's surface and this allows the sand to be displaced by cold air fronts coming from Siberia.
Ningxia lies in a arid and semi-arid region.
This region is subject to numerous sand storms to say the least, and these drag thousands of tons of dust to the Yellow River.
During the last decade the region has cooperated with Japan on a number of occasions to stop the spread of desertification and has achieved tangible results.

hl.seg: \ 17 William Burns decides to postpone his visit to Beirut to tomorrow Thursday

p.seg: Beirut December 12 \ Shenkhu \ Lebanese government sources have announced that the visit of the American Assistant Secretary of State, William Burns, which was planned for today, Wednesday to Beirut in connection with his peace function in the Middle East, was postponed until tomorrow, Thursday.
It was originally decided that Burns would visit Beirut on November 30 last, but he postponed his visit without explanation.
During his visit to Beirut, Burns will meet the Lebanese President, Emile Lahoud.
His visit comes at a time of differences between Washington and Beirut on the Shiite Hizbollah, which the United States considers to be a terrorist organization.
Lebanon rejected an American request to freeze Hizbollah's accounts as part of the anti-terrorist campaign and asserted that it is a resistance movement against Israel.
This week Burns will also visit Syria at a time not yet specified to study the escalation in the Middle East, according to the American Embassy in Damascus.
Burns visited the region at the end of last November with retired General Anthony Ziny in an attempt to achieve a ceasefire between the Palestinians and Israelis.
Ziny is currently pursuing his mediation between the Israelis and Palestinians.

hl.seg: \ 42 The Jordanian monarch: Arafat represents the Palestinian people

p.seg: Amman December 12 \ Shenkhu \ The Jordanian monarch, King Abdullah the Second, confirmed that President Arafat represents the Palestinian people and that Jordan will support him without interfering in internal Palestinian affairs.

The Jordanian news agency, PETRA, today quoted the Jordanian monarch as saying in a statement to the Arabic newspaper, Al-Sharq al-Awsat, which it will publish tomorrow, that the current Palestinian situtation was very difficult and that he was anxious because of recent developments, stating that there are some who try to link Islam to terrorism, which is rejected by and not acceptable to any Muslim, whilst asserting that Jordan will undertake to counter terrorism.

King Abdullah denied in his statement the news circulating that Jordan will send military forces to Palestinian territory, explaining that there are two Jordanian Armed Forces hospitals on Palestinian soil to treat the wounded from the Palestinian intifada.

The Jordanian monarch pointed to the participation of the Jordanian forces working with the international peace keeping forces in areas of tension in the world and to the despatch of a field hospital to treat the wounded in Afghanistan.

hl.seg: \ 94 Confirmation of the friendship between China and Myanmar in Yangon

p.seg: \ third and last addition \

Jiang also studied the internal situation in Myanmar, saying that his country enjoys social stability and economic development, and that the Myanmar government is making efforts to build a prosperous peaceful state.

Jiang expressed his pleasure at the Myanmar government's achievements in recent years, saying that China believes that the world is multicolored and that every state has the right to choose the path to development which suits its special circumstances.
He added that China will continue as usual to support the efforts of the Myanmar government to protect social stability and strengthen economic progress.
The two leaders also exchanged points of view on international and regional issues of joint concern.
Jiang invited Than Shwe to visit China again and the latter accepted the invitation.

Following the discussions, the two leaders attended the ceremony to sign the bilateral cooperation agreement covering border defence, economic and technological cooperation, encouragement, reinforcement and protection of investment, plant and animal quarantine, also public health and fish and petroleum resources.
This evening Than Shwe held a banquet in honour of Jiang and after the banquet the two leaders attended a display by local artists.
Jiang arrived here this afternoon on a state visit to Myanmar lasting four days in response to an invitation from Than Shwe.

hl.seg: Rumsfeld says: The end of the Afghan war is a long way off

p.seg: Washington December 12 \ Shenkhu \ Three months after the terrorist attacks of September 11 against the United States, the American Minister of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld, said, Tuesday, that the end of the military strikes led by the United States in Afghanistan was still a long way off.

Rumsfeld explained during a press conference: "The end of the war is a long way off. I have read many dreadful things and seen on the television a great haste to announce its success and end, but I am sorry to say that it is not yet over, and we have still to attain our clear aims."

He added: "We know that the war will last some time and will not end with the occupation of Kabul or Kanduz or even Kandahar, nor yet with the arrest of some members of the Taliban movement and Al-Qaeda Organization leaders in Afghanistan."

The minister warned that the danger facing the Alliance forces under the leadership of the United States will increase in spite of the reduction in the area of the regions controlled by the Taliban movement and Al-Qaeda Organization.
He stated that the men of the Taliban movement and Al-Qaeda Organization can hide in the mountains, and they can hide in the caves, and can even hide in the towns.
Rumsfeld said: "They know these places well."
They can flee across the borders, reassemble their forces and plan another attack. They have promised to do this."

It is clear that the American forces are still uncertain of the location of the Taliban movement leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, and the location of Osama bin Laden is also still surrounded in obscurity.

hl.seg: \ 95 The European Parliament reaffirms its support for Arafat

p.seg: Paris December 13 \ Shenkhu \ The European Parliament, which is the legislative body of the 15 member states in the European Union, reaffirmed today its support for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and criticized Israel for accusing Arafat of being directly responsible for the recent suicide attacks.

In a recommendation it adopted this morning in its headquarters in Strasbourg, the European Union also called for the European Commission, which is the executive body of the Union "to continue to support the Palestinian National Authority and its institutions."

Regarding Wednesday's suicide attack which led to the death of 10 persons and the wounding of about 30 others in Palestinian territory, the Parliament stated that it not only condemned the terrorist acts by the Palestinian organizations, but also "the policy of executions without trial and kidnappings by Israel."

The Parliament called upon Israel to adopt a joint strategy on the Middle East concentrating on the principle of "the right of the Palestinian people to live in a sovereign state and in security, democracy and peace."

hl.seg: \ 126 Annan "is greatly alarmed" by the wave of violence in the Middle East

p.seg: The United Nations December 13 \ Shenkhu \ The Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, stated today that he was greatly alarmed at the recent wave of violence in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territory, and he urged both sides to take the steps necessary to avoid violent confrontations and to return to the negotiating table.

A spokesman for Annan said in a statement issued in the United Nations headquarters in New York that the Secretary General had called upon the President of the Palestinian National Authority, Yasser Arafat, to "take decisive action against those responsible for these terrorist acts."
He added: "The recent incidents have caused an increase in the serious damage suffered to mutual trust and have deepened the feeling of bitterness and hopelessness."

However the Secretary General wished in these extremely critical times, once again to remind the Israelis and Palestinians that permanent peace and security will not be achieved for the two sides other than through a negotiated settlement of their differences."
Annan sent his sincere condolences to the victims' families and reaffirmed that the targeting of civilians is "unacceptable", according to the spokesman.

hl.seg: \ 45 The main headlines in the major German newspapers

p.seg: Berlin December 13 \ Shenkhu \ Below are the main headlines in the major German newspapers issued today, Thursday:

The Minister of the Interior, Otto Schily, stated in the Parliament that the prohibition of the organization, which has 1,100 members, had become possible following the lifting of what is called the religious privileges which grant legal protection to religious organizations.
\\ Die Welt: \\

-- Distribution of the first set of coinage: Yesterday the Governor of the Federal Bank, Ernst Welteke personally delivered a set of coinage valued at 10.23 euros to Chancellor Gerhard Schr�der and members of his government.
The first set of the new coinage will be sold to familiarize citizens with it from December 17.

hl.seg: The Russian President supports Caribbean regional solidarity

p.seg: Caracas December 13 \ Shenkhu \ It was reported in an official statement made at the Third Summit of the Association of Caribbean States that the Russian President, Vladimir Putin, had expressed his support for the Caribbean region and his desire to cooperate with this Association.

The statement said that Putin had confirmed that his country "was extremely interested in the solidarity of this organization, which aims to strengthen its voice in international affairs and in regional integration."
The Russian President praised the efforts of the member states of the Association for their handling of the economic and social problems in their region.
Putin stated that his country, as an observer to the Association, is eager to establish vigorous relations with it.
For this purpose the Russian leader called for a meeting of experts from these states.

The meeting of the Association of Caribbean States, which will last for two days, was formally opened Tuesday on the Island of Marguerita, a distance of 330 kilometers north of the Venezuelan capital, Caracas.

The heads and representatives of 28 member states of the Association are participating, including the Venezuelan President, Hugo Chavez, the Jamaican Secretary General of the Organization, Norman Girvan and the Cuban President, Fidel Castro.

hl.seg: Chinese agriculture faces the challenges arising from joining the World Trade Organization

p.seg: Peking December 14 \ Shenkhu \ China will make efforts to augment the strategic changes to its agricultural structure, to improve the quality of its agricultural produce and to increase its competitive capability in the market to meet the challenges arising from joining the World Trade Organization.

Du Qing Lin, the Chinese Minister of Agriculture, stated in a meeting held recently by the Ministry that agricultural departments will concentrate their efforts on improving the quality of agricultural produce, standardize it, expand volumes, improve the processing of agricultural produce, publicize regional areas of excellence, and in particular develop high-grade produce.

Regarding highly resourced agricultural produce, such as grain, cotton and oil, it will concentrate on reducing cost and improving quality with a view to reducing the impact of foreign rivals on them.
China is also planning to implement a "Soya bean promotion program" and to expedite measures to establish a basis for soya bean production especially for producing oil, in north eastern China.

hl.seg: An international exhibition of the insurance industry in Shanghai

p.seg: Shanghai December 14 \ Shenkhu \ The Second Shanghai International Exhibition of the Insurance Industry began last Wednesday in the Pudong District of Shanghai in eastern China. It is planned that it will last four days.
This is the first major exhibition of the Chinese and foreign insurance industry since China joined the World Trade Organization.
More than 20 well-known local and foreign companies will participate.

Personalities in insurance circles and Chinese visitors will consider new concepts, technology, the categories of the international insurance industry and development trends of the Chinese insurance industry since China joined the World Trade Organization.

An "International Insurance Symposium" was held on the fringes of the exhibition. Participants spoke about opening up the insurance market, supervising it, restructuring the current international economy and the competitive strength of Chinese institutions in the world since China joined the World Trade Organization.

hl.seg: The Chinese army forms a partnership with the people of minority ethnic groups in good times and bad \ third addition \

p.seg: It is stated that the population of this province is 32,000 of whom more than 80 per cent belong to the Tajik ethnic group, the remainder belonging to 12 other ethnic groups, including the Uigur, Kirgiz, Shebhu, Hui and Han groups.
Because of the low population, extensive area and long borders in this province, the tasks of the border guards of the People's Liberation Army are extremely difficult.
The shepherds of all local ethnic groups have continuously undertaken the role of volunteer guards to collaborate with the army in protecting the north western borders of China.
Official statistics show the local shepherds have arrested 109 infiltrators and illegal migrants on the borders since 1953.
Hazim stated: "The felt tent acts as a guardhouse, and the shepherd is the guard.
Our participation in guarding the country's borders means the maintenance of our homes."

hl.seg: The Chinese army forms a partnership with the people of minority ethnic groups in good times and bad \ second addition \

p.seg: In August 1999 the Province of Tashkorgan suffered destruction and disaster from floods and inundations carrying mud and rocks which led to the destruction of a felt tent and loss of more than 30 head of goats for the shepherd Hazim.
The members of his family were surrounded by flood water for two days.

A group of soldiers of the People's Liberation Army hurried from 40 Km away to the afflicted area to rescue the shepherd, Hazim, his family and more than 140 other shepherds, to transport them to an army camp where these shepherds resided without charge for 45 days.
The military units stationed locally also provided sufficient fodder for the local shepherds' livestock in the winter.

Yei Ming Jiang, the Deputy Head of Tashkorgan Province stated that the units of the People's Liberation Army stationed locally had sent more than ten thousand men and 122 vehicles to assist areas afflicted by the natural disasters, and made cash donations of 210 thousand yuan and donations in kind valued at 51.5 thousand yuan to local victims over the last three years.

hl.seg: \ 41 Vietnam urges an end to violence in the Middle East

p.seg: Hanoi December 14 \ Shenkhu \ Vietnam has again called upon all the parties concerned to exercise self-control and end all acts of violence in the Middle East.

A spokeswoman for the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry, Fan Thieu Thanh, stated today that the current situation in the Middle East became extremely dangerous when Israel announced that it had broken off its relations with Yasser Arafat, President of the Palestinian National Authority and continued its military attacks against Palestinian targets.

Thanh stated that Vietnam considers the Palestinian Liberation Organization under the leadership of President Yasser Arafat to be the sole true representative of the Palestinian people in the struggle to obtain its fundamental national rights.
The Vietnamese spokeswoman affirmed that Vietnam opposed all forms of violence.
She added that Israel and Palestine must make efforts to resume negotiations soon on the basis of International Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 and the principle of "Land for Peace".

hl.seg: \ 132 Syria sends its reply on counter terrorism to the United Nations

p.seg: Damascus December 13 \ Shenkhu \ A source in the Syrian Foreign Ministry announced here today that Syria sent its reply today to its permanent delegation in the United Nations to issues raised regarding International Security Council Resolution 1373 concerning matters of terrorism so that the Syrian Permanent Mission can deposit it with the Security Council.
The source said that the Syrian reply was based on Syrian counter terrorist laws and legislation and imposes severe penalties on perpetrators of terrorist acts against Syrian territory.
He added that Syria has insisted in its reply on the need to distinguish between terrorism and legitimate resistance to foreign occupation, which was guaranteed by the United Nations Charter.
He explained that the Syrian reply was based on the principles of the United Nations Charter and respect for national sovereignty.

It should be noted that the United States of America has placed a number of Palestinian groups which have their headquarters in Damascus, or which have opened offices in Damascus, such as the Islamic Palestinian Resistance, Hamas, the Palestinian Islamic Jihad Organization and the Lebanese Hizbollah, which is supported by Syria, on the list of terrorist organizations, whereas Syria considers that these organizations are not terrorist groups but national resistance organizations opposing Israeli occupation.

hl.seg: The Asian Development Bank approves a loan to Nepal

p.seg: Katmandu December 14 \ Shenkhu \ The Asian Development Bank has approved a loan of 30 million US dollars for an administrative reform program in Nepal, according to a newspaper report issued by the Bank on Friday from its office here.

The program, which will continue for four years, aims to prepare a more effective civil administration and to establish administrative conditions which will assist in achieving higher economic development, thereby reducing levels of poverty in the country, according to the statement.

The reform program will help eliminate financial and management weakness, reinforce institutional capabilities and eliminate bureaucratic barriers through significant changes to the Civil Service Law in Nepal.
The loan will have a repayment period of 24 years, including a period of grace of eight years, at an interest rate of one per cent during the period of grace and 1.5 per cent thereafter.
The statement added that an agreement to this effect was signed between the Nepalese government and the Bank here Thursday.

hl.seg: Direct foreign investments in a Chinese coastal city

p.seg: Jingdao December 15 \ Shenkhu \ Statistics have shown that the coastal City of Jingdao in Shandong Province, eastern China, has attracted 6.7 billion US dollars during the past decade.
The Mayor of Jingdao, Do Shi Jiang, said that the city had significantly increased its capacity to compete using these investments.
Manufacturing industry had spent about 5 billion US dollars, that is 73 per cent of the foreign investments.
The real estate and services industries are the second and third largest users of foreign capital.

With the inflow of foreign capital, Jingdao, which customarily had only light industries such as textiles and foodstuff processing, now has specialist industries in electronic data and mechanical - electrical integration and fine chemical products.
The real estate industry has used more than 600 million US dollars and this has assisted in the construction of about 70 per cent of the high buildings in the eastern part of the city.
It should be noted that companies with foreign investments have a 70 per cent share of total commercial exports and imports, amounting to ten billion US dollars in Jingdao.

hl.seg: Opening of the first Sino- Burmese Border Trade Fair

p.seg: Ruili, Yunnan Province December 19 \ Shenkhu \ The first Sino- Burmese Border Trade Fair opened Tuesday in the Jiegao Border Trade Area in the Province of Yunnan, south western China.

More than 350 firms from Myanmar and China took part hoping to find buyers for more than a thousand types of commodities which include minerals, electrical and chemical equipment, jewelry, jade, wood products, water products and mineral products.
It has been decided that trade negotiations will take place with a view to strengthening bilateral economic cooperation.

The area of the Jiegao Border Trade Area covers 2.4 square kilometers. It borders Myanmar to the east, south and north, and obtained the approval of the State Council last year as a special trade area enjoying preferential treatment in respect of the inflow of people and goods.
This Area lies in the City of Ruili in the State of Autonomous Prefecture of Dihong, of the two ethnic groups of Dai and Jingpo, which became an open border trade area in 1985.
According to statistics from Myanmar, China has become its third largest trade partner and the value of bilateral trade was 499 million US dollars during the period January - October this year.

hl.seg: Electronic banking transactions at the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China

p.seg: Peking December 16 \ Shenkhu \ The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China declared a few days ago that it had completed electronic banking deals to the value of 3.14 trillion yuan during the first 11 months of this year.
It became the first Chinese merchant bank to exceed a value of 3 trillion yuan in its deals.
A spokesman for the bank stated that the value of its banking transactions on the networks amounted to 500 billion yuan.
And last November alone it completed transactions to the value of 110.5 billion yuan.

He added that electronic banking deals will become a hot new procedure at merchant banks for expanding their business and attracting customers and competition with banks with foreign investment in line with advances in information technology and the rapid popularization of computers.

In the arena of telephone banking services, 11 branches of the Bank which trade in foreign currencies by telephone completed 690 thousand transactions during the past 11 months to the value of 41.5 billion yuan, constituting more than 80 per cent of the Bank's total in this regard.
So far the bank has opened banking services on the networks in more than 280 large and medium-sized towns throughout China.
This year the banking system level on the networks has been increased twice and this has effectively increased posts in the system technology platform.

hl.seg: The United States and Thailand cooperate on economics and on the fight against terrorism

p.seg: Washington 15 December / Xinhua / The American President George Walker Bush met Friday with the visiting Thai Prime Minister, Thaksin Shinawatra. They talked together on bilateral cooperation in the fields of economic development and the fight against terrorism.

In a joint statement issued after their meeting in the White House, Thaksin expressed his support for the war against terror led by the United States and said that his country would participate in the rebuilding of Afghanistan after the war.
The Thai Prime Minister also stated that his country would move fast in signing all the agreements that combat terrorism.

Bush described Thaksin's visit as "an additional confirmation" of the relationship of solidarity between the two countries. He promised Thailand a privileged position in obtaining support and training within the international program for boosting peace-keeping capabilities.

It should be pointed out that the American Secretary of State, Colin Powell, and his Thai counterpart, Surakiart Sathirathai, also came to an agreement regarding the economic cooperation between the two countries.

hl.seg: International Special Envoy to Afghanistan briefs Annan and the Security Council on the results of his talks

p.seg: United Nations 15 December / Xinhua / Al-Akhadar Al-Ibrahimi, the special representative of UN Secretary General, Kofi Annan, in Afghanistan, briefed the Secretary General and the Security Council on his talks with Afghan leaders in Kabul.

According to a UN spokesman, Al-Ibrahimi, before submitting his report to the Security Council, had had talks with the Secretary General who had earlier returned from Sweden and was expected to attend the Security Council meeting on Afghanistan.
The spokesman said that Al-Ibrahimi would return to Kabul on the 22nd of the current December when power would be transferred to the interim government.

hl.seg: Russia and Venezuela pledge to keep fair oil prices

p.seg: Caracas 15 December / Xinhua / Visiting Russian Prime Minister, Mikhail Casyanov, said here Friday that Venezuela and Russia would cooperate in order to maintain the stability of oil prices in international markets.

Casyanov arrived here Thursday on an official visit, the first of its kind, lasting two days, in which he would exchange views with the Venezuelan authority and the businessmen in the country concerning the state of the international oil market.
He is also expected to sign a series of bilateral agreements during his visit.

After a special meeting with Venezuelan President, Hugo Chavez, held at the Presidential Palace at Meraflores, Casyanov announced that four agreements in the fields of energy, politics as well as economics and tourism would be signed.

hl.seg: Palestine condemns suicide attacks in Israel

p.seg: United Nations 15 December / Xinhua / Palestine expressed on Friday its rejection and condemnation of suicide bombings targeting Israeli civilians, saying that it would continue to uphold its commitments to existing agreements with Israel in order to achieve peace through negotiations.

Nasir Al-Qudwa, the permanent Palestinian observer at the United Nations, in his comment during the open discussions at the Security Council and in the midst of escalating tensions between Palestinians and Israelis said, "We reject suicide bombings targeting Israeli civilians in Israel and condemn these operations".
"Our attitude is clear and firm," he added, pointing out that Israel's attacks against the Palestinian Authority, "means that it / Israel / has given up the peace process".

The session was held on the invitation of Egypt's Ambassador at the international organization, Ahmad Abu Al-Gheit, who is also the Head of the Arab Group at the United Nations, in a letter sent to the President of the Security Council. In this letter, he said that the Arab League was calling for a Security Council emergency session to be held for discussing the current situation in the Middle East and taking the necessary steps.

hl.seg: The largest investment exhibition on the province level in China

p.seg: Shenzhen 15 December / Xinhua / A commercial exhibition for Liaoning goods and a discussion forum on economic cooperation were opened Friday morning. Liaoning Province, in northeastern China, organized both events in the city of Shenzhen in Guangdung Province in South China.
Around ten thousand businessmen from the provinces of mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao and the countries of south-east Asia will participate.
The two events represent the largest investment and promotional activity on the level of the province in China.
The governor of Liaoning Province, Bo Xilai, came to Shenzhen, heading a delegation made up of more than 6000 government officials of different levels, businessmen and institutions in the province.
He said that the exhibition displayed and promoted the excellent products of Liaoning and the economic activities of the province.

Liaoning had organized two similar exhibitions this year in the city of Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province in Eastern China, and the city of Urumqi, the Capital of the Xinjiang region in the northwestern part of China.
The commercial transactions and investment contracts that were completed in these two exhibitions totaled 17.826 billion Yuan and 23.839 billion Yuan respectively.
It should be pointed out that Liaoning is an old industrial base in the northeastern part of China where integrated industries are to be found.
As for Guangdung, it is the most economically developed province on the coasts of China.

hl.seg: Th Colombian government and the National Liberation Army prepare the schedule for peace talks

p.seg: Bogota 16 December / Xinhua/ The Colombian government and the second largest militia group in the country, the National Liberation Army, prepared on Saturday the agenda for the peace talks that have been resumed recently.

The official government news agency, Anncol, said that the agenda was part of the Havana declaration. This is the new agreement that was reached on Saturday between the two parties in Havana, Cuba, during their second round of peace talks.
The main items on the agenda, which continues from January to June 2002, include:
Holding a peace summit in Havana from 30 December 2001 until 1 January 2002 in order to evaluate the progress made and the obstacles still remaining in the path of the peace process.

hl.seg: Facts and figures... Chinese trade with North America

p.seg: Beijing 17 December / Xinhua / Following are the most recent facts and figures concerning Chinese trade with North-American partners in the period from January to October of the present year, according to the General Customs Authority.
The rate: compared to the same period last year.
United States: A total of 66.766 billion American dollars, with an increase of 8.9 percent compared to the same period of the previous year.
Exports totaled 45.180 billion American dollars, with an increase of 4.2 percent, and imports totaled 21.587 billion American dollars, with an increase of 20.2 percent.

Canada: A total of 6.023 billion American dollars, with an increase of 4.5 percent. Exports totaled 2.817 billion American dollars, with an increase of 6.4 percent, and imports totaled 3.206 billion American dollars, with an increase of 2.8 percent.

hl.seg: 60 / Moslems in northwestern China celebrate Al-Fitr Feast

p.seg: Yinchuan 17 December/ Xinhua / Around 1.89 million Moslems in the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region in northwestern China today celebrated Al-Fitr Feast.
They congregated in about 3000 mosques spread throughout the region that is considered one of the largest areas inhabited by Moslems in China.
Moslem state officials in this region were granted a special vacation in celebration of this occasion.
Senior government officials in the area, including the governor of the region, Ma Qizhi, visited the Moslem citizens, especially mosque preachers in several cities and governorates.
Many state officials from the Han sect celebrated the Feast with their Moslem friends.
No fewer than 20 million Chinese Moslems had fasted the month of Ramadan in peace, in strict adherence to Islamic precepts.
Chinese Moslems are free to conduct their prayers. According to Imam Xing Quang Yuan, the Head of the Chinese Islamic Society, there are more than 34 mosques in the various parts of the country.

hl.seg: Iraq accuses Washington and London of continuing to suspend import contracts

p.seg: Baghdad 17 December/ Xinhua / The Iraqi Health Minister, Dr. Omed Medhat Mubarak, accused the American and British representatives at the Resolution 661 Committee of the United Nations of continuing to suspend import contracts of food stuff, medical supplies and other provisions, with lame and groundless excuses in order to aggravate the suffering of the Iraqi people.

The Health Minister, Medhat Mubarak, in a statement made Sunday evening, pointed out that the American and British representatives have suspended 18 contracts belonging to stages eight, nine and ten. These included reserve materials for air-conditioners, cooling chambers for the preservation of corpses, dental x-ray systems, atropin sulphate, reserve materials for x-ray machines and laboratory materials.

hl.seg: The largest base in the world for producing Christmas goods Xinjiang 17 December/ Xinhua / The city of Xinjiang which is situated close to Hong Kong has become the largest base in the world for producing and exporting Christmas-related goods.
The value of Christmas gift exports exceeds two billion American dollars a year.

p.seg: The United States of America, it should be pointed out, is the largest market for these exports. Annual exports exceed 300 million American dollars while Christmas tree exports exceed 100 million American dollars.
Around 70 percent of these trees are bought by Americans from Xinjiang.
At present there are 300 institutions in the city of Xinjiang for the production of Christmas-related goods, including 20 that produce Christmas trees.
It should be pointed out that the Christmas goods produced by the city of Xinjiang are diverse and are in high demand by foreign markets.

hl.seg: Treating soil erosion in northeastern China

p.seg: Chang-ch'un 22 December / Xinhua / Effective control has been achieved over soil erosion in the basins of the rivers Songhua and Liaohe, in northeastern China, thanks to the efforts dedicated to the treatment of soil erosion in recent years.
The area of the basin is 780 thousand square kilometers.
Its waters reach three provinces in northeastern China and four cities in the area of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region in the north of China.
It is an important base for the production of edible commercial grains and industrial goods in China.

In the past ten years, these provinces, as well as the autonomous region, have treated the eroded soil in an area of 66 thousand square kilometers, and detected more than 10 thousand cases of infringements against water and soil conservation laws and regulations. They agreed to carry out more than 30 thousand projects aiming at conserving water and soil. All this has led to a more effective control over soil erosion.

hl.seg: 73/ The numbers of Israeli settlers in Palestinian areas drop

p.seg: Jerusalem 18 December / Xinhua / The numbers of Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip fell to their lowest level in ten years during the first nine months of the year 2001.

According to official figures published today by the Israeli Central Statistics Bureau, the number of settlers has risen by 3.3 percent during the above-mentioned period. This makes the additional number of Israelis living in these areas reach 6600. Of these 6400 live in the West Bank and 200 in the Gaza Strip.
The number of settlers had grown by 7.8 percent in the year 2000 and the growth average reached 8 percent annually in the preceding five years.
The number of settlers in the Bank and the Strip in the period from January to October of this year grew to 204,900, with an increase of 4.4 percent compared to the same period the year before.
The published figures, however, did not include the Israelis living in the Jerusalem areas that Israel had annexed in the 1967 six-day war.

A spokesman for the Council of Jewish Settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip said that the organization data show a similar decrease in the population growth rate. He pointed out, however, that the number of settlers totaled 227,000.

hl.seg: 35 / Moussa: Arab Foreign Ministers refuse Israeli-style peace

p.seg: Cairo 18 December / Xinhua/ The Secretary General of the Arab League, Amr Moussa, reiterated today, Tuesday, that the meeting of the Arab Foreign Ministers to be held in Cairo next Thursday "will come out with a clear, unambiguous position in regard to the refusal to submit to the Israeli-style peace that the Israeli government is trying to impose".

In press statements made today, Moussa said that the move agreed upon during the consultations taking place after the meeting of the Foreign Ministers of The Islamic Organization Conference recently held in Doha was based on approaching the Security Council. This was something that he personally found to be politically productive.

He added that the coming Arab Foreign Ministers Meeting would serve Arab coordination efforts. It would also be a good chance to listen to Palestinian suggestions and to formulate an Arab stand towards the current Israeli policies and the continuous Israeli military escalations against the Palestinian People and the National Palestinian Authority.

Regarding his assessment of the last statement given by Arafat, Moussa said that despite that statement, the Israeli Army continued its policy of aggression and destruction against Palestinian interests. "We were hoping," he added, "that the statement would represent a chance for the return to political dialogue. But what Israel does is fresh evidence that its present government is not willing to engage in political dialogue but tries to impose a status quo that the Arabs have not accepted and will never accept in any case".

hl.seg: Dialogue between Serbia and the Black Mountain resumed

p.seg: Belgrade 19 December / Xinhua / Through the mediation of Javier Solana, the High Representative of the European Union Foreign Policy, Serbia and the Black Mountain, the two republics constituting the present Yugoslav Union, agreed on Monday to resume talks on future relations between them.

With the help of Solana, an agreement was reached between the Yugoslav President, Vojislav Kostunica, the Deputy Prime Minister, Miroljub Labus, the President of the Black Mountain, Milo Djukanovic, the Prime Minister, Filip Vujanovic and the Serbian Prime Minister, Zoran Djindjic.
After the talks, Solana said to the press that he was happy about the progress achieved on the Yugoslav issues.

Solana had explained during his visit to the two republics last month that the European Union preferred Serbia and the Black Mountain to remain as one country for the sake of stability in Yugoslavia and the Balkans in general.
The European Union opposed the Black Mountain's attempts to gain independence and called for more dialogue as soon as possible.

French President Jacques Chirac and the Head of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Adrian Sevelin, also declared their support for the unity of Yugoslav lands, which means a great deal for the stability and security of Europe.

hl.seg: Brazil refuses to hand over a former Paraguay officer

p.seg: Brasilia 18 December / Xinhua / The Brazilian Supreme Court refused on Monday a request from Paraguay for the handing over of the former army chief, Lino Oviedo, saying that he had been the victim of political persecution in his country.

With this decision, it would be possible to set Oviedo free shortly and for him to stay in Brazil close to the prison. Paraguay accuses him of planning the assassination attempt on the former Vice President, Luis Maria Argana, in 1999.
Oviedo, 58, was arrested in June 2000 in the town of Foz do Iguacu, close to the borders with Paraguay, after he had entered Brazil illegally. He had been detained in military barracks in Brasilia.

hl.seg: Underground heat resources in the Chinese oil city

p.seg: Harbin 18 December / Xinhua / Daqing, the most famous oil city in China, which is also renowned for its hot springs, is planning for the serious use of its abundant underground heat resources.
Daqing lies in Heilongjiang Province in northeastern China.
It possesses verified geothermal resources amounting to 300 billion cubic meters over an extended area in the north and middle parts.
Underground heat resources were discovered in the sixties of the twentieth century but the exploration of these resources only started in 1998.
Underground water heat averages between 47 and 54 degrees Celsius. There are three wells in different places in the city.
These waters contain more than 20 trace elements, and they meet the standards set by the state for drinkable mineral water.

hl.seg: Chinese railways transport 130 million passengers next spring season

p.seg: Chongqing 20 December / Xinhua / During the peak season for passenger train travel in China, tens of millions from the whole country will be transported back home for next traditional spring feast.
Passengers are expected to total 130 million, the highest figure in history.
The Railway Ministry said that the next spring season for railway travel would begin on 28 January and end on 8 March of next year.
Most travelers during this season are workers passing through and college students returning home to spend their winter vacation.
In addition, there are increasing numbers of people going on holiday during the spring period.
The Chinese transport network, especially the railway sector, is working hard to guarantee safe traffic in view of the huge number of travelers during this period.

The Ministry expects the railway sector to handle 130 million passengers during the peak season of 2002, which will last 40 days, with an increase of 17 million compared to last year. This is the equivalent of 3.25 million every day.
Leo Tche Jion, the Deputy Minister, said that the Ministry laid down a practical transport plan, guaranteeing safe and quick transportation services during this period.

hl.seg: Taming the desert in a Chinese Moslem area

p.seg: Yinchuan 19 December / Xinhua / The rate of desert taming has accelerated in the past few years in comparison with the rate of desertification in the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region inhabited by Moslems in the northwestern part of China.

Statistics from the local Forest Agency show that the area of desertified lands in the Ningxia Region has shrunk from 1.65 million hectares in the past to 1.26 million hectares at present. This is a drop of 23.6 points percent in comparison with the early eighties of the last century. Ningxia has thus become one of the few regions in which desertification has receded due to human efforts.

At the same time, in the economic sphere Ningxia has achieved hundreds of millions' worth of Yuans through the development of eco-industries, medical plant and fruit agriculture, cattle husbandry and desert tourism.
Ningxia lies in the eastern part of North-West China, surrounded in three parts by the deserts of Tonkur, Mo Os and Ulan Buha. 73 percent of its lands have desertified and 24.3 percent are deserts.
It is one of the most desertified areas in China.

hl.seg: 88 / Annan urges Iraq to cooperate in the case of the persons missing in operations

p.seg: United Nations 18 December / Xinhua / The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, urged Baghdad to change its "wrong" attitude towards cooperating with the international official responsible for dealing with the case of missing persons during the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990.

In his report to the Security Council issued here today, Annan said that throughout the past four months Iraq persisted in its attitude of non-cooperation with Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov, the High International Coordinator for this case.

Annan said, "I strongly urge the Iraqi leadership once again to re-consider its present policy towards the coordinator. As I mentioned earlier on several occasions, the coordinator will not be able to achieve what he is assigned to do unless Iraq changes its attitude".
International officials said that Vorontsov was still willing to meet Iraqi officials at any time and in any place.

The Secretary General said, "I strongly believe that the dialogue between the Iraqi government and Ambassador Vorontsov will achieve positive results in the attempt to find a solution for the humanitarian problems that he is assigned to deal with".

hl.seg: 12 / Seoul denies reports on the seizure in Afghanistan of arms manufactured in Democratic Korea

p.seg: Seoul 19 December / Xinhua / South Korea denied on Wednesday a news report on the seizure by the United States of weapons manufactured in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea in Afghanistan and the presence of evidence of telephone calls between Pyongyang and Taliban.
The South Korean Ministry of Trade and Foreign Affairs said in a statement, "This report has no basis in truth".

The report published today on the front page of the local daily newspaper, Kyunghyang Sinmun, through unspecified sources, indicated that guns, automatic weapons, pistols and other fire-arms manufactured in Democratic Korea were captured during the war against terror led by the United States in Afghanistan. The American authorities found evidence of telephone calls between Pyongyang and Taliban.

hl.seg: 15 / China and Japan fail to achieve progress in trade talks

p.seg: Tokyo 19 December / Xinhua / China and Japan failed today, Wednesday, to achieve progress in their talks in Tokyo at vice-ministerial level concerning the trade disputes resulting from Japan's emergency import curbs on three agricultural products most of which are imported from China.
The talks took place today, Wednesday, after the failed ministerial meeting held last week in Beijing

The two countries intend to hold another ministerial meeting in a last attempt at resolving the dispute before Friday when Tokyo will decide to curb imports for four whole years, according to sources close the talks.

Japan will take complete protection measures to restrict the imports of green onions, mushrooms, and tatami rushes, used in the manufacture of mats, in the event that the two countries fail to reach an agreement until Friday.
Japan had called upon China to impose certain levels of restrictions on its exports of the three agricultural products in a manner that would satisfy both parties.
Chine had refused the proposal, saying that this was tantamount to imposing protection measures to curb imports.
This trade dispute started in April when Japan imposed emergency import curbs on three agricultural products for 200 days.
In June, China condemned the Japanese discriminatory measures and responded by imposing punitive tariffs amounting to 100 percent on its imports of Japanese cars, mobile phones and air-conditioners.

hl.seg: 36 / Five Israeli Arabs arrested for violently demonstrating in protest against the President's visit

p.seg: Jerusalem 19 December / Xinhua / The Army Radio said today that Israeli police arrested five Israeli Arabs late last night in the town of Sakhnin, north of Galilee. It was rumored that they took part in violent demonstrations during the visit there by President Moshe Katsav.

The demonstrators called upon Katsav to "go home" and fought with the police when the President visited Sakhnin to pay his respects to 13 Israeli Arabs, who had been killed by Israeli police last October during their demonstrations in support of Palestinians after the outbreak of the Aqsa Intifada.

Katsav, in an interview on Radio Israel today, accused Israeli Arabs of becoming more and more extremist by the day. He said that Arab leadership should draw the line between what is allowed and what is not, in the struggle for equal rights.
He denied reports that he was forced to shorten his visit or change his schedule after the demonstrations.

hl.seg: 16 / Archaeological discoveries in Tel Arbid in Syria

p.seg: Damascus 19 December / Xinhua / The joint Syrian-Polish archaeological mission has recently discovered a burial place in Tel Arbid, which lies to the north-west of the city of Hasaka in North Syria. The cemetery belongs to the Mitanni Period 1400 BC, according to the Syrian official newspaper, Al-Baath, published today.
The newspaper pointed out that the dome-shaped burial place was built of mud and straw, with a length of 2.2 meters and a width of 1.4 meters.

The archaeological mission, which has been working on the site since 1996, found inside the burial place a well-preserved skeleton of a woman in her thirties, nineteen pottery jars of different sizes and shapes, and two silver nails covered with a thin gold layer.

The mission also indicated that an administrative building lying to the south east of the burial place and dating back to the third millennium BC was discovered. Its wall is 3 meters long and 90 centimeters wide. Inside was found a seal imprint representing a scene of conflict between Man and lion.

hl.seg: 32 / Al-Tureki: Situation in the region is serious and requires strong Arab measures

p.seg: Cairo 19 December / Xinhua / The Secretary of the Libyan Popular Committee for African Unity Affairs, Ali Abd El Salam Al-Tureki, stated here today, Wednesday, that the situation in the Middle East was extremely serious, requiring a clear Arab stand as well as strong and real Arab measures to confront Israel's acts of aggression and oppression against the unarmed Palestinian people.

In press statements he made today immediately after his arrival in Cairo, Al-Tureki said, "We believe that as long as there is an international coalition against terrorism, it makes sense that Palestinians should get their rights in a fair and just manner".

Al-Tureki expressed his hope that the meeting of Foreign Ministers to be held tomorrow, Thursday, would have a positive outcome for the Palestinians and Arabs, and would not turn out to be like numerous other meetings held earlier that did not properly address Palestinian hopes.

Al-Tureki said that if the meeting did not come out with strong resolutions, there would be general frustration on the Arab street, which expects an Arab stand in the face of the state terrorism exercised by Israel against the Palestinians.

Al-Tureki had arrived earlier today in Cairo, heading the Libyan delegation participating in the emergency meeting of the ministerial Council of the Arab League starting tomorrow in the Arab League headquarters for the discussion of the deteriorating situation in the Palestinian occupied territories.

hl.seg: 53 / President Jiang: Central government to help Hong Kong overcome difficulties

p.seg: / First and last addition /

Jiang said that both Tung and the Hong Kong government are working very hard to boost the economy of Hong Kong, to promote the economic cooperation with the mainland and to develop connections and extensive exchanges with international communities. All this has helped preserve the status of Hong Kong as an international center for finance, trade and shipping.
Jiang said that Tung, in his capacity as Chief Executive of the region, had withstood different storms, and is capable of dealing with complex situations.
The President told Tung that he had absolute confidence in the Central Government, which was completely satisfied with his administration and would continue to support him.

Jiang also expressed his appreciation of the speech given a few days earlier by Tung, in which he declared his intention to run for elections for a second term in office. He said that his decision to seek re-election was a brave commitment to Hong Kong and to the cause of "one country, two systems".

Jiang expressed his hope that Tung, during his possible second term in the office of Chief Executive of Hong Kong, would lead the government and people of Hong Kong to overcome the temporary difficulties and to create a better future for Hong Kong.
